title: Maura W. Gaffney Prospective Bride
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 31Mr. and Mrs. Will N. Robins have announced the engagement of their niece, Miss Maura W. Gaffney, to Lieut. (j.g.) Raymond C. Lynch, U.S.N.R., son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip of Cedarhurst, L. I. Miss Gaffney is a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Maurice L. Gaffney, also of Cedarhurst. A September wedding is planned.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: PENN CENTRAL UNITS OMITTING DIVIDENDS
description: The Penn Central announced yesterday that its leased line, the Cleveland & Pittsburgh Railroad, would not pay the dividends due Sept. I on its per cent guaranteed and 4 per cent special guaranteed betterment stock. It said the omission was because of the uncertainty of its making continued rental payments to the C. & P., which it operates under lease.

title: Trust Suit Alleges Armco Steel Used Illegal Reciprocal Deals
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) The Government charged the Armco Steel Corporation today with using illegal reciprocalpurchase arrangements with suppliers and customers.

title: Plan for LowCost Housing Arouses Anger in Suburban Ramapo
description: AIRMONT, N.Y., July 30Let's face it, when you put a project in my backyard, I'm going to be skeptical, said Mrs. Marvin Rosenfeld as she stood watching her children play on the lush green lawn that reaches back to a thicket behind her home here.

title: Bonn Said to Seek Soviet Return To 1955 Policy on German Unity
description: MOSCOW, July 31 West German sources today revealed details of Foreign Minister Walter Scheel's tactics in seeking Soviet approval of a provision supporting the principle of a unified Germany in the treaty now being negotiated here.

title: FIRSTHALF PROFIT UP AT AETNA LIFE
description: The nation's largest allline insurer, the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, reported yesterday that net income, including realized capital gains, rose to $34.5million, or $1.30 share, in the first haf from $28.1million, or $1.05 a share, in the yearearlier period.

title: CONTINENTAL CAN CO. TO INCREASE PRICES
description: The Continental Can Company announced yesterday a price increase averaging $10 a ton on all grades of combination boxboard, effective Sept. 1.

title: Yankee Stadium Not Available
description: The New York Yankees announced late yesterday that Yankee Stadium would not he available to the producer of the Powder Ridge rock festival.

title: Girls Visit White House
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI)Girls Nation delegates toured the White House today with Mrs. Spiro T. Agnew, wife of the Vice President, as their hostess.

title: Private Rites Held for Szell; Memorial Concert Monday
description: CLEVELAND, July 31 (AP)A private funeral service was held this afternoon for George Szell, music director of the Cleveland Orchestra, who died last night at the age of 73.

title: Snipers Open Fire As Troops Battle Rioters in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Island, Saturday, Aug. 1 (Reuters)Sniper bullets sounded in Belfast at dawn today as British troops clashed with rioters for the second time in four hours.

title: Music: Seeking Out Treasures of the 19th Century
description: NEWPORT, R.I., July 31It is not the grandest of music festivals, this 10day series that started here officially last night and unofficially the night before. But it is in many ways the most endearing, with the most unusual repertory in the most glamorous setting.

title: STOCKS GIVE BACK EARLY ADVANTAGE
description: Stock prices rallied in early trading yesterday, following news of Israel's acceptance of United States proposals for Middle East peace talks, but the strength failed to hold and the market lapsed into the mixed pattern that has characterized most trading this week.

title: If You Miss a Try for a Birdie, You Can Grimace or Just Stand There, but if It Sinks You Can Only Smile
LINDSAY CANCELS POLLUTION ALERT
description: Saying that air pollution had dropped to substantially lower levels, Mayor Lindsay yesterday canceled the alert condition that he had declared on Wednesday.

title: LONDON STOCKS UP IN ACTIVE TRADING
description: London stocks scored a solid advance in active trading yesterday.

title: ROLE IN MURDER LAID TO PANTHER
description: NEW HAVEN, July 31The jury in the Lonnie McLucas trial heard a New Haven detective say today that the order to kill Alex Rackley was relayed by a member of the central committee of the Black Panther party, Landon Williams.

title: Mayor of Jackson Says Critics Seek To Destroy Me
description: JACKSON, Miss., July 31 (UPI)Mayor Russell C. Davis said tonight that criticism by a grand jury of his action, during the violence at Jackson State College, in which two Negro Youths were killed, was an unwarranted personal attack encouraged by persons who wanted to destroy me.

title: Safetyman Eager to Test Knee
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 31Jim Hudson, one of the New York Jets stalwart performers, in their Super Bowl victory, followed Harry Theofiledes, a quarterback candidate, into the team's training camp tonight at Hofstra University.

title: Drug Agency Fearful On Mislabeled Bottles
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP)The Food and Drug Administration issued an urgent, nationwide warning today about mislabeled castor oil bottles that may contain lethal turpentine instead.

title: ARMY TO STOCKPILE NERVE GAS ANTIDOTE
description: WASHINGTON. July 31 (AP) The Pentagon says it is confident that its plan to transport deadly nerve gas hundreds of miles by rail and sink it at sea next month is safe, but it plans to stockpile a lifesaving antidote at hospitals along the way just in case.

title: LOUIS LOMAX, 47, DIES IN CAR CRASH
description: SANTA ROSA. N. M., July 31 (UPI)Louis E. Lomax, a nationally known black writer who was working on a threvolume history of the Negro, died in an automobile crash, the state police said today. He was 47 years old and lived in Baldwin Harbor. L.I.

title: Article 1  No Title
New Books
description: FICTION

title: School Paraprofessionals Win Big Pay Increases
description: The United Federation of Teachers announced yesterday that it had reached agreement with the Board of Education on a contract covering the 4,000 paraprofessionals represented by the union.

title: Article 2  No Title
Manufacturer Inventories Off $150Million in June
description: WASHINGTON, July 31Manufacturers inventories declined S150million in June, returning to the April level, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: JOSEPH MACLEAN, 81, EXMUTUAL LIFE AIDE
description: YARMOUTHPORT, Mass., July 31 Joseph B. Maclean, vice president and actuary of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York from 1941 to 1947 and consulting actuary until his retirement in 1950, died Wednesday. He was 81 years old and lived here.

title: Proposals on Rail Dispute Going to Nixon Next Week
description: WASHINGTON. July 31 (UPI)  A Presidential emergency board said today that it would submit next week its recommendations for settling the 11year dispute over the use of firemen on diesel engines.

title: Market Place
description: Massive blocks of Hanna Mining Company stock pushed this stranger to the active list to the top of the heap yesterday.

title: Candidate's Son Arrested
description: MERIDEN, Conn., July 31 (UPI)Patrick B. Dorsey, 19yearold son of Donald T. Dorsey, who is Mayor of Meriden and Republican candidate for State Attorney General, has been arrested on a narcotics charge. The Mayor confirmed today that his son was among 11 young people arrested by detectives at a house in North Haven last night.

title: JACOB E. ECKEL
Pathet Lao Envoy Seeks To Arrange Negotiations
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, July 31 (Reuters)A special envoy of the Pathet Lao arrived in Vien; tiane today in an effort to arrange negotiations with the Laotian Premier, Prince Souvanna Phouma.

title: To These 2 Vignerons, Producing Champagne Is More Than a Business
description: CALISTOGA, Calif.  Robert Louis Stevenson described Jacob Schram's winery in his book, The Silverado Squatters, after he had paid a visit here in 1880.

title: HENRY C. MEYER 3d
description: Henry Coddington Meyer 3d, who retired several years ago as a partner in the engineering firm of Meyer, Strong & Jones, 230 Park Avenue, died yesterday in Martha's Vineyard (Mass.) Hospital. He was 70 years old, lived in Tequesta, Fla., and was spending the summer at Edgartown. Mass.

title: AMEX STOCK INDEX RISES 0.02 POINT
description: The American Stock Exchange index of prices inched ahead yesterday to close at 20.50 up 0.02  in a day that was marked by volume of 2,186,490 shares. This compared with] trading of 1,916,405 shares on Thursday.

title: Cameroon Denies Killings
description: YAOUNDE, Cameroon, July 31 (Agence FrancPresse)Cameroon officially denied today a report from Lagos that 30 Nigerian fishermen had been killed by Cameroon customs officials.

title: JOAO SOARES, 91, FOE OF SALAZAR
description: LISBON, July 31  Joao LOpes Soares, an indomitable democrat and educator, died here today at the age of 91, four days after his lifelong enemy, Dr. Antonio de Oliveira Salazar, the dictator who ruled Portugal for 40 years.

title: Executive Changes
description: Raymond R. Schwartz has been elected vice presidentcontroller, Raymond International, Inc.

title: Queens Heroin Wholesaler Is Sentenced to 20 Years
Vanguard Data Systems Files Under Chapter 11
description: Vanguard Data Systems disclosed last night that it had filed a petition under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: U.A.R. Leaders to Meet
description: CAIRO, July 31A special meeting of the eightmember Higher Executive Committee of the Arab Socialist Union was called for tomorrow in apparent reaction to the announcement from Tel Aviv that Israel had decided to go along with the United States peace plan. The Arab Socialist Union is the United Arab Republic's only political organization.

title: ELEVATOR REPAIRERS IN WILDCAT STRIKE
description: Three Housing Authority highrise apartment buildings were left without elevator service last night as some 200 elevator mechanics in city facilities began a wildcat walkout.

title: U.S. Vetoes G.E. Deal
description: The Justice Department has! turned down the sale of the Budd Company's railroad division to the General Electric Company, and G.E. says it plans to set up production of electric rapidtransit cars on its own.

title: Bank of America Plans to Open International Unit in Chicago
description: The San Franciscobased Bank of America, the nation's largest bank, plans to open an international banking subsidiary in Chicago. If the Federal Reserve Board approves the proposal, it would mark the first time that an American bank from outside Illinois has set up shop in the rich industrial heartland that surrounds the Windy City.

title: Equation, Robin, Wahini Gain Victories in Races to Newport
BREWERS BEATEN BY 73, 53 SCORES
description: MILWAUKEE, July 31Seemingly baffled for six innings, during which they were shut out with only two hits, the New York Yankee struck wth fury in the seventh tonight to score all their runs in a 73 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The Western Electric Company was awarded yesterday a $232million prime contract for development of the Army's Safeguard ballistic missile system. Senator George Murphy, Republican of Califronia, said that $75million was committed by the Army to cover the Aug. 1Sept. 15 period and the balance would be funded in increments.

title: Textile Action Weighed
description: GENEVA, July 31Major trading nations have revived the idea of voluntary curbs on textile exports in fastminute efforts to avoid a threatened trade war.

title: Sapling Draws 15 Colts Today, 7 at $5,000 Supplementary Fee
description: If anybodyneeded convincing that racing's 2yearold division lacked a standout, the lineup for today's $136,370 Sapling Stakes should end the debate.

title: NEW MUSCAT RULER BACKS A GULF UNION
description: MUSCAT, July 31  The new ruler of Muscat and Oman declared today that he was willing to cooperate with other rulers of the Persian Gulf area in forming the proposed Federation of Gulf Emirates, which would consist of nine sheikdoms.

title: RELIGIOUS FERVOR HAILED BY BLACKS
description: SALISBURY, N. C., July 31  A bishop of the African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church invited all white Christians today to save their souls by joining a black church.

title: Concern's Name Is Changed
description: The Equity Funding Corporation of America has renamed the Presidential Life Insurance Company of America, acquired in 1967, as the Equity Funding Life Insurance Company.

title: Roundup: Orioles Feast On Royal Losing Streak
description: Was this the record?

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To the Editor: John K. Fairbank (Topics column July 18) has somehow attributed our nonvictory in Vietnam to faulty, cold war rationales; to stop aggression to insure selfdetermination... to save democracy from totalitarian tyranny.. to win this round in the cold war... and so on.

title: French, Too, Are Banning Pop Music Weekends
description: AIXENPROVENCE, France, July 27The French authorities have been trying to keep the younger generation cool this summer by banning several pop music festivals in the South of France.

title: Charles Piloting Plane Involved in Near Miss
Dance: Kirov's Sylphides in London
description: LONDON, July 31  Why do we in the West see so little of Leningrad's Kirov Ballet? How many years is it since it was last in New York? Six or seven? London is perhaps a little luckier, but even so, the Kirov is hardly a frequent visitor, and as a consequence its present season at the Royal Festival Hall  where it is vying with the American Ballet Theater across the river at Convent Garden  is a rare chance to see these Leningraders outside their natural habitat, the Kirov Theater.

title: Functional Gloves That Pack a Wallop
description: Scarves are in So are beads and belts. But gloves? As a status symbol, even as a sign of gentility, they've lost their standing. At best, they're worn to keep the hands warm.

title: EnvoyDesignate Ill
description: MOSCOW, July 31  Diplomatic sources said tonight that Vladimir I. Stepakov, reportedly named as the new Soviet Ambassador to Communist China, was seriously ill.

title: SERIES IN SARATOGA OPENED BY ORMANDY
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., July 31 (AP)Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra opened their fifth summer season at Saratoga Performing Arts Center last night joined by the trio of Isaac Stern, violinist, Eugene Istomin, pianist, and Leonard Rose, cellist.

title: 5 WAIFS IN FAMILY REJOINED BY CITY
description: Five brothers and sisters who had been separated since they first entered the city's overcrowded facilities for abandoned and neglected children were reunited yesterday as they and 13 other youngsters were transferred to facilities run by voluntary agencies.

title: POPE REBUFFS DUTCH ON ISSUE OF CELIBACY
description: UTRECHT, the Netherlands, July 31 (UPI)Pope Paul VI has rejected an appeal by Dutch bishops to allow married men to be priests, the bishops said today in a statement.

title: JONES'S CATCHES CEMENT VICTORY
description: The Mets, for the first time since July 11, are back in first place in the Eastern Division of the National League.

title: Urban Slums Resist Census Takers
description: Census takers in the city are encountering serious difficulties in poverty areas, and the count is lagging far behind other sections.

title: STRIKING PLAYERS FEAR REPRISALS
description: Concern by players over possible reprisals and concern by club owners over the loss of exhibitiongame income next weekend developed yesterday as an insignificant number of experienced performers entered National Football League training camps.

title: Cambodia Reports Drive By Enemy Above Capital
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Aug. 1 (UPI)Supported by rockets and heavy mortars, Communist troops in Cambodia began a thrust north of Promperh last night and early today, military spokesmen said in Promperh.

title: City Power Margin Improves Slightly; Pollution Alert Off
description: New York City's electric power safety margin widened slightly yesterday  thanks to continuing conservation efforts and some increase in supply from outside the cityas the work week ended for most people.

title: China Developing MaoStyle Colleges
description: HONG KONG, July 30The resumption of technological studies at university level in Communist China has been spurred by the launching of new Maoist type of higher education at Tsinghua University in Peking, the country's foremost school for science and engineering.

title: ARTHUR MERMIN, 49, LAW PARTNER, DIES
description: Arthur Mermin, a partner in the New York law firm of Cahill, Gordon, Sonnett, Reindel & Ohl died Tuesday of a stroke at his home, 4475 Douglas Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx. He was 49 years old.

title: Youths at Powder Ridge Maintain Festival Atmosphere
description: MIDDLEFIELD, Conn., July 311 "I'm here because my people are here, said a New Haven student, lowering a knapsack and then gazing upon a vista of multicolored tents, flags, moItorcycles, trees and tanned bodies.

title: Key Witness Says That She Once Regarded Manson as a Messiah
Revving Up the Votemobiles
description: Again this summer as last summer, the New York City Board of Elections is conducting a neighborhood voter registration drive, this year by widespread use of votemobiles which, cruising through local communities, will seek out the many potential voters who have never before been placed on the registration rolls. The votemobiles begin a trial run today with fullscale operations scheduled for next week.

title: Borstal Boy Suspending
description: Borstal Boy, the Frank McMahon adaptation of Brendan Behan's prison book, now playing at the Lyceum Theater, will be suspended for the sum mer after tonight's performance. The Michael McAloneyBurton Kaiser production will resume its Broadway, run in midSeptember.

title: Engineer and Youths Seized In Home on Drug Charges
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y., July 31 Policemen and sheriff's officers raided the home of an engineer here early today and arrested the engineer, his 16yearold daughter and 12 of her friends on narcotics charges.

title: Heath Appoints Minister Chairman of Tory Party
description: LONDON, July 31Peter Thomas, considered a moderate, was appointed chairman of the Conservative party today by Prime Minister Health.

title: Judge Accepts Data in Seale Inquiry
description: CHICAGO. July 3I Judge Julius J. Hoffman of Federal District Court accepted in a sealed envelope today the Government logs of electronic, eavesdropping on Bobby G. Seale, Black Panther party chairman.

title: Bridge:
description: The biggest change in tournament schedules in the last two decades has been caused by the remarkable popularity of Swiss Team contests, in which short headtohead matches are played but no team is eliminated.

title: Hartford Is Put on Curfew as Violence Continues
Federal Contracts to Set Job Equality for Women
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson said today that the Government would set employment goals for women in some Federal contract work to eliminate discrimination because of sex.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International Israel announced yesterday that she would accept the United States peace formula for the Middle East. The acceptance of the limited ceasefire and the opening of talks with the United Arab Republic was voted 17 to 6 by the Cabinet in a twohour meeting. The Government said its action was based on certain clarifications by the United States Government. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: 4 Firemen Hurt Fighting Brookyln Synagogue Blaze
description: Four firemen were Injured, none seriously, while battling a twoalarm fire in a Brooklyn synagogue early this morning.

title: M. RUDOLPH PREUSS, LAWYER, L. I. LEADER
description: MASSAPEQUA, L. I., July 31 M. Rudolph Preuss, a lawyer with offices in Hempstead and a leader in community activities, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 45 Club Drive. His age was 63.

title: Sweet Grapes
description: Long years of patient labor in the vineyards of trade union organization, nonviolent protest and national boycott have at last resulted in a historic contract between the grape pickers and grape growers in California. We are overjoyed that peace has come to the valley, said the owner of a vineyard in San Joaquin. All grapes will be sweet grapes again, said Cesar Chavez, the leader of the United Farm Workers Organizing Committee.

title: Tremors in Latin America
description: LIMA. Peru, July 31 (AP)The earth shook in Latin Amerca today from the Caribbean to Buenos Aires. No damage or injuries were reported. Observatories in Lima, Caracas. Venezuela grid San Juen purto Rico, pinpointed the disturhance along the eastern border of Ecuador

title: HOUSE WOULD LET PRESIDENT IMPOSE PRICEWAGE CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 Overriding Administration protests, the House voted today to give President Nixon stand by authority to impose wage, price and rent controls.

title: Smog Is Now a Problem Even High in the Andes
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 24 A Chilean politician chatting with friends on a downtown corner paused to cough and looked up into the haze where snowcapped mountain peaks should have been visible.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
For Bulgaria's Orthodox Church, a Renaissance
description: SOFIA. Bulgaria, July 31 (AP)  In spite of unabated atheist propaganda, Bulgaria's Orthodox Church, observing its 1,100th anniversary this year, is undergoing a seeming renaissance. Doubt and dissent may mar many other Christian churches, but Bulgarian Orthodox leaders report that faith is becoming firmer.

title: Miss Elizabeth Bryden Is Wed
description: Miss Elizabeth Jane Bryden, a teacher in the Edinburgh school system, was married in Trinity Church in her native Lockerbie, Scotland, yesterday afternoon to Robert A. Cuddihy, a student at the University of Edinburgh. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John Fletcher of the Church of Scotland.

title: Last Rum Tot Goes Down
description: LONDON, July 31  The Royal Navy sadly today ended one of its fondest traditionsthe daily tot of rum. The 283yearold tradition was considiered inappropriate in a modern, instantresponse navy. At Portsmouth, solemn music was played as chief petty officers, around a blackdraped barrel in a coffin, sipped their last measure.

title: Topics: The Failure of Vietnamization by Any Name
description: Vietnamization, like the proverbial cat, seems to have at least nine lives, about five of which have already been lived. Vietnamization was tried first by the French nearly 20 years ago. On May 10, 1970, General Henri Navarre, formerly commander of the French forces in Indochina, said: Vietnamization is an old idea. It was the basis of my own plan when I was sent to Indochina in 1952.

title: Federal Court Here Rejects Challenge to Film Ratings
description: A Federal judge, in a preliminary action, turned down yesterday an attack on the X rating of movies that exclude children under 17.

title: N. E.T. to Show Japanese Film of Atom Bomb Damage
description: A film made from footage taken by Japanese cameramen at Hiroshima and Nagasaki and classified as secret for more than 20 years will be broadcast over National Educational Television on Monday.

title: New Brunswick Seizes Volunteer On PoliceImpersonation Charge
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., July 31  A 41yearold man who volunteered his services here to cool racial disturbances last weekand whose advice led in large measure to the imposition of a state of emergency and two nights of curfew  was arrested this morning on charges of impersonating a policeman and carrying a concealed weapon during that period.

title: ISRAEL REPORTS JETS HIT JORDANIAN ARMY
Monetary Fund Pressing Canada to Fix Dollar Rate
description: WASHINGTON, July 31, (Reuters)  Informed sources said today that the executive board of the International Monetary Fund has formally decided to continue to press Canada to return to a fixed exchange parity for the Canadian dollar as soon as possible.

title: Joseph M. Mulford, Banker And G.O.P. Aide. Dies at 80
description: THE PLAINS, Va., July 31Joseph Minot Mulford, senior partner from 1930 to 1935 of the former J. M. Mulford & Co., New York investment hankers, died today. He was 80 years old and lived here.

title: War in the Streets
description: The bloody riot in Chicago and the fatal shooting of a young black militant leader in Houston this week reflect the serious social disorders which are straining the nation. These phenomena can no longer be regarded as isolated or purely local episodes which can be left to routine police work. Such disorder likely to spread and intensify unless the leaders every community and of the nation bring to bear more imagination, energy and effective moral concern.

title: Embattled Doctor Quits
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) A doctor who dabbles in politics resigned from a policymaking committee of the Democratic party today after stumbling into a hornets' nest of

title: DEMOCRATS BACK NIXON ON TRADE
description: WASHINGTON, July 31A group of liberal Democratic members of the House urged President Nixon today to counter foreign actions in the trade field that violate our international trading rights in order to head off protectionist trade legislation.

title: CALIFORNIAN GETS 5 BIRDIES IN ROW
description: HARRISON, N. Y., July 31Caught in a late rainstorm, John Miller, a slim. 23yearold California professional, scored a 67 today and finished as the 36hole leader in the $250,000 Westchester Golf Classic with an aggregate of 136.

title: Exporters Seen Favoring Wider Use of U.S. Ships
description: American exporters have begun to respond favorably to a Nixon Administration effort to encourage the use of United Statesflag merchant ships, according to Federal and Maritime industry leaders.

title: Leading Pairings Today In Westchester Classic
description: 9:32 A.M.  Jack McGowan, Steve Oppermann.

title: EXI.O.S. OFFICER SETS COMPETITION
description: A former top sales official off I.O.S., Ltd., the ailing international mutual fund and insurance complex, disclosed yesterday that he has set up a rival company that would join with other former Investors Overseas Services personnel in the financial services business.

title: CortisoneLike Compounds Produced
description: WASHINGTON, July 31A chemistry research fellow at Harvard University was granted a patent this week for compounds that are said to provide the antiinflammatory benefits of cortisone drugs without the unfavorable side effects. Eric T. Fossel, who holds a Ph.D. from Harvard and two master's degrees from Yale University, assigned Patent 3,522,244 to Unimed, Inc., Morristown, N. J., of which his father, Spencer M. Fossel, is president. The senior Mr. Fossel called it the company's most important patent and a significant advance in medicine. Unimed specializes in the development of drug compounds and licenses manufacturers in this country and abroad.

title: C.P.A. UNIT EASES MERGER PROPOSAL
description: The Accounting Principles Board, wracked by internal dissension and heavy pressure from the business community, formally adopted yesterday compromise set of rules to govern corporate merger accounting.

title: Cragwood's 4Horse Entry 35 in Tidal Today
Sale of Diamond Chips by U.S. Arouses Anger of Some Dealers
description: After some rather stormy negotiations with several diamond dealers and one brief skirmish in Federal District Court, the Government has completed the first major sale of industrial diamonds from its strategic stockpile in more than eight years.

title: Even on Waterfront, People Like to Own Pools
description: When Mr. and Mrs. Edward Fenton of Huntington, L. I., celebrated their 35th wedding anniversary recently, the former Maria Gambarelli and her husband gave a poolside party for 100 friends and relatives.

title: General Demoted and Retired; Figure in Investigation of PX's
Britons Bar U.S. Magazine With Article on Margaret
High Greek Officers Retired
description: ATHENS, July 31 (Reuters)The armybacked Government today retired 25 major generals, 23 brigadier generals, two rear admirals and one air vice marshal, as well as a number of lowerranking army and navy officers. Four colonels were made brigadier generals.

title: Muscle Ships Tend Big Buoys Needed for Mammoth Tankers
description: The mammoth tankers now being built are too big for most of the world's ports. With their deep draft, they often hate to moor far offshore when taking on or discharging their cargo.

title: American Export Line Names Chief
description: American Export Isbrandtsen Lines has named Joseph G. Barkan as president. He will succeed Manuel Diaz, who is relinquishing the post.

title: Con Ed's Plans for Astoria Opposed by Kretchmer
description: In the midst of the latest electrical power crisis, Jerome Kretchmer, the city's Environmental Protection Administrator, is opposing a major expansion of the Astoria, Queens, plant of the Consolidated Edison Company, contending that it would significantly increase air pollution.

title: Stanley Beard, ExDirector Of Lederle Laboratories
description: Stanley Drew Beard, a former director of Lederle Laboratories, died yesterday in Nyack (N. Y.) Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived at 88 North Main Street, Pearl River, N. Y.

title: Ocean Hill Defendants Leave Hearing on Their Arraignment
description: Four hours after bench warrants were issued for their arrest. members of the defunct governing hoard of the Ocean HillBrownsville demonstration school district returned yesterday to a Brooklyn courtroom that they had quit in what the judge called a contemptuous act.

title: Huntley Bids Brinkley and N.B.C. Last Good Night
description: And so, for the last time, good luck and good night, Chet,

title: DuPont, Clore Forgan Lays Off 50 in Merger
description: A spokesman for F. I. duPont, Glore Forgan & Co., a brokerage house formed by a recent merger, said yesterday that the firm was laying off 50 workers as a result of the completion of the merger.

title: Ellin Halbert Affianced
description: SOUTH FALLSBURG, N. Y., July 31Mr. and Mrs. Mannie Halbert, who operate the Raleigh Hotel here, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellin Halbert, to Frederick T. Cohen. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Cohen of West Hartford, Conn. A wedding in January is planned. Miss Halbert was graduated from the the University of Miami, where her fianc is senior.

title: RICHEY ADVANCES TO U.S. SEMIFINAL
description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 31 (AP)  Cliff Richey, the topseeded United States player, defeated Fred McMillan of South Africa, 75, 36, 86, in the quarterfinals of the $50,000 national clay court tennis tournament today.

title: Nixon Hails Israel's Move But Warns of Difficulties
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 31President Nixon today hailed Israel's acceptance of the United States proposal for a 90day ceasefire in the Middle East, but he warned that no one should underestimate the difficulties that lie ahead.

title: Better Pineapple Grown
description: KUALA LUMPUR (AP) Malaysian researchers have developed a pineapple plant capeble of yielding 12 tons of fruit per acre compared with current yield of about seven tons.

title: RALLY BY PINNACLE WINS JUMPER TITLE
description: MIDDLETOWN, N. Y., July 31 Pinnacle came through under pressure today and won the intermediate jumper championship at the Orange County Horse Show with 11 points.

title: KEARNEY SCORES ON A 65YARD RUN
Suspended Aide To Quit I.C.C. Post In Funds Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON July 31 (AP)H. Neil Garson, whose expense accounts have come under the scrutiny of Government investigators, said today he intended to resign his $30,000ayear job as secretary of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

title: Dr. Howard D. Fabing, 62, Early Researcher of LSD
description: CINCINNATI, July 31  Dr. Howard D. Fabing, a former president of the American Academy of Neurology and of the Society of Biological Psychiatry, died here Wednesday at his home. He was 62 years old.

title: Pace of Vienna Arms Talks Intensifies As U. S. and Soviet Hold Extra Sessions
North Dakota Bank Indicted With Six
description: FARGO, N. D. July 31  A Federal grand jury in Fargo today indicted the First Western State Bank of Minot, N. D., and six prominent state Democrats charging that bank funds had been illegally used to make political contributions.

title: EXPLOSIVES SEIZED ALONG WITH DRUGS
description: CHATHAM, N.J., July 31 (UPI) The police seized black powder, explosive chemicals andl instructions on how to makel both explosives and drugs and arrested four young men in raids on four houses in this Morris County community.

title: Ohio Special Election Set
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 31 (AP)  A special primary election to choose candidates for the unexpired term of Reppresentative Michael J. Kirwan of Youngstown, a Democrat, has been set for Sept. 22 by Gov. James A. Rhodes. Mr, Kirwan died earlier this week.

title: Brazil's Pledge on Vigilantes
description: President Medici has finally condemned Brazil's death squads and promised to bring them to swift, severe justice. It was the first time the military regime had even conceded the existence of the vigilante groups, believed to consist mostly of offduty policemen, who have been accused of murdering 500 to 1,000 persons in the last six years.

title: Hanoi Aide Assails Nixon
description: PARIS, July 31A spokesman for the North Vietnamese delegation at the peace talks said here today that President Nixon's remarks about Vietnam at a news conference last night showed that his Administration still cherishes the delusion of obtaining a military victory in order to gain position of strength at the conference table.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT Activities

title: Frayn's First Play, Attempt at Comedy, Is Given in London
description: LONDON, July 31Michael Frayn, the newspaper satirist, television playwright and novelist, has succeeded in every form he has touched, perhaps we were expecting too much of his debut in the theater. There is nothing terribly wrong with The Two of Us, a twohanded quartet of marital sketches at the Garrick Theater on the model of Neil Simon's Plaza Suite; but you do leave the theater feeling that practically anyone could have written it.

title: J. H. Oakley Fiance Of Edythe Donovan
description: PELHAM, N. Y., July 31The engagement of Miss Edythe Walden Donovan to John Howard Oakley has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard P. Donovan. Her fianc is the son of Mrs. J. Preston Miller of Paxton, Mass., and the late Alfred Oakley, who was vice president of Jackson & Jackson, a textile concern in Tryon, N. C.

title: TEXAS U. REGENTS PARTITION SCHOOL
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., July 31 (AP)Regents of the University of Texas at Austin voted tonight to split the College of Arts and Sciences into three parts.

title: SINGLE NEW ISSUE OFFERED IN WEEK
description: A California producer of electronic measuring instruments was the only company this week to sell its stock to the public for the first time, according to a weekly survey of newissue underwriters.

title: Israel Accepts
description: Israel's acceptance of United States peace proposals, previously endorsed by Egypt and Jordan, clears the way for the most intensive effort to negotiate a lasting settlement in the Middle East since the establishment of the Jewish state 22 years ago.

title: Owen Ely, 80, Specialist For Brokers Concern, Dies
description: MANHASSET, L. I., July 31  Owen Ely, who retired last year as a specialist in public utilities for Loeb Rhoades & Co., brokers of New York, died yesterday in St. Francis Hospital, Roslyn. He was 80 years old and lived at Munsey Park.

title: BOMBING SUSPECT REPORTED MISSING
description: Larry Grathwohl. a 22yearold Cincinnati man who is under indictment for being part of an alleged nationwide bombing conspiracy by the radical Weathermen, some of whom suspect him of being an undercover police agent, had an additional warrant for his arrest issued against him yesterday for bailiumping.

title: Connecticut Fans Cheer Ballo, HomeGrown Star
description: HARRISON, N. Y., July 31 Most spectators come here to cheer the bigname superstars, but there is always small group of fans who, with fingers crossed, root for one of their local favorites to hit that $50,000 jackpot.

title: COACH LINE AND CITY REACH SETTLEMENT
description: Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., and its subsidiary, Surface Transit, Inc., indicated yesterday that they had agreed on a settlement with the City of New York to fix compensation for the condemnation acquisition by the city in 1962 of the bus service system and operations of the two companies.

title: SQUATTERS SCORE NEARBY WRECKING
description: Five squatters in two nearly vacant sixstory tenements opposite the Cathedral, of St. John the Divine on Morningside Heights, chosen to speak for the 54 families that occupied apartments in the buildings on July 25, appealed to the owners yesterday to stop, demolition of adjacent buildings.

title: MUSIC IS HEARD AT ROCK FESTIVAL
description: MIDDLEFIELD, Conn., July 31A popular rock balladeer and two professional bands performed at the Powder Ridge ski area last night, but a state's attorney said it was not quite clear whether they had violated a court order prohibiting a rock festival here this weekend.

title: Police in Copters Help Others Foil Hijacking
description: Policemen in helicopters covering a 50mile route from Long Island to lower Manhattan guided colleagues in cars yesterday to $85,000 in hijacked meat and the arrest of five men allegedly involved in the crime.

title: Nils Hogner, an Illustrator And Muralist, Dies at 72
description: LITCHFIELD, Conn., July 31 Nils Hogner, an artist and illustrator died yesterday. He was 72 years old and lived at Hemlock Farm.

title: Jimmy Conzelman, 72, Is Dead; Coached Cardinals to Grid Title
description: ST. LOUIS, July 31 (AP)Jimmy Conzelman, who was coach of the Chicago Cardinals football team and had been member of professional football's Hall of Fame since 1964, died today after a long illness. He was 72 years old.

title: Eagles in Britain Hatch, First in Over a Century
description: LONDON, July 31A pair of golden eagles has successfully nested and hatched offspring in England for the first time in more than a century, the Royal Society for the protection of Birds announced today.

title: Screen: Random Move
CHARLES E. GILLHAM OF FIELD &
description: Charles E. Giliham, associate editor of Field & Stream magazine, died Tuesday in a St. Louis hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in Edwardsville, Ill.

title: Sports of The Times
description: I have a fear, said Paul Martha of the Pittsburgh Steelers several years ago, that someday my boy and will be watching a pro football game on television, and after the first quarter one of the teams will walk off the field because of a working grievance against management.

title: WARS IN PARK GET A REPRIEVE
description: The New York Shakespeare Festival yesterday rescinded the Aug. 9 closing notice of The Wars of the Roses in Central Park and extended its run through Aug. 22 because the New York State Council on the Arts has decided to contribute to the festival $50,000 more than originally expected.

title: SIDEROWF DOWNS BERBERIAN, 3 AND 2
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., July 31Rain played havoc with the Metropolitan Golf Association's 68th amateur championship today.

title: Sordidness Adorns The New Life Style
CONFUSION MARKS NIXON STATEMENT
description: SAN CLEMENTE. Calif., July 31The White House press secretary, Ronald L. Ziegler, qualified somewhat today President Nixon's statement last night at a news conference that the number of Federal officials sent to Southern schools this fall would be governed by requests from the Southern school districts.

title: China Says Soviet Troops Are Massing Near Border
description: HONG KONG, July 31Communist China, marking the 43d anniversary of its army's founding, accused the Soviet Union today of massing troops near the Chinese border.

title: VOCALS BY THOMAS SPARK JAZZ GROUP
description: There have been singers in the past who have served as leaders of jazz groups. But none have been as integral a part of the group as Leon Thomas, who appeared with his septet Thursday night at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: BEAME DISCOUNTS CITY HALL CHANGE
description: Reacting to Lindsay adminstration charges that Controller Abraham D. Beame was. playing Clubhouse politics in the controversy over city consultants, Mr. Beame hurled the same charge at the administration yesterday.

title: Mansfield Predicts Cuts Of $5Billion in Spending
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 Senator Mike Mansfield predicted today that Congress would cut appropriations by a net of $5billion this session, but he did not mention numerous other Congressional actions and inactions on spending and revenue that threaten to add billions of dollars to the budget deficit.

title: Antiques: U.S. Ceramics
description: Not so long ago, only Rookwood and Knowles, and Taylor and Knowles were familiar names. Now the list has grown more than tenfold. Marked pieces from potteries all over the country are being sought. Some concentrate on wellknown names such as Weller, Buffalo, Van Briggle, Revere, Roseville and Dedham, others are more interested in the design than the name.

title: A Stiffer Nixon Stand on Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, July 31In their effort to counter speculation that the allies are preparing to make new concessions in the Vietnam talks, both President Nixon and President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam have indicated in the last 24 hours how little they expect from the next phase of negotiations in Paris. When Mr. Nixon announced on July 1 that he was sending a senior diplomat, David K. E. Bruce, to head the American delegation, he emphasized American flexibility and referred to the new instructions that Mr. Bruce would be carrying.

title: Air Quality Guardian
description: Just three years ago, a youthful chemical engineer named Robert Norman Rickles took the witness stand here before the state's Air Pollution Control Board.

title: X15 Pilot Gets New Post
description: EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, July 31 (AP)Col. Robert H. White, 46 years old, who flew the X15 rocket plane to the fringes of space in 1962, became today the commander of the Air Force Test Center here. Colonel White, a native New Yorker, was honored by the White House after he flew the X15 to an altitude exceeding 50 miles.

title: Lefkowitz Gains Endorsement Of Silent Majority Committee
description: The Silent Majority Mobilization Committee, which describes itself as a nonpartisan middleoftheroad organization, added Attorney Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday to the list of candidates it is supporting for statewide office.

title: Tapewatchers Dwindle as Stock Prices Sag
description: I haven't seen more than eight tapewatchers in here at one time in more than a year, or ever since the market started its decline.

title: THIEU IS ADAMANT ON PEACE TERMS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 31  President Nguyen Van Thieu declared tonight that South Vietnam's conditions for peace were unchanged and ruled out any coalition government with the Communists except one that might result from free, internationally supervised elections.

title: Rockefeller Noncampaigns Actively in Upstate Tour
description: VALHALLA, N.Y., July 31The campaign is really not going to get started until after Labor Day, Governor Rockefeller told a reporter after landing at the Orange County Airport yesterday afternoon.

title: Weapons Costs: New Policy Appears Old
description: WASHINGTON, July 31The much advertised fly before you; buy system of weapons procurement adopted by Secretary, of Defense Melvin R. Laird may produce airplanes that fly and guns that shoot, but there is no guarantee that it will save the taxpayers any money.

title: New State Planned in India
description: NEW DELHI, July 31Prime Minister Indira Gandhi announced in Parliament today that Himachal Pradesh, 10,000square mile hill territory at the foot of the Himalayas, would become the 18th state of India. She said legislation would be introduced shortly to confer statehood on the territory, now administered by the central Government.

title: 19 Blacks Seized in New Bedford Panther Raid
description: NEW BEDFORD, Mass., July 31 (AP)Nineteen blacks were arrested today in what the police said was the city's Black Panther headquarters. The arrests followed three nights of disturbances and sniper fire in the South and West End sections.

title: Toyota Builds Shrine to Those Killed in Its Cars
description: TATESHINA, Japan, July 31 (UPI)The President of Japan's Toyota Motor Company has had a $445,000 shrine constructed for the repose of the souls of people killed in Toyota cars.

title: COMMANDO CHIEF BARS COMPROMISE
TEAMSTERS FINED AT UNITED PARCEL
description: A union that ordered United Parcel Service drivers off the job Thursday was fined $25,000 a day yesterday for refusing to obey a court's instructions to get the men back to work.

title: Houston Negroes Dispute Police on Fatal Gun Fight
description: HOUSTON, July 31  Five days after a gun battle between policemen and black youths along Dowling Street, there is much disagreement between police reports and accounts of black residents as to just what happened.

title: Undersea Oil Rig Started in Persian Gulf
description: The stark sight of oil drilling rigs etched above oceans and bays around the world may soon be a picture from the past.

title: DR. IRVING SMILEY, A GYNECOLOGIST, 82
description: Dr. Irving Smiley, who retired in 1956 as director of gynecology at Bronx Hospital, died yesterday at his apartment in the Mayflower Hotel, Central Park West and 61st Street. His age was 82.

title: FIELDS ARE VICTORS IN JUNIOR SAILING
description: SEA CLIFF, L, I., July 31 Todd Field of the Port Washington Yacht Club won in his Lightning Class division and his younger sister, Bonnie, captured her Blue Jay Midget division honors today as 145 boats sailed in the Junior Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound open regatta on Hempstead Harbor.

title: Lawyers Accused Of Seeking Clients In Courts Building
description: Two lawyers and a merchant seamon were arrested here yesterday, accused of solieiting legal business in the corridors of the Manhattan Criminal Courts Building.

title: Golf Facts and Figures
description: ScheduleToday and tomorrow. 18 holes daily. Sudden death follows and of tomorrow's play in event of tie for first place. Starting field of 158. Low 70 scorers and ties and those within 10 strokes of leader after second round continue for third and fourth rounds. Purse $250,000. First prize, $50,000.

title: CABINET IN ISRAEL ACCEPTS U.S. PLAN BY A 17T06 VOTE
description: TEL AVIV, July 31  The Israeli Cabinet decided tonight to accept the United States formula for a limited ceasefire and the opening of peace talks with the United Arab Republic. The vote was 17 to 6, and the dissenting ministersall from the hardline Gahal faction  are now expected to withdraw from the Government partnership.

title: Susan Forman Will Marry on Aug. 16
description: GREAT NECK, L.I., July 31Miss Susan Lois Forman and Robert Dana Pickman, candidates for M.A. degrees at C. W. Post College of Long Island University in Brookville, plan to be married on Aug. 16 in the Great Hall at the college.

title: Saigon Corps Commander Denies He Criticized Thais
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 31Lieut. Gen. Do Cao Tri, commander of South Vietnam's III Corps tactical zone, around Saigon, denied today that he had made remarks critical of Thai military forces, attributed to him in an article in The New York Times on July 19.

title: Conzelman Dead at 72
description: Jimmy Conzelman, who coached the Chicago Cardinals to the National Football League championship in 1947, died yesterday at age 72. He coached the Cardinals for six seasons194042 and 194648. Obituary on Page 23.

title: ABM CRITICS SAY PENTAGON AGREES
description: WASHINGTON, July 31Opponents of the Safeguard antimissile system contended today, in the Senate that the Defense Department had conceded that the system, as designed, would not effectively protect Minuteman missiles against a Soviet attack.

title: Byrd, 2 Others Arrive
description: BROOKVILLE, L.I., July 31Although a move to report to training camp developed today among some Giant regulars, Fran Tarkenton contended that the overwhelming majority of the players had decided not to report.

title: Miss Cogswell Becomes Bride Of a Lieutenant
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, July 31  The marriage of Miss Heather Cogswell to. Second Lieut. William A. Palmer, U.S.A., took place in the Episcopal Chapel of Our Saviour here today. The Rev. James Burnette performed the ceremony.

title: U.S. Finds Serious Defects In 3 TedescoOwned Buses
description: WASHINGTON, July 31A Government safety official said today that his agency had found serious defects in three. buses operated by the Tedesco Bus Company, Inc., of Jersey City.

title: New Sixth Fleet Commander
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (Reu ters)The Navy today appointed Vice Adm. Isaac C. Kidd as new commander of the Sixth Fleet, in the Mediterranean. He will replace Vice Adm. David C. Richardson, in August, when Admiral Richardson will become deputy commander in chief of the Pacific Fleet.

title: Books of The Times
description: All the victories in this book of short stories andthere are someare small ones. People do cope, they do come through. They patch up a family crisis, reconcile a child to the remarriage of her mother, secure the husband and security they desire, accept the fact that they are their father's sons. But these victories are only holding actions; the afflictions of the spirit Mr. Schwartz deals with are part of the very grain of living. We can turn away our eyes, cauterize our nerves, numb our minds, but we can never eradicate these ashes ?? our hearts. Every man is both body and hayonet at some point of his life, says a character in the book. The pain we inflict and endure not from evil or cruelty or ill will but from the nature of life itself. Men weep in these stories, but not because they are in dire straits, but, as Vergil pointed out 2,000 years ago, because of the tears of things.

title: Agreement in Principle
description: Directors of Computer Applications, Inc., and Volt Information Sciences, Inc., agreed in principle yesterday to a merger of the two cornpanies.

title: TRADES STABILIZE IN SUGAR FUTURES
description: Atter its sharp decline on Thursday, the world sugar futures market regained a little equlibrium yesterday. Trading slowed from a near record 6,344 contracts to 1,400 contracts.

title: Milton Stamos Weds Mrs. Fleisher
description: Mrs. Fridolyn Fleisher of New York, a great granddaughter of the late Ellis A. Gimbel, a founder of Gimbel Brothers, was married here yesterday afternoon to Milton J. Stamos of New York, owner of the Riviera Florist here. The civil ceremony took place at the Municipal Building.

title: Air Crash Kills Marine
description: EL TORO MARINE AIR STATION, Calif., July 31 (UPI)First Lieut. Roger W. Mullins, Vietnam war veteran who had been decorated 34 times was killed yesterday and four other men were seriously injured when their KC130.refueling plane crashed while making a practice landing here.

title: GUERRILLAS SEIZE TWO IN URUGUAY
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, July 31  The chief United States adviser to the Uruguayan police force and the Brazilian consul were kidnapped by Marxist guerrillas here today. Two other American officials were injured in an unsuccessful kidnapping attempt.

title: LEAD AND ARSENIC FOUND IN STREAMS
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) Preliminary tests show that substantial amounts of lead and arsenic are being poured into Louisiana's waterways, according to Federal water quality officials.

title: BLACK SQUATTERS QUIT ELLIS ISLAND
description: A group of black squatters ended their 13day occupation of Ellis Island yesterday.

title: Carol Lucinda Colman Plans Marriage to R. L. DeGroff
description: PINE LAKE, Wis., Aug. 1Miss Carol Lucinda Colman, a security analyst with the United States Trust Company in New York, and Ralph Lynn DeGroff Jr., who is with Dillon, Read & Co., investment bankers, in New York, will be married here Oct. 3.

title: Maria (1970) Trapps Her Man
description: WITH The Sound of Music and Pal Joey running on the summertime circuit, the perennial argument begins anew  who wrote the better songs, Rodgers and Hart or Rodgers and Hammerstein? Show tune buffs are split down the middle on this one. While many prefer the wit and sophistication of Lorenz Hart's lyrics, just as many fancy the more sentimental approach of Richard Rodgers later partner, Oscar Hammerstein.

title: HEAD OF OHIO GUARD URGES JURY INQUIRY
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. I Still smarting from the Justice Department report that his men may he liable to criminal charges for the shootings at. Kent State University, Maj. Gen. Sylvestor Del Corso, the Ohio National Guard commander, has called for a grand jury investigation.

title: Reservists Aid Peace Drive
description: BOSTON, Aug. 1, (AP) I Forty Army reservists in the Boston area have donated $424 from their summer training pay to Congressional peace candidates and antiwar organizations.

title: TV Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: YOUR story about the Lone Ranger in your July 12 issue was so convincing that it needs correction. No, we have not sold the rights to the Lone Ranger for the production of an updated version.

title: CAIRO IS PRESSING FOR ARAB BACKING OF PEACE EFFORTS
description: CAIRO, Aug. 1Israel's acceptance yesterday of the United States proposals to stop shooting and start talking has touched off a scramble among the divided Arabs, with Cairo urging realism toward the peace endeavor instead of damaging and disruptive sloganeering.

title: Study Confirms Southeast Is Leader in Stroke Deaths
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UPI) A team of medical researchers has confirmed that more people die of strokes in the nation's southeast coastal region than in other sections. But this is not due to inadequate medical care, the group said.

title: Well, Kansas Has The Biggest One There Is
description: GREENSBURG, Kan.  Most autoborne tourists speed across the flat countryside east of Dodge City and hardly give the sign a second glance. But here, on U. S. 54, where the monotony of the fertile land is broken only occasionally by skyscrapertall grain elevators, is 'The World's Largest HandDug Well.

title: Stamps
description: A NEWSIZE 6cents Flag stamp, the tercentenary of the founding of the State of South Carolina, and a stamp that Postmaster General Winton M. Blount hopes will focus attention on one of the nation's mounting problems pollution of the land, of the water and of the air, are in the offing.

title: The Evolution Of Man And Society
description: C. D. Darlington of Oxford is one of the world's foremost biologists; justly renowned for his researches into the mechanisms of change in the world of cells, chromosomes and genetic systems. In this imposing book he joins the growing number of biologists who believe that the same principles which illuminate mantheorganism also illuminate, and provide causal understanding of, human history: that is, the history, or histories, of civilizations and cultures.

title: SCIENTISTS TRACE A 1553 SHIPWRECK
description: PORT MANSFIELD, Tex., Aug. 1The captain of a Spanish treasure galleon, driven westward across the Gulf of Mexico by a hurricane in 1553, set both anchors when the western shore of the Gulf appeared.

title: Recordings
description: BUSONI's heroic, monumental, mystic opera, Doktor Faust has been recorded by Deutsche Grammophon (3 disks, 2709032) and there can be no doubt: it is a masterpiece and Busoni was one of this century's most original composers.

title: 100 Marching on U.N.
description: SALISBURY, Md., Aug 1 (UN)  About 100 persons, mostly blacks, began a 300mile, 45day march today to the United Nations, where they will call for an end to what they say is the genocide of nonwhites by the United States Government. The march was organized by Making a Nation a newly formed Hark rights organization.

title: Twins Win, 124, on 8 in 10th; Athletics Defeat Senators, 50
description: DETROIT, Aug. 1 (AP)Rick Renick doubled home two runs and Oscar Tovar singled in a pair in an eightrun 10th inning tonight, giving Minnesota a 124 victory over Detroit and snapping a threegame losing streak for the Twins.

title: Law
description: So some of the criticism, at least, had had an effect. Attorney General John Mitchell had seen two of his handpicked Supreme Court nominees thoroughly discredited and cast away; now, looking for all the world like a man who had met his match and lost, he is going to try a new approach. From now on, said the Attorney General, he would let the American Bar Association's judiciary committee look over all potential candidates for the Court before he sent them to the President.

title: Personality:
description: In the United States alone, recovering waste materials and preparing them to be used againwhat the ecologists call recycling and what much of the public persists in calling the junk business  is an activity worth more than $8billion a Year.

title: Staten Island Cricket Victor
description: The Staten Island Cricket Club defeated St. Vincent Cricket Club yesterday by two wickets at Walker Park on Staten Island. Staten Island scored 68 runs for eight wickets, while St. Vincent had 63.

title: PHILS TURN BACK GIANTS BY 65, 61
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1 (UPI)Successive homers by Don Money and Deron Johnson in the third inning propelled Philadelphia to a 61 victory over the San Francisco Giants and a sweep of a doubleheader tonight. The Phillies won the opener, 65, in 11 innings on a throwing error by the left fielder, Ken Henderson.

title: Mary Wright, Cyril M. Hetsko Plan to Marry
description: EAU CLAIRE, Wis., Aug. 1  Mrs. John McMaster Wright has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Wright, to Dr. Cyril Michael Hetsko, both of Madison. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Cyril F. Hetsko of Ridgewood, N. J.

title: Italian Plant Makes Silk With Care
description: People who handle silk treat it with a special reverence and nowhere in the world does it get more loving, tender care than in the Lake Como area of.Italy. Como is probably silk's last stand in the Western world as a result of its losing fight in the battle of textile fibers.

title: Rabid Pet Skunk in Seattle Is Called an Isolated Case
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 1 (AP) The Center for Disease Control has reported that the discovery of a rabid pet skunk in Seattle was apparently an isolated case.

title: Wilson Writing Memoirs
description: LONDON, Aug. 1 (UPI)The Thomson Organization announced today that it had acquired rights to a book that Harold Wilson is writing about his term as Prime Minister of Britain, from 1964 to 1970. Extracts from the hook will appear in The Sunday Times of London next year, the organization said.

title: Of War and Man's Inhumanity to Man
description: A SMALL, excellent and topical exhibition, Against Violence: Callot, Goya and Daumier, currently on view in the secondfloor print galleries of the Metropolitan Museum, brings together the etchings and lithographs of three masters on a common themethe bestiality of war.

title: Friday Night Fight
description: SAN DIEGORonnie Wilson. 164 pounds, San Diego outpointed Larry Cruz, 164, Salt Lake City, 10 rounds.

title: Caroline Louise Burlingham Bride
description: Miss Caroline Louise Burlingham. daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Burlingham of Suffern, was married at St. James Episcopal Church here yesterday afternoon to John Raymond Ellis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred C. Ellis Jr. of Philadelphia. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Ralph R. Warren Jr.

title: Mrs. Joan Sommerfield Is Wed In Suburbs to Robert Bernhard
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 1Mrs. Joan Mack Sommerfield of Greenwich and Robert A. Bernhard, grandnephew of the late Gov. Herbert H. Lehman and greatgrandson of Adolph Lewisohn, the philanthropist, were married here this afternoon. The ceremony was performed by acting Judge Kenneth Simon of Mamaroneck at the home of the bridegroom's cousins, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence B. Buttenwieser.

title: BargeCarrying Ships Are Growing in Favor
description: The startling sight of a 100by65foot barge poised in midair will soon be commonplace in major ports throughout the world.

title: How to Lose The Bermuda Race
description: IN the Washington offices of Time, Inc., one morning last spring, a dark, thickset, 46yearold man named Juan Cameron leafed perfunctorily through a stack of mail. An associate editor for Fortune, Cameron's prime concern was a story in his typewriter on the Nixon White House. But one envelope caught his attention: the return address read Cruising Club of America. Glancing up at the photo of his own 40foot sloop, Lancetilla, Cameron ripped open the letter. This is to notify you, it began, that your entry in the Bermuda Race has been approved  Cameron took a breath. Now, he said to himself, the work begins.

title: The World
Federal Court Rejects a Section of Maine Debtor Law
Blue Ribbon Secrets
description: BLUE ribbons rarely just happen. Experienced exhibitors plan months ahead of flower shows and practice the basic rules of good culture to develop high quality entries. If little thought has been given to exhibiting in fall flower shows until now steps can still be taken to ensure fine entries.

title: Tombs Begins Methadone Experiment
description: A shaggyhaired heroin addict lay in a prison hospital bed last week and told Mayor Lindsay, who was sitting on the edge of the bed, that he felt greatI ate breakfast and everything.

title: The loaf with a secret
description: This round loaf of homemade rye is a picnic in itself along with mustard, a few pickles and a salad or two. Guests may look alarmed at what seems like austerity fare, but slice this haminrye and watch their expressions change. Haminrye is a compact and practical way of packing sandwiches that will not dry out on the way to the beach or lake. The loaf can be made a day ahead or served hot for a picnic supper on the porch.

title: It's Really NiceIf You Dig Real People and Have Tough Feet
description: NICE, FranceSurely I'm not the only traveler who shuns the artificial setting and lifestyle of the typical resort: the beach, the dull street behind the beach, the days spent reading every magazine in the racks, the sameness of the other people in the hotel, the growing testiness with the manager and his waiters.

title: Joe Louis Tribute Set For Detroit on Aug. 12
description: Berry Gordy Jr., a former boxer who is president of Motown Record Corporation, has accepted the honorary chairmanship of the Salute To The Champ, Joe Louis tribute scheduled Aug. 12 in Detroit's Cobo Hall.

title: Point of View:
description: The railroads of America are at an economic crossroad, with no clear signals ahead.

title: Suharto Defends an Aide Accused of Swindling State
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 1 (Reuters)  President Suharto told Indonesian student leaders today that their charges of corruption against one of his chief aides were unfounded.

title: Hanoi Defense Chief Says That Time Is Against U.S.
description: HONG KONG. Aug. 1 (Reuters)  Defense Minister Vo Nguyen Giap of North Vietnam said last night that the United States would be defeated in Indochina because the Communists had time of their side.

title: Letters:
description: To THE FINANCIAL EDITOR: Oscar Lasdon's article in The Times of July 26 surmises that the reorganization of the Penn Central may require from 5 to 20 years. His observations as to the manifold and complex problems which the four trustees must face are most timely and important  not least that, if a railroad is to be successfully reorganized, it must be put in shape to make money on a daytoday basis.

title: The World
description: TEL AVIV  Every Thursday the Government of Israel moves, in effect, from Jerusalem, the capital, to Tel Aviv, center of the country's commerce and party politics. Streams of small cars carry cabinet ministers and their aides, the politicians and the hangerson, down the Judean Hills and across the coastal plain.

title: Christopher J. Sumner to Wed Mary Powell, a Law Student
description: RICHMOND, Aug. 1Miss Mary Lewis Gwathmey Powell and Christopher James Sumner, students at the University of Virginia Law School, will be married here next month.

title: Suit Challenges Nonpublic School Aid
description: A controversial measure providing $28million in state funds for nonpublic schools was challenged in Federal District Court here last week as providing aid to parochial schools in violation of both the Federal and State Constitutions.

title: Elizabeth S. Hulsart Wed to David Wilson
description: KENT, Conn., Aug. 1 Miss Elizabeth Sharon Hulsart and David Matheus Wilson were married here this afternoon in St. Andrew's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Robert Griffiths, the rector.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: I feel that the article on luxury apartments in Manhattan ["Rents for Luxury Soar, July 19] missed the mark. As exclusive leasing agent of four of the five buildings mentionedthe Stratford, the Dorset, One Sherman Square and Gracie PlazaI want to make the point that while luxury apartments are slightly smaller today than they have been in the past, the number of services and amenities the New York City luxury tenant receives is unparalleled.

title: Orioles Crush Royals, 91, for 22d Straight Time, a Major League Record
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 1 (AP)The Baltimore Orioles established a major league record tonight by beating the Kansas City Royals for the 22d straight time.. Jim Palmer, wearing No. 22, hurled a sixhitter and gained the 91 victory.

title: BERNARD SMITH, 68, COUNSEL ON TRADE
description: Bernard B. Smith, a corporation lawyer, died Friday of heart attack at his home, 1165 Park Avenue. He was 68 years old. His office was at 460 Park Avenue.

title: Horton Hanover Beats Chief Crazy Legs by Neck in Overcall Pace at Yonkers
description: YONKERS, Aug. 1Horton Hanover, with George Phalen catchdriving for the absent Joe O'Brien, registered the first sub 2minute mile of the harness racing meeting tonight in the Overcall Pace at Yonkers Raceway.

title: HAWKINS AND GREEN IN STOKES BENEFIT
description: Four of the top players in the National Basketball AssociationConnie Hawkins of the Phoenix Suns, John Green of the Cincinnati Royals and Kevin Loughery and Jack Marin of the Baltimore Bulletshave accepted invitations to play in the Maurice Stokes Memorial benefit basketball game at Kutsher's Country Club, Monticeilo, N.Y., on Tuesday, Aug. 18.

title: Police Revising Their Manual Covering Rules and Procedures
description: The city's Police Department is reviewing and rewriting its massive manual of rules and procedures, including one brief passage dealing with a policeman's association with criminals.

title: LONG ISLAND PLAN HELD IN JEOPARDY
description: SMITHTOWN, L. I., Aug. 1  The chairman of the Suffolk County Legislature has warned that the comprehensive plan for Long Island's development by 1985 stands a good chance of suffering infant mortality.

title: Noise and Ecology Standards for SST Are Sought
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1The Environmental Defense Fund has decided to ask a Federal court to order the Federal Aviation Administration to set noise and environmental standards for the supersonic transport be fore certifying its worthiness for air.

title: Revisions Likely to Be Made In Davis Cup Rules Next Year
description: Revisions seem certain for the Davis Cup next year, American tennis officials believe, but no two officials are willing to venture a guess as to just what changes will be made.

title: Army Bandsmen on S.I. Charge Persecution on Peace Activities
description: Members of the 26th Army Band at Fort Wadsworth, S.I., have charged that they are being punished and intimidated by their commanding officers because they engaged in legal, offduty antiwar activity.

title: Golf Guide Available Free
description: Phil Galvano, who conducts a golf school in New York has written a Guide to Strategic Golf, a 32page booklet with a new approach to golf instruction. The illustrated booklet is available free by writing to Seagram's, 375 Park Avenue, New York, N. Y. 10022.

title: Charter Flight Hearings Set
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP)  Representative Samuel N. Friedel, Democrat of Maryland, chairman of the House Commerce Subcommittee on Transportation and Aeronautics, said yesterday he would start hearings Aug. 10 on charter flight regulations.

title: Brazil's Rights Council to Hear Torture Charges
description: RIO DE JANEIRO. Aug. 1During the last six weeks in Brazil, a young man held briefly investigation by military police here charged that he was given short electric shocks once by his jailers just to show me how it was none. Some residents of an apartment block in Brasilia the nation's capital, were kept awake one night by screams from a civilian police station next door.

title: The Two Archipenkos
description: ALEXANDER ARCHIPENKO was born in Kiev, in the Ukraine, in 1887. He died in New York in 1964. His artistic career was long and distinguished. His production as a sculptor was copious and original  in some respects, historic. He belongs to that magic circle of courageous talents that changed the entire face of painting and sculpture in the first two decades of the present century. Had he passed from the scene in 1923, he would still be remembered as one of the most inventive and resourceful sculptors of the School of Paris in the halcyon days of Cubism and its immediate aftermath. Indeed, had Archipenko passed from the scene in 1923, his career would offer us a tidier and far less problematic subject than, in fact, it now does.

title: Child of Fashion
description: It's ethnic, with a healthy slice of Americana, in children's wear this fall.

title: Slump in Economy Hurts Some Party Fund Drives
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1The economic slowdown is seriously crippling some political fundraising efforts this year, but many of the nation's candidates are as financially healthy as ever or only slightly hampered.

title: Exchange Club Elects Head
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 1 (AP)Arturo L. Carrion Jr. of University Gardens, P. R., has been named president of the National Exchange Club. He is the first native Puerto Rican to hold the office. Mr. Carrion was elected by acclamation at the organization's annual convention here Tuesday.

title: Best Seller List
description: This analysis is based on reports obtained from more than 125 bookstores in 64 communities of the United States. The figures in the righthand column do not necessarily represent consecutive appearances.

title: Photography
description: Los ANGELES IT wasn't until I was halfway through my first meeting with Robert Heinecken, one of the leaders in threedimensional photography, that I realized it was my second encounter with him. Leafing through a copy of Are You Rea"a limited edition portfolio of his workI remembered that in the winter of 1965, I spent an evening with several photographers who were experimenting with slide shows. Among them apparently was Heinecken, for of all the work I saw that dampish night, it was his which had remained in my mind.

title: DRUG PERIL EASES AT POWDER RIDGE
description: MIDDLEFIELD, Conn., Sunday, Aug. 2A physican serving as medical director of the aborted rock music festival near here said early this morning that the drug situation that he had described yesterday as approaching the crisis stage was no longer so serious.

title: Article 2  No Title
WELL MANNERED TAKES HANDICAP
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1Bwamazon Farm's Well Manered extended a winning streak to five today by winning the $55,750 Minuteman Handicap at Liberty Bell Park by eight lengths over J.I.B. Farm's Rol licking. The favored Silent Screen finished last in the field of six 3yearolds.

title: Bank on Fifth Ave. Damaged by Bomb; 3d Blast in 2 Weeks
description: For the third time in two weeks a bank was bombed here yesterday.

title: Headliners
description: When Benjamin O. Davis Jr., a highly respected retired Air Force general, was appointed safety director in Cleveland, the Plain Dealer observed: All of the general's past endeavori indicate that he could be the very person to deal effectively with Cleveland's No. 1 problempublic safety. This was an allusion to the general's reputation for discipline, to the fact that he was a Negro serving under a Negro Mayor, Carl B. Stokes, and to the city's racial troubles. But last week, after just six months on the $24,000ayear job, General Davis decided to quit. The Mayor and administration continue not to give me support for programs that I require and continue to provide support and comfort to enemies of law enforcement, he said. General Davis was reported considering offers from the academic field, and also the idea of running for Mayor of Cleveland next year.

title: Music
description: A MOSTLY MOZART FESTIVAL, they are calling it, and it starts tomorrow in Philharmonic Hall, to run the entire month. This kind of thing has been going on in August at Philharmonic Hall ever since 1966 (except for last summer, when Philharmonic Hall was closed for an acoustic restoration); and, as before, it is being backed by the Lincoln Center Fund. From the beginning the series has provided a welcome interlude in the cheerless New York summer months. The finest music has been presented, in an airconditioned hall, at relatively low prices. Perhaps the public response has not always been as gratifying as the sponsors would have wished, but they feel that there is a real need for this kind of series, as indeed there is, and they are prepared to persevere.

title: A Costa Rican Find
description: COSTA RICA in 1965 released six stamps and a souvenir sheet to commemorate the XVIIIth Olympiad in Tokyo in 1964, it not being an unusual procedure for some countries to remember past events, especially when there are subjectmatter, or topical, collectors who dote on such stamp issues for events such as Olympic Games.

title: POLL ON CONGRESS LED BY DEMOCRATS
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 1The current division of the vote for Congressional candidates shows the Democratic party with a 54to46 per cent lead over the Republicans, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Ford to Build Plant in France
description: DETROIT, Aug. I  The Ford Motor Company plans to build an automatitc transmission plant in France with the site to he picked by December, the company said here.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Plans for a conference of leaders from Arab confrontation countries in Tripoli, Libya, in the next day or so to try to coordinate their policies toward the American peace plan for the Middle East were announced yesterday in Cairo. The United Arab Republic, at the same time, was urging Syria and other reluctant nations to support the peace endeavor.[Page 1, Column 8.]

title: A Signal for Rozelle
description: As the National Football League labor impasse continues the question arises: How will it be resolved, and how soon? Increasing hostility between the club owners and the players would appear to compel Commissioner Pete Rozelle to arrange a resumption of negotiations. When he attended several meetings last month, settlement developed on sonic vital issues. Perhaps his presence would inspire a complete settlement.

title: AID TO ERADICATE OPIUM SUGGESTED
Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To the Editor: In December 1965 I wrote after my first trip to Vietnam, Whereas before my trip, I felt we should settle for nothing less than a complete military victory, I feel now that if we could get a satisfactory negotiated peace I would gladly accept such a peace. After my second visit to Vietnam during much of which I was accompanied by the late Bernard Fall, I recommended to Secretary Robert McNamara that we stop the bombing of North Vietnam. Thus, I feel can speak as neither hawk or dove but as one interested in an early end to the hostilities

title: INTREPID WINNER IN CRUISING RACE
Ceylon Seeking Oil From U.A.R.
Johns Hopkins Adds Aide
description: Howard J. Shulman, an assistant at Northwestern High School in Baltimore the last two seasons, has been named freshman football coach at Johns Hopkins University.

title: INQUIRY IS SOUGHT INTO POLICE CLASH
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 1  A brawl involving black and white policemen at the annual picnic of the Fraternal Order of Police has increased racial tensions and resulted this week in a request for an investigation by the Department of Justice.

title: Man Is Shot to Death on Street in RiotTorn Hartford
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 1  Witnesses and the police differed today over whether a 28yearold Puerto Rican man was shot and killed by a sniper or by policeman as a curfew was continued in effect here last night.

title: MOSCOW ASSAILS BAGHDAD'S STAND
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 1The Soviet Union today criticized Iraq for opposing President Gamal Abdel Nasser's acceptance of the American proposal for a settlement in the Middle East.

title: Village of Brewster Troubled By ApartmentBuilding Boom
description: BREWSTER, N.Y.  For decades, this village, with six churches, five policemen and two bars, had been quietly languishing upon a hillside 52 miles north of New York City.

title: Kings Point Academy Post
description: Norman C. Scott, executive vice president and director of the Matson Navigation Co., San Francisco, has been named chairman of the advisory board of the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point. He succeeds Dr. J. R. Skretting, head of the department of social studies at Florida State ??

title: National Guard Draws More Vietnam Veterans
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1The National Guard has met with mixed results in a twopronged campaign for experienced volunteers that some see as a forerunner of the effort to create an allvolunteer Army.

title: Harlem Fans See Top Basketball Free
description: Freddie Crawford doesn't have to recruit talent for the Harlem Professional Basketball Tournament anymore. Now the talent comes to him.

title: Architecture
description: QUESTION: What is more deadly than the automobile? Answer: The automobile and the Federal Government together. The combination has a destructive capacity that is one of the few efficiencies that bureaucracy has ever produced; vide the highway program.

title: Commodity Futures Faring Well
description: While the words soybean oil and fresh eggs may lack the glamourtinged ring of aerospace; laser technology and automatic data processing, an increasing number of speculators are finding that the rarefied atmosphere of commodities futures trading can offer rewards.

title: Cooke Will Visit U.S. Bases
