description: Cardinal Cooke, military vicar for Roman Catholics in the armed forces, will leave tonight to visit United States Air Force bases in England and Army bases in Germany. He is scheduled to leave Kennedy International Airport at 9:30 P.M. and to stop in Ireland to visit relatives and to celebrate mass in Galway Cathedral. He is expected to return to New York on Aug. 15.

title: Yonkers Will Lower Flags To Honor Hugh Redmond
description: YONKERS, July 31  The flags at City Hall and other public buildings here will fly at halfstaff Monday in memory of Hugh Francis Redmond, former Yonkers resident who was held in a Communist Chinese prison for 19 years until his death several months ago.

title: Reader's Report
description: Thumb Tripping By Don Mitchell. 182 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $5.95.

title: For Customers'
description: Back in the days when so many people were eager to own a share of American industry, one midtown registered representative made $2,000 a month fulfilling their needs.

title: Idea of Monster's Death Stirs Loch Ness Area
description: GLASGOW, Scotland, Aug 1 (Reuters)Defenders of the Loch Ness monster have turned furiously on a scientist who suggested that it had been killed by pollution.

title: EARLY TALKS SEEN ON MIDEAST PEACE; U.S. Aides Feel ?? Can Arrange Details in a Week
Minnesingers
description: LIECHTENSTEIN'S promised last commemoration of its famed minnesingers will show the great Wolfram von Eschenbach, and three other singing story tellers of the past in a miniature sheet to be issued August 27.

title: PISTONS WILL PLAY 41 HOME CONTESTS
description: DETROIT, Aug. 1 (AP)The Detroit Pistons will play a record 41 home games for the 197071 National Basketball Association season.

title: Australia Has Second Thoughts As Immigrants Swell Population
Hi Q Beats Windy Mama By a Nose in Coast Race
description: DEL MAR, Calif., Aug. 1 (AP) Hi Q rallied from sixth place in the stretch and hung on to beat Windy Mama by a nose today in the $22,600 Ramona Handicap.

title: Soviet Union Wins 5 Titles In Canoe, Kayak World Meet
description: LAKE BAGSVAERD, Denmark, Aug. 1 (AP)  East European countries totally dominated the finals in the world canoe and kayak championships at Lake Bagsvaerd, near Copenhagen, today. The Soviet Union took five of the eight titles. Hungary and Rumania captured one each.

title: City Manager Named
description: BERLIN, N. H., Aug. 1 (AP) Joseph Burke, 52 years old, Public Works Superintendent in Lexington, Mass., has been named City Manager. Mayor Normand Tremaine said Wednesday that Mr. Burke would assume his new duties Aug. 24 at an annual salary of $16,400.

title: World Academy Revises Debts
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 1 (UPI)  World Academy, Inc., a travel service whose bankruptcy stranded 3,100 students abroad in June, has revised its debts to $2.5million and its assets to $1.9million.

title: Marsha Gelberg Affianced
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y.. Aug. 1  Mr. and Mrs. Bernard R. Gelberg have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marsha Robin Gelberg, to Mark Richard Harris, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert J. Harris of Scarsdale. A March wedding is planned. Miss Gelberg is a student at Beaver College. Her fianc, a graduate of the New York University School of Engineering and Science, is working towards his master's degree at Columbia University.

title: Atmosphere in Mississippi Town Has Changed and a Black Runs for Mayor
description: WEST POINT, Miss., July 29 There is no fear left. The evidence is lodged in their dark faces as they campaign out on Main Street on these hot, steamy afternoons.

title: City Landmark Gets a Chance For Survival
description: While other cities watch and Chicago, in particular, hopes, New York has taken a giant step into the controversial field of air rights transfer. If the Board Estimate approves the action taken by the City Planning Commission and backed by the Landmarks Preservation Commission, a 42story office tower will go up on the east side of Third Avenue between 49th and 50th Streets adjacent to Amster Yard. The tower will be built, in part, with the air rights from that 19thcentury landmark.

title: Dave Hill Donates to Charity
description: HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 1 Dave Hill declined his allotment of free tickets for the Westchester Golf Classic, officials said today. Each contestant was alloted three season guest badges worth $40 each. When Hill learned Lhe price he wrote out a check and asked that it be given to the tournament beneficiaries, the six Westchester hospitals.

title: Hope for the Bluebird Population
description: MENTOR, Ohio SINCE early Colonial times, the bluebird has been a sentimental favorite. Settlers in the Plymouth Colony welcomed its melodic song and gorgeous blue feathers which reminded them of their English robin redbreast.

title: Rise Is Reported in Arrests For Postal Crimes in Year
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UPI) Postmaster General Winton M. Blount has reported arrests and convictions for postal crimes set a record during the past fiscal year, with sharp increases in offenses dealing with drugs and obscene materials.

title: Miss Edith Joy Becomes Bride Of Paul K. King
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., Aug. I  Miss Edith Halsted Greacen Joy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick van Reuren Joy was married in St. Peter's Episcopal Church here this afternoon to Paul Kevin King, son of Mr. and Mrs, Thomas L. King of Arlington, Mass. The ecumenical ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert C. Harvey of St. Peter's and the Rev. John Dericks of the Assumption Roman Catholic Church.

title: Chinese Free Briton Held 3 Years as Spy
description: HONG KONG, Sunday, Aug. 2 (AP)George Watt, a British engineer, crossed the border from China today after he spent 34 months in a Chinese prison on charges of spying.

title: Record Number Immigrate To New Zealand from U.S.
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Aug. 1Migration figures released for year ended March 31 show a record influx of United States citizens intending to establish permanent residence in New Zealand.

title: The Nation
description: The House of Representatives, which is supposed to be the part of the Federal Government closest to the people, has long hidden many of its significant operations behind a bewildering set of procedures. Most members preferred it that way and the public did not seem to care. It was therefore a major shift in the House's sense of itself when it decided last week to abandon the most important of these procedures, the unrecorded teller vote.

title: Poems 19341969
description: An ordinary man is a message to the world, David Ignatow says in an early poem in this book. But if he is modest more often than arrogant in the exercise of his gift, if he praises life more than he berates it, no one would call these the characteristics of an ordinary poet today. And in fact the beautiful attention with which he has recorded the lyric experience of 35 years has accumulated here to an extraordinary autobiography.

title: Hungarian Postage Stamps Honor Man's Best Friend
description: When the delegates of 35 nations gathered at Budapest for the annual Federation Cynologique Internationale conference, there was considerable enthusiasm over an issue of stamps highlighting purebred dogs.

title: Mrs. Witman Wed in Florida
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Aug. William Persons Gwinn. chairman of the United Aircraft Corporation, and Mrs. Rachel Coleman Witman. widow of John H. Witman and owner of John H. Witman Interiors, were married here today. The Rev. George W. Wyer of the Episcopal Church of BethesdabytheSea performed the private ceremony at the bride's home. A reception followed at the Beach Club.

title: Late Listings for Today's TV
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2.

title: Brooklyn restoration
description: Many seedy neighborhoods in New York are being brought back to life as young families buy up the decaying brownstones and renovate them. In Brooklyn's Boerurn Hill, now beginning to be revived, the Robert T. Snyders found a prize: a 120yearold brownstone that had been occupied continuously by one family and that was structurally sound. It needed restoration, but it was there to be restored, said Mrs. Snyder, who paints under her maiden name, Patricia Stegman. (Mr. Snyder is a labor lawyer.) Their main tasks were modernizing the wiring and plumbing, peeling away a houseful of ancient wallpaper and relandscaping the rather oldfashioned backyard. The Snyders were lucky enough to be able to buy some of the house's original furnishings and have added more Victorians to go with them. HOUSE AND GARDEN The Snyder house, framed by old trees, is red brick with green shutters. The railings are black iron. The garden (right), just beyond the kitchen door, serves as their 4yearold son's playground. It is filled with flowering shrubs and plants in pots. In good weather, the Snyders have lunch, dinner and weekend breakfasts at the round table. The iron settee was an antique crib. When their son outgrew it, they took off one side to make it a cushioned garden bench.

title: Carolyn A. La Corte Is Married
description: CRANFORD, N. J., Aug. 1 Miss Carolyn Anne La Corte, daughter of Mrs. Nicholas St. John La Corte of Cranford and the late Mr. La Corte, was married here this morning to William Robert Finnegan 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. William R. Finnegan, also of Cranford.

title: Fame and Obscurity
description: Gay Talese is a journalist who can be a graceful, accomplished writer gifted with a shrewd eye, a stout and ample heart, and the patience to wait endlessly until the moment finally arrives when the subject of his portrait, his vigilance lulled, drops his guard. His intention, he says, is to absorb the whole scene, the dialogue and mood, the tension, drama, conflict, and then... write it all from the point of view of the persons I am writing about, even revealing whenever possible what these individuals are thinking during those moments I am describing.

title: ASBURY PARK FIRE RAZES 2 BUILDINGS
description: ASBURY PARK, Aug. 1A blaze reportedly started by fire bombs wrecked two fivestory buildings early today in a business area here near where riots ravaged a threeblock section of the predominantly Negro West Side several weeks ago.

title: Ann H. Cummings Wed to Banker
description: SCARBOROUGH, N. Y., Aug. 1  Miss Ann Haven Cummings, an account executive with Batten, Barton. Durstine & Osborn, and Clifton Iverson Jr., who is with the metropolitan division of the Chemical Bank, were married here this afternoon in St. Mary's Episcopal Church. The Rev. William J. Clague officiated.

title: Soviet Lifter Sets Record By Pressing 403 Pounds
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 1 (AP)Alexander Kidyaev, a Soviet weight gifter, broke a world record in the middle heavyweight division by pressing 403 pounds, according to Tass, the official Soviet press agency.

title: Black Party Backs a Candidate To Face Wallace for Governor
description: SNOWDOUN, Ala., Aug. 1 The predominantly Negro National Democratic Party of Alabama met in the woods of a green lakeside in Southern Alabama today to nominate a black candidate to oppose George C. Wallace for Governor in November.

title: 10 Preseason Games Scheduled For Knicks, With 2 in Garden
description: The world champion New York Knickerbockers will play 10 preseason games before they open their 25th National Basketball Association campaign at Madison Square Garden Oct. 13 against the Boston Celtics.

title: The Nation
T.V.A. Payments To Local Units Up
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 1 Tennessee Valley Authority payments in lieu of taxes to state and local governments will total about $16million for the fiscal year ended June 30 and an additional $24million paid by municipal and cooperative electric systems will bring the total to $40million.

title: Vietcong Radio Says Nixon Wants to Prolong the War
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 1 (UPI) The Vietcong said today that President Nixon demonstrated in his news con ference last Thursday his wish to prolong the Indochina war.

title: STAUB'S 4 HOMERS HELP EXPOS WIN 2
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 1 (AP)Rusty Staub crashed two home runs in each game, driving in four runs in the opener and snapping a seventhinning tie in the second, tonight as the Montreal Expos swept a doubleheader from the Los Angeles Dodgers, 116 and 65.

title: 50 Yachts Are Entered In Corinthians Cruise
description: Richard N. Jayson, master of The Corinthians, has announced that about 50 yachts have entered the 1970 invitation race cruise starting with a feeder race on Friday evening from Stamford to Newport, R. I.

title: Prices Up On Counter And Amex
description: Stocks on the American Stock Exchange showed slight gain last week in heavier trading than the week before. The index on Friday closed at 20.52, up.18 for the week.

title: Shopping Center Growth Slowing
description: New shopping centers have been getting larger and more numerous throughout the United States in recent years, but many builders, investors and money lenders now feel that harder times may be just around the corner.

title: Hog Cholera Outbreak
description: WILMINGTON, Ohio, Aug. 1 (UPI)  An outbreak of hog Cholera has caused 35 farms in Clinton County and 21 farms in Brown County to be placed under Federal quarantine. Federal authorities said about 500 hogs had been destroyed.

title: French Fishing Town Worried About the Vanishing Sardines
description: LORIENT, France, July 23 Emile Rio raised his tumbler of yin ros in a sad salute to the waters of the Bay of Biscay.

title: Chicago Job Plan For Negroes Gets Its First Trainees
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (AP)The Chicago Plan's administrative committee has approved the first training program and recruiting centers aimed at finding construction jobs for minority group workers.

title: Horse Shows Its Heels To StockCar Drivers
description: GLYNDON, Minn., Aug. (AP)A horse led the field in a stock car race at the Glyndon Speedway the other day. It suddenly appeared on the track and led for twothirds of a lap.

title: Computers to Help Ease Capital Traffic
description: A new computerized urban traffic control system with a builtin priority for transitsystem buses will be installed, in downtown Washington over the next three years.The experiment, of interest to other cities that seek to disentangle their vehicle traffic, is being funded by the Department of Transportation. The Department's Federal Highway Administration and Urban Mass Transportation Administration have entered into a $3,775,691 contract with the Systems Management Division of the Sperry Rand Corporation of Great Neck, L.I., for a system using sensors that will tell D.C. Transit Company buses from all other vehicles.

title: Urgent Plea for Drivers Issued by Red Cross Here
description: The New York chapter of the American Red Cross in Greater New York yesterday issued an urgent appeal for volunteer drivers.

title: Mahler Madness At Fever Pitch
description: IT begins to look very much as if Gustav Mahler has made it into the club. Before the longplaying record, that marvelously mixed blessing, put him before a large audience, his chances of attaining oldmaster status seemed slight. A few musicians who claimed to know his works talked lot about what they regarded his his as hos banality, his longwindedness, and his morbidity. Oddly, some of these same experts enthusiastically accepted the most banal Wagner and Strauss, and even Max Reger.

title: FRESH AIR FUND HAS BUNYAN DAY
description: The thermometer outside the door to the recept'on building at the entrance to the Fresh Air Fund's Sharpe Reservation camping center in Dutchess County registered 82 degrees at noon one day last week.

title: Letters: Debacle of a Tour Agency
description: To THE EDITOR: THE financial collapse of the World Academy student tour company that left 3,500 American young people stranded in Europe raises a number of questions not answered in the words of the spokesman who blamed the situation on the current economic situation.

title: Tigers Buy Kevin Collins
description: DETROIT, Aug. 1 (AP)The Detroit Tigers today purchased Kevin Collins, a lefthanded hitting infielder, from Winnipeg of the International League. Collins, a former New York Met, is scheduled to join the Tigers tomorrow.

title: Miss Ducey Ensign's Bride
description: NORTHEAST HARBOR, Mc., Aug. 1Miss Georgina Munson Ducey was married here this afternoon to Ens. Joseph Hooper Field, U.S. C.G.R., in St. Mary'sbytheSea Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Malcolm Sawtelle, who was assisted by the Rev. John Haynes.

title: Washington: What's ThisGood News?
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1It may just be the illusion of the vacation season, but common sense seems to be breaking into the headlines these days. A ceasefire now seems assured in the Middle East war. The casualty rate is down and the withdrawal is proceednig on schedule in Vietnam. The strategic arms limitation talks with the Soviets are going along slowly but sensibly and the American economy is beginning to get over the shakes.

title: Foreign Affairs: The High Cost of Freedom
description: DENVER, Colo. Although President Nixon has faced sea of internal and external troubles since taking office, he seems determined not to be deflected from longrange goals. One of these is a drastic military refOrm which would eventually do away with conscription.

title: New York
Eagles Drop Brennan
description: READING, Pa., Aug. 1 (UPI) The Philadelphia Eagles asked waivers today on Terry Brennan, a Notre Dame tackle. The 6foot4inch, 250pound rookie was the team's seventh draft choice.

title: Calendar of Motor Sports Events
Jersey to Get New Trains For Use of Commuters
description: A longawaited modernization of the ErieLackawanna's northern New Jersey commuter system is scheduled to begin this month with the delivery of the first of 105 new passenger cars.

title: T.V.A. Chief Defends Plan To Increase Power Rates
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 1Answering opposition to the Tennessee Valley Authority's announcement of a rate increase to its power distributors, A. J. Wagner, the authority's chairman, said today that there is no realistic alternative.

title: MASSMAN IS CHOSEN AS TRAINER OF NETS
description: Fritz Massman, trainer at Boston College for the last four years, has been named trainer of the New York Nets American Basketball Association club.

title: URUGUAY PRESSES GUERRILLA DRIVE
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 1Despite more than 50 arrests by the Uruguayan police during the last 24 hours, the authorities have apparently made no important progress toward freeing a United States police adviser and a Brazilian diplomat kidnapped yesterday by Marxist guerrillas.

title: Temple Names Shrier Aide To the Director of Athletics
description: Allen Shrier has been appointed assistant to the director of athletics at Temple University. Charles (Chico) Sacchetti will become business manager of athletics.

title: Miss Christine Anna Billhardt Is Bride of John R. Gambling
description: MANHASSET, L. I., Aug.1 Christ Episcopal Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Christine Anna Billhardt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Philip Billhardt, to John Raymond Gambling, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Alfred Gambling of Plandome. The Rev. Frank N. Johnston, the rector, performed the ceremony, which was followed by a garden reception at the home here of the bride's parents.

title: Movie Mailbag
A Family Failure
description: In this German first novel, a masterpiece of terse allusions cast in laconic prose, Kuno is an aging child in his late fifties, the very model of a proper little German who, never once raising his voice, tells the story of how he grew up to be a basket case.

title: Tufts to Deny House Panel List of School's Speakers
description: MEDFORD, Mass., Aug. 1 (AP)  Tufts University has disclosed that it will not comply with a request from the House Internal Security Committee to forward the names of all speakers who have appeared at the school in the last two years.

title: In the Battle Against Hunger
Mary Sperling Wed Near Capital
description: CHEVY CHASE, Md., Aug. 1The North Chevy Chase Christian Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Mary Sperling, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Godfrey Sperling Jr., to Ens. John Herbert McAuliffe, U.S.C.G.R., who is on active duty in the Washington headquarters of the Coast Guard. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Dean McAuliffe of St. Joseph, Mich.

title: Modern Pentathlon Lead Is Gained by Hungarians

title: Blind Man Charged With Using Cane To Mug Cab Driver
description: A 27yearold blind man was arraigned in Criminal Court yesterday on charges of mugging and robbing a cab driver before accomplices. dawn on an isolated Bronx street with the help of several accomplices.

title: Is It the Role of the Artist to Change Society?
description: EVERY sentence that begins The role of the artist is... is untrue as soon as spoken. Professors have roles, politicians have roles, speakers in debates have roles. No sooner do you clothe an artist in a role than he slips out of it and is skipping away down a road you hadn't imagined. Roles are things to be performed in front of other people. The artist does something else  obeys a necessity, solves a puzzle, fills a hole, makes mess, sheds a skin, sets fire to himself. Whatever he does and however he does it.it is an act in search of freedom, and cannot be contained in the straitjacket of definition.

title: 2 NATIONS TESTING ALGAE AS A FOOD
description: BONN, August 1A joint project begun this week by West Germany and Thailand foresees the cultivation and processing of proteinrich algae as a food on a large scale.

description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., Aug. 1Miss Judith Ann Knutson and John Francis Calabrese were married here this morning in St. John's Episcopal Church. The Rev. Joseph F. MacGinnis performed the ceremony.

description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1The University of Pennsylvania has announced it will observe an 11day unstructured period that will facilitate student participation in the November elections.

title: Television

Soap plots are too tortuous to synopsize in less than a million words, so let it suffice to say that in this particular plot line, Cathy has been experimenting with drugs.

description: SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, Aug. 1 (Reuters)Jose Urtain, the Basque from Spain, lost for the first time tonight when he was disqualified for a low blow against Alfredo Vorig of Italy in the third round.

title: Sports of The Times
description: HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 1It was totally out of character. Jack Nicklaus normally keeps his emotions under tight rein and reflects neither exultation nor anguish in the mercurial fashion of his buddy, Arnold Palmer. But when Big Jack sank his final putt to clinch the British Open championship a few weeks ago over the sacred sod of St. Andrews in Scotland, he jubilantly flung his putter in the air.

title: Chiefs Show Stars Pro Finesse Despite Only 5 Days of Drills
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 1The College AllStar game, won easily by the Kansas City Chiefs, 243, was tedious because Dennis Shaw and Mike Phipps, the AllStar quarterbacks, could not attack the pro champions defense. They completed only 7 of 25 pass attempts and the entire offense gained only 89 yards.

title: Farrow and Martin Take National Tennis Crowns

title: T.V.A. Digs For Coal Near Home
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 1With coal piles low and some power going to Consolidated Edison in New York, the Tennessee Valley Authority is turning to digging in its own back yard.

description: BASSETERRE, St. Kitts, Aug. 1A motor launch carrying more than 150 people from this Carribbean island to the nearby island of Nevis capsized and sank today.

description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 1 (Reuters)  Foreign Minister Abba Eban said tonight that President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic had helped Israel in formulating the answer to the latest American proposals for a solution to the Middle East crisis.

title: Joyces Are Athletes for All Seasons
description: Need any golf of basketball advice? See the Joyce Brothers. No, not Dr. Joyce Brothers, the blonde psychologist, but Mike, Tom and Bob, the golf professionals, and Kevin, the heralded sophomore of the South Carolina basketbal team.

title: Egypt's BirthControl Program Is Found to Have Limited Effect
description: CAIRO, July 28The fecundity of Egypt is visible in every street and alley, teeming with children and pregnant women. It is estimated that 3,000 babies are born every day and that the population, now nearly 34 million, will reach 45 million by 1980. The country's landreclamation program can hardly keep up with it. We do not talk to the women about population control, said Mrs. Aziza Hussein, a pioneer of the movement We talk about happy families.

title: Portrait Of a Decade
description: THE 1970 census will show that the United States has a population somewhat in excess of 205 million, an increase of about 25 million since the last census was taken in 1960. This will hardly come as a revelation, for sample surveys taken by the Bureau of the Census since the last complete count provide an accurate annual record of broad changes in the American population. The question has even been raised as to whether the nation might not dispense with a laborious head count every 10 years and substitute the cheaper and actually more reliable sample surveys to keep track of population growth and change. However, only a complete count can provide the detailed knowledge of individual states, counties, cities and smaller areas desired by many users of the census for political, commercial and scientific purposes. Indeed the primary reason for taking a census as prescribed by the Constitution is to discover shifts in the population of Congressional districts before reapportioning seats in the House of Representatives.

title: Jersey Group Again Seeks New Trot Track Approval
description: The New Jersey Racing Commission said yesterday it had received an application from Meadows Racing Association, Inc., to conduct a harness race meeting in the Bergen County borough of Carlstadt.

title: Miss Cain Wed To a Bank Aide
description: BUFFALO. Aug. 1Miss Susan M. Cain of Buffalo and Stephen E. Shipman of New York were married here this afternoon in the Holmes Chapel of the Westminster Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Wallace Easter.

title: The Merchant's View:
description: The retail picture should become clearer after Labor Day, but observers of the business scene are more and more stressing a bottomingout of the economic downturn and are making cautious predictions of a gradual upturn.

description: NORTH COLEBROOK, Conn., Aug. 1Mr. and Mrs. Warren Main Humes have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Dorothea Humes, to Dr. Sylvan Kornblum, a research psychologist at the Mental Health Research Institute at :the University of Michigan.

title: Virginia Economy Slows Down
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Aug. 1With figures in for the first six months of 1970, Virginia's economy mirrors the national slowdown, according to the latest Virginia Business Index. The index, published by the William & Mary School of Business Administration and edited by Dr. Leland E. Traywick, director of its Bureau of Business Research, covers economic and business trends in some sectors that were be ginning to pick up in June after earlier slowness. However, the upturns were not described as significant.

title: The Grande Dame of Winnipesaukee
Everything Comes Out Berlioz!
description: WTHAT, people always ask, is music's future'? Are they asking: what will the future of music be? or, what will future music be? Either way, like planned obsolescence in automobiles, the concern is more for the future than for the present. The nervousness of the question reveals a very 20thcentury obsession by evaluating art beyond the immediate purpose it serves, an evaluation that would have been unknown to, say, Bach. The questionusually posed by the academic middleaged  also implies that art, as a value, is in a precarious situation, that it should last, but probably won't. Meanwhile, certain young people maintain that the lasting ingredient makes no difference. As long as 20 years ago painters were already painting in momentary materials; some of the pictures destroyed in the Museum of Modern Art conflagration in 1958 would have, in any case, disintegrated by now.

title: Movies:His Happiness Is A Thing Called 'Joe'
description: THERE he was as big as a Mack truck"Joe"standing on the stoop of his West 79th Street brownstone, dressed entirely in black, his bald pate gleaming under the mid-morning sun. His name is really Peter Boyle, and he's a 34-year-old former Christian Brother from Philadelphia. But it's hard to think of him as anyone but "Joe" after seeing his sensational performance as the gun-loving, beer-swilling, tough-talking tool-and-die maker from Queens who hates "niggers," hippies and fags, and not necessarily in that order. Peter is such a good "Joe," in fact, that columnists are already touting him for the 1970 Oscar as best actor. And even those critics who jumped on "Joe" raved about Peter's performance.Peter is waiting outside his building, he says, because he doesn't want any stranger to see his sparsely furnished (TV, two chairs, a "Joe" poster, a bed) bachelor apartment. So he decides in his rather assertive manner ("I'm really very shy") that we will walk down Broadway and get some breakfast at a neighborhood greasy spoon. Peter is stopped several times along the way, and it is obvious by his reactions that he loves the recognition. Well, the guy deserves it. It's taken him 10 years of odd jobs, two-bit roles and "tough guy" commercials to get it."Hi, Joe!" a shaggy-haired youth shouts in passing. "Loved your movie." "Thanks," the grinning actor replies, proudly hoisting his slightly pot-bellied, 220-pound frame up to its full 6-feet-2-inches. At 77th and Broadway, where a scene for Woody Allen's new movie, "Bananas," is being filmed, a red-haired woman extra rushes up to Peter and kisses him on the cheek. "Oh, you were wonderful!" she squeals. "Thanks, Naomi." On the edge of the crowd, a handsome black actor pumps Peter's hand and says, "Hey, man, do you remember me from that beer commercial in Pittsburgh? You wore my orange sweatshirt." Peter remembers, and they talk about old times.Peter chooses a coffee shop at 75th and Broadway, and after ordering ham and eggs, he begins talking about the "incredible timing" of "Joe." At first his tone is matter-of-fact, but as he goes on, it becomes somber, disconsolate."We finished it last February, and that was way before Kent State or Jackson State or the construction workers beating up on the kids on Wall Street. Mylai had happened, of course, and I think the last scene in "Joe," where the kids are murdered in the commune, may have been inspired by that massacre. But none of us were propheticnone of us knew that the hardhats were going to do what they did on Wall Street. The minute I heard about it, I knew it was going to affect the way the movie was received. I wasn't happy . . . who could be happy about that? If anything, I'm scared. I've been scared for a couple of years. I get scared when I meet people like Joe. And I get scared when I hear that kids are standing up at the end of the movie and yelling. 'I'm going to shoot back, Joe.' In fact, the other night I was walking down 46th Street and I had a flash of myself being shot down in the street, just because someone thought I really was Joe."Peter pauses for a moment, plucks eight pills in assorted colors of red, white and brown  "all vitamins," he saysfrom his shirt pocket, and gulps them down with orange juice."The message of the movie is very plain," he goes on. "It says that we'd just better stop that war in Vietnam now; that we'd just better stop killing our children there or we're going to be killing our children in the streets here. The Bible says that if you live by the sword, you die by the sword, and that's what's going to happen."Politically speaking, Peter says he is probably best described as a "conservative radical." "I got that from Norman Mailer," he says, "and I like it, although I did not support Mailer for Mayor. I did not want to encourage such excesses of megalomania." Peter traces his "leftward leanings" to Chicago in the summer of 1968, when he was acting at Second City at the time the Democratic convention was going on."One night I was standing peacefully with some friends in front of a bar in Old Town," he recalls, "and some cops started chasing us. An Episcopal clergyman picked us up in his car, and gave us sanctuary in his house. I remember saying, 'My God, I'm in America, and I'm afraid for my life!' I'm always ready for a fight at any time, but quite frankly, I didn't want my face beaten in just then because I had acting jobs. On another night I was just sitting in my apartment on Schiller Street and I was tear-gassed. At first I thought it was a sneeze coming on, so I took a vitamin C tablet. Then I discovered it was tear gas wafting down from Lincoln Park where the kids were getting gassed."Despite it all, Peter says he is not entirely unsympathetic with "Joe." "He's a man who's really trapped," he says. "He doesn't like his job, his taxes are sky high, and his kids are causing him trouble at home. Sometimes I worry that maybe we were too hard on him. He is lovable in his own way. But then I get to thinking how scary it is that the hardhats are becoming activists, and it reminds me of the brownshirts in Germany during the thirties. The hardhats say they're patriotic, but their unions are the most notoriously racist of all the unions. If that's who's representing patriotism in our country, then we're really in trouble."Peter wasn't the first choice for "Joe." He read for the part three times and was told he was "marvelousbut too young," so an older, more experienced actor was selected. He didn't work out, and Peter was called in after production had begun to take over the role. He was paid a total of $2,520 for six weeks' work."At the tryouts, I improvised instead of reading the script they gave me," he says, "because I had been hearing that character all my life. In Philly, where I grew up, people all around me were spouting off about 'those damn niggers, and people on welfare, and wops, and kikes.' I did the same type of character at Second City, and I knew the character so well that when it came to the actual shooting of the movie, I was worried that I would do a caricature.""Joe" is not his first movie, but it is the first one he has made a splash in. He was an extra in "The Group," and played the man who ran the gun range in "Medium Cool." Peanuts, as far as money goes, but he managed to support himself fairly well doing commercials for TWA (he was the baggage handler), Buick (he was a customer) and Instant Replay (he was a baseball catcher who caught "the best pitcher in baseballTom Seaver"). He has a small part in a group therapy scene in the upcoming "Diary of a Mad Housewife," which he did after "Joe" was completed. "David Gill ["Joe's" producer] told me I was crazy to do that bit with 'Joe' coming up. I said, 'Look, I don't have any idea what's going to happen to 'Joe.'"Breakfast is over. We walk up Broadway and into Riverside Park, where Peter straddles a park bench. Curly black hair shows beneath his unbuttoned shirt, and he looks so rough, tough and ugly-handsome that he reminds one of Rod Steiger . . . no, Telly Savalas . . . no, the late William Bendix, Or better yet, a mixture of the three, Machismo.It's not surprising, then, that his acting idol is Marlon Brando. "He's the best," Peter declares. "I had this fantasy of meeting him the other day. Frankly, I'd be a little scared of meeting him. I mean, what would I say?"Peter was born in Philadelphia to Irish immigrant parents. His late father, whose professional name was Pete Boyle, was a commercial artist who later hosted children's shows on a TV station there. Mrs. Boyle now lives in New York with one of Peter's two sisters.Peter became a Christian Brother while a student at La Salle College, but he left the order soon after graduation. "My name was Brother Francis," he recalls, "and I prayed so hard I had callouses on my knees. I tried to reach God, I did a lot of studying, and I found it was an unnatural way to live. The celibacy is ridiculous. Boy, I really got horny."I'm really into a Zen thing now," he goes on, lying down on his back on the park bench. "I just don't like the authoritarianism of the Catholic Church. And I don't like the materialism I see in the parishes, with their concern for money and building larger and larger schools. But there are some very exciting people in the church now, like Father Berrigan."The next stop after the monastery was the U. S. Navy, where Peter was discharged after a few months of service because of a "severe nervous breakdown." Then he headed for New York, with dreams of becoming an actor. He took lessons from Uta Hagen, worked in the Post Office and as a bouncer at O'Neals' pub, toured in the national company of "The Odd Couple," and finally hit pay dirt in the television commercial world.Although he has nothing in the works right now, he says he hopes his next job will be another movie. "You can improvise in the movies. I know, I know, the screenwriters will pull out their hair when they read that. They're all overpaid, anyway. When people first started making movies, the actors improvised. Charlie Chaplin improvised."Peter improvised some of the dialogue in "Joe," including one line of his lone nude scene where he makes love to a hippie girl. "I really felt uptight about that scene," he says. "For one thing, I weighed 10 pounds more than I do now. Anyway, I take her breast in my mouth and she says, 'Hey, wait a minute.' Well, I ad-libbed. 'I hope I'm not out of line,' and they left it in."Does he worry about being typecast as a Silent Majority man?"It's a danger. I've been thinking about it a lot recently. But I think I can do other things. I remember once going up for it part, and the woman said, 'You don't look menacing enough.' This summer I'm in the CBS Comedy Tonight show [Sundays at 9 P.M.], and I took that so I could show people I could do other things, too." (If you don't recognize him on the show, that's probably because he'll be wearing his hair-piece.)Although Peter has been "reasonably close to marriage once or twice," he is wary because he has seen so many unhappy marriages among his friends. "I know that if I'd gotten married when I came out of the monastery, I would probably be getting a divorce by now. Being a bachelor has its points. By the time you're 34, you've really been through a lot of things with women, and you know what you don't want. What I want is children. I think a man and woman who live together and have children are very courageous."It is noon and Peter has an appointment with a photographer, so we walk back to his building. I leave him as I found him, standing on the stoop and guarding the door because he is ashamed of having a stranger see his bare apartment.Judging from the long lines of people queued up to see "Joe," Peter probably won't he ashamed much longer.

title: Intrepid Defeats 3 America's Cup Rivals in Race for Caritas Cup
FIFTH AVE. CLOSING IMPRESSES TOKYO
description: Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that Tokyo had decided to follow New York City's lead by closing its main shopping avenue, the Ginza, to motor traffic on a weekend day.

title: STAUNCH AVENGER FIRST IN SAPLING
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 1The colt many Easterners called with a smirk, the Chicago horse, Staunch Avenger, came out of the West to manhandle a field of 13 other 2yearolds today and capture the $135,870 Sapling Stakes at Monmouth Park.

title: Panther Trials Have Contrasting Airs
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 1If the airconditioning were turned off and the bulletproofed windows opened, spectators might have expected to hear the humming of bees outside the courtroom where a 24yearold Black Panther named Lonnie McLucas was on trial here last week.

title: Men's Amateur Tennis Set For Meadow Club on Aug. 10
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 1The country's top amateur tennis players will renew bids for national rankings at the Meadow Club Aug. 10 through 17 in the United States Lawn Tennis Association men's amateur grasscourt championships.

title: MRS. LESTER C. MIGDAL
description: Mrs. Ellen Marcus Migdal, wife of Lester C. Migdal, senior partner in the law firm of Migdal, Low, Tenney & Glass, died yesterday at University Hospital alter a long illness. She was 49 years old and lived at 58 East 92d Street

description: Before yesterday's fire there were four serious accidents on the city subway system in recent months. The chronology follows:

title: Hogan Will Compete in P.G.A. Title Tourney Starting in Tulsa on Aug.
description: HARRISON, N. Y., Aug. 1Ben Hogan, an unhappy fella in the $250,000 Westchester Classic, is planning to resume tournament play soon.

title: The Week in Finance
description: The consensus in a survey of a dozen nonGovernment economists by The New York Times last week was that the economy would move upward at a slightly faster pace the rest of the year, with inflationary pressures abating somewhat.

title: Bridge on River Kwai, Built by P. 0. W's, Now a Thai Tourist Spot
description: AT A BRIDGE ON THE RIVER KWAI, Thailand, July 26  When a train rumbles across the trestle, the tourists scamper onto the little escape platforms the prisoners of war did not build. The prisoners could hardly foresee, nor could their Japanese captors, that one day the bridge would be a goal of excursionists.

title: World
description: fighting In the Middle East was not curbed, was willing to endorse the ceasefire plan once it had improved Egyptian air defenses and had established its own positions near the Suez Canal.

title: RANGERS TO PLAY IN 10 EXHIBITIONS
description: A pair of games in Madison Square Garden, including one against the Stanley Cup champion Boston Bruins, are listed on the New York Rangers 10game preseason schedule.

title: Orders for Shipbuilding Setting Record
British Troops Use Gas to Quell Rioters in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 1 (UPI)British troops used gas to quell rioters for the third successive night tonight in the Roman Catholic area of Belfast around New Lodge Road.

title: MISS WILKINSON WINS GOLF FINAL
description: ROCKVILLE, Md., Aug. (AP) Martha Wilkinson of Anaheim, Calif., defeated Nancy Hager of Dallas today for the women's TransMississippi golf championship, 7 and 6, over 36 holes.

title: Christmas Tree Trade Hurt by ManMade Kind
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. The business of growing live Christmas trees in Pennsylvania has been stunted by a rise in the popularity of artificial trees.

title: Patricia Crum Married Here
description: Miss Patricia Ann Crum was married here yesterday afternoon to Frederick Haywood Gilchrest by the Rev. Dana Klotzle in the chapel of the Unitarian Church of All Souls.

title: Judith R. Dillingham Engaged To Ens. Alfred Woodworth Jr.
description: HONOLULU, Aug. 1Mr. and Mrs. Bayard Harrison Dillingham have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Randolph Dillingham, to Ens. Alfred Skinner Woodworth Jr., U.S.N.R., who is serving aboard the destroyer Barry, based at Newport, R. I. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Woodworth 2d of Chestnut Hill, Mass., and Prouts Neck, Me.

title: THIS IS IT TAKES HORSE SHOW TITLE
description: THREE BRIDGES, N.J., Aug. 1This Is It, owned by Sally McKegg of Somerville, N.J., and handled by her coach, lain Crawford, captured the green working hunter championship at the Hunt Cap Farm's horse show today.

title: Irish Setter Named Penn Ridge Best
description: HILLTOWN, Pa., Aug. 1A; handsome Irish setter, Ch. Tirvelda Middle Brother, owned by Mrs. Helen Olivio of Brooklyn, and Alan Levine of Whitehouse Station, N. J., triumphed over 1,006 opponents yesterday at the 13th annual Penn Ridge Kennel Club event at the Hilltown Civic Association Field.

title: 500,000 Federal Workers Reported Living in Poverty
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UPI) More than half a million Federal workers live below or at the poverty level, according to a spokesman for the nation's largest Federal employe union. He said many would defy Federal law by going on strike if wages were not improved.

title: D'Inzeo of Italy Regains Cup at Royal Horse Show
description: LONDON, Aug. 1 (Reuters)Capt. Raimondo D'Inzeo of Italy won The Daily Mail Cup, the top event at the Royal Inernational Horse Show, at Wembley tonight.

title: Delaware Handicap Is Taken by Obeah
Quota of Days for Showing Brazilian Films Is Doubled
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Aug. 1 (AP)Starting next year, according to a new decree, all the country's movie theaters must show Brazilian films 112 days a year, or double the quota imposed now by the National Cinema Institute.

title: Power Crises Aid Some
description: This last week was a nightmare for electric utilities as they juggled power supplies from the service area of the Tennessee Valley Authority to the East Coast.

title: Doris Fleeson, Columnist, Dies; Winner of Journalism Honors
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1Doris Fleeson, a newspaper reporter and syndicated columnist here for nearly 40 years, died at her home early today, just 36 hours after her husband's death. She was 69 years old.

title: NICKLA US, CRAMPTON AND HINSON PACE GOLF AT 206; METE BEAT PADRES, 42
description: HARRISON, N. Y., Aug. 1The rivalry continued between the experienced campaigners and the younger players today during the third round of the $250,000 Westchester Golf Classic. After 54 holes there Was no single tourney leader. Instead three shared the lead at 206, 10 under par.

title: Scientists Ask SST Delay Pending Study of Pollution
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 1Scientists from the United States and Europe, after a monthlong meeting here on environmental problems, recommended today that largescale operation of supersonic transport planes be delayed until serious questions about the planes potential for environmental contamination can be answered.

title: Poverty on Mexico Border Is Attributed to U.S. Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) A former Federal official has blamed Washington for contributing to poverty along the United StatesMexico border by allowing 100,000 Mexican nationals to cross each day to jobs in the United States.

title: Roan Case Going to Courts
description: About 40,000 Americans, some of them confused or angry or both, will be affected financially by a series of events in Africa this month and by related, subsequent events in the Federal District Court in Philadelphia.

title: U.S. Aide Ends Athens Talks
description: ATHENS, Aug. 1 (AP) Rodger P. Davis, United States Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, today concluded talks with the Greek Government. He did not disclose the topics, but informed sources said they had inclued full resumption of military aid.

title: TICKERTON HANDLING ARMY TICKET SALES
description: Army football fans will be able to purchase tickets for all five home games at Michie Stadium and the ArmyNavy game in Philadelphia through 217 remote computer terminals on the East Coast, according to an announcement made by Col. Gus Dielens, the director of athlet1 ics.

title: Singleton Notches a Double In Ohio Schoolboy Hurdles
description: BOWLING GREEN, Ohio, Aug. 1 (UPI)Fred Singleton of New Rochelle won the 180,yard low hurdles in 18.8 seconds and the 120yard highs in 113.5 seconds today and was named the outstanding performer at the third annual National Junior Invitational Track and Field championships.

title: Ford Fund Sets Up Grants For Innovative Education
description: The Ford Foundation announced yesterday that 10 to 12 grants, ranging from $100,000 to $250,000 each, would be given annually for the next four years to improve undergraduate education in colleges and universities throughout the country.

title: Laotian Restraints
description: In a lengthy statement on Laos last March 6 which proved to be less than wholly candid, President Nixon declared that his Administration had no plans for introducing ground combat forces into Laos.

title: FOUR WALKS HELP SHAPE YANK RALLY
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 1Four walks, one intentional, presented to the Yankees by Bob Humphreys of the Brewers in the 12th inning today, provided a punchless final sequence to what had been a tense game as New York downed Milwaukee, 41, for its sixth straight success.

title: JOBLESSNESS FRAUD IS LAID TO TONGYAI
description: GENEVA, N. Y., July 31 Thomas Tongyai, 26 years old, a sheriff's undercover agent on the Hobart College campus here this spring, was arrested today and charged with receiving state unemployment checks while actually employed.

title: Wind Shortage Cancels Sail
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., Aug. 1 The first cancellation of the Yacht Racing Association championship season resulted today from an absence of sufficient sailing breeze for the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club regatta, which was the 22d scheduled Y.R.A. event.

title: Master'
To See, To Take
description: To See, To Take, Mona Van Duyn's title, like our first verbs, sounds innocent at the outset, fierce and telling later on. Infinitives in certain languages are imperatives as well; and so they are here, in poems where seeing and taking are urgent as well as pleasurable activities:

title: Summer and the Single Channel
description: EVER seen those ads for Radio Free Europe? The ones with the people huddling around a precious, truthgiving radio, listening with all their might to news of the outside world? Have you ever sat on the Fifth Avenue Bus looking at one of those Madison Avenue depictions of life behind the Iron Curtain (Radio Free Europe ads are a staple of Fifth Avenue bus decor) and told yourself, It couldn't happen here"?

title: Bridge
U.A.W. Is Laying Off 175 And Cutting Travel Expense
description: DETROIT, Aug. 1 (AP)The United Auto Workers Union has announced that it is laying off about 175 employes and cutting back travel and other expenses to bring its general fund into balance.

title: Gen. Bull, U.N. Truce Chief, Pays Farewell Visit to Egypt
description: CAIRO, Aug. 1 (Reuters)Lieut. Gen. Odd Bull, the chief Middle East truce supervisor for the United Nations, who is retiring, arrived here for a twoday farewell visit.

title: Siena to Compete in Track
description: Siena College will participate in intercollegiate track and field events for the first time next spring, athletic director Gene Culnan has announced. Culnan said he had arranged meets at Albany State, Union, Hartwick, New Paitz and said the team would compete in the LeMoyne relays, the New York State championships and the I.C.4A championship.

title: SUNDAY BLUE LAW UPHELD IN VERMONT
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., Aug. 1 (AP)The Vermont Supreme Court has upheld the constitutionality of the state's controversial Sunday blue law, which prohibits the sale of certain articles on Sundays.

title: Nixon Works and Relaxes At. West Coast White House
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 1 (AP)President Nixon got in a little business and a little loafing around the Western White House today, with more of both on tap for tomorrow before he flies to Washington Monday with a stop at Denver.

title: Service Will Ease Rules on Hunting Migratory Birds
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UPI) The Fish and Wildlife Service says regulations on hunting of some migratory birds will be more liberal next fall and winter.

title: Jersey Police Told to Stop Harassing Youths in Cars
description: MEDFORD, N.J., Aug. 1 (AP) The Burlington County prosecutor has ordered the police here to cease and desist from harassing longhaired youths by stopping and searching their cars without cause.

title: John Billings Marries Lucy E. Adams,Smith'70
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Aug. 1The First Presbyterian Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Lucy Ely Adams, who was graduated this year from Smith College, to John Clinton Billings, a 1969 graduate of Brown University. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr., minister of the church, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Thomas Derr of the department of religion at Smith.

title: Women's Liberation Wins Battle in Vienna
description: VIENNA. Aug. 1 (UPI)Women's liberation won a battle this week with a ruling by Parliament that all women over 18 years of age must be called Frau. or Mrs.

title: Chess
Scream of MIG's Disrupts Calm of Egyptian Resort
description: AGAMI, United Arab Republic, July 28Sovietbuilt MIG21 fighter planes screaming in low from the Mediterranean and dayandnight flying by helicopters in combat training have disrupted the normal tranquillity of this resort community situated amid palms, pines and white sand just west of Alexandria.

title: BIG TRADE NATIONS FEAR RISING CURBS
description: GENEVA, Aug. 1The major industrial nations sought today to prevent a tide of protectionism from engulfing world trade.

title: Bus Service to Liberty Bell Will Begin Here Tomorrow
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1Colonial Coach will begin daily roundtrip bus service from New York to Liberty Bell Race Track on Monday.

title: In the Excelsior, Bitterness Replaces Tenant Unity
description: The Excelsior, at 303 East 57th Street, is an apartment house divided against itself.

title: Ceremony Joins C. A. Fogarty, Miss Rockefeller
description: RYE, N. Y., Aug. 1Christ's Episcopal Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Mary Gillett Rockefeller, oldest of Mr. and Mrs. William Rockefeller's three daughters, to Clayton A. Fogarty, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Auwell Fogarty of Wilmette, Ill.

title: From Dory Previn to Ben E. King
description: ON MY WAY TO WHERE: Dory Previn (Media Arts Records Z4RS 7758). Art imitating life or life imitating art? The question is raised by Dory Previn's debut recording as a singersongwriter. She is, of course, the former (or almost former) wife of Andre Previn and, up to the present, has been known principally as a fine lyricist (among her songs, Come Saturday Morning from The Sterile Cuckoo and You're Going To Hear From Me from Inside Daisy Clover).

title: Vivian Parker Is Bride
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 1 In the First Presbyterian Church here this afternoon, Miss Vivian Claire Parker was married to Nicholas Charles Yacabucci, an electronic development engineer for the Burndy Corporation in Norwalk. The Rev. Thomas Nissly performed the ceremony. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Elmer K. Parker and Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Yacabucci, all of Port Chester. N. Y. Mr. Parker is owner and president of the Parker Tool and Products Company in North Pelham, N. Y. The bridegroom's father is a manager with the Westchester County Park Commission.

title: Job Changes:
description: The United Aircraft Corporation has announced the election of J. Lynn Helms as president of the Norden division in Norwalk, Conn.

title: Colonial Ft. Stanwix Undergoing Restoration Upstate
description: ROME, N.Y., Aug. 1 Auggust 31st this Day (1758) two men Belonging to the York Regiment were wipt For Disartion one had three hundred Lashes and the other Eight hundred Nothing Extradenary, according to a diary of a junior officer in a British expedition against the French in Canada.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Article 5  No Title
description: A NOBLE, pretty and indiscreet lady said at a dinner party recently that the thing she adored about Brussels was the good air connections with London and Paris. The air connections are good. But the lady was a bit unfair. Brussels's fate is to be continually compared, invariably unfavorably, with the great capitals to the west and south. Brussels, London and Paris are, or course, in different leagues, although I will presently argue that the best restaurants of Brussels are, in many cases, superior to any in the world. Nevertheless, Brussels must be taken as Brussels, and if the visitor is willing to accept this principle, he can find much to enjoyespecially if he looks to cuisine and comfort and takes culture as it comes.

title: Fleet Fails to Finish in Time
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 1 There were no finishers within the time limit today because of a dying wind on Long Island Sound in the first half of the Yacht. Racing Association's annual eastern Connecticut area championship regatta for cruising ?? at Black ?? Y. ??

title: Irishman Swims Channe
description: FOLKSTONE, England, Aug. 1 (Reuters)Ray Cossom, a 37yearold post office worker from Northern Ireland, reached here today after swimming from France to England, becoming the second successful English Channel swimmer of 1970. The Channel Swimming Association said his time for the crossing was 13 hours and 41 minutes.

title: ACCEDES VICTOR IN OPEN JUMPING
description: MIDDLETOWN, N. Y., Aug.. 1Alcedes, an outsider in the strong field, scored the most important triumph of his caJeer today when he captured. the East Coast Challenge Trophy for open jumpers at the, concluding session of the eightday Orange County Horse Show.

title: Ruth Lawrence Becomes Bride Of T. L. du Pont
description: Miss Ruth Anne Lawrence and Thomas Lewars du Pont, recent graduates of Rollins College, were married here yesterday afternoon at the St. RegisSheraton Roof. The Rev. Peter M. Sturtevant, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: ProSihanouk Radio Begins Broadcasting
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 1 (Reuters)A new radio service run by the Pekingbased Cambodian government in exile, headed by Prince Norodom Sihanouk, went on the air for the first time today.

title: Donna E. Miller, '66 Debutante, Is Married to Lyman H. Casey
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug 1Miss Donna Elizabeth Miller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard K. Miller, was married in St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church here this afternoon to Lyman Henry Casey, son of Princess Ranieri di San Faustino of San Francisco and Alexander Casey of Hillsborough.

title: Flashy or Sloppy, the Play's the Thing
description: Rusty Staub leaps high, grabs the ball as it's headed over the fence, fires it to first base and gets a double play. Tommy Helms races behind second base, spears the hard grounder backhanded, spins around and gets the runner at first.

title: Storm in Gulf Labeled Dangerous Hurricane
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 1 (UPI)  The Weather Bureau classified Celia, the season's third tropical storm, as dangerous hurricane tonight and said a hurricane watch might be needed along the Gulf Coast tomorrow.

title: Coast Citizen Groups Oppose Oil Well and Freeway
description: PACIFIC PALISADES, Calif., Aug. 1Citizens groups are fighting proposals for an oil well and a freeway system that they feel will mar the scenic beauty of the Pacific Coast in and around Los Angeles.

title: O.K., Amigos, Join the Jam!
description: FALLOWFIELD, MASS. THOUSANDS of music lovers streamed into this tiny town in the Berkshire Mountains today to hear the final concert in the annual Interwoven Summer Festival of Classical Music. The crowd, which spread over several acres of neatly manicured grass, gave an enthusiastic response to the music, despite a few unexpected ?? changes.

title: APPRAISAL POLICIES TIGHTENED BY F.H.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UPI) George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development announced yesterday tighter appraisal policies by the Federal Housing Administration to prevent slum landlords from abusing the Federal housing subsidy for poor families.

title: Tom Lee Jones And Mrs. Rosen Married Here
description: Mrs. Katharine Lardner Rosen and Tom Lee Jones were married here yesterday afternoon in a ceremony performed at the bride's home by the Rev. Dana Klotzle of the Unitarian Universalist Association.

title: Sniper in Ontario Town Is Caught After Shooting
description: LONDON, Ont., Aug. 1 (AP) One person was shot and scores of shoppers scattered from a downtown intersection today as a sniper with a rifle sprayed bullets from a fifthfloor window of the London Hotel opposite City Hall.

title: STOKES ASKS RISE IN CLEVELAND TAX
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 1Some Cleveland commuters face the possibility of paying two municipal income taxes if proposals by Mayor Carl B. Stokes are approved.

title: FIRE IN IRT TUNNEL LEADS TO A DEATH; SMOKE FELLS 50
description: A woman died and 50 passengers and rescue workers were overcome by smoke in suffocating electrical fire yesterday morning in the Lexington Avenue subway tunnel near the Bowling Green station in lower Manhattan.

title: Paperbacks
description: FICTION

title: ARMS SALES CALLED A SYMPTOM OF WARS
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 1 (AP)A study of arms sales by the great powers to underdeveloped nations has concluded that arms sales are a symptom rather than a cause of the large number of conflicts that have abounded in the Third World since the end of World War II.

title: Miss Schappert Plans Nuptials
description: MONTVILLE, N. J., Aug. Miss Patricia Ann Schappert and Carroll Arnn Potter, who were graduated last month from George Washington University, have made plans to be married here Oct. 10 in St. Pius X Roman Catholic Church.

title: Car Owned by Princess In Crash Near London
description: LONDON, Aug. 1 (AP)A blonde in a pink trouser suit driving a car belonging to Princess Margaret was involved in a crash with a fire engine last night.

title: U.S. BLACKS INVITED TO WORK IN ZAMBIA
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Aug. 1 President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia has invited black Americans to come and work in his country because we lack skilled manpower in all fields.

title: Car Bumpers That Really Bump On Way
description: DETROIT, Aug. 1A few weeks ago at the General Motors Corporation's sprawl?? technical center outside Detroit a strange, bobnosed Pontiac drove headon at 10 miles an hour into a parked car.

title: Playing On Our Prejudices
City Pension Costs Increase Sharply
description: Vast increases in the city's pension commitments are being viewed with mounting concern by municipal fiscal officials.

title: Janet F. Rice and John Hose Wed
description: Miss Janet Florence Rice, manager of the subsidiary rights department for the Cambridge University Press here was married in Christ's Episcopal Church in River:dale, the Bronx, yesterday afternoon to John Robert Hose, executive officer of the University Faculty Senate at the City University. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Howard Bingley of St. John's Episcopal Church on Staten Island.

title: N. F. L. Owners and Players Deny Reports That a Labor Settlement Is Near
description: The time for decision on the National Football League's first weekend of exhibition games, next Friday and Saturday, grew shorter yesterday as the labor impasse remained at a standstill.

title: Letter to the Editor 1  No Title
REDS DOWN CUBS WITH 4 IN 8TH, 64
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 1 (UPI)Ty Cline's pinchsingle with the bases filled capped a fourrun eighthinning rally tonight and paced the Cincinnati Reds to 64 victory over the Chicago Cubs. The loss snapped the Cubs fourgame winning streak.

title: Shipping Broker Sees Firm Rates
description: LONDON, Aug. 1 (AP)World freight market rates should continue firm during the next 12 months despite a current lull that has caused spot positions for voyage rates in particular to decline, according to Eggar, Forrester, Ltd., London shipping brokers.

title: Nancy Mortimer Plans Marriage To Law Student
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., Aug. 1Mr. and Mrs. Charles Greenough Mortimer Jr. have announced the. engagement of their daughter. Miss Nancy Brooks Mortimer, to J. R. Peter Wilson. son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank P. Wilson of Franklin Lakes.

title: You've heard of Yukio Mishima, novelist, general, swordsman, karate student, movie star, lecturer, bon vivant and maybe soon Nobel Prize winner?
Arizona Signs Mine Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) Arizona has become the first state to sign with the Federal Government for mutual inspections of noncoal mines. The Interior Department announced the agreement Wednesday. The agreement provides for state inspection under guidelines equivalent to the Federal standards, but the Bureau of Mines will also inspect every Arizona underground noncoal mine at least once a year.

title: Point of View
description: The statement that New York City does not need more luxury housingthat is, nonsubsidized apartments renting at $125 to $150 per room a monthwill come as a great surprise to all those who are scurrying around frantically looking for precisely such units.

title: Labor Aide Appointed
description: WASHINGTON, Aug 1, (AP)  The Labor Department has announced the promotion of Frank M. Kleiler from director of the Office of LaborManagement and Welfare Reports to Deputy Assistant Secretary for planning and evaluation for labormanagement relations. Mr. Kieller, 56yearold Labor Department career official, formerly served with the National Labor Relations Board.

title: Home Improvement
description: THE instructions on almost every can of paint will tell the user that any of the old paint which is blistered, cracked, peeling or chalking badly should be removed before the new coat is applied. However, few tell how this should be accomplished.

title: RAVEN CLASS SAIL TAKEN BY PAGELS
description: BAY SHORE, L. I., Aug. 1Bill Pagels, who will defend his Raven Class championship later this month, was among the winners today as the Greatl South Bay Yacht Racing Association's annual Race Week championships got under way. Bill Ludlum was the runnerup, in the class.

title: Police Report 108 Arrests In Taxi and Truck Protection
description: Policy Headquarters announced yesterday that 108 arrests had been made by the taxi and truck surveillance unit.

title: ALLEN GRAND SLAM HELPS CARDS WIN
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 1 (UPI)Richie Allen capped a 14hit attack with his second grand slam homer of the season tonight and paced the St. Louis Cardinals to a 147 rout of the Houston Astros.

title: Chicanos in Texas Bid For Key Political Role
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Aug. 1 La Raza UnidaThe United Peoplegrowing more militant all the time and having added its own political party to its brown power movement, expects to hold the balance of power in this fall's Senate and governorship election in Texas.

title: Son Born to Bonebakkers
description: NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Aug. 1A son was born on July 30 to Mr. and Mrs. Erno R. Bonebakker at the CooleyDickinson Hospital here. The child has been named Erno Barel. Mrs. Bonebakker, is the former Miss Victoria Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Brown of New York. The child is also the grandson of Mr. and Mrs. Erno B. Bonebakker of Carppinteria, Calif. The child's father, until last week, served as a lieutenant with the Coast Guard.

title: Music: Fun on Sultry Day in Newport
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 1There was once a composer named Franz von Koczwara, and he died in 1793, and hardly anybody today remembers his name. But he composed one piece that made him famous. For over a generation his The Battle of Prague graced the racks of every piano in Europe. Who was there that did not thrill to the bugle calls, the infantry charge, the cannonades, the national anthems? Koczwara established the genre known as the battle piece, and there were thousands of imitations soon on the market.

title: MR LEADER SCORES ON AQUEDUCT TURF
description: The Cragwood Stable's plan to smother its opposition by sending a fourhorse entry into the $61,600 Tidal Handicap on Aqueduct's closingday program yesterday met with success. Mr. Leader, ridden by Chuck Baltazar, came from way back in the field of 15 to win the 1mile turf event, heating the HerJac Stable's Naskra by the convincing margin of lengths.

title: Theodore Roosevelt 4th Marries Constance Rogers in Bay State
description: FALMOUTH, Mass., Aug. 1Miss Constance Lane Rogers and Theodore Roosevelt 4th, a greatgrandson of President Theodore Roosevelt, were married here this afternoon in St. Barnabas Episcopal Church by the Rev. Donald McKinney.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: THE almostadmirable Luciano Berio, while trying to kill at least two birds with one groan, has accused the New York City Opera of extravagant costuming of the Virgin Mary in Puccini's Suor Angelica. Let me hasten to assure him that the figure of $750 he came up with (did it really look that expensive?) is completely wrong and almost four times the actual cost.

title: Nigerians Burn Union Jack
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Aug. 1 (UPI) Demonstrators burned the Union Jack here today during march protesting proposed British sales of arms to South Africa. The police estimated that several thousand men and women had marched.

title: Richey Gains Final; Smith Def eats Ashe
Santa Anita Plans Shopping Center
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Aug. 1Picturesque Santa Anita, built in the midst of citrus groves in the nineteenthirties, apparently is yielding to the encroachments of the urban sprawl of the seventies.

title: Pollution Beginning To Blight Even The Florida Keys
description: KEY WEST, Fla.For 30 years Cecil Marvin, a charterboat captain, took his clients fishing on Lake St. Claire in Michigan in the summer and off the Florida coast in the winter. It was pleasant life.

title: U.S.C. Places Two Players, On Collegiate AllStar Nine
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug 1 (UPI)Players from the south and west dominated the 1970 College AllAmerica baseball squad picked for the Sporting News by scouting directors for the major league clubs.

title: Ann Hodgkinson Married to C. D. Low
The World
description: BONN  They've got to be difficult, said one of Chancellor Willy Brandt's senior aides, commenting off the cuff and off the record on last week's treaty negotiations between West Germany and the Soviet Union. If they were not difficult we would have a hard time selling them to the German public.

title: Fire Official Urges Aid by the Public On False Alarms
description: Lieut. John E. Kelly president of the Uniformed Fire ;Officers Association, has asked the public to help reduce the ;growing number of false alarms now plaguing the city.

title: Spotlight
description: Large blocks of stocks have been flying thick and fast on the New York Stock Exchange and to the stockbrokers who arrange these largeblock sales this indicates significant change in the nearpanic psychology that swept through the market two months ago.

title: RUSSIAN MOTIVES IN TALKS ASSESSED
description: WARSAW, July 26The Soviet Union's decision to end its traditional hostility toward Bonn and to enter into negotiations with the West Germans was motivated above all by economic reasons, Eastern European specialists believe.

title: Moving Through Here
description: Don McNeill was a young man from the Northwest who came to New York when he was 20 to attend New York University, dropped out of N.Y.U. when he was 21 to write for the Village Voice and drowned two years later in a lake in upstate New York. His death was accidental and therefore seemed doubly pointless and tragic. He lived his brief adult life in the radical bohemian underground, where identity is more nearly a matter of choice than in any other segment of our society, and where early death most often comes as result of one's life style.

title: Car Hits Tenement
description: A tenement on the Lower East Side collapsed yesterday morning when a car crashed into it, killing the driver, injuring at least 10 persons and toppling several residents of the building into the falling debris.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: MENEMSHA. Mass.Capt. Edward (Spider) Andresen and I were headed for No van's Land Island in his 24foot Wahoo when we saw herring gulls hovering over Devil's Bridge, a nasty underwater rock ledge off Gay Head on Martha's Vineyard Island.

title: Education
description: In its three brief but turbulent years of existence, the tiny Ocean HillBrownsville demonstration district in Brooklyn cast a long shadow over the entire New York City school system and, to some extent, over the nation's urban school scene.

title: Police Display New Slogan
description: LAKELAND, Fla., Aug. 1 (UPI)  The police in Polk County are displaying a new slogan on bumper stickers on their cars. The stickers read: If you don't like police, next time you're in trouble call hippie.

title: Flood Waters Rise in Dacca
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Aug. 1 (Reuters)Rapidly rising flood waters today swirled kneedeep through the streets of Dacca as army helicopters dropped relief supplies to other stricken districts in East Pakistan. Authorities announced that more than 30 million people had been affected by the floods. At least 50 have died.

title: Copout clothes
description: If you want to cop out of the midimini question, there are clothes around that will let you hide your legsand show them, too. Minidresses take cover beneath buttonon midiskirts or disappear under long, billowy capes. In short, the long of it isn't the only look this year.

title: History And Human Survival
description: Every American decade seems to discover a new mirror image of itself and to invent its own special psychological experience. In the 1950's we saw ourselves as David Riesman's otherdirected man and William H. Whyte's organization man. In the 1960's, our elder sons and daughters saw themselvesmediated through the vision of Erik Eriksonas having an identity crisis. Now, in the 1970's, it seems that our younger children are in uneasy pursuit of themselves as protean man, and is to the searching essays of Robert J. Lifton we must turn for current instruction as to what it all means.

title: Horses Are Given Little Schooling in South Africa
description: They don't waste time with show horses in South Africa. The horses come off the track, get a few brief schooling sessions, then it's on to the shows.

title: LARSSON BREAKS SWIM MEET MARK
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1 (AP) Gunnar Larsson, a 19yearold from Long Beach, Calif., set a a meet record of 4 minutes 42.9 seconds in the 400meter individual medley today at the 12 annual Los Angeles invitation swim meet

title: The Nation
description: People were crawling about, people were screaming, whimpering, gasping for breath, touching each other, vanishing in the dark, and ever and anon being pushed off the platform on to the live rail.

title: Soccer Players Strike Over Salary Dispute
description: MILAN, Itaiy, Aug. 1 (AP)  The members of toe Milan Soccer Club went on strike today to protest having their salaries reduced.

title: Protestant Book Publishers Sales Rise
description: A new kind of piety that stresses immediate personal experience and encounterencounter with other humans and with the divineand that deemphasizes doctrinal formulations has given Protestant religious publishers a big new surge in sales.

title: Bathtub Races Are Creating Waves in Canada
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba Bath salts, a new breed of Canadian sailors, will wind up their regatta season here on Aug. 15 with a sixmile race on the Red River.

title: U.S. ALTERS DRAFT ON SEABED RICHES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1Congressional pressure has forced the Nixon Administration to temper an international treaty it was to have proposed on Monday that would have used the untapped riches of the ocean floor to benefit underdeveloped nations.

title: France No Longer Immune
description: Only hours after the Security Council had called on all United Nations members to tighten and extend the arms embargo against South Africa, France turned over the first of three 700ton submarines to South Africa's Navy. It was the kind of thing France hag done with impunity for years, despite Security Council appeals for an arms ban for the Pretoria regime.

title: Cardinal Pizzardo Dies at 93; Helped to Shape Lateran Pact
description: ROME, Aug. 1  Giuseppe Cardinal Pizzardo, at 93 the oldest of the 131member College of Cardinals, died at his home here today.

title: Roma to Face Paris Today In Women's Soccer Here
description: Something new in international soccerwomen's competitionwill be played today at 4 o'clock at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island, with Roma of Italy opposing Paris of France.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 1This ancient spa is girded and ready for the August race meeting, the climax of its season. It awaits the exacta with the composure with which it has met all the innovations, crises and changes that have dotted its history.

title: For Young Readers
description: Sidonie Matsner Gruenberg, former and longtime director of The Child Study Association, used to tell a story about one of her children who came and asked her some rather technical question about reproduction. She asked him, Why don't you ask your father? He's doctor and understands all that better than I do. The child replied, He knows too much; just tell me what you know.

title: The Papers of Robert H. Goddard
description: The history of flight, of man's conquest of the air and of planetary and outer space, may be written as a dialogue between dreamers and doubters. The myth of Daedalus and Icarus invokes an early dream of human flight, using wings bouna together with wax. The myth is a cautionary tale of the doubters, however, for the fate of Icarus, plummeting down when the wax was melted by the sun's rays, symbolizes the fate awaiting those who would defy nature by leaving the earth. The warning conveyed by the story or Icarus has the familiar ring of many statements made by eminent scientists at the end of the 19th century, explaining why a heavierthanair machine could never fly. They pontificated that even if the airplane would rise above the ground, it would fall and crash.

title: the traveler's world
description: JUST ABOUT this time every summer, one or more travel entrepreneurs, agents or promoters collapses financially, leaving several hundred wouldbe tourists stranded sans holiday, sans transportation home, sans money paid in advance and, usually, sans much hope of recovering it. The summer's biggest collapse to date involved 3,000 students who were stranded in Europe plus another 2,000 whose foreign travel plans evaporated before they had a chance to leave home. Fortunately for the 3,000 abroad, their charter airplane passage had been paid in advance and the airline arranged to shuttle them back earlier than scheduled.

title: The Role of the Budget
description: The Nixon Administration has announced that the Federal Government ran a $2.9billion budget deficit during fiscal year 1970 that ended last June 30. This was quite a turnaround from the $5.8 billion surplus it had predicted in the spring of 1969, before the last fiscal year began.

title: Hydrangeas Are Summer Bouquets
description: HYDRANGEAS display bouquets of latesummer flowers when few other shrubs or trees are in bloom. They are striking and longlasting.

title: Andretti Weighs Several Offers To Race in Grand Prix Abroad
