description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 4  The improved Cleveland Indians, again demonstrating they were very much at home in their tailored minipark, gave the Yankees a hostile welcome to night as they posted a 61 vic tory in the opener of a twogame series.

title: Commitment for a Loan Cited by Earth Resources
description: DALLAS, Aug. 4 (UPI)The Earth Resources Company said it has a firm commitment for an $8million term loan to fi nance its Nacimiento copper mine in New Mexico.

title: Witco Plans to Phase Out Operations at a Refinery
description: The Witco Chemical Corpora tion said yesterday it would phase out its operations at Franklin, Pa.

title: Tax Aid Is Planned For U.S. Troops In Cambodia Action
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4Military personnel who recently served in Cambodia would be entitled to the special tax bene fits received by service person nel in combat areas, under a proposed change in tax regula tions announced today by the Treasury Department.

title: ANACONDA SHOWS DROP IN EARNINGS
TeenAge Gangs Plague Merchants in Chinatown
description: On the quaint streets of Chinatown, under the neon fa cade but hidden by the commu nity's durable social structure, there are four teenaged gangs of ChineseAmerican youths, at tempting, without much success so far, to shake down the local merchants for protection money.

title: Jarring Opens Talks
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 4Ambassador Jarring held the first round of talks today in the new drive for a settlement in the Middle East.

title: Official Subway Critic
description: I think, says Myron Cohen, an ideal subway sys tem is one that is safe, reli able, cool in the summer and warm in the winter, quiet and not uncomfortably crowded.

title: Fulbright Calls Access to TV Vital to Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 Senator J. W. Fulbright said today that the balance in American Government would be effectively destroyed unless Congress could command auto matic access to network tele visionthe same access that the President now enjoys by informal courtesy of the broad casting industry.

title: Major League Baseball
description: National League

title: TV Use of Domestic Satellites Could Cut Distribution Cost 35%
description: The three national television networks released yesterday study reporting that they could save from 25 to 35 per cent in the cost of distributing their programs either by means of domestic satellite system or by a specialized microwave relay system on the ground. They now use the facilities of the American Telephone and Tele graph Company.

title: JUDGES DISALLOW CLAIM IN 2D RACE
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 4Native Partner, the ex perienced stakes performer owned by Ralph Wilson, waged a splendid stretch drive to win the feature event on today's Saratoga program.

title: Ratings of Foods By Quaker Oats
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4The Quaker Oats Company, using the same system employed by a nutritionist who criticized the breakfastcereal industry two weeks ago, offered its own listing today to rebut the crit ic's contentions that most of the cereals were low in nutri tional value.

title: 9 DEAD AND 29 HURT BY FRENCH TORNADO
description: BORDUAUX. France. Aug. 1 (Reuters)A tornado battered the coast of southwest France today, killing at least 9 persons and injuring 20. with 11 persons reported missing.

title: Governor Acts to Uncover Hepatitis Germs in Blood
description: ALBANY, Aug. 4Governor Rockefeller today ordered the State Department of Health to scour the country for a sub stance to uncover hepatitis germs in blood used for trans fusions.

title: Ray, Phyllis Gaspard Win World SkeetShoot Titles
description: SAVANNAH, Ga., Aug. 4 (UPI)Wayne Ray of Galves ton, Tex., outlasted a group of marksmen to win the world 26gauge skeetshooting cham pionship at the Forest City Gun Club today.

title: Upheaval in Bolivia
description: President Alfredo Ovando Candia of Bolivia seems to be at the point where he must choose between the conservative military elements that supported his rise to power and the leftistreformist forces whose rhetoric he often employs. After his Cabinet resigned yester day, General Ovando insisted that he would maintain a national leftist line.

title: The Philanthropist Staged in London With Alec McCowen
description: LONDON, Aug. 4  In the first scene of Christopher Hamp ton's The Philanthropist at the Royal Court Theater, a boy blows his brains out against the back wall. In the second we learn that the entire British cabinet has been machine gunned down in the House of Commons.

title: Israeli Planes in Action Along Suez Canal Zone
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 4 (Reuters) Israeli planes were in action throughout the morning against Egyptian military objectives along the Suez Canal, an army spokesman said.

title: RUSSIANS LINKED TO SUEZ DOGFIGHT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4Circumstantial evidence has persuaded some United States officials that Soviet pilots en gaged in aerial combat against, Israeli planes in the Suez Ca nal region last Thursday, but other officials regard the evi dence as too flimsy for such a judgment.

title: Woman Sentenced in Slaying
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., Aug. 4 (UPI)  A Long Island house wife drew a prison sentence of up to three years today for her role in the robberyslaying of a delicatessen owner in May 1969 Mrs. Opal Smith 35 years old of Bay Shore. L. T. had pleaded guilty to a charge of attempted robbery The police said she drove the getaway car in a holdup that resulted in the death of Jacob Bailin of Bay Shore.

title: Nixon, Greeting Mobutu, Lauds the Congo
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4President Nixon welcomed President Joseph D. Mobutu of the Congo to the White House today for a conversation that lasted almost two hours.

title: Cartier's Head, Mrs. McGowan Are Wed Here
description: Michael Hall Thomas, presi dent of Cartier, Inc., the jewelers, and Mrs. Jeanne Beaupre McGowan of Fort Worth were married at his apartment here on Sunday. Criminal Court Judge Milton Shalleck performed the cere mony.

title: SellHelp Sanitation Service Is Started in Bronx
description: A Selfhelp Sanitation Serv ice got under way in the South Bronx yesterday with city of ficials voicing optimism and community residents, hired as sanitation aides, complaining of a lack of equipment.

title: Rockefeller Considers Declaring Addiction Epidemic
description: Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that he would con fer with legal and medical ex perts to determine whether to declare drug addiction an epi demic.

title: New School Career Ladder
description: The new union contract covering paraprofessionals in the public school system ranks among the most significant steps ever taken in this city to overcome poverty and to build more cooperative relations between the ghetto areas and the schools.

title: Fresh Air Family in Bay State Finds Room Despite 6 Children
description: Even though Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Nogueira of Plymouth, Mass., have six children of their own, they are having two young guests this summer, in stead of one, at their ranch home overlooking Plymouth Harbor.

title: PENN CENTRAL PLANS 2WAY TRAIN RADIOS
description: In the wake of its third fire within a week, the Penn Cen tral announced yesterday that all trains using Grand Central Terminal were scheduled to have twoway radios for quick communication installed by November.

title: Brands of Conservatism
description: Democratic Presidents cus tomarily attach labels to their political and economic philoso phies. Thus, there were Wood row Wilson's New Freedom, Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal, Harry Tru man's Fair Deal, John F. Kennedy's New Frontier and Lyndon B. John son's Great Socie ty. Republican Presidents are much less given to such brand labeling. True, Theodore Roose velt, a maverick among Repub licans, named his philosophy the New Nationalism.

title: Bond Market Uncertain About Where It's Going
description: The bond market ambled along yesterday, trying to get a better idea where it is headed.

title: Teacher Linked to Queens Drugs
description: A former Queens College lecturer in biology, described by a Federal prosecutor as a major supplier of marijuana on that campus, was held in $24,000 bail yesterday.

title: Columbia PresidentElect Finds Widespread Alienation of Youth
description: LOS ANGELES. Aug. 4 (UPI) The number of alienated young people is much greater than most people believe, and a speedup of the educational system will be a prime need as their numbers grow, a Presi dential commission was told today.

title: SCHOOL PROGRAM PRAISED IN STUDY
description: An independent consulting concern has recommended ex panding the city's More Effec tive Schools program, a con troversial effort to improve the education of children from dis advantaged homes.

title: Bridge:
description: Few players are acknowl edged to be in the top flight in both rubber bridge and tournament play. One mem ber of that elite group is Jer emy Flint, an Englishman who made a great impact on this side of the Atlantic in 1966. He played with Peter Pender of San Francisco for a ninemonth period, and they finished in the top two places in the McKenney Tro phy contest, which depends on master points won in tournaments.

title: CLAY MATCH WON BY DICK STOCKTON
description: ROCHESTER, Aug. 4 (AP)Dick Stockton of Garden City, L. I., advanced to the third round of the United States clay court championship today, but Steve Turner of New York was eliminated.

title: Easy Kansas Victory
description: TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 4 (AP) Attorney General Kent Friz zell won the Republican nom ination for Governor in today's primary.

title: Bendix Unit Gets F15 Work
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 4 (UPI)The McDonnell Douglas Corpo ration today awarded a con tract for about $700,000 to the Bendix Corporation's navigation and control division, Teterboro, N.J. The contract is to provide a lead computing gyro for the gunsight of the Air Force's new F15 fighter.

title: 4 African Ministers Meet On British Arms Policy
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 4 (Agence FrancePresse)  East and Central African foreign ministers from four Common wealth states met here today for three hours to work out a common front on the pos sible resumption of arms sales to South Africa by Britain.

title: MUSKIE ATTACKS OIL SPILL RULES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 Senator Edmund S. Muskie sug gested today that proposed reg ulations on oil spills drawn by the Department of the Interior could enable Spillers to circum vent the intent of Congress and possibly escape penalties.

title: Marshall E. Turnbaugh Dead; Technician for Atomic Ships
description: QUINCY, Mass., Aug. 4 (AP) Marshall E. Turnbaugh of York Beach, Me., a pioneer Navy and civilian developer of nuclear submarine and surface ship power plants, died last night at his apartment, appar ently of a heart attack. He was 54 years old.

title: Joint Control Plan Reported for U.S. Bases in Japan
description: TOKYO, Aug. 4Within the next several weeks, Japan will start sharing in the control of many of the military bases the United States operates in the country, according to the min ister in charge of Japanese de fense.

title: Ford Developing Ignition To Promote Use of Belts
description: DETROIT, Aug. 4The Ford Motor Company said today that it was developing an ignition system connected to its auto lap belts that would prevent a car from starting unless the belts, a safety device, were fastened.

title: Roundup: Division Race Is In the Cards
description: At least two managers in the National League's East ern Division feel the St. Louis Cardinals still can win the title in the National League's Eastern Division.

title: Mr. Nixon's Loose Talk
description: Speaking extemporaneously on important issues can be a dangerous practice for any President, as President Nixon proved Monday with his assertion that one the defendants in the Sharon Tate murder case was guilty, directly or indirectly, of eight murders without reason.

title: Film Fete Here Lists Its First 10 Features
3 SHOT IN BOWERY IN STREET BATTLE
description: As Bowery residents scat tered out of the line of gun fire, a battle between a nar cotics detective and a suspected drug dealer ended with both men shot and a by stander nicked in the leg by a bullet yesterday afternoon.

title: S.E.C. Hearings Slated
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today it will hold hearings on charges that Financial Programs, Inc., of Denver and its former presi dent, Thomas J. Herbert, made misleading statements and vio lated the antimanipulative sec tions of the securities laws from 1961 through 1968. The Denver firm is principal underwriter and advisor for the Financial Industrial Income Fund, the Fi nancial Industrial Fund, and the Financial Dynamics Fund.

title: Baby Dies, Stepfather Held
description: A 28yearold Brooklyn man was charged last night with fa tally beating his 16monthold stepson, Romel O'Neil, who died in Cumberland Hospital. The police said the death had resulted from a beating by his stepfather, George Lee, 28, of 47 Van Buren Street.

title: U.S. Aide Concedes SST Could Affect Stratosphere
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4The director of the supersonic. transport program conceded today that there were two major uncertainties about the potential atmospheric effects of supersonic airliner opera tions.

title: Mrs. Chadsey Wins FirstRound Match On Bedford Links
description: BEDFORD, N. Y., Aug. 4Mrs. Carl T. Chadsey Jr. of Round Hill, medalist, and Mrs. Thomas J. Hory of Winged Foot, the defending champion, led the way through the first round today in the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association championship tour nament at Bedford Golf & Ten nis Club.

title: Symington Renominated
description: ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 4 (AP) Senator Stuart Symington easily defeated four political unknowns in the Democratic primary today to win renomi nation for a fourth term, and State Attorney General John C. Danforth captured the Repub lican senatorial spot.

title: Breakfast Cereal Industry Tells Senators Nutrition Critic Erred
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4The, breakfast cereal industry de fended itself today against charges that twothirds of its products are nutritionally de ficient.

title: Train Kills Jersey Man
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., Aug. 4 (UPI)  A sevencar commuter train slammed into a compact car at a grade crossing here at 7:55 A.M. today, killing the 21yearold driver and hurling the auto 75 feet into a utility pole. The police said the driver, Randy Buirkle of Hackensack, had a wife and infant child. None of the 200 passengers on the train were reported injured.

title: CROSBY T. SMITH
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 4Crosby T. Smith who retired as vice president of the First National City Bank in 1965 died today at the Yale New Haven Hospital. He was 64 years old, and lived on West (Road in New Canaan.

title: STARK REPORTED READY TO RESIGN
description: Borough President Abe Stark of Brooklyn, the senior mem ber of the Board of Estimate, is expected to resign within the next month because of failing health.

title: MARINE TAKES LEAD IN PISTOL SHOOTING
description: CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 4 (UPI)Francis Higginson, a warrant officer in the Marines, scored 887 out of 900 points today, won the centerfire title and moved into first place in the national pistol champion ships with a twoday total of 1,775 points.

title: QUOTA BILL GIVES NIXON WIDE POWER
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) Sweeping authority for Pres ident Nixon to suspend in the national interest any quotas set up by the pending trade bill has won preliminary committee agreement, informed persons said today.

title: JESSE S. MOORE
description: Jesse S. Moore, who ran the shopathome service di vision at Gimbel's, died yes terday at his home in Scars dale. He was 73 years old.

title: Political Footwork and Martial Law Bolstering Premier in Turkey
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 4Astute political footwork and martial law seem to have stabilized, at least for the mo ment, the position of Premier Suleyman Demirel.

title: MAYNARD BARNES, DIPLOMAT, 72, DIES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4Maynard B. Barnes, a former Foreign Service officer, died at his home in Georgetown, Sun day. He was 72 years old.

title: T.W.A. Appoints Official
description: The appointment of Daniel P. Reid as vice president sales and services of Trans World Air lines was announced yesterday. Mr. Reid, who has been vice president of the New York re gion, has been with T.W.A. since 1946.

title: Senate Passes Money Bill $541 Million Over Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4The Senate approved today an appropriation bill $541million higher than President Nixon's budget request. There were indications that Mr. Nixon would not veto the measure despite earlier hints that he might. The bill authorized total spending of $18billion for miscellaneous Federal agen cies, including the Veterans Administration and the Na tional Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: Qaddafi Back in Libya After Failure To End Rift Between U.A.R. and Iraq
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Aug. 5 Premier Muammar elQaddafi returned tonight from a futile effort to heal the breach be tween Iraq and the United Arab Republic over the United States plan for a settlement with Israel. The Libyan Revolu tionary Command Council then denounced what it termed the slanderous campaign against President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic,) the leader of the Arab nation.

title: Frank's Restaurant In Central Harlem Is Offered for Sale
description: Frank's Restauranta gather ing place for politicians, city officials, businessmen and visi tors to Harlemis for sale.

title: Warren Named to Golf Post
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 4 (UPI)Paul Warren of Cleveland was named today to direct the 1971 Greater Milwaukee open golf tournament. Warren is cur rently director of the Florida Citrus, the Avco, Doral, Jack sonyille, Tallahassee, Atlanta and Philadelphia tournaments.

title: COUNCIL PLANNING A SUBWEY INQUIRY
description: Citing recent accidents in which three subway riders died, the Democratic majority leadership of the City Council announced plans yesterday for a special investigation of sub way safety.

title: French Forces May Get HBombs by 1972
description: PARIS, Aug. 4Qualified mil itary sources predicted today that France's nuclear production team would be able to provide hydrogen bombs for French forces by 1972, or at least three years earlier than official Gov ernment forecasts have indicat ed.

title: Executive Changes
description: Daniel P. Reid has been named vice president, sales and service, of Trans World Airlines, replac ing Thomas F. Huntington, who resigned.

title: Truck Transmission Plant Is Planned by Sundstrand
description: ROCKFORD, Ill., Aug. 4 (AP) The Sundstrand Corporation announced today it planned to enter the automatic truck transmission field and said it would build a manufacturing plant in Ames, Iowa, for a new hydromechanical unit.

title: Victim Says He Took Burglary Suspect To Station in Vain
description: A Brooklyn burglary victim said yesterday that he had caught a suspect, taken him by the arm to a police station and they had been told by a detec tive that the suspect could not be arrested because this is the wrong precinct.

title: Suit Seeks to Curb Fire Ant Pesticide In 9 Southern States
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5The pesky fire ant, which ranges over nine Southern states, may be a nuisance but the insecti cide used to curb it poses public health hazard, an en vironmental group charged to day.

title: Stanwick Gets Contract
description: ARLINGTON, Va., Aug. 5 (UPI)  The Stanwick Corpora tion said today it had obtained a $1.6million Navy contract for data management services.

title: Saigon General Missing
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 5 (AP)Brig. Gen. Nguyen Van Thien, commander of Government military zone en compassing Quangnam Province and Danang, has been reported missing on a flight from Da nang to Saigon. The South Vietnamese Air Force jet he was in is believed to have crashed yesterday.

title: A Suit by 15 States Bids Auto Makers Cut Pollution Fast
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI)  Fifteen states filed suit in the Supreme Court today to force the four major automo bile manufacturers to equip cars with better pollution con trol equipment and to provide pollutionfree engines at the earliest feasible date.

title: 650 Treated for Tokyo Smog
description: TOKYO, Aug. 5 (Reuters)A chemical smog blanketed Tokyo for eight hours today and health officials reported that more than 650 persons had been treated at hospitals for eye and throat irritations. The smog struck Tokyo for five consecu tive days from July 23 to 27.

title: JULY REDEMPTIONS OF SAVINGS BONDS UP
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI) For the 20th consecutive month, more people redeemed United States Savings Bonds than purchased them, according to Treasury Department figures published today.

title: Vigorous F.D.A. Chief Charles Cornell Edwards
description: The word among staff mem bers of the Food and Drug Administration in Washing ton these days is: There's a surgeon in charge, and when he's ready to operate you had better be ready too.

title: Executive Changes
description: Vincent L. Gregory has been elected president and chief executive officer of the Rohm & Haas Company. He succeeds F. Otto Haas, who has been named chairman of the board. Dr. Haas re places Ralph Connor, who becomes chairman of the executive committee.

title: Roundup: Pirates'
description: Luke Walker hasn't had any trouble getting to the ball park at the right time recently, and sometimes that means trouble for the oppos ing team.

title: F.C.C. STUDY URGED OF TV CEREAL ADS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5Dr. Jean Mayer, the nutritionist, called on the Federal Govern ment today to monitor televi sion advertising directed at children when it pertains to their health and nutrition.

title: 20 SUE TO ASSURE SUBWAYS SAFETY
description: A group of subway workers sued the Metropolitan Transpor tation Authority yesterday in behalf of the public and them selves to prevent the use of defective and dangerous equipment that the workers said would cause additional ser ious subway accidents.

title: TV Heads to Consider More Time for Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5The presidents of the three com mercial television networks said today they would consider new, voluntary means of bal ancing their coverage of Con gress and the President  pos sibly including grants of prime evening time in which Congress could pick its spokesmen, issues and format.

title: N.F.L. Clears Wheelwright of Impropriety
description: Ernie Wheelwright, the New Orleans Saints running back who had been under investi gation by the, National Football League because of alleged un desirable clientele in his New Orleans nightclub, was exon erated of wrongdoing yesterday by Commissioner Pete Rozelle.

title: A.F.L.C.I.O. to Expand Drive for Bargaining Rights for Farm Workers
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 5Plans for an expanded drive to win col lective bargaining rights for farm workers throughout the nation were jointly announced., today by the American Federa tion of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations and by the United Farm Workers Or ganizing Committee.

title: Enzyme Is Found Helpful in Studying Body's Molecules
description: Research designed to deter mine what chemical changes within the body lead to the wasting effects of weightless ness has disclosed an enzyme that can he used to decipher some of the body's key mole cules.

title: Chinese Broadcasts Challenge And Defend Role of the Army
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 5The dominant role of the army in the political and administrative life of Communist China has been obliquely questioned in Shanghai, a radical stronghold, and strongly defended in Hu peh and Honan, regions repre sentative of conservative mili tary influence.

title: 3 ARMED MEN ROB REGENCY'S SAFE
description: While 500 guests slept early yesterday morning three armed men spent more than an hour rubbing 17 strongboxes and small safe in the lobby of the Regency Hotel.

title: John F. Ryan Jr. Will Marry Katharine F. Bell, a Teacher
description: Mrs. Rheinfrank Bell of New York and Frank Suy dam Bell of Perrysburg, Ohio, and Palm Beach, Fla., have made known the en gagement of their (laughter, Miss Katharine Fuller Bell, to John Francis Ryan Jr.. son of Mr. and Mrs. Ryan of Brightwaters. L. I.

title: HOUSE APPROVES LIMIT OF $55,000 ON FARM SUBSIDY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5The House voted today to limit subsidy payments to any one farm to $55,000 a year for each of three cropswheat, cotton and feed grains.

title: CONCERN ON SMUT HELD UNFOUNDED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) Fears that erotic films, books and magasines are aggravating sex crimes and corrupting the morals of youth are unfounded, a draft report of the President's Commission on Pornography lays.

title: PEP PILL MAKERS ACCUSED BY F.D.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5The Commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration accused the drug industry today of shirking its responsibilities by not helping to prevent abuse of amphetamines.

title: 3 SENATE RIVALS OPEN TO DEBATES
description: The three major candidates for United States Senator from this state declared yesterday their willingness to meet each other in a series of debates throughout the election cam paign.

title: BOND ISSUE SOLD AT REDUCED YIELD
description: Investment bankers are again experimenting with lower yields on high grade bonds. Their efforts yesterday were highly successful with tax exempt bonds and not so suc cessful with corporate bonds.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: RANDOLPH E. BROWN
description: Randolph E. Brown, who re tired in 1959 as first vice presi dent and director of the Ameri can Surety Company of New York, later the Transamerica Corporation, died Sunday in South Egremnont, Mass. He was 72 years old and also lived in Tenafly, N. J.

title: Bankers Trust Plans Link
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation plans to acquire the Industrial Bank of Bing hamton, N.Y., for $3.3million of its stock in an agreement announced yesterday.

title: I.O.S. TO RECEIVE CORNFELD VIEWS
description: GENEVA, Aug. 5 (UPI)Ber nard Cornfeld, founder of In vestors Overseas Services, was told today he could meet with its board of directors tomor row to outline his plan for the company's recovery.

title: Officer at Induction Center Discounts Defective Scale
description: A spokesman at the Armed Forces Induction Center at 39 Whitehall Street stressed yes terday that it was unlikely that anyone had been inducted into service because of an inac curate weighing scale.

title: FM ROCK DIVISION CREATED BY A.B.C.
description: The American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., created a sep arate division yesterday to de velop frequencymodulation ra dio as a medium stressing pro gressive ressive rock music and offer ing talkin shows for those in terested in today's modern life style.

title: Levitt Urges City to Maintain Units for Homeless
description: State ControllerArthur Levitt recommended yesterday that the city consider maintaining apartments for temporarily housing welfare clients who have been made homeless by fires and other disasters. He said the city could save sub stantial sums by doing so in stead of putting them up in hotels.

title: Music: Schubert's Trout
description: Lincoln Center's MidSum mer Serenades have other fish to fry than Mozart this summer, as the Philharmonic Hall series carefully suggests by its subtitle, A Mostly Mo zart Festival. There was, for instance, Schubert's Trout on Tuesday night, presented by the New York Chamber Soloists both in the version for voice and piano and in transmutation as the varia tions movement of the Quin tet in A for Violin, Viola, Cello, DoubleBass and Piano.

title: Suburbs Cool to New Con Edison Plants
description: Suggestions by city officials that Consolidated Edison build plants outside the city to pro vide more power drew strong opposition yesterday from the suburbs.

title: Ford Planning Rise Of 5% in'71 Prices; Warranty Curtailed
description: DETROIT, Aug. 5  The Ford Motor Company an nounced today that it was tentatively raising 1971 car and truck prices by more than 5 per cent. This will be the sharpest price increase in recent years, if it holds.

title: 2 BRITISH CONCERNS DROP MERGER PLANS
description: LONDON, Aug. 5  Hill, Samuel & Co., the merchant bankers, and the Metropolitan Estate and Property Corpora tion, Britain's second largest real estate company, have dropped plans for a $480mil lion merger.

title: Ewbank Says He Will Not Fine Star Until He Hears Joe's Story
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 5Although Joe Namath, the New York Jets star quarterback, was not in camp for the third, straight day of official work outs, neither Weeb Ewbank, the team's coach, nor Gerry Philbin, one of his teammates, appeared to be uptight about his absence:

title: ... And Los Alamos, a Suburb Without a City, Is Affluent, WellRead, Isolated and Aging
description: LOS ALAMOS, N. M., Aug. 5The fences are down now around the secret atomic city gone for 13 yearsand the old guardhouse on the road from Santa Fe has been turned into a restaurant.

title: Illustrated Listing of U. S. Prints Issued by the Library of Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4A 568page catalogue of Amer icanmade prints in the Li brary of Congress collection was published this week by the Johns Hopkins Press for the library.

title: P. '
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 5 (AP)The Procter & Gamble Com pany announced plans today to build a household paper prod ucts converting plant at Mo desto, Calif.

title: Marketplace:
description: The last time we talked to Super Boar he was wor ried that the nation might he headed for another 1929. That was in midApril when the DowJones industrial av erage had already been bat tered down to 772.

title: Patelin Wins Schuy lerville at Saratoga
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 5  Patelin, a finelook ing daughter of Cornish Prince, performed as well as she looked in the 530,700 Schuyler ville today. George D. Wide ner's Kentuckybred made her way between rivals in the stretch to win the sixfurlong sprint for 2yearold fillies by 3 lengths.

title: REDUCED VOTING AGE IS SET BY 21 STATES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) Fewer than half of the 48 states that do not allow 18yearolds to vote have indicated that they will comply with the lower voting age in the new Federal Voting Rights Act, At torney General John N. Mitchell said today.

title: Stockton Advances In Amateur Tennis By Defeating Ward
description: ROCHESTER, N. Y., Aug. 5 (AP)All the seeded singles players survived today's round of the United States amateur clay courts tennis champion ship despite a few close calls.

title: Uruguayan Rebels Firm in Demanding Prisoners'
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 5 (Reuters)Leftwing guerrillas said today that they would accept nothing less than the release of all political pri soners before they granted free dom to a kidnapped American official and a Brazilian diplo mat.

title: 30 Reported Dead in Crash Of Pakistan Airline Plane
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Thursday, Aug. 6 (Reuters)A Fokker Friendship aircraft of Pakistan International Airlines crashed soon after takeoff to day, killing 30 people.

title: FAIRCHILD CAMERA CUTTING BACK COSTS
description: The Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation an nounced yesterday costreduc ticn measures including execu tive salary cuts and a 9 per cent reduction in the work force.

title: Bus Company in Fatal Crash Shows Defects in U.S. Study
description: BAYONNE, N..J., Aug. (AP)A team of United States Transportation Department in vestigators has found safety de fects in 10 of the 15 buses owned by the company that provided the bus that crashed in Allentown, Pa., killing seven children.

title: TRUST SUIT IS FILED AGAINST 3 CONCERNS
description: The National Distillers and Chemical Corporation said yes terday it had filed an antitrust suit seeking more than $150 million in damages against two West German companies and one American corporation.

title: A JOINT VENTURE TO MANAGE ASSETS
description: A new and apparently unique joint venture in the asset man agement field was announced yesterday by Marine Midland Banks, Inc., and the Dreyfus Corporation, a pioneer in the mutual fund industry.

title: TWORUN HOMERS MARK 73 VICTORY
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 5Two run homers by Thurman Mun son and Bobby Murcer off Sam McDowell in the fifth inning led the New York Yankees to a 73 victory tonight over the Cleveland Indians.

title: Church in Rhodesia Appears to Modify Segregation Stand
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Aug. 5 (Agence FrancePresse) The Roman Catholic Church in Rho desia has issued a pamphlet in dicating that it is considering softening its attitude toward the Land Tenure Act, which reg ulates racial segregation.

title: Clarke Finishes Sixth in Final 10,000Meter Race Before His Retirement
description: OSLO, Aug. 5 (AP)Ron Clarke of Australia finished sixth in the 10,000meter race at the Bislet meet tonight, but the world recordholder was given a warm and sentimental farewell by 13.500 spectators.

title: Multiple Blunder on Spain
description: The Nixon Administration will compound old errors and commit ominous new ones by signing today nontreaty form the socalled Agreement of Friendship and Cooperation Between the United States and Spain. It is obvious in the first place that the signing was advanced because of growing opposition on Capitol Hill to the form and content of the agreement.

title: Leftist Japanese Historian Challenges Regime's Power to Censor Textbooks
description: TOKYO, Aug. 5  A left leaning historian is locked in protracted legal battle with Japan's Education Ministry over whether it has the right to dis approve the contents of high school textbooks.

title: TEXAS MAYOR ACTS IN WAKE OF STORM
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Aug. 5 (UPI)The Mayor of Corpus Christi, the largest city bat tered by Hurricane Celia, as sumed emergency police pow ers today to stop profiteering and get the devastated city back on its feet.

title: Auto Racer Dies of Injuries
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 5 (AP)Jerry Titus, 41yearold auto racing driver from Tarzana, Calif., died today at St. Joseph's Hospital of injuries suffered at Elkhart Lake two weeks ago. Titus suffered head injuries when his Pontiac Firebird crashed into a bridge abutment during qualifying for a Trans American race on July 18.

title: In The Nation: Putting Congress on the Tube
description: Any number of objections can and will be raised to Senator J. W. Fulbright's demand that Congress get automatic access to network television, just as the President does. But this demand nevertheless recognizes two fundamental facts of polit ical life today.

title: West Pointer Seeks Discharge As a Conscientious Objector
description: A West Point senior has asked the Army for a discharge as a conscientious objector, the first such request to have been made by a student at the United States Military Academy.

title: Burlington Northern's Net
description: Burlington Northern, Inc., which was formed in March by the railroad merger of the Great Northern and Northern. Pacific with the Chicago, Bur lington & Quincy, announced yesterday a consolidated net income of $4,464,000, or 33 cents a share, for the quarter ended June 30. In the year earlier period on a pro forma basis, the net income was $9, 560,000, or 74 cents a share.

title: New Books
description: Middle East Oil: A Study in Poli tical and Economic Controversy, by George W. Stocking (Van derbilt University, $15).

title: Last Chance for Mideast Peace
description: Israel's formal acceptance of United States peace proposals and Premier Golda Meir's concurrent com ments in the Knesset add momentum to what must become an irreversible movement toward settlement of the ArabIsraeli conflict.

title: Goldberg Links Subway Trouble To Neglect by Gov. Rockefeller
description: Arthur J. Goldberg charged yesterday that the city subway system has the worst accident record of any major system in the world. He blamed Gov ernor Rockefeller for neglect of masstransit facilities.

title: Tommy Bob Wins by Neck
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 5 (AP) Earle K. Rosen's Tommy Bob outlasted Flame Burgos by a neck to win the first running of the $10.$00 Valiant Man Stakes at Arlington Park to day. In the 5??furlong race for ??noisbred 2yearolds, Tommy Bob was timed in 1:06 3/5 and returned $9.60.

title: RETAIL CHAINS CITE RISE IN JULY SALES
description: Leading retail chains re ported yesterday increased sales in July over the like yearearlier month.

title: NIXON UNIT MEMBER HAS UNIT OF HIS OWN
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 5 (UPI) The youngest member of the Presidential Commission on Student Unrest has a com mission of his own to keep the investigation honest.

title: Plant Discharging Mercury Will Be Shut Down in Maine
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI) The Government won its first victory against meremy pollu tion today when the Oxford Paper Company division of the Ethyl Corporation agreed to close a plant on the Androscog gin River at Rumford, Me.

title: Renewal Plan Disclosed
description: NEWARK, Aug. 5  The Newark Housing Council, a community organization creat ed two years ago to oversee the renewal and rehabilitation of the city's strifetorn and de cayed Central Ward, made pub lic today a comprehensive de velopment plan for the first phase of the task.

title: Buffalo G.I. Is Killed in War
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI) The Defense Department re ported today that Pfc. Robert J. Brown Jr. of Buffalo has been killed in the war in South east Asia.

title: SickOut  by Hospital Guards
description: BOSTON, Aug. 5 (AP)Func tions of the security force at City Hospital were taken over today by administrative per sonnel because most guards called in sick. Hospital officials said the sickout apparently was in reaction to the suspen sion Monday of two guards involved in a disturbance in side the hospital July 2 during which they arrested a brother and sister on charges of as sault and battery, trespass and disturbing the peace.

title: Foreman Camp Vague on Plans For Quarry Bout Here Oct. 23
description: George Foreman's manager Was vague yesterday about planned Oct. 23 bout between his unbeaten 21yearold heavy weight and Jerry Quarry at Madison Square Garden.

title: Basset Judge in Worldwide Demand
description: Mrs. Lynwood (Peg) Wal ton of Mount Holly, N. J., is the bench show chairman of the largest oneday outdoor show in the EastTrenton. Six years ago, when she be came chairman, Trenton had an entry of 2,060. Last May, it had 3.615.

title: 300 Stoning Autos At Harvard Square Routed by Tear Gas
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. Aug 5; (AP)  About 300 dissidents stoned automobiles and buses tonight, made targets of fire fighters and erected a barricade near Harvard Square, but were driven off by police using tear gas.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Nixon Asks Paperwork Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) President Nixon issued memorandum today that fixed twin goals of saving the public five million manhours a year in filling out Federal reports and saving $200million in Federal spending for such pur poses.

title: CLEAN AIR GROUP OPPOSES CON ED
description: Citizens for Clean Air, a civic group, and former Bronx Bor ough President Herman Badillo urged Mayor Lindsay yesterday to block the controversial new Consolidated Edison electric power project for Astoria, Queens, as a likely air polluter.

title: STOCKS RETREAT AS TRADING EBBS
description: The stock market was be calmed in the midsummer dol drums yesterday.

title: NEW HAVEN JUDGE RELEASES PANTHER
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 5 Frances Carter, the 21yearold secretary of the local Black Panther chapter, was set free today after a 15month legal battle for bail and against contempt order.

title: Adverse Operations Cut Tenneco's Net
description: Tenneco, Inc., the conglom erate based in Houston, achieved record revenues in this year's second quarter and first half, but rising operating costs, strikes and poor results in two divisions reduced earnings by more than 20 per cent.

title: 2 Youths Held in Fatal Knifing Of Boy Tied to Chinatown Gang
description: Two 17yearold youths were held last night in the slaying of a 14yearold earlier this week that the police said had resulted from knife fights be tween members of two Chinese youth gangs.

title: Paris Talks: A New Phase Opens
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5The United States will field its fourth negotiating team in two years at the Paris talks with North Vietnam tomorrow, with only slender hope that it can break the deadlock in the foreseeable future.

title: Westchester Tennis Team Keeps Junior Wightman Cup
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Aug.  Westchester retained the Eastern Lawn Tennis Associa tion's Junior Wightman Cup to day by defeating New jersey, 6 matches to 3, at Bronxville Field Club in the final round of the annual girls triangular comnetition.

title: U. S. TO SIGN PACT WITH SPAIN TODAY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug, 5The State Department announced today that the United States and Spain would sign a new agreement tomorrow providing for continuing American use of military bases in Spain.

title: LUCIEN LAMOUREUX
description: CLERMONT FERRAND, France, Aug. 5 (AP)Lucien Lamoureux, who was Finance Minister when France fell to the Germans in 1940, died today after a heart attack at his home in the village of CreuzierleVieux. He was 82 years old.

title: REV. CYRIL R. CARRIE
description: JERSEY CITY, Aug. 5The Rev. Cyril R. Carrier, rector emeritus of St. John's Episcopal Church, died Monday. He was 82 years old and resided at 2600 Kennedy Boulevard. Mr. Carrie retired in 1960 after 30 years as rector of St. John's.

title: Article 1  No Title
Senate Unit Rejects Job Training Plans Proposed by Nixon
Books of The Times
description: Yesterday's column, under my byline, began to chart the agony of a male ego confronting Kate MiIlett's Sexual Politics (Doubleday, $7.95), an uncommonly force ful and exquisitely reasoned analysis of how man lords it over woman, puts her down, blots out her sexuality, dehumanizes and oppresses her, and all the while dis astrously negates half his own being (and hers) on the illreasoned grounds that sex is bipolar, that maleness equals mascu linity exclusively and can brook no femi ninity in its nature.

title: PERCY W. BIDWELL, TRADE ADVOCATE
description: Dr. Percy Wells Bidwell, for mer director of studies of the Council on Foreign Relations and author of books on foreign trade policy, died Tuesday at his home, 3030 Park Avenue, Bridgeport, Conn. He was 82 years old and formerly lived in Hartsdale, N. Y.

title: Freeloader, 14, Flies Sydney to Paris
description: PARIS, Aug. 5  A 14yearold schoolboy flew 12,000 miles first class from Sydney to Paris last weekend with only 10 cents in his pocket. He said today that he had got on the jetliner by running through customs after a family and shouting: Papa! Papa! Wait for me!

title: Miss Eileen Gallagher Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Theodore J. Gallagher of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eileen Patrice Gallagher, to John Carver Vining Jr., son of Mrs. John C. Vining of Philadel phia and Cannes. France and the late Mr. Vining. A wed ding in December is planned.

title: G.M. Tests Engines
description: DETROIT, Aug. 5 (AP)The General Motors Corporation said today it has bought rotary engines from abroad and in this country for several years strictly for testing in search of a power source with less air pollution than the conventional internalcombustion engine.

title: Lindsays Give Lawn Party for Wounded Veterans
description: Mayor and Mrs. Lindsay were hosts to 160 wounded Vietnam veterans yesterday at a lawn party at Gracie Mansion the first reception Mr. Lind say has given Vietnam veterans in his four and one half years as Mayor.

title: Bank Merger Is Approved
description: The New York State Banking Board approved yesterday plan to merge the Millerton Na tional Bank into the National Bank of Westchester, an af filiate of Lincoln First Banks, Inc.

title: Cambodian Says Only Aid From U.S. Will Bar Defeat
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Aug. 5One of Premier Lon Nol's closest advisers said today that the Cambodian Government could last only six months more without important mili tary and economic aid, princi pally from the United States.

title: CHARLES J. FREEMAN, RETIRED FIRE CHIEF
description: Former Deputy Chief Charles J. Freeman, who had been pres ident of the Uniformed Fire Officers Association, died yes terday in St. Luke's Hospital of lung cancer. He was 60 years old and lived at 1635 Plymouth Avenue, the Bronx.

title: American Electric Power Orders Three Generators
description: The American Electric Power System announced yesterday that it had placed what it de scribed as the largest single order for the fabrication and erection of structural steel in history.

title: Pamela Hoes To Be Bride
description: Mrs. Bertram J. L. Ains worth of Fairfield, Conn., and Dr. John Spotswood Hoes of Cooperstown and Rome, N.Y., have made known here the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Pamela Wiggins Hoes, to Peter James Cohen. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Perry Cohen of Highland Park. III.

title: Archives of American Art Expanding
description: When the Archives of American Art started in 1954 with the aim of documenting United States art and its his tory, it scraped along with little more than a tiny office in Detroit and a collection of artists autograph letters.

title: Laotians See Some Basis Of Hope of Limited Truce
description: VIENTIANE. Laos. Aug. 5 Optimism that a limited truce may be reached between the neutralist Government and the Communistled forces is greater here now than it has been in recent months.

title: Inspectors Study Manners
description: TRENTON, Aug. 5 (UPI) About 750 New Jersey motor vehicle examiners will take a fourhour course during the next two weeks to help them improve their manners toward drivers getting their cars in spected. Ronald M. Heymann, Motor Vehicles Division Direc tor, said Eastern Air Lines would run the school, estab lished after he had received numerous complaints from drivers about a lack of courtesy shown by the examiners.

title: U.S. Again Bars Troops To Save Lon Nol Regime
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5Ad ministration sources reiterated today that the United States would not.use American ground troops in Cambodia to save the antiCommunist regime of Pre mier Lon Not and would not raise the level of the war there.

title: Tanqaeray Is Awarded Trademark on Bottle
description: Charles Tanqueray & Co., Ltd.. of London, the producer of Tanqueray Gin, has been granted use of its bottle as a trademark by the United States Patent Office. The bot tle is a replica of an oldtime London fireplug in dark green with a bright red seal containing the letter T in scrint.

title: TIMES OF LONDON GETS FISCAL HELP
Syracuse Bishop Resigns
description: ROME, Aug. 5 (UPI)Pope Paul VI has accepted the resig nation of Bishop Walter A. Foery, 80 years old, of Syra cuse, N. Y., and has named him Titular Bishop of Miseno, Italy. The Vatican announced yes terday that Bishop Foery had requested retirement because of his age. Coadjutor Bishop David F. Cunningham, 69, who has been his assistant for 20 years, has automatic right of succession to the diocese which comprises Broome, Che nango, Cortland, Madison, Oneida, Onondago and Oswego Counties.

title: Bus Company in Albany Plans to End Operations
description: ALBANY, Aug. 5The major bus company in the Albany Troy area is planning to dis continue operations.

title: NEVILLE BLOND DIES; BRITISH TEXTILE MAN
description: LONDON, Aug. 5  Neville Blond, a textile industrialist who was patron of the Royal Court Theater, died here yester day at the age of 74.

title: U.S. PROCESSING ORCHESTRA GIFTS
description: The bill under which the Fed eral Government more than doubled last year's appropria tion for the National Endow ment for the Arts has begun producing its first major fruit. Staff members of the endow ment, which has been given $17.59million to spread around the nation's arts during the next year, were at work yes terday on a $1.68million grant to 34 symphony orchestras, de tails of which will be an nounced in a few days, accord ing to an endowment spokes man. Grants to groups and individuals in other areas of the arts will be disclosed later.

title: Hartack Rides Locust Hill Colt To 3Length Monmouth Victory
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 5 Resembling a $125aweek exercise boy, Bill Hartack, the $100,000ayear jockey, gal loped Tyrant an eighth of a mile at Monmouth Park today.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To the Editor: The recent decision of the U.S. Army to dispose of lethal nerve gases (including GB) in the Atlantic raises some alarm ing questions, none of which have as yet been asked by Congress.

title: Nevada Prison Uprising
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., Aug 5 (UPI)  Warden Carl Hocker fired three tear gas shells into a recreation room at the Ne vada State Prison today to put down an uprising by 16 black convicts who earlier had beaten three white inmates. The 16 were taken into custody and placed in solitary confinement. Mr. Hocker said he surmised the attack by Negro inmates was in retaliation for the stab bing of a black prisoner Mon day by a white convict.

title: PROBLEMS CITED BY QUARTERBACK
description: Prodded into discussing his indecision regarding his foot ball future, Joe Namath an swered criticism last night from Al Atkinson and Gerry Philbin, two of his teammates, and ex plained his absence from the New York Jets training camp.

title: JUDGE RESTORES PENNSY DEPOSITS
description: Federal Judge John P. Fullam ordered yesterday nine banks to restore S4.5million of de posits of the Penn Central Transportation Company, which the banks had taken to offset loans and other debts owed them by the railroad.

title: CANADIAN RESERVES SET RECORD IN JULY
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 5 (Canadian Press)Canadian foreign ex change reserves rose $110.6 million during July to reach an unprecedented $4.44billion at the end of the month, the Finance Department reported today.

title: Kresge Is Pushing Aggressive Expansion Program
description: The S. S. Kresge Company, Detroit, which transformed it !self in the last eight years from just another varietystore com pany into one that also includes the country's largest discount store chain, is continuing to pursue the retail industry's most aggressive expansion program.

title: Mrs. Romney Scores Narrow Victory
description: DETROIT, Aug. 5  Mrs. George Romney won a narrow victory in yesterday's Michigan Primary election and will be the Republican candidate for the United States Senate seat held by the Democratic incum bent. Philip A. Hart.

title: Mrs. Meir Plans Note For Nixon
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 5  Pre mier Golda Meir is planning to send a letter to President Nix on underlining the reliance that Israel places on the President's military and political assur ances as preparations are made for a ceasefire and peace talks.

title: High Unemployment Is Giving Bristol, Conn., an Extra Inflationary Pinch
description: BRISTOL. Conn., Aug. 5This city of 57.000. land scaped by the Industrial Revolution into gray chim neys and redbricked fac tories is caught in the slack of the nation's economy.

title: 2 SENATORS CLASH ON EXPANDING ABM
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, told the Senate today that the United States must expand the Safeguard antiballistic mis sile system to counter an alarming increase in the So viet strategic threat.

title: Sports of The Times
description: On the floor of the lobby of Madison Square Garden a man jerked and twisted and moaned while guards argued whether he should he carted off in a wheelchair or stretcher. Policemen formed a circle and pushed passersby away. C'mon, keep moving, one said, it's just a fit. and the crowd streaming out of the arena shrugged and moved on. They had already seen their accident.

title: Cunard Names Former T.W. A. Aide
description: The appointment of Richard B. Patton as president of Cu nard Line North America was announced yesterday. Mr. Patton comes from Trans World Airlines, where he had been vice president in charge of passenger sales and services. He succeeds C. N. (Nick) Anderson, who recently was named manag ing director of Cunard's shipbrokerage subsidiary, H. E. Moss & Co., Ltd., of London.

title: Klemperer to Be Immigrant
description: JERUSALEM, Israel. Aug. (Reuters)Dr. Otto Klemperer, the 85yearold conductor, will become an Israeli immigrant. tonight at his special request. the Israeli radio reported. Dr. Kelmperer will receive his im migrant's certificate after a performance here. The conduc tor, a West German national, lives in Switzerland.

description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 5 (UPI) The Hughes Aircraft Company said today it had obtained two Navy contracts totaling $34.3 million for engineering work on shipboard weapons and missile systems.

title: One Painting But It Rules the Room
description: STAMFORD, Conn.  Ra nan Lurie has no intention of becoming an interior dec orator. On the other hand, he wonders if there won't be problems for buyers of his unusual paintings it he doesn't.

The presentation was made by Adrian Levy, as sociate commissioner for voca tional rehabilitation in the State Education Department. and John A. Baldwin, director Social Services Commission for the Blind and Visually Handi capped. They represented the United States Department of Health. Education and Welfare.

The bill would au thorize an area of 71,068 acres along Lake Michigan. The Senate has taken no action on the proposal in this Congress but twice in prior years has passed similar bills.

title: Private Guards Patrol the East Side

title: TENNESSEE HOLDS PRIMARIES TODAY
description: NASHVILLE, Aug. 5Ten nessee voters, possibly a million of them, will select tomorrow their Democratic and Republi can nominees for Governor, United States Senator and host of other offices.

title: Stillwell Wins Title Shoot
description: SAVANNAH, Ga., Aug. 5 (AP)  Harry Stillwell of Oreland, Pa., broke 160 straight birds today to win a 12way shoot off for the world's 20gauge skeet shooting championship. Stillwell won when Dr. Archie Coffee of Charlotte. N. C., missed his 60th bird in the shootoff. Ann Yancey of Gas tonia, N. C., captured the women's division with 100 straight.

Now that three passen gers have been killed in a rash of recent subway acci dents scores injured and thousands inconvenienced, the Council will roll out its investigative powers and begin an overdue inquiry.

title: Personal Finance
description: The variableinterestrate mortgage, which has been de signed to help lending insti tutions adapt more readily to changes in the money market, has been the subject of in creasing attention.

description: Community representatives in four of the slum areas where the Sanitation Department said it collected garbage five and six times a week reported yester day that the pickups were spo radic and occurred about twice a week

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5The Commerce Department reported today that consumers had step ped up their buying plans for houses for the next six months.

description: OUTSIDE SKOUN. Cambo dia, Aug. 5 (AP)Seven Amer ican planes gave direct air sup port to Cambodian ground troops here today.

description: OUAGADOUGOU. Upper Volta. Aug. 5 (Reuters)Maurice Yameogo, the first President of independent Upper Volta, was released from jail today after having served 15 months of a 2year sentence for embezzling public funds.

title: RUFFELS UPSETS GIMENO IN TENNIS
10RACE PROGRAMS SET FOR YONKERS
description: YONKERS, Aug. 5  Ten event programs have been scheduled for Friday and Sat urday nights at Yonkers Race way, but betting on each night will be restricted to nine. There will be no change in the usual daily double and four exacta Propositions.

title: Westchester Bus Fare Rise
description: ALBANY, Aug. 5 (UPI) The Westchester Street Trans portation Company of Mount Vernon will raise adult oneway fares from 25 cents to 30 cents on Monday under tariff revi sions approved today by the Public Service Commission. Despite the increase, which will produce added annual revenue of $159,200, the company still faces a deficit of about $31,000 this year, according to figures filed with the P.S.C.

title: Iraqis Get Soviet Pledge For Just Peace in Mideast
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 5The Soviet Union said today that would do everything within its power to aid in the search for an equitable political settlement of the conflict between Arabs and Israelis in the Mid dle East.

title: Manson Mistrial Barred Again; Jurors Held Still Unprejudiced
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 5Su perior Court Judge Charles H. Older refused again today to declare a mistrial in the murder trial of Charles M. Manson and three young women codefend ants.

title: HIROSHIMA PANELS GOON EXHIBIT OCT. 15
description: Eight panels, depicting scenes in Hiroshima after the first atomic bombing 25 years ago today, will he seen for the first time in the United States be ginning Oct. 15 at the New School Art Center.

title: Commonwealth United in Default
description: The Commonwealth United Corporation, whose overseas fi nancing arm failed this week to make a required interest payment of $862,500 on a bond issue sold abroad, is in default on two other bond issues sold domestically, the trustee for the bonds said yesterday. Interest on a third issue sold domesti cally is also overdue, the trus tee said.

title: Samuels's Son, 17, Wins a Dismissal Of Drug Charges
description: Drug charges against Howard C. Samuels, son of the indust rialist who ran unsuccessfully this year for the Democratic nomination for Governor, were dismissed here yesterday on the recommendation of the youth's courtappointed counselor.

title: Fire in Downtown Plainfield
description: PLAINFIELD, N. J., Aug. 5 (AP)  The fivestory Babcock Building in downtown Plain field, on which demolition was to get under way tomorrow, was extensively damaged by fire tonight. The building had been unoccupied since a fire last Dec. 7.

title: Mayor Will Extend Shopping Mall Plan To 8 More Streets
description: Extending the concept of nedestrian shopping malls, Mayor Lindsay yesterday broad ened the closing of main ave nues to vehicular traffic in va rious parts of the city.

title: L.I.R. Says Weed Killer Made July 7 Train Skid
description: A Long Island Railroad (spokesman said yesterday that a residue of a weed killing spray that remained on the tracks was the apparent cause of a train accident in Long Beach on July 7.

title: Karen K. Hartmann Plans Bridal
description: Dr. and Mrs. Hans A. Hart mann of New York have an nounced the engagement of Dr. Hartmann's daughter, Miss Karen Kohler Hartmann, to Robert Allen Hoffman. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Hoffman of Mequon, Wis. The couple plan to be married in January.

title: Screen: 'Losers' Arrives:Motorcycle Gangsters at War in Vietnam
description: Sooner or later it was bound to happen  a picture about American motorcyclist supermen pitted against the Vietcong on enemy terrain. Brought together overseas by a wary Army command, these five super-tough civilians include two veterans of Vietnam. Their mission is to rescue a Presidential adviser held captive in a remote village."The Losers," opening yesterday on the circuits, has a good idea with some fine, ironic possibilities. And sure enough, this low-budget enterprise uses a slam-bang, blood-dripping massacre of a climax, spearheaded by these hardies, to stress the seeming futility of the war. The film also falls all over itself along the way in dawdling admiration of the bone-crushing quintet as symbols of rebellion.For a full hour  and we timed it  the recruits slam around an outpost town in typical cyclist-movie style, brawling, drinking and anchoring to the local brothel. Watching them cynically, unlike the camera, is a tough-talking Army captain, played by that excellent Negro actor, Bernie Hamilton, who finally gets them  and the showon the road.Two sideline romances extend right to the front, with the secret-mission truck also carrying two girl friends, and we're not kidding. One of them, as a native girl with a Negro baby from the bordello, is beautifully played by a young Philippine actress named Ana Korita. Her stunned moment of reunion with the captain, who had deserted her, is the only genuinely touching thing in the picture.As for that climactic rescue, the boys roar into the thatched-hut village for an explosive holocaust, with blood flying, quite literally, at the slow-motion camera. The liberated "Presidential adviser" turns out to be a cringing, snapping man in a white-linen suit who denounces his burly rescuers as "trash," and leaves two of them to dieall five do. He then barks to the captain: "Now get me back to Washington so I can straighten out this mess."On one count, this project shows solid pluck. It was filmed entirely in the Philippines by an independent outfit called Fanfare. The exotic settings, stamped with harshly colored photography, look authentic every inch of the way. There is also evidence that the strapping William Smith, as the brightest of the five, can act. But the scenario by Alan Caillou and the limber direction of Jack Starrett (who also plays the Washingtonian) seem mainly concerned with one thing. War or no war, you can't push these guys around.

title: Advertising: MultiMedia Shows Are Tried
description: Some 7,000 industrial films will be produced this year, with the dollar volume of those made by independent companies estimated at somewhat more than $135 million. Yet only 5 per cent or so of this amount falls into the broad category of multimedia presentationsthose combinations of films, slides, sound, light and so forth that have recently been attracting widescale atten tion.

title: When Not Cooking in One of the Kitchens, She's Busy in the Other
description: PORT CHESTER, N. Y.Rose Fama's cooking, an acquaintance said recently, falls into the category of the superb. Her husband, Michael, the friend add ed, makes a hearty and excellent dry white wine in their cellar, and he uses not a hand crank but a machine of his own devising for Dressing the grams.

title: An Instant Philanthropist Passes Out Money Here
Wood, Field and Stream
description: New York State deer hunt ers may obtain party permit application forms the first of next month, according to the State Department of Environ mental Conservation.

title: EDWARD COSTELLO
description: BOSTON, Aug. 5 (UPI)Ed ward Costello, associate sports editor of The Boston Herald Traveler, died yesterday. He was 64 years old.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT

title: EDWARD ROBINSON, FORMER L.I. JUSTICE
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Aug. 5Edward Robinson Jr., a retired Supreme Court Jus tice in Nassau County, L.I., died in a hospital here yester day. He was 70 years old and had moved here from Oyster Bay, L.I., after his retirement two years aeo.

title: Gonzales in Canadian Open
description: TORONTO, Aug. 5 (AP)Or ganizers of the Canadian open tennis championships announced today that Pancho Gonzales be came the 20th and final entry for next week's $23,200 tourna ment. The 42yearold Gonzales, from Los Angeles, was seeded fifth in the field.

title: T.V.A. Slated to Increase Payments to the Treasury

title: Company Expands Credit
description: MIAMI, Aug. 5 (UPI)The, General Development Corpora tion said today it had increased its shortterm credit lines with, three New York banks to $20 million from $10million.

title: JACKLIN REJOINS PRO TOUR TODAY
description: AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 5Tony Jacklin will seek another American golf title as well as lots of prize money in the next four tournaments on the pro tour. The 26yearold English professional who returned home last June with the United States Open championship out lined his plans today for further golfing gold and glory.

title: Edward Perry, Slocumb Hollis Plan to Marry
GRETEL II TO LEAVE PHILADELPHIA TODAY
description: Gretel II. Australia's would be America's Cup challenger, is scheduled to leave Philadelphia tonight for Providence, R.I., aboard the freighter New York Star.

title: U.S. JUDGE REJECTS DEATHHOUSE PLEA
description: TRENTON. Aug. 5Edgar H. Smith, who has been on Death Row longer than any other con demned man in American penal history, lost another legal battle to escape the electric chair to day when a Federal judge re fused to strike down the confession that led to Smith's conviction of murder 13 years ago.

title: Chase Manhattan's Shares Near Paris Bourse Listing
description: PARIS, Aug. 5 (UPI)  The Chase Manhattan Corporation of New York has become the first American banking concern to win a listing on the Paris Bourse, people in financial circles reported today.

title: Fire on 33d Floor of New Building Kills Two
Racial Bars Easing In Stores'
description: The reaction has been minimal to the black manne quins in the windows of the most elegant specialty shops throughout the country, even those in the South.

title: $710,000 in Securities Lost From Bank on Wall Street
description: Detectives of the Old Slip police station reported yester day that negotiable securities valued at $710,000 were miss ing from a Wall Street bank. The securities, described as United States Treasury bonds and notes payable to the bearer, disappeared from the Bankers Trust Company at 16 Wall Street.

title: Chess:
description: The mounting activity among chess buffs these days in the San Francisco Bay area is stimulated by the performances of two indomi table spirits.

title: Kaiser Steel Joining Rise In Prices of Tin Mill Goods
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation announced yesterday an in crease in prices of its tin mill products, effective Oct. 1. The rise, the same as that an nounced by the United States Steel Corporation Tuesday, is 65 cents per base box, a quan tity amounting to 31,360 square inches of metal.

title: DRUG CASE SUSPECT DIES OF GUN WOUNDS
description: A man suspected of being drug dealer died yesterday fol lowing a gun battle with po licemen on Third Street in the East Village Tuesday.

title: Making the City Dirtier
description: The Lindsay administration seems determined insure that no section of the city will ever qualify really clean. That is the only conclusion we can draw from the Sanitation Department's announcement that garbage collection for families living in small homes will be cut back from three times a week to two.

title: LONDON BOARD UP; OIL ISSUES STRONG
description: Stock prices advanced in moderate trading yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.

title: Jacob's Pillow Sees Judgment of Paris
description: LEE. Mass., Aug. 5  The First Chamber Dance Company, founded in the early 1960's to bring technically strong classi cal ballet to smaller communi ties, is entering the seventies by adding substantial choreo graphic weight of its repertory.

title: BRITISH SEE THREAT IN U.S. COMPONENTS
description: LONDON, Aug. 5 (UPI) Imports of lowpriced Amer ican electronics components were viewed today as threaten ing the British industry. The chief executive of one of the big companies in the field said the danger was that Amer ican concerns might win total control of parts of the British market.

title: Bank Plans Bahamas Branch
description: The First National Bank of Miami said yesterday it had ap plied for permission to open an overseas branch in Nassau, the Bahamas. It would be the bank's first branch outside the United States.

title: U.S. AIDE BACKS DUMPING OF GAS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5The President's chief adviser on the environment gave a cautious endorsement today to the Army's plan to dispose of 12,540 rockets containing nerve gas by dumping them into the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Mary C. Lallande Sets Fall Wedding
description: Miss Mary Claudel Lal lande, an associate editor of Glamour magazine, and Clin ton Jansen Kendrick who is with the Stuyvesant Asset Management Corporation here, plan to be married in October.

title: 4 FREIGHTERS SOLD FOR $38.4MILLION
description: MooreMcCormack Lines an nounced yesterday that it would sell its four newest freighters forming the Sea bridge class to American Ex port Isbrandtsen Lines for $38.4million. The sale has been approved by the boards of both companies but is sub ject to execution of a final contract and the final approval of the Maritime Administra tion.

title: Adderley Joins Alworth In Football Retirement
description: Herb Adderley, a corner back for the Green Bay Packers, joined Lance Al worth, the San Diego Charg ers wide receiver, in pro football retirement yester day.

title: Sony Asks Big Board To List Its A.D.R.'s
description: The Sony Corporation an nounced yesterday it had ap plied for listing its American Depositary Receipts on the New York Stock Exchange, becoming the first Japanese company to apply for such a listing.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
ARTISTS CRITICIZE SHOW AT COLISEUM
description: The first New York Interna tional Art Show, which opened last Friday at the Coliseum. came under scrutiny yesterday from some of the exhibitors and from Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz.

title: CRIME TASK FORCE IS DUE FOR JERSEY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5Top officials of the Justice Depart ment, New Jersey and Newark agreed today to establish a joint Federal, state and municipal task force to attack organized crime in New Jersey.

title: Higginson Takes Title Pistol Shoot
description: CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. (AP)A marine warrant officer, Francis Higginson of Placerville, Calif., withstood a late challenge today by the defending cham pion, Navy Petty Officer Donald Hamilton of Wollaston, Mass., to win the national pistol cham pionship with a threeday total of 2,656 points.

title: Military Death Penalty Bill
description: WASHINGTON. Aug. 5 (UPI)  Senator Mark O. Hatfield. Republican of Oregon, has a bill to abolish the death penalty for military personnel and make other major changes rn the code of military justice. Mr. Hatfield's proposals would create a nindependent military justice system responsible sole ly to the judge advocate gen eral, open certain crimes to Federal district courts, abolish summary courtsmartial and limit punishment dealing with general disciplinary problems of servicemen to nonjudicial punishment.

title: MRS. HORY REACHES SEMIFINAL ON LINKS
description: BEDFORD, N.Y., Aug. 5Mrs. Thomas J. Hory of Winged Foot, the defender, reached the semifinal round of the 48th an nual Women's Westchesterand Fairfield Golf Association cham pionship at Bedford Golf and Tennis Club today by rallying for a 1up victory over Mrs. Allan V. Becker, Westchester Country Club.

title: JAMES C. LEWIS
description: James Campbell Lewis, re tired vice president of research for E. R. Squibb & Sons, Inc., died Tuesday in Claremont, N. H. He was 82 years old and lived in Cornish. N. H.

title: HUNGARIAN TEAM WINS RUN, TITLE
description: WARENDORF, West Ger many, Aug. 5 (AP)  Peter Kelemen took the individual title and led a strong Hungar ian team to the modern world pentathlon team championship today. The United States team finished fourth.

title: Air Fare Increase Sought
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 American Airlines asked the Civil Aeronautics Board today Ito approve higher air fares be tween New York and Wash ington, Boston, Rochester, Buffalo and Syracuse. The pro posal called for a 25 per cent increase in first class fares and increases ranging from $2 to $5 in the oneway coach fare. The coach increase would be based on mileage.

title: Far Rockaway to Open A New Surfing Area
description: A new surfing area in Far Rockaway between Beach 49th and 50th Streets will he opened tomorrow at 1:30 P.M., in ceremonies highlighted by a shootthewaves demon stration to rock music, City Recreation Commission er Joseph W. Halper has announced.

title: Mute Wins Dismissal of NarcoticsSale Charge
description: Charges that a 22yearold Brooklyn man had sold nar cotics were dismissed yesterday after District Attorney Eugene Gold disclosed that the de fendant could not have said the things a police agent said he did since the defendant is virtually mute.

title: U.S. Step Gets Approval
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 5The Soviet Union, Britain and France joined today in formal approval of the new peace initiative in the Middle East proposed by the United States.

title: Subterranean Hot Water Ocean Seen as Power Source in West
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 5 A University of California professor said today that the discovery of a 4 billion to 6 bil lion acrefoot ocean of hot water below the Imperial Valley might supply enough pollutionfree geothermal power to meet most of Southern California's electri cal energy needs for the rest of this century.

title: PRESS CRITICIZED ON NIXON REMARK
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5  A California Congressman de clared today that President Nix on's comments on the murder trial of Charles M. Manson, while wrong, had been rela tively unimportant news and that the press had acted ir responsibly in mooning them.

title: Negro Is Killed by Police In a Clash in Lima, Ohio
description: LIMA, Ohio, Thursday, Aug. 6A black woman was shot to death by the police last night, touching off a wave of violence that led to the cordoning off of a 12block area on the Negro Near South Side.

title: JORDANIANS DEMAND FULL WITHDRAWAL
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 5 (Reuters)  In accepting the American Middle East peace proposal, Jordan has insisted that Israel accept the principle of withdrawal from all Arab territories occupied in the 1967 war, it was announced here today. The reply to the United States proposal also insisted that the full rights of the Pal estinian people, approved by United Nations resolutions, be recognized as a safeguard for

title: 28 PIANISTS UNITE JAZZ AND CLASSICS
description: A piano recital in which Ravel's Hommage a Haydn balanced Blues for Art Tatum, a Scarlatti sonata followed Tea for Two, and St. James In firmary was cheek by jowl with a Chopin polonaise was given Tuesday evening at the Library and Museum of Lincoln Center.

title: OHAN S. BERBERYAN
description: BEAUFORT, S. C., Aug. 5Ohan S. Berberyan, an authority on antique English carpets, died Monday at a geriatrics center here. He was 88 years old and lived on Hilton Head Island.

title: 5Horse Jumpoff Is Won by Act I In Jersey Fixture
description: BRANCHVILLE, N.J., Aug. 5 Act I, who has developed nto one of the divisional stars this year, captured the first open jumper class at the Sus sex County horse show today, defeating four rivals in a jump off.

title: Karen T. Connelly To Marry Aug. 29
description: BEL AIR, Calif., Aug 5Miss Karen Therese Connelly and William C. Donovan will be married Aug. 29 in St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Westwood.

title: Nassau College Plays Host To Its Own Equity Troupe
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Aug. 5For the first time at any unit of the State University, a professional theatrical com pany, made up solely of grad uates, is in residence on the campus of Nassau Commu nity College.

title: Celler Says 3 U.S. Agencies Obstruct Douglas Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 The chairman of a special House subcommittee considering the impeachment of Associate Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court contended today that its preliminary in quiry was being obstructed by the refusal of ?? ?? cies to supply necessary infor mation.

title: Nashua Colt $4.20 Victor
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5 (AP) Walnut Hill Farm's Buck's Nashua, a 2yearold son of Nashua, remained unbeaten with his fourth victory in the $12,000 Dunks Ferry Purse, fiveandahalffurlong race to day. The winner scored by two lengths over Dixiana's Distant Day and paid $4.20. The victor's time was 1:04 15.

title: Mrs. Ricki Hunter Is Married Here to Dr. Stephen Goodyear
description: Mrs. Ricki Hunter and Dr. Stephen Goodyear, a psy chiatrist she met on the tele phone when she was working as an operator for his answering service, were mar ried yesterday afternoon in civil ceremony at the Muni cipal Building.

title: Samuel B. Mosher Is Dead at 77; Founder of Signal Oil '
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Aug. 5Samuel B. Mosher, who founded the Signal Oil and Gas Company in 1922 and built into a giant conglomerate with interests in air freight, aero space, real estate, broadcasting and athletic teams, died yester day at his home. He was 77.

title: 1969 Loss to Be Reported By Domestic Air Express
description: Domestic Air Express, Inc., an international air and surface forwarding company, said yes terday that it expects to report a loss of about $1.6million for 1969, subject to final review and certification by its ac countants.

title: HUGE RENOVATION OF APARTMENTS STARTS IN HARLEM
description: An $11million lowincome housing rehabilitation projectone of the largest in the city's history  was started in Har lem yesterday in a joint ven ture by black and white con tractors.

title: Deborah Cline, 70 Debutante, Wed
description: SALISBURY, N. C., Aug. 5 In the chapel of the Pint Methodist Church here to night. Miss Deborah Adrienne Cline a June graduate of St. Mary's School in Raleigh, was marriedto Thonlas Aus tin Finch 3d, who is a junior at Princeton University. The Rev. D. Edwin Bailey per formed the ceremony.

title: Parcel Dispute Enters 7th Day As Talks Fail to Settle Issues
description: A strike of Teamster Local 804 against the United Parcel Service moved into its sixth day yesterday as a meeting be tween the company and the union broke up with no resolu tion of the issues.

title: NEWTON IS FREED ON $50,000 BAIL
description: OAKLAND, Aug. 5  Huey P. Newton, the Black Panther minister of defense who was found guilty of shooting an Oakland policeman nearly two years ago, was released from orison today.

title: U.S. AUTO OUTPUT ROSE DURING JULY
description: DETROIT, Aug. 5 (AP)United States auto makers pro duced 453,804 vehicles in July, up from 433,002 during the yearearlier month.

title: Hoff a Appeal Denied Again
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 5 (AP)The United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit denied today a request by James R. Hoffa, president of the team sters union, and five other ap pellants to overturn their con viction for mail and wire fraud and conspiracy. It was the third time the court had rejected Hoffa's attempt to reverse the 1964 conviction.

title: The High Cost of Bigotry
description: The South African economy is paying a steep price for its policy of racial apartheid. The nation suffering from a labor shortage that feeds inflation, a foreigntrade deficit, a decline in investment plant and equipment, a drag in its economic growth, and a fall in the stock market.

title: New Apollo 15 Landing Site Reported Being Considered
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 5 (UPI)The fear that Apollo moon mis sions may be cut back sharply is causing space agency offic ials to consider a rugged new landing site for next year's scheduled Apollo 15 mission.

title: Robert Kennedy Jr. and Cousin, Shriver Son, in Marijuana Case
