description: A theatrical touch will be given to a polo match for the Maharajah of Jaipur Mem orial Cup at International Polo Field in Oak Brook, Ill., today.

title: Mideast 2: Nasser Risks Arab Disunity
description: CAIRO  President Nasser's charisma, still strong in much of the Arab world despite seem ingly endless intrigues, setbacks and challenges, is facing what may be its ultimate test amid the clamor of Arab extremists against his move toward a peaceful settlement with Israel.

title: Karla Klumpp, W. R. Berger, Marry on L. I.
description: MANHASSET, L. I., Aug. 8  Miss Karla M. Klumpp, daughter of Dr. Theodore G. Klumpp, board chairman of Winthrop Laboratories, the pharmaceutical manufactu rers, and Mrs. Klumpp of Sands Point, was married here today to William R. Berger of Glen Cove.

title: TIRUCK SECOND TO 710 FAVORITE
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y., Aug. 8 Columbia George registered the fastest mile in the 13year history of Monticello Raceway today, when he captured the George Morton Levy Pace in 1:58 15.

title: Hollis Stacy to Risk U.S. Title In Junior Golf at Apawamis
description: Led by 16yearold Cindy Ferro, the Forest Hill Field Club's newly crowned Metro politan junior girls champion, a group of five players from this district will tee up at the Apawamis Club in Rye, N.Y., tomorrow in quest of the 22d annual United States Golf As sociation's junior girls title.

title: Observer: A Very Strange City
description: LONDON, Aug. 8This is strange city.

title: David Lee to Wed Stacey L. Schneer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Schneer of London have an nounced here the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Stacey Lee Schneer, to David Harold Lee, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur I. Lee of Peekskill, N. Y. The wed ding will take place on Aug. 25 at the Fenway Golf Club in White Plains.

title: Shoemaker Registers No. 6,000 on Coast
description: DEL MAR, Calif., Aug. 8 (AP)Bill Shoemaker became the second jockey to pilot 6,000 winners today.

title: Letters
description: STICE FOR LACKS

title: U.S. Ski Coaches Named
description: DENVER, Aug. 8 (AP)Adolph M. Kuss, ski coach at Fort Lewis College in Colorado was named Nordic combined coach for the United States na tional team today by the United States Ski Association. Also appointed were Lloyd Severud, of Chetak, Wis., jumping coach; John Caldwell of Putney, Vt., crosscountry coach, and John Curtin of Jackson, Wyo., women's crosscountry coach.

title: U.S. Sweepstakes Listed for Red Bank Saturday
description: The Navesink River at Red Bank, N.J., will be torn next Saturday and Sunday by the National Sweepstakes Re gatta, one of the old events in power boat racing. It is not so mighty in the national picture as when the Gold Cup thunderboats were spot lighted, but Red Bank still lays claim to being the River Sports Center of the East.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Astronauts in Germany
description: BONN, Aug 8, (AP)The Apollo 14 astronauts will con duct a training session in West Germany next week on the site of a meteorite crater in Bavaria. The Science Ministry announced Wednesday that the astro nauts would train on the site known as Noerdlinger Ries.

title: FRESH AIR CAMPS PROVIDE VARIETY
description: The sounds of circuses and Shakespeare are emanating from the Fresh Air Fund's Sharpe Reservation camping, center in Dutchess County this summer.

title: Miss Lennon Becomes Bride
description: HOT SPRINGS, Va., Aug. 8 Miss Kathleen Lennon and Robert Harry Pampillonia were married at noon today at theRoman Catholic Shrine of the Sacred Heart in Hot Springs. The Rev. Joseph J. Sellinger, president of Loyola College, performed the cere mony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: Rosetti Captures Shootoff In World Sheet Tourney
description: SAVANNAH, Ga., Aug. 8 (AP) Tony Rosetti of Biloxi, Miss., won the allgauge high over all shootoff and Mrs. Julia Ar mour of Coral Gables, Gla., set a women's mark in the Na tional Skeet Shooting Associa tion's world championships to day.

title: Stray Animals Offered The Latest in Comfort
description: CHATSWORTH, Calif., Aug. 8 (AP)Over a 3.3acre spread, the city has built A fashionable new guest ranch for stray animals, wild and domestic.

title: Sweep of 7 Finals Made By East German Oarsmen
description: IOANNINA, Greece, Aug. 8 (AP)The United States failed to win a medal today as East Germany completely dominated the first world junior rowing championships by winning all seven final races.

title: Chess
description: THE 1970 World Chess Olympiad, the 19th in the series, is scheduled for Siegen, West Germany, this year, from September 5 to Sep tember 28. Nearly 60 four man teams with two alternates from as many countries will compete for global supremacy.

title: 3 Long Island City Youths Die in Westchester Crash
description: HAWTHORNE, N. Y., Aug. 8  Three youths from Long Is land City, Queens, were killed and a fourth critically injured today when the car in which they were riding went out of control and smashed into a tree a mile south of Westchester, County Parkway Police Head quarters here on the Saw Mill River Parkway.

title: Eagle Has Landed
description: He has landedTranquillity Base. Eagle is at Tranquillity. With these words on July 20, 1969 N.A.S.A. an nounced that man at last had reached the moon. How the giant leap into space was achieved is told in these competently written, technically ac curate books.

title: Death Comes to The Peregrine Falcon
description: LAST Nov. 7, a week before the Federal Government restricted Awl DDT and similar persistent poisons which for 24 growing seasons since 1946 had been sprayed abundantly on the landa group of hawk experts met at Cornell to plan new research on American birds of prey. Their meeting turned out to be the postmortem conference on Falco peregrinus anatum, the bold, baleful, freeflying peregrine falcon, or duck hawk, that once bred on cliffsides across America. In 23 breed ing seasons since 1947, when the first sign of disaster was seen, butmisdiagnosed, the peregrine has be come all but extinct as a breeding bird, outside Alaska. DDT, unques tionably, caused its demise.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: In America, the blue mus sel flourishes in neglect. Ranging from the Arctic Ocean to South Carolina, this abundant and tasty bivalve is largely ignored.

title: DDT CALLED PERIL TO COAST PELICANS
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Au. 8 (UPI)The California Fish and Game Department says the in ability of pelicans to reproduce on an island north of Los An geles is closely correlated to DDT contamination of major conseauence.

title: 2 New Rivals for Kingsmen
description: The Brooklyn College soccer team will have two new op ponents next fallC.W. Post College and Lehman College.

title: US. Aide Talks On Latin Trade
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 8 (AP) The impression that the United States has enjoyed a large and persistent trade surplus with Latin America during the last decade is in correct, John R. Petty, As sistant Treasury Secretary for International Affairs, said here this week.

title: MARCOS UPGRADING LANDREFORM POLICY
description: MANILA Aug. 8President Ferdinand Marcos today an nounced a more aggressive land policy stressing utilization of land and designed to insure that no Filipino shall remain a squatter in his own country.

title: As Every Bettor Knows, the Surest Thing at Saratoga Nowadays Is Culture
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS N.Y., Aug. 8Sure horses are im portant. They wake up this lazy resort town every Au gust, and nobody thinks it could survive without them, spas and golf courses not withstanding. But there's a serious rival looming at the top of the stretch. It's Cul ture, spelled with a Capital C, and it takes myriad shapes.

title: BLACK COALITION PLANS PROTESTS
description: The United Black Coalition for Jobs in the Construction Industry plans a campaign of mass demonstrations at con struction sites across the state to force the hiring of more members of minority groups.

title: PURGER SAYS COURT WORKS IN SUMMER
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 8  Chief, justice Warren B. Burger re jected yesterday the assertion made in the Senate Wednesdayl I that the Justices of the Supreme, Court spend iackadaisical summers during the three Imonths in which the high court is not in session.

title: Pickets at Disneyland
description: NAHEIM, Calif., Aug. 8 (AP) Pickets paraded in front of Disneyland today as a strike by employes of the American Guild of Variety Artists began. Sev eral hundred employes went on strike seeking higher wages and better conditions, said Penny Singleton, a national union of ficer.

title: Hairs Key Evidence in Murder Trial
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Aug. 8 The firstdegree murder trial of John Norman Collins, a 23yearold former college student, moves into its fourth week Monday in the midst of a com plicated scientific controversy upon which the verdict prob ably hinges.

title: Adelaide Winfree, Wheaton'66, Is Wed to Lorenzo Simpson Jr.
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 8In Christ Church and St. Michael's, Episcopal, here at noon today, Miss Adelaide O. Winfree, a 1966 graduate of Wheaton College in Norton, Mass.,was married to Lorenzo C. Simpson Jr. who was graduated in 1967 from Yale University. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. W. Hamilton Aulenbach.

title: ULSTER EXPLOSION RUINS BRITISH POST
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sunday, Aug. 9 (Reuters)The main British customs post near the border between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic was blown up early today.

title: It's the Young Who Get Busted For Using Marijuana
description: The arrest on marijuana charges of Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and R. Sargent Shriver 3d, 16yearold cousins, which came to light last week when they were placed on probation at a Cape Cod court house, added two more famous names to a long list of the children of politically prominent fathers who have got ten into the same sort of trouble. The fathers include Senators George McGovern, Alan Cran ston and Ernest Hollings, Gov. William Cahill of New Jersey, and Howard Samuels, former Undersecretary of Commerce and a losing candidate this year for the Democratic gubernatori al nomination in New York.

title: Rose's Domination of Liberals Is at Issue in. Queens Court Test
description: Alex Rose is neither the plaintiff nor defendant, but he is the central issue in an ob scure trial that began last week in Queens.

title: Indiana
description: CUSTER DIED FOR YOUR SINS: An Indian Manifesto, by Vine Deloria Jr. (Macmillan, $5.95.) An informative, straight forward chronicle of abuses that challenges the stereotypes and myths that white society has built up about the Indians and asserts the dignity of the red man's cultural heritage. Mr. Deloria's latest book, We Talk, You Listen, will be pub lished by Macmillan in October. HOUSE MADE OF DAWN, by N. Scott Momaday. (Harper, $4.95; paper, Signet, 95 cents.) A Pulitzer Prizewinning first novel, which dramatizes the American Indian's. relationship to the reservation and to the white man's civilizationas subtly wrought as a piece of Navajo silverware.

title: Hank McGraw a Holdout for Long Hair
description: The saga of the Shaggy Hank took a turn toward a happy ending yesterday when Hank McGraw, 27yearold career minor leaguer, was traded by Eugene, Ore., to Honolulu in the Pacific Coast League, still unshorn.

title: Major Leagues to Name a Black Manager Within 3 Years Study Forecasts
description: Major league baseball's first black team manager is likely to be named within the next three years, possibly as early as 1971, according to a two part report released in Nash ville, Tenn, by the Race Rela tions Information Center.

title: Boston Bank Opens Brazilian Branch
description: The First National Bank of Boston, which has long been active in banking in South America, has announced the opening of a fullservice branch in Porto Alegre, Bra zil, the capital of that coun try's southermost state.

title: America and the Progressive Era 19001917; By Fon W. Boardman Jr. 169 pp. New York: Henry Z. Waick. $5. (Ages 12 and Up)
description: Fon Boardman has been moving backward through American history (The Thirties, America and the Jazz Age) and has now arrived at the 20thcentury's opening years. His new book runs from McKinley to Wil son, from the SpanishAmerican War to World War I, from The Wizard of Oz to Prufrock, from Christy Mathewson to Tris. Speaker.

title: WEAVERS
description: Laotian weavers at work are depicted on three stamps, 30, 70 and 15 kip, issued in July to note Laos's participation in Expo at Osaka, ja pan. Laos in September is planning a 3stamp series pic turing three wild animals.

title: JARRING CONFERS WITH U.N. ENVOYS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Aug. 8Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring held intensive discussions here today on the key questions of his mission to negotiate peace in the Middle Eastthe site, the starting time and the level of national representation for the substantive talks.

title: Rome looks East
description: Two Italian women looked to the East for inspiration and scored a double coup in this summer's Rome couture shows. They produced clothes that were exotic and, in their way, classic. They also focused attention on women's right to design clothes for women. Irene Galitzine's inspiration washer collection of Chinese porcelain and Coromandel screens; Mila Schon drew upon her memory of a trip to Japan. Both diverted attention from the flappers, nineteen thirties movie heroines, Old West dancehall hostesses and other demode characters invading the fashion world today.

title: Disembark, Under Olivares, Triumphs at Finger Lakes
description: CANANDAIGUA, N. Y., Aug. 8 (AP)Jose Olivares guided Disembark to victory in the $2,500 featured eighth race to day at Finger Lakes Race Track.

title: Digging of Subway Splits Walls And Divides Officials in Rome
description: ROME, Aug. 8When an urgently needed subway line crosses with bureaucratic rival ry, the result in one Rome neighborhood is paralysis, fear, anger and confusion.

title: LarchmontBlock Island Races Start Thursday With 33 Craft
description: The Governor or Rhode Is land yacht races, twin events to and from Block Island spon sored by the Storm Trysail Club, have drawn 33 entries. The first half will begin from Larchmont on Thursday and the second back to Larchmont on Saturday. Although there will be variations in the cours es, each will be 100 miles long.

title: Vatican Gives Support To Mideast Truce Plan
description: ROME, Aug., 8The Holy See gave full diplomatic sup port to the United. States plan for a truce in the Middle East, informed sources in the Vatican Secretariat of State disclosed here today.

title: Czechs Seize 24 on Border
description: FURTH IM WALD, West Germany, Aug. 8 (AP)Twen tyone American teenage tour ists and three West. Germans strayed over the West German horder into Czechoslovakia to day and were taken into cus tody by Czechoslovak border guards. Bavarian officials are hopeful the 24 will be released quickly.

title: QUARANTINE OVER AT SCOUT RANCH
description: CIMARRON, N. M., Aug. 8State health officials have lifted a quarantine at the near by Boy Scout Ranch at Phil mont. It was instituted last night when officials feared that the death of a 12year old Scout had been caused by a variety of the plague.

title: U.S. Seeks Broad Agreement On Use of Seabed
description: GENEVA  With the earth growing more and more crowd ed, and with refuse from auto mobiles, jet planes and factories polluting both the rivers and the atmosphere the United States has put forward a farreaching proposal forthe orderly utiliza tion of the one great unexploited asset remaining to mankindthe bottoM of the sea.

title: Long Island Horsemen Decide To Restore HizhScore Awards
description: The Long Island High Score Awards Association, which disbanded this year, will he back in business in 1971 if all goes well.

title: BENGALS TROUNCE REDSKINS, 27 TO 12
description: CJNCINNATL Aug. 8 (AP)Lamar Parrish and Sandy Durko turned defensive gems into touchdowns tonight and led the Cincinnati Bengals to a 2712 National Football League pre season victory over the Wash ington Redskins.

title: Green Bay's SecondHalf Drive Overcomes a 21Point Deficit
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., Aug. 8The New York Giants to night accomplished something they could not manage last summerthey played an exhibition game without losing. They did dissipate a 21point lead to finish in a 3131 tie with the Green Bay Packers, but after five straight losses last summer, tonight's opening tie was undoubtedly a sign of progress.

title: All This Stuff
description: As one sports columnist put it, Turmoil follows Joe Nemeth everywhere. The reason for this is that Namath is a talented and highly paid quarterback who led the New York Jets to the 1968 pro football championship; but at the same time he's an outspoken high liver who prefers wine, women and song to training and discipline. When the Jets assembled at training camp last week, Namath, who spent the offseason making movies, was absent. More turmoil. Al Atkinson, an idealistic teammate who is a member of the Fellowship of Christian Athletes, charged that Namath was responsible for a lack of team unity, and announced his retirement. Whereupon Namath said he might quit because of all this stuff. While the quarterback has talked before about the trouble his injured knees give him, he never has saidas he did last weekI don't want to play football.

title: Truce is Greeted In Cairo With Quiet Satisfaction
description: CAIRO, Aug. 8The ceasefire that quieted the guns along the Suez Canal early today was greeted with quiet satisfaction in Cairo, but there was no sense of excitement, no dancing in the streets and no expectation of an early re turn to peacetime pursuits.

title: Miss Dickson Engaged to Wed Captain Barnes
description: HASTINGS ON HUDSON, N.Y., Aug. 8Miss Deborah Florence Dickson, a medical social worker with the Ameri can Red Cross in Vietnam, will be married next month to. Capt. Victor Gerard Barnes, U.S.A.F., who re cently returned from a tour of duty in Thailand and Vietnam.

title: Robin Lee Ridder Is Married To Howard Candler Wright
description: ST. PAUL, Aug. 8  Miss Robin Lee Ridder and How ard Candler Wright, students at the University of Cali fornia at Santa Barbara, were married here today in an Epis copal ceremony performed at the home of the bride's par ents by the Rev. Kenneth Simmons.

title: Rahim and Tanner Reach Final Round In Amateur Tennis
description: ROCHESTER, Aug. 8 (AP)Haroum Rahim, a Pakistani who attends the University of Cali fornia, Los Angeles, upset top seeded Zan Guerry of Lookout Mountain, Tenn., 64, 63, 64, today in the semifinal round of the United States amateur clay courts tennis championship.

title: Packers in Good Hands: Starr Returns
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., Aug. 8There were times last season when Bart Starr looked more like a civilian than one of the great est auarterbacks in history.

title: Infections Contracted in Hospitals Stir Concern
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 8Hospital associated infections, often from germs that are difficult to treat, affect about 1.5million Americans each year, but much more information Is needed to cope fully with the problem, doctors said here at a week long international conference.

title: Daniel Ellsberg of M.I.T. Marries Patricia Marx
description: NORTH SALEM, N.Y., Aug. 8  Miss Patricia Marx, daughter of Louis Marx of Scarsdale, and the late Mrs. Rene Saltzman Marx, was married here this afternoon to Daniel Ellsberg. The Pres byterian ceremony was per formed at the home of the bride's brother, Louis Marx Jr., by the Rev. John Boyles, who is the chaplain of Haver ford, Swarthmore and Bryn Mawr Colleges.

title: American University Names Splaver to Information Post
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8Marc Splaver, a May graduate of American University, has been named the school's sports in formation director.

title: Women Get the Vote
description: A TWOPANEL commemo rative stamp will be is sued August 26 at Adams, Mass., to com memorate the 50th anniver sary of Woman Suffrage in the United States. Adams was the birthplace of Susan B. Anthony, a pioneer in the crusade for women's rights, the 6 cents postage stamp being an observance of the golden jubilee of ratification of the 19th Amendment to the Constitution, which gave women the right to vote.

title: Dard of Dhanks
description: ALTERMrs. Mae Altar, wishes to expres her deep appreciation and thanks to all her friends for their many kindnesses and the beautiful tributes to her beloved hus band the late Bob Alter.

title: If They're Into Rock, Study Rock
description: PHILOSOPHER Alan Watts once drew a beautiful picture of so ciety. A child Is born, and he has a few short years for playing  years when he wants to be. Mommy, don't want to go to bed. I want to be more. I want to fill my senses. I want to experiment. And then this child (you) is put into a system. He's taught No, you don't touch this, you don't eat that, you don't talk this way, you don't say that at this time. You're put into kindergarten, which leads to grade school, and the programming starts for the future. Grade school leads to high school, and you still haven't made it because then there's college. But college isn't enough. You may want to stay in school indefinitely so you become a college pro fessor, still in there with the marks and the school. All right, you've had it with col lege and want to go out into the world. You gointo busi ness, and what happens? You get a quota, and have to work for that quota. When you reach that quota, you get another quota. Along with this you get financial bene fits that enable you to satisfy certain material desires. Do you have time to enjoy those material desires? Do you use the yachts and the cars? If yes, then I'm very happy. But how many people are too busy meeting their quota? They get their name on the door. They get power. They get status. They get ulcers. They're 65. Finally when they reach this point of wis dom (they've lived, they've felt) they're out of society. We put them into senile re tirement communities. And next to these communities? Billboards advertising grave stones. The future, the future.

title: Major Vegetable Grower Struck by Farm Workers
description: SALINAS, Calif., Aug. 8 (UPI)Cesar Chavez's farm workers union, fresh from victory in a fiveyear struggle to organize California grape vineyards,1 struck one of the largest vege table growers in the rich Sa linas Valley today.

title: Spotlight:
description: Cigarette manufacturers are selling fewer cigarettes but will make more profits this year than last.

title: RANGERS TO PLAY 39 GARDEN GAMES
description: The New York Rangers, starting their 45th season in the National Hockey League, will open their home season on Wednesday, Oct. 14, against the Buffalo Sabres at Madison Square Garden. The game will be the first of 39 at the Garden for the Rangers in 197071.

title: ST WART CRITICIZES DISRUPTIVE LAWYERS
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 8 (AP)Associate Justice Potter Stew art of the Supreme Court said today that disruptive trial law yers were working against the American judicial system and that their tactics might boom erang against their clients.

title: REP. G. R. WATKINS OF PENNSYLVANIA
description: CHESTER, Pa., Aug. 8 (AP) Representative G. Robert Watkins, died last night after having been stricken during a speaking engagement at the Penn Oaks Country Club. He was 68 years old.

title: In the White Man's Tongue
description: We're people in a hurry, Jeanette Henry explains when describing the ambitious plans of San Francisco's newly founded American Indian Edu cational Publishers.

title: Stamps
description: EXCEPTING an air con ditioner, which can keep us cool in sum mer, or a heating unit to keep us warm in winter, there is little anyone can do about the weather. We put up with it. Farmers have had their own particular prob lems with weather through out time, but shortly after the Army established a school of meteorology at Fort Whip ple (now Fort Myer), Virginia, in 1870, farmers and rural communities were among the first recipients of the bene fits of this establishment, created pursuant to Congres sional action.

title: Lindsay Names Ted Gross A Deputy Commissioner
description: Ted Gross, one of the group that joined the Lindsay Admin istration as part of Sid Davi doff's crew of advance men for the Mayor, has been pro moted to deputy commissioner of the Youth Services Agency.

title: BLOOMFIELD FIRST IN ORIENTA SAIL
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 8 Robert A. BloOmfield brought Chalet d'Ete home 7 minutes 33 seconds inside the time limit today to give the Shields Class an official race on Long Island Sound in the Orienta Yacht Club's 64th annual re gatta.

title: Coins
description: VISITORS to the Ameri can Numismatic Asso ciation convention in St. Louis, Aug. 18 through 22, will have the op portunity to view the great est exhibition of coins, med als and paper money ever as sembled by the ANA. The dis plays, including those to be submitted on a competitive (prize) basis, will be shown in the Exhibit Hall of the Chase Park Plaza Hotel in Forest Park, official head quarters for the 79th anniver sary convention.

title: ScientificAtlanta Profits
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 8Scien tificAtlanta, Inc., a not so young technologyoriented company that has been strug gling to keep a profit in the last two years now finds it self in an enviable turn around position in the mid dle of a general business slowdown, according to its president and chairman, Glenn P. Robinson Jr.

title: SwedenU.S. Day Canceled
description: KALMAR, Sweden, Aug. 8 (UPI)Fear of antiAmerican demonstrations forced the can cellation of SwedenAmerica Day in this southern Swedish town today for the first time since the early 1950's. Kalmar, a town of 35,000 persons, calls itself the home town of the majority of Swedish immi grants to the United States.

title: Maria knew what nothing means
description: A new novel by Joan Didion is something of an event. Since her first one, Run River (1963), she has gathered a quiet following with her nonfiction pieces that were col lected under the title Slouching Towards Bethlehem and published to critical enthusiasm, in 1968. It was interesting to wonder what sort of fiction Miss Didion's beautiful writerly skills would now make of her cleareyed and anguished per cention of our time.

title: Article 2  No Title
Pasadena Playhouse Sold At Coast Auction to Bank
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 8 (UPI)  The financially troubled Pasadena Playhouse was sold at auction yesterday to the Bank of America, the only bid der for $285,675.47.

title: Road Work in Mobile Uncovers Fort
description: MOBILE, Ala., Aug. 8 The longlost foundations of the early eighteenthcentury French fort that started this city have been discovered as a byproduct of the Federal highway program to close the gap in Interstate 10. be tween Pascagoula, Miss., and Pensacola, Fla.

title: Susan Elizabeth Lardner Wed to Fred HeHerman
description: WESTON, Conn., Aug. 8  Barefoot beneath a maple tree outside the bridegroom's farm house here, Miss Susan Elizabeth Lardner, daughter of the late John Lardner, a writer, and herself a staff writer for The New Yorker, was married this aftenoon to Fred Hellerman. He is a song writer and musician who co founded the Weavers, the former folksinging quartet.

title: Bonn and Moscow Open A New Chapter
3 DEBUTS SPICE DANCE FESTIVAL
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug 8 A broad anthology of dance approaches was offered last night at Connecticut College's American Dance Festival. Three choreographers, Peter Saul, Dorothy Vislocky and Lucas Hoving, each offered a premiere, and Richard Englund presented a work from repertory. The program was equally divided among dancers who concerned themselves with an older world that perhaps was and a current world that certainly Is.

title: Yacht Arrives in Newport Damaged
Elizabeth Ann Barron Is Married
description: CAPPAQUA, N. Y. Aug. 8Miss Elizabeth Ann Bar ron was married here this morning to William John Ferretti. Msgr. Robert J. Skelly performed the cere mony and celebrated the nup tial mass in SS. John and Mary Roman Catholic Church.

title: Sharks and Swimmers: An Uneasy Coexistence
description: SOON AFTER President (Richard Nixon purchased his retreat at Key Biscayne, Fla., workmen enclosed the private beach on the property with a wire net treated with shark repellent. Just a few days after the net was installed, trap pers for Seaquarium, a local tourist at traction, pulled six big, snapping tiger sharks out of the water not far away.

title: 12 JERSEY CADDIES GIVEN SCHOLARSHIPS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Aug. 8The selection of 12 caddies to attend Rutgers Uni versity this fall on scholarships given by the New Jersey State Golf Association brings to 150 the number of recipients since the program was initiated in 1947.

title: G.O.P. IS SELECTING 6 U.S. JUDGES HERE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8New York Republican leaders are in the final stages of selecting six nominees for coveted lifetime appointments as Federal District judges in the New York City metropolitan area.

title: Shipping Broker Sees Firm Rates
description: LONDON, Aug. 8 (AP)World freight market rates should continue firm during the next 12 months despite a current lull that has caused spot positions for voyage rates in particular to de cline, according to Eggar, Forrester, Ltd., London ship ping brokers.

title: DISTINCTIVE TIES DELAWARE MARK
description: STANTON, Del., Aug. 8 (AP)  Herbert Allen's Distinctive captured the $55,650 du Pont Handicap today, the closingday feature of Delaware Park's 61 day meeting, and equaled the track record.

title: Styles are thrifty, mechanics skillful, all the mots justes
description: The editor's introduction says that this collection from the new Transatlantic Review's first 10 years of publication shows the range of stories we have published and, hopefully, the quality of writing we have tried to encourage. Fortunate ly, the quality of the stories is higher than this sample of Mr. McCrindle's prose; the mis use of hopefully does not ap pear elsewhere in the book. In fact, the quality is very high indeed. With one or two ex ceptions, all of these 30some stories  most of them short and none very long  are in teresting in both the critical and popular meanings of the word. And all, without excep tion, are supremely competent.

title: Singapore Sees 9% Growth
description: SINGAPORE, Aug. 8 (Reu ters)Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew of Singapore, in his an nual radio and television mes sage marking national day to morrow, said tonight that economic growth for 1970 would probably be over 9 per cent, with unemployment at an alltime low. Lee also warned that the Communists are out to exploit racial and other con flicts, they are out for violence and terror.

title: The New Thing Meets Rock
description: THE avantgarde cor ner turn that jazz took a little over a decade ago was christened, the New Thing by many, and to most 1970's listeners it re mains just that  a thing, new, opaque and forbidding.

title: Mitsnbishi Seeks Chrysler Lines
description: TOKYO, Aug. 8 (Reuters) The Mitsubishi Motor Corp. has announced it is studying the feasibility of assembling its Cotl Galant passenger car model overseas using idle assembly lines of the Chrys ler Corporation.

title: Italian Leader Installs 58 Under Secretaries
description: ROME, Aug. 8 (Reuters)Italy's new Premier, Emilio Colombo, today swore in 58 under secretaries in his Gov ernment, the 32d since the fall of Fascism.

title: Architecture
description: THE environmental im pact of even a small work of quality can be startling in a city that swallows the supercolossal without a scar. Casual stroll ers along 42d or 43d Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues have been noticing a new bit of environment this summer. They have be come aware of it without the publicity ballyhoo that ac companies bigger, noisier building projects and they have been reporting it to this writer in surprising numbers. Quality, that rarest of New York products, can pop up unexpectedly and unan nounced.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: The
description: LONDONI realize America can't be as fascinating as some of the films make out, says Miss Susan Chorley, a 21yearold clerk from Liverpool.

title: Furor Over Plan To Dump Nerve Gas
description: WASHINGTONWhen Amer ican ground forces In Korea were overwhelmed by Chinese Com munist human wave attacks near the Yalu River almost two decades ago, Pentagon policy makers realized that the situa tion had forced a challenge up on them: Find a way to stop mass infantry attacks.

title: Oxford's Myopic Companion to Art
description: NEXT month the Oxford University Press will publish the latest in its comprehensive Companion reference books "The Oxford Companion to Art ($25). Edited by Harold Osborne, this volume of 1,277 pages is superbly de signed in the classic typo graphic style that is familiar to us from so many hand somely produced Oxford ref erence works. It is also, con sidering its size, remarkably compact and easy to handle. As an object, it commands respect.

title: Dance
description: AMSTERDAMWHAT is a small coun try like the Nether lands doing with one ballet com pany, let alone two? Come to think of it, it has three. Why? Is ballet so madly popular here? Oddly enough, it seems not.

title: Melinda Vercini Plans Fall Wedding
description: TRUMBULL, Conn., Aug. 8Mr. and Mrs. Fred A. Vercini have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Melinda M. Vercini, to Brian Sean Noon an, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. Noonan of South port.

title: An erotic genius, Arnaud inflamed every libido but his own
description: The Cupidevil is, I think, destined to be that rare item, a ribald classic. Its author, Hu bert Monteilhet, previously known for five icy and elegant mysteries of which The Pray ing Mantises was the most celebrated, is an erotic stylist as refined as his Gallic ances tress in literary dalliance, Mar guerite of Navarre, He writes, however, no delicately androg ynous lays of ancient Rome, no Renaissance contes. Mon teilhet's scene is today, or rath er yesterday rural France just before the end of the Ger man occupation.

title: The Dispute Goes on Over Those Breakfast Cereals
description: WASHINGTONThose [dry] breakfast cereals sold in the greatest quantity are not nu tritiously superior, and in many respects are nutritionally in ferior, to many very common and much cheaper foods, such as bread, rice, beans and corn products.

title: 21% RISE REPORTED IN LOBBY SPENDING
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8Pressure groups have reported spending more than $5.1million to lobby Congress last year, an increase of 21 per cent over the 1968 total and the second high est total since 1951.

title: HORNE, MISS PANKEY ON U.S. SKATING TEAM
description: The United States Amateur Roller Skating Association's national dance champions have been certified to represent the United States in the 1970 world roller skating champion ships, next weekend in Lin icoln, Neb.

title: Complaint Agency To Assist Soldiers Opened in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) A G.I. Office to advance the cases of servicemen with com plaints against the armed serv ices has been opened in the nation's capital, Jane Fonda, the actress, and other sponsors announced today.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: MOSCOWOn another August day, 31 years ago, another Ger man Foreign Minister, Joachim von Ribbentrop, left Moscow after signing a nonaggression treaty which stunned the world. The HitlerStalin pact of 1939 created a brief detente in GermanSoviet relations. But, more important to history, it left the Germans free to plunge the world into its worst war so far.

title: British Exports To China Rise
description: LONDON, Aug. 8 (AP)British exports to Com munist China rose slightly in the first six months of this year, compared with theyear before, the SinoBritish Trade Council reports.

title: Louis G. Lower 2d Is Fiance Of Adrienne Adair Borger
description: The engagement of Miss Adrienne Adair Borger to Louis Gordon Lower 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elmer W. Lower of New York, has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William H. Borger. The wed ding will take place late next month.

title: Writers Honor Casper
description: QUINCY, Mass., Aug. 8 (AP) Billy Casper was selected to day to receive Golf Writers As sociation of America's first Bartlett Award for unselfish contributions to the betterment iof society, it was announced Rogeraby Barry, golf editor of The Quincy PatriotLedger and ipresident of the G.W.A.A.

title: Don Schollander Becomes College Swimming Coach
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 8 (AP) Don Schollander, winner of four gold medals in swimming in the 1964 Olympic Games, has been appointed coach of the swimming and water polo teams at Lewis and Clark College.

title: Magnusson Finishes First In Half Ton Cup Yacht Race
description: SANDHAMN, Sweden, Aug. 8 (AP)Joker H. sailed by Rolf Magnusson of Sweden defeated English, German and American sailors today in one phase of the Half Ton Cup yachting corn netition.

title: Landmark for the Mails
description: With passage of the new United States Postal Service Act, the 91st Congress has registered its first historic achievement, possibly excepting a votingage measure of doubtful legality. What is all the more to the credit of Congress is that the postal reform will cost it con siderably in pork, patronage and power. Yet only Representative Gross of Iowa, that most predictable of all House conservatives, complained in the end that the action had taken the Post Office away from the American people and, more pointedly, from the Congress.

title: Divorce Rights Equalized
description: LANSING. Mich., Aug. 8 (AP)Gov. William G. Milliken has signed a bill that, in effect, gives equal rights to men in divorce cases. The measure pro vides that in divorce cases the court may award alimony, child support or other payments to the husband as well as the wife.

title: Surprise! It's Your Birthday!
description: WHEN Alan Carter, founder director of the Bennington Composers Conference, was asked the other day what the BCC would be doing to celebrate its 25th anniversary season, at its annual twoweek session this month (Aug. 1630) Mr. Carter was taken by surprise.

title: Trinidad Cyclist Sets Pace In TriCity Carolina Race
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Aug. 8 (AP)  Patrick Gellineau, 18 years old, of Trinidad averaged 30 to 35 miles an hour today to lead the pack in the 118mile first leg of the South Carolina Tricentennial TriCity Olympic bicycle race.

title: A. S. Fox Weds Nancy Neilson
description: MALVERNE, L. I., Aug. 9 Miss Nancy Elizabeth Neil son, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Neilson, was married here today to Abijah Shawhan Fox, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abijah Upson Fox of Greenwich, Conn. The noon ceremony was performed in the Community Presbyterian Church by the Rev. A. David Bos of the National Experi mental Ministry in Smith town.

title: Nancy Lomenzo Wed in Rochester
description: ROCHESTER, Aug. 8Miss Nancy Jane Lomenzo, daugh ter of John P. Lomenzo, New York Secretary of State, and Mrs. Lomenzo, was married here this morning to Peter Edward Muller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Muller Jr. Msgr. Leslie G. Whalen per formed the ceremony at a nuptial mass in Our Lady of Lourdes Roman Catholic Church.

title: Former Press Secretary Details Bitter JohnsonWirtz Battle
description: On Oct. 24, 1968, two weeks before the national elections, President Johnson demanded, and received, the resignation of Labor Secretary W. Willard Wirtz in a bitter disagreement over policy matters, including Vietnam, according to a forth coming book by George Chris tian, who was then Mr. John son's Press secretary.

title: Beard, Shaw Share Akron Lead at 205
description: AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 8With a flash of phenomenal putting today Frank Beard tied Tom Shaw for the 54hole lead in the $150,000 American Golf Classic. Using only 10 putts on the last nine, Beard, who was last year's leading moneywin ner on the circuit, scored a 67 over the Firestone Country Club course this afternoon for an aggregate of 205.

title: Revolt of Priests in Guatemala Against Archbishop Collapses
description: GUATEMALA, Aug. 8A monthold open rebellion of native Guatemalan priests against the authority of their Spanishborn Roman Catholic Archbishop, Mario Cardinal Ca sariego, collapsed this week as most of the rebels recanted.

title: STUDY OF HOUSING PAINTS GRIM VIEW
description: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 8The outlook for residential housing construction in West chester is even more grim than its present state of decline, ac cording to a study prepared for the county's Department of Planning.

title: Twice Worthy 4Length Victor And Shatters Monmouth Mark
2 Whites Are Seized By Black Prisoners In Tombs Incident
description: Two white prisoners were held hostage for more than an hour yesterday by about 30 black fellow inmates of the Manhattan House of Detention. The black prisoners were de manding the return of a Negro prisoner who had been removed from the floor after he alleged ly struck a guard.

title: APARTHEID FOUGHT BY PART OF PRESS
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af ricaEveryday there is some protest in the press here against racial discrimination and the loss of citizens rights. Every day there is some de nunciation of the horrors and absurdities of apartheid, the Government's racial segrega tion policy.

title: AID TO CONSUMERS GROWING IN NATION
description: American consumers victim ized by shoddy goods, unhonor ed warranties and cutthroat credit are finding that state and local governments are starting to take an active interest in their troubles.

title: Fire in City Court Building
description: A fire broke out on the 15th floor of the Criminal Court Building at 100 Centre Street yesterday afternoon, causing slight damage to records of court appearances the Fire De partment reported., The fire was believed to have been started by a dropped cigarette.

title: Leaders in Akron Golf
Toward a Political Renaissance
description: Selfgovernment thrives on the political vitality of individual citizens. Democracy cannot be left to those inevitable participants, the economic interest groups and the political careerists. If ordinary men and women do not care enough about some communitywhether it be their own neighborhood or their nation or the great globe itselfto band together in new organiza tions determined to cut through the routines and the apathy, then selfgovernment will slowly wither and ultimately die.

title: New Jersey Bank Closed; $3Million Reported Gone
description: EATONTOWN, N. J., Aug. 8The Eatontown National Bank has been declared insolvent and closed indefinitely following a, report of an embezzlement estimated at $3million to $5million.

title: Mrs. Neff and Stepson In Semifinals in Sailing
description: Mrs. W. Perry Neff of Cen ter Island, L. I., and her step son, Terry, will start sailing for qualifying places in North American title events in sep arate competitions on Tues day.

title: 95% of Those Reported Jailed In South Africa Are Black
description: CAPETOWN, Aug. 8On an average day from mid1968 to mid1969, there were more than 88,000 prisoners in South Africa's jails, according to a Government report on the prison service.

title: Marian Rian Bride of Lieutenant
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 8 Miss Marian Edwina Rian was married here this morn ing to 2d Lieut. Brian Joseph Hays U.S.M.C., in the Miller Chapel of Princeton Theo logical Seminary.

title: NEW STUDY FIELD: POLICY SCIENCES
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., Aug. 8A new scholarly journal and a growing number of graduate degree programs mark the emergence of a recognized academic specialty based in large part on the problemsolv ing, decisionmaking and fore casting techniques pioneered by the nation's think tank re search institutions.

title: If That's Your Attitude, That's That, I Guess
description: AT the Brooklyn Museum just now (and until Oct. 1), you may see as exhibition called Attitudes, sponsored by the museum's art school, for what reason is not clear un less it is to demonstrate to art students that they should think twice before commit trig themselves to a way of life in which the main ac tivity seems to be treading water. This, I am sure, was not the thesis that the ex hibition set out to develop, but it is the only one that Can be deduced from the re sults.

title: Yale, With 634 Victories, Leads List of College Football Winners
FEW BROWNOUTS SO FAR THIS YEAR
description: So far this summer New Yorkers and some of their New England neighbors have been the only ones exposed to elec tric power brownouts that had been widely forecast for the eastern half of the nation.

title: Chiefs Defeat Lancers, 30
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 8 (UPI)The Atlanta Chiefs won their third straight North American Soccer League game tonight, downing the Rochester Lancers, 30. The loss was Rochester's second in its last seven games.

title: Marriage Held For Ruth Gibbs
description: CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., Aug.  Miss Ruth Ann Sutton Gibbs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Gibbs of Ossi ning, was married here this afternoon to Richard Harold Becker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold G. Becker of Juneau, Wis.

title: Weekend Commuters Take Wing
description: IT WAS EARLY in the season and Verlyn Geriene, the pilot of the Pelham Airways seaplane, wasn't sure of the exact location of our community on Fire Island.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The city is moving toward the elimination of a legal snag that has blocked for ward progress on 12 apart ment construction projects in Manhattan.

title: Aviation Student Is Sued Over Crash in the Rockies
description: FORT COLLINS, Colo., Aug. 8. A New York aviation stu dent, who crashed Monday at the base of the Colorado Rockies after his plane was caught in a down draft, now faces a complicated legal battle.

title: Twins Down A's, 31, on Reese's 2Run Homer and Increase Division Lead
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 8 (AP)The Minnesota Twins widened their lead in the West Division of the American League to nine games today by defeat ing the Oakland A's, 31, Rich Reese's tworun homer in the second sparked the victory.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Israeli soldiers along the Suez Canal were able to stand up and look directly at the Egyptian town of Ismailia for the first time in more than a year yesterday as the fight ing between the countries was halted in the first day of a 90day ceasefire. A pat tern of random shellings and terrorism across Israel showed, however, that Pales tinian guerrillas were not honoring the ceasefire. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Motorcycle Racing Unit Names March Director
description: Russell E. March has been named executive director of the American Motorcycle As sociaticm. The announcement of the appointment was made by the A.M.A. pres ident, William Bagnall, from his offices in Los Angeles.

title: In the Sports Editor's Mailbox
description: Tinker, Evers, Chance

title: STUDY QUESTIONS METHADONE USE
description: A professor at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, employing a computer to sug gest ways to attack heroin ad diction, reports that metha donedespite its successes and growing popularityis not by itself going to become the solu tion to the city's drugabuse problem.

title: Leary Strengthens Force As Midtown Thefts Rise
description: Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary has ordered a unit of the Tactical Patrol Force to augment existing patrols in the midtown area.

title: Curfew Lifted in Ohio
description: LIMA, Ohio, Aug. 8 (UPI)Mayor Christian Morris lifted a dusktodawn curfew today, but continued a state of civil emergency because of racial troubles. Officials said 43 per sons were arrested last night, bringing to 78 the number of arrests made during three nights of disorders.

title: Mideast 3: Israel Agonizes Over Map Of Peace
description: JERUSALEMThere's at least one wag at Israeli social gather ings these days who suggests some quick tourism around the Israelioccupied West Bank re gion of Jordan  because we might not have it much longer.

title: Ann Arbor Blues Festival Opens on Note of Contrast
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Aug. 8 The lure of the blues brought more than 8,000 persons to the opening concert of the three day Ann Arbor Blues Festival last night. The audience was predominantly young and pre dominantly white, in contrast to the performers who were, almost without exception, black and in their forties, fifties and sixties.

title: Letters:
description: To THE FINANCIAL EDITOR:

title: Office Queen Registers HalfLength Victory in $57,500 Liberty Bell Race
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 8 Office Queen made her owner's trip here from Florida worth while today by winning the $57,500 Cotillion Handicap for 3yearold fillies by half a length from Ellen Girl. Fast Attack was another halflength back in the 10horse field at Liberty Bell Race Track.

title: Tennis Ball of Confusion
description: Events of the last few weeks have obscured rather than illuminated the path of professional tennis to big league status.

title: Klecatsky Scores a Double in Rowing
description: Dr. Larry Klecatsky of the United States Navy scored his 31st and 32d victories of the season yesterday on the Or chard Beach lagoon rowing course.

title: Countdown
description: Well, here's another crisis to worry about: a corrupt space program. Spaceport City, Flo ridian home base of the Pegas us Project, is such an incuba tor for human frailty it's a marvel anything ever gets launched.

title: Reader's Report
description: The sweet affluence that has allegedly been swaddling America for the past decade never quite stretched to the Cumberland Mountains of east ern Kentucky. Here, the hard life of coal mining families has been made harder by di minishing markets, automation and endemic unemployment. Mr. Burke takes these, harsh facts and brings them to life in a surging, bitter novel as authentic as moonshine.

title: Eugene M. McCarthy, 70, Dies; Former Judge of the Civil Court
description: Eugene M. McCarthy, who re red last year as a Judge of the city Civil Court, died Friday in his home at 140 Seventh Avenue at the age of 70.

title: WINNERS NAMED IN COLISEUM SHOW
description: Ten artists were declared winners yesterday at the New York International Art Show, which opened at the Coliseum on Aug. 1. But it was a moot question if they would receive any money.

title: SUEZ FRONT QUIET ON THE FIRST DAY OF MIDEAST TRUCE
description: OPPOSITE ISMAILIA, Israeli Occupied Sinai, Aug. 8The ar tillery was silent and the skies were clear or combat aircraft today, on the first day of the ceasefire in the war of attri tion along the Suez Canal.

title: MARINE TEAM WINS CAMP PERRY SHOOT
description: CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 8 (AP)The Marines, the Army Red team and the Rabbits, A junior team, fired identical scores in the small bore rifle prone competition today, but the Marines won by hitting more xrings.

title: Three Pianists Who Avoid Ruts
description: IF MORE pianists shared Grant Johannesen's curi osity about the piano rep ertory, his catholicity of taste and his willingness to apply his time and talents. to the promulgation of music that lies off the rutted track of most recital and record ing fare, the public might possibly evince a bit more interest in piano recitals and records than it is showing just now.

title: Chiefs Down Lions, 3017
description: DETROIT, Aug. 8 (AP)Kansas City scored three touchdowns on pass intercep tions in the second half, en route to a 3017 victory over the Detroit Lions tonight.

title: 1,000 MARCH HERE IN BOMB PROTEST
description: About 1,000 people, many of them teenagers or in their early 20's, marched up Broad way and Seventh Avenue yes terday in a No More Hiro shimas parade.

title: Bulls Are Striving To Bolster Attack For Knights Game
description: Allan Webb, the new head coach of the Long Island Bulls, is seeking a guard, tackle and pass receiver to bolster his of fensive unit as the Bulls gird for their opening Atlantic Coast Football League exhibition against the Hartford Knights, Northern Division champions at Hartford next Saturday night.

title: Rangers Turn Back Dunfermline, 41, in Scottish League Soccer Cup Opener
description: LONDON, Aug. 8 (Reuters)Colln Stein, the Rangers star center forward, scored the first goal of the Scottish Football season today, two minutes after the start of the Rangers League Cup match against bunfermline Athletic.

title: Gretchen Elsa Lundgren Is a Bride
description: ATTLEBORO, Mass., Aug. 8In the Evangelical Cove nant Church here today Miss Gretchen Elsa Lund gren, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Arnold Lundgren of Attleboro and Falmouth, was married to Alexander Inger soll Lewis 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Ingersoll Lewis Jr. of Grosse Pointe, Mich.

title: 11 Specialty Shows Listed
description: Eleven breed clubs will hold specially shows at the West chester Kennel Club fixture in Croton Point Park, Crotonon Hudson, Sept. 6. The breeds that will be seen are Weimaran ers, boxers, Dobermans, Great Danes, Shelties, Kerry blues, Manchester terriers, Brussels griffons, Italian greyhounds, standard schnauzers and Pekingese.

title: BREWERS SCORE OVER ROYALS, 53
description: KANSAS CITY, Aug. 8 (UPI) Ted Savage hit a tworun homer in the third inning to night to help the Milwaukee Brewers break a fivegame los ing streak with a 53 victory over the Kansas City Royals.

title: Friedman to Fight. Old Pros Exclusion From Pension Plan
description: BLAIR, Neb., Aug. 8 (AP)The National Football League Players Association displayed brashness and arrogance be yond belief by not including pre1958 players in the pension benefits negotiated with team owners, according to an old pro, Benny Friedman.

title: Make Some Room For the Iris
description: THE idea of transplant ing perennials in the middle of summer may seem a bit odd, but some plants respond best then. Bearded irises do. Though irises are likely to sur vive transplanting any time between April Fool's Day and Columbus Day, the most fa vorable time is during July and August.

title: Dutch Babe Ruth Loop Nine To Visit Cooperstown Today
description: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 8 (UPI)  The dutch Babe Ruth League team, coming to the United States to participate in a tournament at Wellington, Kan., will visit Cooperstown tomor row to play an exhibition game and tour the national baseball hall of fame.

title: 33d Floor Feud: Elliman's Version Given in a Letter
description: A number of persons have queried us for an explaria ton of a dispute between tenants in a building at 444 East 82d Street formerly managed by Douglas L. Elli man & Co., Inc. for Winston Holzer Corporation. The dis pute, which took place over a period of time in the late summer and fall of 1967 and the winter of 1968 involved two tenants who lived across the hall from each other in the highrise luxury apart ment building: Sanford Soco low, producer of the Walter Cronkite Show for CBSTV, who lived in Apartment 33A, and his neighbor, Herbert Kaye, who lived in Apart ment 33B.

title: Canadian Christmas
description: TWELVE stamps will take note of Christ mas this year in Can ada, according to Eric Kierans, Minister of Commun ications. They will be based on designs by children who participated in a. design con test in which approximately 50,000 entries were received. There will be the usual 5cent and 6cent stamps, which are primarily for domestic let ters and cards, but to this will be added 10cent and 15cent stamps for use on packages and international airmail.

title: Namath to Return to Jets If They Grant Big Loan
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 8 Joe, Namath's return to the New York Jets will depend on the club granting his request for a big loan to resolve his financial problems. But even if the Jets president, Philip J. Iselin, agrees to provide the money, will it repurchase the quarterback's competitive fire? Namath has stated that I don't want to play football. Will a temporarily solvent finan cial situation really alter his thinking?

title: Perkins Stops Tsujimoto
description: TOKYO, Aug. 8 (AP)Ed die Perkins, a former world junior welterweight boxing champion, scored a technical knockout today over Hidemori Tsujimoto, Japan's No. 3 junior lightweight. in the last round of a 10round nontitle Perkins weighed 142 4/5 pounds, Tsujimoto 143.

title: SELFHELP URGED ON POORER LANDS
description: A selfhelp program for poor er countries, designed to reduce dependence on outside assist ance personnel in the develop ment of natural resources, has been proposed in a United Nations report.

title: Drifting Down Arkansas Rivers, Business Barons Become Huck Finns
description: CALICO ROCK, Ark.They come from such farflung points as Santa Barbara and Baltimoresometimes in expensive private planesto loll in little, flat bottomed boats drifting aimlessly down the clean mountain rivers of Arkansas, as their fathers did when hard times made Huck Finning in the Ozarks the only vacation many Arkansans could afford.

title: Miss Shipley Wed To J.R. Downey Jr.
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., Aug. 8Miss Susan Jean Shipley, daughter .of Mr. and Mrs. Morgan Bowman Shipley Jr., was married in St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church here today to James Russell Downey Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Downey of McLean, Va.

title: Pay for State Legislators Is Up 538% Since 1950
description: KANSAS CITY, Aug. 8 (AP) State legislators in the 20 years since 1950 have seen an increase of 538.8 per cent in their compensation, a study by the Citizens Conference on State Legislatures shows.

title: Bessie Smith Grave, Unmarked Since'37, Finally Gets a Stone
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 8 (AP) Janis Joplin, the bluesrock singer, and Juanita Green, a registered nurse from Philadel phia shared the cost of a stone for the Empress of the Blues, whose grave lay un marked for more than 30 years.

title: Cigar Settles Court Case
description: MISSOULA, Mont. Aug. 8 (AP)  Lynn O'Brien, Pine Grove, Mont., paid a Missoula parking ticket with a cigarand the judge dismissed the violation. Mr. O'Brien was given a parking ticket while waiting insde a Missoula hos pital for his daughter, Darcy Lynn, to be born. He wrapped the cigar in the ticket en velope and mailed it to Police Court along with Darcy's weight and measurements. The judge dismissed the violation.

title: SCHOLARS DEBATE JEWISH TENSIONS
description: REHOVOT, Israel, Aug. 8The tension between the uni versal and the particular in Jewish religion, culture and pialitics evoked debate and some agreement this week among a group or American Jewish and Israeli intellectuals at the Weizmann Institute.

title: C. J. Dodd, Son of the Senator, Marries Miss Susan Mooney
description: WILMETTE, Ill., Aug. 8St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church was the set ting here this morning for the marriage of Miss Susan Mooney, a former speech writer and legislative aide on the staff of Senator Thomas J. Dodd of Con necticut, to the Senator's son, Christopher John Dodd.

title: New and Recommended
description: FICTION

title: Problem Of a Fair Trial for Manson
description: LOS ANGELESAfter Presi dent Nixon made his statement last week that Charles Manson was guilty, directly or in directly, of eight murders, a local writer mused: With Cam bodia and the economy and everything else he's got to worry about, why was Nixon reading about Manson anyway?

title: Theodorakis in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 8 (AP)Mikis Theodorakis, the Greek, composer, arrived today in Moscow with his family. The Soviet press agency Tass said he had been invited for rest and medical treatment. Mr. Theodorakis, who has been re ported ill with tuberculosis, was recently released from a Greek prison.

title: Army Wins Tennis Event
description: SAN ANTONIO. Tex., Aug. 8 (AP)Army tennis players de feated their Air Force counter parts, 471, today to win the Leech ('up tram championship trophy in the final of the All Service tournament.

title: City's Offtrack Betting Unit Selects Computer Installer
description: Howard J. Samuels, chairman of the New York City Offtrack Betting Corporation, announced yesterday the selection of the Computer Sciences Corporation to develop and install an off track betting computer system.

title: Growing Fight for Access to The TV Soap Box
description: WASHINGTONWho gets to use television? Almost every body would like to, but only one man, the President, is as sured of the chance and even that is by courtesy, not right.

title: Ecuador, Colombia Play Soccer Today At Randalls Island
description: New Yorkers of South Amer ican origin can celebrate Ecua dorian Independence Day at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island this afternoon when the Barcelona Soccer Club of Ecua dor meets Deportivo Cali, the soccer champions of Colombia. The game is slated to get under way at 4 o'clock.

title: Singlemindedness, new beginningsand fate
description: I cannot commend this account of Richard Nixon's political comeback as an inspiration to the young, but I do urge it upon those mature read ers who wish to ponder the uses of duplicity in Presidential politics.

title: Mayor Church of New Rochelle Marries Mrs. Rita D. Bobbing
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Aug. 8Mayor Stanley W. Church and Mrs. Rita Diehl Bobbing, widow of Ernest J. Bobbing, a developer of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., were mar ried here this afternoon in the Christ United Methodist Church. The Rev. Arthur G. Bareon officiated.

title: Arab Armies Hold Fire On the Eastern Fronts
description: AMMAN. Jordan, Aug. 8Arab armies here on Israel's eastern front held their fire today as the IsraeliEgyptian truce went into force. There was no sign of the threatened intensification of commando raids against the Israelis.

title: SHORT OF RELIES SUBDUES CUBS, 63
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 8 (UPI)  Stone drove in three runs with a pair of singles today as the Philadelphia Phillies scored a 63 victory over the Chicago Cubs behind the sixhit pitching of Chris Short.

title: Gunmen Kill a Bar Patron And Wound a 2d in Passaic
description: PASSAIC, N. J., Aug. 8 (UPI) One man was killed and an other was shot in the hip today as four gunmen terrorized and robbed patrons of a bar, then escaped in a car driven by an accomplice. The police said late today that the suspects were, still at large.

title: Hyphenated Americans in old Philadelphia
description: Perhaps Tom McHale is an expriest or exseminarian. Perhaps he was formerly married to or in love with an Italian girl. Maybe, in terms of the very interesting, funny, morbid and ethnic novel about Philadelphia morticians, Italians, bogIrish, priests, blacks and nuns that he has written, this is merely two ways of saying the same thing. Ethnic must go in quotes because just recently a society to defend hyphenated Americans (the phrase is Woodrow Wilson's), espe cially Polishand Italo, against racist slurs was founded and held its first conference. The lady in charge calls us all ethnics. This reminds me of two things: a) Whatever became of the Italian American antidefamation society that Sinatra founded in the early 1960's? Or, to introduce a direct quotation from a McHale character, Aunt Lucrezia, Whatever happened to the simple wops of yore? b) What ever became of Henry James?

title: Judith Costello Wed To James R. Bedell
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 8 Miss Judith Anne Miriamne Costello and James Robert Bedell were married here this afternoon in the Roman Cath olic Church of St. Anne. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John J. Wiest, pastor of St. Mary's Parish in Manhasset.

title: Textile Pact Set
description: TOKYO, Aug. 8 (UPI)The Toray Company, one of Japan's leading textile con cerns, has announced it has concluded a tieup agreement with the Angelica Uniform Company of the United States for production and sales of work uniforms. The Angelica Uniform Company is said to be the largest uniform maker in the United States with annual sales of about $52.8 million.

title: PRO STARS TO MEET IN BENEFIT SEPT. 3
description: Stars of both the American Basketball Association and Na tional Basketball Association will battle one another on Sept. 3, at St. John's University gymnasium in a game spon sored by the Jamaica Chamber of Commerce.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Mystery authors sometimes use a character from one series in another. It's a ploy I find attractivemuch like encoun tering an old friend in an un expected place. In Frances and Richard Lockridge's 1958 Cap tain Heimrich adventure Ac cent on Murder, a perceptive professor of English named Walter Brinkley gave the Cap tain a few bits of crucial lay assistance. Now, having achieved retirement and the publication of his magnum opus on regional accents, Dr. Brinkley walks into a murder case that becomes the special preserve of Bernie Simmons of, the New York D.A.'s office in Richard Lockridge's TWICE RETIRED (Lippincott, $4.95).

title: BOARDWALK LAW PUT OFF IN JERSEY
description: OCEAN CITY, N. J.When a boardwalk pavilion that has long been a resting spot for the elderly became a hangout for hippies here the city's solution was simple: close the pavilion.

title: Carl. J. Schmidlapp 3d Weds Phyllis F. Rowley
description: SOUTHPORT, Conn., Aug. 8  Miss Phyllis Farmer Rowley and Carl Jacob Schmidlapp 3d were married here this afternoon at Trin ity Episcopal Church. The Rev. Francis X. Cheney offi ciated.

title: Brooklyn Youth, 19, Seized As Illegal Subway Operator
description: A 19yearold Brooklyn youth was arrested yesterday for allegedly operating a subway train unlawfully in the Coney Island BMT yards, the police reported.

title: Tremors Rock Iran Villages
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 8 (Reu ters)Two earth tremors rocked villages early today near the Bujnurd region of northeastern Iran where 175 persons were killed, 500 injured and 10,000 left homeless in an earthquake July 30.

title: LAYER AND ROCHE GAIN TENNIS FINAL
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 8How can Rod Laver improve, you say? What more is left for the little redhaired Rocket aft er two grand slams, over $100, 000 in money winnings, and countless commercial endorse ments?

title: Sarah Battenhouse Wed to Paul Bonjour
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 8.Miss Sarah Lorinda Battenhouse, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Paul F. Battenhouse of Wethersfield, was married here this afternoon to Paul Frederick Bonjour, son of Mr. & Mrs. Ernest F. Bonjour of Portace. Mich.

title: Advertising:
description: When Max B. Pearlman started his own agency short ly after World War II, there was a paucity of clients and an equal paucity of money in the till. So to supplement his income, he became a part time teacher of advertising at Pace College and later New York University.

title: Pollution Hearings to Resume
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (UPI) Senator Philip A. Hart, Demo crat of Michigan, said today that a Senate environment sub committee would resume hear ings Aug. 26 and 27 on poi sonous water pollution. The subcommittee of which Senator Hart is chairman, heard testi mony last week on a recent in crease in the level of mercury in various rivers and lakes.

title: Dr. Fager Stakes Won By Willmar in Florida
description: MIAMI, Aug. 8 (AP)The Tartan Stables heavily fa vored Willmar took the lead approaching the halfmile pole today and staved off a hid by Papago to win the Dr. Pager Stakes by a length at Tropical Park. The race was named for the Tartan Stables great horse, now in stud.

title: Rock Fetes Draw 250,000 to Ontario And Michigan Area
description: More than 250,000 young people rocked along yesterday as the halfway point of the weekend rock festivals at Goose Lake, Mich:, and Mosport, Ont., passed with relatively few prob lems.

title: New Kidnapping In Uruguay
description: Winter rains pelted the Uru guyan capital of Montevideo last week as the Government's cam paign against a band of urban guerillas calling themselves the Tupamaros reached a new pitch of intensity. The latest events began a week ago Friday with the kidnapping by the Tupamaros of Dan A. Mitrione, an adviser to Uruguyan police employed by the United States Agency for Inter national Development. The same day the Tupamaros kidnapped Aloysio Mares Dias Gomide, a Brazilian consul. Then, last Friday, another American, soil expert Claude Fly, was kidnapped ann held hostage. The Tupamaros threated to kill the hostages un less the Government freed about 150 political prisoners.

title: Mining Ocean Floor: A New Metal Source?
description: GLOUCESTER POINT, Va. Out in the Atlantic the other day, in about 3,000 feet of water and about 120 miles east of Charleston, S.C., a converted cargo vessel dropped a string of nineinch diameter steel pipe to the ocean floor. Operating some what like a vacuum cleaner, it began to suck into the ship a thundering stream of air, water and nodulessmooth, applesized lumpsof rich metallic ore.

title: Frugal Consumers Expected to Shift
description: Consumer sentiment, which holds the balance between prosperity and recession, may be shifting toward a renewal of spending for most types of merchandise.

title: McElhenny, Fears, Pihos and Christiansen Join Pro. Football Hall of Fame
description: CANTON, Ohio, Aug 8His voice cracking with emotion, Hugh McElhenny said at his induction into the pro football Hall of Fame today, I want to pay tribute to the athletes that I played with for their second efforts which made my runs successful and to my opponents for all the mistakes they made to make me look good.

title: Hayes Jones Keeping Active in Track
description: When Hayes Jones decided to retire from track and field six years ago, he didn't just hang up his spikes, he gave them away.

title: The Fight Against MS
description: Multiple sclerosis, a disease of the nervous system caused by a destruction of the myelin sheath of the nerves, afflicts 500,000 Americans. The term, with its aura of the unknown, is terrifying to the victims, their families and their friends. The cause is not known, and there is no specific treatment.

title: 3 HIJACK AIRCRAFT IN CZECHOSLOVAKIA
description: VIENNA, Aug. 8 (AP)Three men hijacked a Czechoslovak airliner today and forced the pilot to land at Vienna's Schwe chat Airport, the police re ported.

title: Four Undefeated Skippers Clinch Sailing Titles
description: BABYLON, L. I., Aug. 8The list of undefeated skippers corn peting in the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's Race Week championship se ries was reduced to five today, four of whom clinched series titles. The series ends tomorrow.

title: HOFSTRA TRYING TO REDUCE DEFICIT
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 8Hofstra University is trying to raise funds from its alumni in a massive phonathon and the Bell Telephone system couldn't he happier.

title: CITY COUNCIL GETS WATCHDOG GROUPS
description: A burgeoning government that more and more is running unbridled and unchecked will be scrutinized by a reorganized City. Council, Thomas J. Cuite, the local legislature's majority leader, announced yesterday.

title: Races for Under2Liter Cars In TransAm Go Unheralded
description: One of the liveliest series of races these days is run ning almost anonymously, and that's a pity. The under 2liter class of the Trans American Championship de serves more attention. The principal difficulty is that the U2 cars are overshadowed by the larger TransAmerican machines, those of the Mustang Camaro Javelin class. Usually U2's race on the same day as the 02 cars. While such pro gramming pinches press coverage, it does not dimin ish spectators enjoyment. The next TransAm in this neighborhood is scheduled for next Sunday, a double header at Watkins Glen in upstate New York.

title: California Skipper Takes 2 Races in 18Footer Sail
description: LONG BEACH, Calif. Aug. 8 (AP)Roger Welsch of New port Beach, Calif., took a com manding lead today by winning both races in the twoday Aus tralian 18footer international challenge sailing regatta.

title: Close Call
description: When Mrs. George Romney announced that she would run in Michigan's Republican primary for a Senate seat, her supporters predicted she would be a shooin. She was well known because of her husband's prestige as a former Michigan Governor and now Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. Her campaign was liberally financed, her photogenic face looked out on the state from scores of billboards, and her theme was, Never before has the voice and understanding of a concerned woman been more needed. But last week she just squeaked through to victory over Robert J. Huber, a relatively unknown conservative State Senator. Charges of bossism and a lackluster cam paign were generally cited as reasons for Lenore RorrineY's close call. As for her coming race against the Democratic incumbent. Philip A. Hart, Mrs. Romney said it's going to be tough.

title: Development Loans Made With Care
description: In the growing variety of development loans being made by the World Bank, one may ask, how are the feasibility and operating success of projects assured: for palm plantations in New Guinea to schools in Colombia?

title: Connoisseurs cakes
description: The origins of the cakes on this page have about as much in com mon as a tropical beach, Hamlet's mother and a Manhattan tower. One is, in fact, from Trinidad, another is Danish and the third comes straight from East 62d Street, Manhattan. But they do share certain characteristics: they are given a liquid glaze while hot they are delectable in flavor and texture, and they are from the collection of Maida Heatter, the celebrated food expert of Miami Beach. Further more, the New York cake was created by her daughter, Toni Marks.

title: Goldenrod Month
description: The season's first goldenrod is in bloom and, un happily, so is the ragweed. The two plants, one a beautiful plume of sunbright blossoms, the other a nondescript head of tiny greenish flowers whose only distinction is their allergenic pollen, often grow side by side. The botanical name of goldenrod is Solidago, which means to heal or to make whole. The rag weed's botanical name is Ambrosia, which must be either irony or a grim joke.

title: Illegal Charter Flights Still Thriving
description: A huge illegal travel indus try that grosses tens of mil lions of dollars a year by op erating illegal charter flights to Europe is continuing to thrive despite two major Government crackdowns this year.

title: Peru Institutes Code for Industry
description: LIMA, Peru, Aug. 8The Peruvian military regime raced along its revolutionary new path between capital ism and communism last week and decreed the most radical industrial operations code since the Castro take over in Cuba.

title: Growing Pains for TieBreaker
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 8Players de test it and threaten mass walkouts; specta tors are divided and undecided; umpires are taking crash courses to learn its rules; ref erees are relieved about marathon matches, and tournament directors wonder whether it is the answer to their promotional pray ers or the start of another Excedrin head ache.

title: Reds Rout Dodgers, 105, as Perez Bats In 6 Runs With 2 Homers and Single
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 8 (UPI) Tony Perez batted in six runs With two homers and a single today as the Cincinnati Reds hit five home runs to trounce the Los Angeles Dodgers, 105.

title: Panel's Draft Urges Liberal Pornography Laws
description: WASHINGTON. Aug. 8 (AP) Pornography laws for the United States that would be nearly as liberal as Denmark's are among the draft recom mendations of the President's Commission on Obscenity and Pornography.

title: Mrs. James L. Hamill 3d Is Remarried
description: BEDFORD, N. Y., Aug 8Mrs. Sarah Richardson Hamill of Coatesville, Pa., widow of James Lyon Hamill 3d, was married here this afternoon to Philip Axel Litchfield of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Robert C. Schrock of the Pound Ridge Community Church performed the cere mony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Roger S. Coolidge, brotherinlaw and sister of the bridegroom.

title: Miss Joan Rosen To Marry Jan. 9
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin E. Rosen of Brook lyn of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Mae Rosen, to David Michael Hoffer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Hoffer of Liberty, N. Y., and nephew of Mrs. Jennie Grossinger, chairman of Grossinger's Hotel.

title: Letters: A Chilly Chinese Reception
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Leila jahncke Is Fiancee Of Henry B. Pickering
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 8 The engagement of Miss Leila Dickerman Jahncke to Henry Benson Pickering of Kennebunkport, Me., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Lee Jahncke Jr. Her fianc is the son of John Pickering 9th of Ogunquit, Me., and the late Mrs. Ruth Benson Pickering.

title: COUPLE LEADING BRIDGE TOURNEY
Gary Bayne Weds Mary L. Baldwin
description: GARRISON, N. Y., Aug. 8 Miss Mary Ludwell Bald win, daughter of Mrs. William Ludwell Baldwin and the late Mr. Baldwin, was married here this afternoon to Gary Gresham Bayne, son of Rear Adm. Marmaduke Gresham Bayne, U.S.N., commander of the Middle East Force, and Mrs. Bayne of Norfolk, Va., and Bahrein, Persian Gulf.

title: HOAD, AT 35, EYES FOREST HILLS NET
description: Lew Hoad, the 35yearold Australian coach of the Span ish Davis Cup team, will be among the sentimental favor ites competing in the $160,000 United States Open tennis championships at Forest Hills, Sent. 2 through 13.

title: The First Family Of Conservatism
description: SHARON, Conn.

title: New Canons For the Sitting Judge
description: ST. LOUISThe Chief Jus tices of the 50 state Supreme Courts sat in rapt attention Thursday morning, nodding approvingly as a short, grandfatherly man stood be fore them and laid down the law. What a judge does with his time while he is not on the bench is of great in terest to the public, he said. It is absolutely necessary that the clear light of day should illuminate any offthe bench activity by a judgeand particularly, any money he makes off of it.

title: Rouzhriders Triumph. 2322
description: HAMILTON, Ontario, Aug. 8 (Canadian Press)  The Sas katchewan Roughriders rallied tonight to defeat the Hamilton TigerCats, 2322. Silas McKin ney combined with the quarter back, Ron Lancaster, on a 91 yard pass play in the final quarter to tie the game. Jack Abenshan's conversion provided point edge.

title: SALMONELLA DEATHS BRING AN INSPECTION
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 8 (UPI)An inspection of all of Balti more's 43 nursing homes for possible cases of salmonella poisoning began today follow ing areport of a possible sal monellarelated death at a third nursing home in the city.
