EQUAL RIGHTS PLAN FOR WOMEN VOTED BY HOUSE, 35015
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 The House of Representatives, by the overwhelming vote of 350 to 15, passed today a con stitutional amendment prohibit ing discrimination on the basis of sex.

title: Disease in Scout's Death Called Noncontagious
description: CIMARRON, N. M., Aug. 10 (UPI)  Dr. Eugene Mariani of the New Mexico Health and Social Services Depart ment said today that James Morris, 12 years old, of Jack son, Mich., died last week of fulminating staphylococcus pneumonia. He said it was not communicable to Scouts who were with him when he died.

title: Thurmond Stopped by Police
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) Senator Strom Thurmond, Republican of South Carolina, was stopped by a District of Columbia policeman today af ter a 16block chase allegedly precipitated when the Senator drove through a red light. Sen ator Thurmond's office issued a statement asserting that the Senator ran no red light noting that he was not given a ticket.

title: U.S. OFFICIAL FEARS CON ED EXPANSION
description: The top Federal airpollution control official said yesterday that it would be imprudent to allow expansion of Con solidated Edison's plant in As toria, Queens, because of the contamination that it would add to the city's air.

title: Dempsey Gets Liquidator; Blair Sells All Branches
description: The liquidation of another major brokerage house was an nounced yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange, which said a liquidator had been pointed in the failure of Demp seyTegeler & Co.

title: United Parcel Strike Is Ended By Lifting of Ban on Flag Pins
description: A teamster strike against the United Parcel Service, started by a dispute over the wearing of various lapel but tons, was ended last night, a union spokesman announced.

title: Metal Makers Join Price Moves
description: For the second time in a month, the St. Joe Minerals Corporation said yesterday that it would cut the price of lead reluctantly. Once again, St. Joe was following a move, which it called un justified, that was initiated by the American Smelting and Refining Company.

title: Thousands of Dead Fish Found on Beaches Here
description: Thousands of dead men haden, one of the most plen tiful and commercially valu able fish of the Atlantic Coast, were found yesterday washed up on beaches bor dering Long Island Sound, from Orchard Beach to Port Washington.

title: RED SOX TRIUMPH OVER TIGERS, 1110
description: BOSTON, Aug. 10 (AP) Billy and Tony Conigliaro, Bos ton!s slugging brothers, led the Red Sox to an 1110 victory over Detroit today despite a sevenrun rally by the Tigers in the ninth.

title: Students Vote Reparations
description: ST. PAUL, Aug. 10 (UPI) The National Student Associa tion voted today to pay the National Association of Black Students $50,000 for repara tions promised at last year's N.S.A. Congress. The vote by bout 500 delegates to this year's congress was over whelmingly for assessing each of the N.S.A.'s more than 500 Nember schools $100 each to pay the $50,000.

title: OVERHAUL OF R.O.T.C. URGED BY 16 IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) Sixteen Republicans in the House proposed today the vir tual removal of the Reserve Of ficer Training Corps from col lege campuses to improve the program and help cool volatile student antimilitarism.

title: Hayward Keniston Dead at 87; Former Dean at U. of Michigan
description: Hayward Keniston, former dean of the University of Michigan College of Literature, Science and the Ants, died yes terday at a nursing home in Yarmouth, Nova Scotia. He was 87 years old.

title: Silk Shipments Reported
description: Silk shipments in July totaled 588 bales of 133 pounds each, against 466 bales in June and 1,663 bales in July of 1969, it was reported yesterday by the American Silk Council. For the first seven months of this year, shipments (including reex ports) came to 6,178 bales, compared with 10.051 bales in the corresponding period of the year before.

title: Governors Bar Highway Fund Change
description: OSAGE BEACH, Mo., Aug. 10 Under strong industry pressure, the National Gov ernors Conference rejected to day a proposal that Governors have limited authority to use Federal highway money for transportation projects other than road building.

title: VON KARAJAN LEADS SALZBURG'S OTELLO
description: SALZBURG, Austria, Aug. 10 A lavish largescale produc tion of Verdi's Otello, con ducted and staged by Herbert von Karajan, was greeted en thusiastically tonight in the Large Festspielhaus.

title: Israeli Ambassador Returns to the U.S. After Consultations
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 10 (Reu ters)  Itzhak Rubin, Israel's Ambassador to the United States, left today to return to Washington.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Books of The Times
description: It may be an exaggeration to say that a reading of this second volume of Robert Frost's biography will permanently chill your enthusiasm for the poet's work, but it is not that much of an exaggeration. The mind and character of the poet re vealed here are so unattractive, nay repel lent, that long before the end, the reader will wonder whether Mr. Thompson realizes what he is doing. What Frost would have thought of such a perform ance can scarcely be imagined this side of Vesuvius. In his private life, violence in thought and ex pression was a function of his be ing. But I'm sure that a reading of this book would have stunned him into a New En gland stillness. Years of triumph, the author calls them. With such triumphs, disasters are unnecessary.

title: Neighborhoods: 6 9 Homes in Corona at Stake
description: From these few blocks in Corona, Queens, some 80 young men went off to World War II. Half of them were killed. The insurance money paid off mortgages on many of the homes in which they were born and in which their parents still live.

title: Bond Prices Drop Before Big Volume Of New Offerings
description: Corporate and Treasury bonds declined in price yester day as the investment banking community prepared to handle this week's huge volume of new fixedincome securities.

title: WEST GAINS LEAD IN RIFLE SHOOTING
description: CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 10 (UPI)  Ronald O. West of Zanesville, Ohio; fired three straight perfect scores today and took the lead in the na tional small bore rifle matches. He had a sevenmatch total of 2,798 points out of a possible 12,800.

title: Betty Furness Heads State's Consumer Board
description: Betty Furness, who was Presi &M. Lyndon B. Johnson's spe cial assistant for consumer af fairs, was named yesterday as chairman and executive director of the newly formed State Con Sumer Protection Board.

title: Seaborg Foresees World Grid For Electric Power Distribution
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 10Dr. Glenn T. Sea borg, chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commis sion, forecast today that electri cal power distribution would be organized in worldwide net works using satellites and pos sible microwave or laser beams to send energy where it is most needed.

title: Joe Lapchick, St. John's and Knick Coach, Dies
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y., Aug. 10 (AP)  Joe Lapchick, one of basketball's Original Celtics, who spent 50 years in the sport as a player and coach, died today at Hamilton Avenue Hospital, where he was taken last week after having suf fered a heart attack. He was 70 years old.

title: BRANDT IS URGED TO DELAY TREATY
description: BONN, Aug. 10The two leaders of the Christian Demo cratic Union told Chancellor Willy Brandt toddy that their conservative parliamentary Op position was against his plan to sign a nonaggression treaty with the Soviet Union in Mos cow on Wednesday.

title: ULBRICHT SEEKING WIDE RECOGNITION
description: BERLIN, Aug. 10Walter Ulbricht, the East German head of state, has appealed to some North Atlantic Treaty Organization countries and nonaligned Western states to grant diplomatic recognition to East Germany in view of the basically new situation in Europe growing out of the SovietWest German accord.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Ever since I can remem ber, I've been hearing that Broadway musicals are dead, said Richard Rodgers. And with that he sat back and watched the beginning of rehearsals for Two by Two, his musical version of Clif ford Oclets's The Flowering Peach, starring Danny Kaye as Noah. The show is sched uled to open at the Imperial Theater on Oct. 29.

title: JUSTICE I. L. LEVEY OF STATE COURT, 71
description: State Supreme Court Justice Irving L. Levey died yesterday while vacationing in Monteca tini, Italy. He was 71 years old and lived at 200 East End Ave nue.

title: Brooklyn School District To Defy City on Cutback
description: A new superintendent of Brooklyn's Community School District 13 was appointed last night and promptly issued a challenge to the citywide Board of Education.

title: Stimulating Medical Careers Is Aim of Youth Project
description: A 16yearold boy who wants to be a doctor took a step yesterday in that direc tion. He was a guinea pig.

title: Caterpillar Damage Found
description: PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 10 (AP)An aerial survey has found that caterpillars damaged or destroyed foliage in 150,000 acres of woodland in western Massachusetts, state officials reported today. Francis Messer, a district forest warden, said the damage was 50 per cent higher than last year at this time.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: 2 POVERTY OFFICIALS ARE FINED IN JERSEY
description: BRIDGETON, N.J. Aug. 10 (AP)A Municipal Court judge convicted two antipoverty offi cials tonight on trespassing charges for having refused to leave a migrant farmwprkers camp where they were attempt ing to conduct an inspection.

title: Bell Bigger Rookie Than Jets Thought
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 10Ever since Eddie Bell ar rived, the New York Jets have proclaimed him to be the lightest player in the club's history at 152 pounds. Sherman Lewis, a Jet in 1966. weighed 156.

title: Keino Takes Dublin Mile In 3:59.2
description: DUBLIN, Aug. 10 (UPI)  Kipchoge Keino of Kenya, drawing on reserves of finish ing speed, burst past Frank Murphy of Ireland tonight to win the Billy Morton Memorial mile in 3:59.2 at an interna tional meeting.

title: A.C.L.U. Urges 5 Campuses Not to Disclose Speakers
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) The American Civil Liberties Union of the National Capital Area advised five universities today to reject a request from the House Committee on In ternal Security for a list of campus guest speakers.

title: INCREASE FORECAST IN U.S. COTTON CROP
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) The Agriculture Department forecast today the 1970 cotton crop at 11,078,900 bales, a 10 per cent increase from last year's output of slightly more than 10 million bales.

title: Globetrotting Duke Stops Off at the Rainbow Room
description: After 11 months of almost constant traveling, Duke Ell ington has settled down at the Rainbow Grill for what has become an annual five week visit. Since he was at the Grill a year ago, he has taken his band across the Atlantic twice for extended tours of Europe and he has gone across the Pacific to Japan and down through Bangkok to New Zealand and Australia.

title: Henry N. Flynt, Lawyer, Dead; Helped Restore Deerfield Village
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 10 Henry N. Flynt, a lawyer who helped spearhead the pres ervation of Old Deerfield, Mass., as a New England village of the 1700's, died tcday at his summer home in Bay Head, N. J. Here, he lived at 547 North Street. He was 77 years old.

title: TOMBS PRISONERS SEIZE 5 HOSTAGES IN 8HOUR PROTEST
description: Prisoners seized five guards and held them hostage for al most eight hours in the Man hattan House of Detention for Men yesterday until they were allowed to present grievances to the press and the Mayor's office.

title: Port of London Announces Price Increases of 27.5%
description: LONDON, Aug. 10 (Reuters) Just two weeks after the end of a costly national dock strike, the Port of London Authority today announced increases up to 27.5 per cent in port charges.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Flood in Oberammergau Cancels Passion Play
description: OBERAMMERGAU, West Germany, Aug. 10 (UPI) Torrential rains and flooding rivers cut all road links with Oberammergau today and forced cancellation of the tiny mountain town's tradi tional Passion Play.

title: Shipments of Mobile Homes Register Slight Decline
description: Shipments of mobile homes declined slightly during June from the level a year earlier, the Mobile Homes Manu facturers Association reported yesterday.

title: Cambodian Spotters Flying On U.S. Observer Planes
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 10 (AP)The U.S. com mand acknowledged today for the first time that Cambodians were flying aboard observation planes piloted by Americans to help spot targets for bombing strikes in Cambodia.

title: Hurricane's Costs Are High
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) The damage inflicted by Hur ricane Celia in central Texas last week may require at least $6million from the American Red Cross to help storm vic tims, the organization reported today.

title: Giants Spend 15 Hours Switching to I Attack
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., Aug. 10  Alex Webster made the big switch today.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Japan's Policies for Industrialization

title: NelsonDerosa Duo Paces Jersey Qualifiers With 66
description: WEST ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 10Doug Nelson and Dave De rosa of Preakness Valley won the medal with a sixunderpar 34, 3266 today at the Essex County Country Club in the qualifying round of the 38th an nual New Jersey State Golf Association fourball champion ship.

title: LAND USE POLICY ASKED IN REPORT ON ENVIRONMENT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 President Nixon sent Congress today the first White House report on the state of the nation's environment. The document gave an exhaustive analysis of the ecological prob lems facing the country but of fered few new proposals for solving them.

title: Gasoline Spillage at Staten Island Quickly Cleaned Up
description: Some 60,000 gallons of gasoline that accidentally spilled early yesterday from a Texaco tanker into the Kill Van Kull and spread over a fourmile area was virtually cleaned up by midday, the Texaco company reported yesterday.

title: Homosexual Marriages Defended by U.N. Aide
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 10Mrs. Rita E. Hauser, the United States Representative to the United Nations Human Rights Commission, said today that laws banning marriages be tween persons of the same sex were unconstitutional.

title: TWO 17YEAROLDS SHARE GOLF LEAD
description: RYE, N.Y., Aug. 10  Laura W. Beeken of Pittsburgh and Elizabeth Pooley of Gainesville, Fla., finished in a tie in the first qualifying round of the 22d annual United States Golf Association junior girls cham pionship today.

title: F.P.C.'s Head Warns Power Shortages Are Possible Next Winter
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 With the nation not yet through its summer power shortages, the chairman of the Federal Power Commission warned to day that further shortages were Possible next winter.

title: Film Festival's Opener
description: The Wild Child (L'Enfant Sauvage), the highly ac claimed film by Francois Truf faut, will open the eighth an nual New York Film Festival on Sept. 10 at Lincoln Center. The festival will end at Phil harmonic Hall on Sept. 20 with Luis Bunuel's latest film Tris. tana.

title: Police Contend Kidnappers Fired First Shots in Courtroom Eseape
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Aug 10 (UPI)  The first shots in a gun battle that killed a judge and three men holding him hostage were fired by the kid nappers, the police said today, and a San Quentin prison guard took what the police said was reasonable, action in return ing the fire.

title: Charlotte Diana Smith Betrothed
description: Miss Charlotte Diana Smith and Bruce Alan Crane plan to be married on Aug. 28. Their engagement has been an nounced by Dr. and Mrs. Ed ward W. Smith of New York, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry D. Crane of Plymouth, N. H.

title: Extra Police Ordered Into Area Of Disturbances in Jersey City
description: JERSEY CITY, Aug. 10 Mayor Thomas J. Whelan or dered the deployment of extra police tonight in a downtown neighborhood that was the scene of a rockthrowing and bottlethrowing involving 200 people last night and early today.

title: R.C.A. and Union Reach Accord in 10Week Strike
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) The Radio Corporation of America and the International Union of Electrical Workers reached a tentative agreement today to end a 10week strike affecting some 12,000 workers at 14 plant locations.

title: Guidelines for Subpoenas to News Media
description: ST.. LOUIS, Aug. 10Fol lowing are guidelines issued to the Department of Justice for subpoenas to the news media:

title: Market Place:
description: Policemen do it, landlords do it, theater cashiers do it. Even some Wall Street institu tional traders do it.

title: M. Lowenstein Expands
description: M. Lowenstein & Sons, Inc., announced yesterday that it would build a warp knit plant in Union, S. C., for manufactur ing and finishing warp knit fabrics for the men's wear trade. The facility, costing more than $3million, would comple ment other Lowenstein knitting plants in Morgantown, N. C., and Los Angeles.

title: U.S.SOVIET PACT ON AIR ROUTE SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP)  United States and Soviet negotiators have reached tenta tive agreement to expand com mercial airline service between the two nations, but diplomatic sources report that the United States has rejected a Soviet bid to permit transcontinental flights over both nations.

title: WEAKNESS SHOWN IN COMMODITIES
description: Weakness in the stock mar ket yesterday had a subduing effect on some commodity fu tures, both as to volume and to price.

title: Unruly Uruguay and a Stubborn President
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 10  President Jorge Pacheco Areco's decision not to yield to the demands of terrorist guer rillas, which prompted their murder of an American hostage yesterday, was entirely consist ent with his record as a rough andtumble politician while chief executive of this small nation. The 50yearold President, a former journalist whom friends and enemies alike have described as the most stubborn man in the coun try, has sought to bring an un ruly and often chaotic country under strong rule.

title: TODAY'S PROBABLE PITCHERS
description: Chicago at New York (2 P.M.) Janeski (811) vs. Stottlemyre (1010).

title: Mideast Talks Expected Soon at U.N.
description: UNITEDNATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 10  The expectation is growing here that indirect Arab Israeli negotiations on the sub stance of a Middle Eastern peace settlement will get under way at the United Nations with in a week.

title: UNITED AIR LINES SEEKING FARE RISE
description: United Air Lines, Inc., an nounced yesterday it had filed with the Civil Aeronautics Board for authority to increase its fares by 5 per cent, ef fective Oct. 15.

title: FREE TIME ON TV GIVEN TO 14 DOVES
description: Twelve Democratic and two Republican Senators have ac cepted an offer of free time on noncommercial television to express their opposition to President Nixon's policies on the Indochina war.

title: Deteriorating Subways
description: It pains Dr. William Ronan, chairman of the Metro politan Transportation Authority, that political capi tal is being made out of the subway accidents that have been afflicting this city. But the appalling state of New York's transit system is, in the most legitimate sense, a political issueand should remain one until drastic steps are taken to improve it.

title: Seaborg Backs Decision
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 10 (Reuters)  Dr. Glenn T. Seaborg, chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, approved today the dumping of the rockets of nerve gas.

title: Nets Get Paultz of Squires For Cash, Future Draft Pick
description: Bill Paultz, a rookie 6foot 11inch center was acquired by the New York Nets yesterday from the Virginia Squires for an undisclosed amount of cash and a draft choice.

title: Outline of U.S.Soviet Pact On Arms Curbs Seen Near
description: VIENNA, Aug. 10 (Reuters) Informed sources said tonight that the first outline of a pros pective agreement between the United States and the Soviet Union on the limitation of stra tegic armaments might be pub lished this week.

title: Barney Reports to Lions
description: BLOOMFIELD HILLS, Mich., Aug. 10 (UPI)Lem Barney, a holdout since the end of the National Football League play ers strike, reported to the De troit Lions training camp today. A team spokesman said the cornerback still had not signed his contract but took part in both morning and afternoon drills.

title: U.S. JUDGE'S ORDER FOUGHT. BY STATE
description: The State Attorney General's office has accused Federal Judge Constance Baker Motley of a Federal invasion of state prison management in her re cent order requiring New York prison officials to submit for her approval a new set of dis ciplinary rules.

title: GAME IS DELAYED BY LIGHT FAILURE
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 10Un deterred by light failure that delayed the start of the game half an hour, and aided by nine walks and two errors in the first four innings, the New York Mets defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 102, tonight as Tom Seaver pitched a sixhitter for his 17th victory.

title: SENATE APPROVAL OF ABM FORECAST
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 Senate Republican leaders ex pressed confidence today that on a crucial vote Wednesday the Senate would approve, by a twovote margin, an Adminis tration proposal to expand the Safeguard antiballistic missile system.

title: Text of Tombs Inmates Grievances
description: We, the inmates of the 9th floor of Tombs City Prison, Manhattan, N. Y., sub mit this petition of grievences and we solicit your attention in this matter.

title: Goldberg Says State's $ 1Billion Isn't Enough to Clean Its Waters
description: ISLIP, L. 1., Aug. 10 Charging that the state's $1 billion pure waters bond is sue had not eliminated water pollution, Arthur J. Goldberg declared today that at least $1.5billion more in state aid, in addition to unspecified Fed eral aid, would be necessary to cleanse the state's waters.

title: Buchan Takes OverAll Lead In World Star Class Sail
description: MARSTAND, Sweden, Aug. 10 (AP)Americans dominated the second race of the World Star sailing championship today as Bill Buchan and James Schoonmaker moved Into the two top spots in the overall standings.

title: Lapchick Rated a Place With Rockne, McGraw
description: Pride was the mainspring of Joe Lapchick's character and philosophy. That he had a philosophy, in the most unpretentious way, was the aspect of his personality that made the most lasting im pression on the thousands of people who had direct dealings with him through the natrcentury he lived in the sports limelight. He preached pride pride in one self, pride in ac complishment, pride in being a true professional who de livers all the effort he is paid for, pride in being able to win without gloating and to lose without whining.

title: Human Latitude
description: Statutes are devised by legislatures to operate uni formly; but it is a corollary that laws must be inter preted for fleshandblood people.

title: Allen Takes Chicago Post
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 10  Dr. James E. Allen Jr., former United States Commissioner of Education, has been named a parttime consultant to the Ed ucational Facilities Center here. The 34story center, a perma nent display, area for educa tional products, is scheduled to open in 1973. Dr. Allen will work with the center's execu tive planning committee.

title: Senator Calls for RailMerger Suspensions
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UPI)Senator Philip A. Hart, Democrat of Michigan, warning of a breakdown in the nation's transportation system, called today for suspension of all railroad mergers and action to stop the trend toward transpor Itation conglomerates.

title: Equal Rights Champion
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 During a balance of payments crisis a few years ago, Rep resentative Martha W. Grif fiths startled the Under Sec retary of the Treasury, Robert V. Roosa, when she asked sweetly: Tell me, Mr. Roosa, why do we have to have gold in the first place? It was no idle, ill intormed question. It was designed to cut through the bu reaucratic flow of facts and figures that so frequently inundate Congressional committees. It was the type of question, seemingly naive but asked for a purpose, that has made Martha Griffiths one of the most effective interrogators in Congress.

title: That Mover Hauling Away Furniture May Bea Mother
description: The people walking on Third Avenue near East 21st Street the other morning could hardly believe their eyes.'Those were women who were lugging furnituire out of an apartment building and loading it onto a truck.

title: MANSON WITNESS GIVEN IMMUNITY; Accused Hippie Asked Her, Who Will Judge Us All?
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 10 Charles M. Manson whispered today to the chief prosecution witness in the murder case against him, a former member of his hippie band, Who will judge us all?

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. The President sent to Congress the first annual report by the Council on Environmental Quality. He issued a statement about Dan A. Mitrione, a United States adviser in Uruguay who was killed by terrorists, and sent messages of condolences to his family. He signed a bill extending unemployment benefits. Later in the after noon he met with the presi dents of major domestic trunk airlines and gave a birthday reception for Bernard Lasker, a friend who is a New York investment banker.

title: Peru Crash Victims Are Mourned Across the State
description: BUFFALO, Aug. 10 (AP) Good students, leaders of high school clubs and student coun cils, athletes, musicians and prom queensthe 20 New York State students killed in a plane crash in Peru yesterday were mourned and praised today by their families, friends and teachers.

title: Thant Condemns Slaying
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 10 The murder of Mr. Mitrione was called senseless and despicable by Secretary General Thant in a statement issued today.

title: ALEXANDER GODE, TRANSLATOR, DIES
description: MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., Aug. 10  Dr. Alexander Gode, a prominent translator and lexi cographer, died of cancer early this morning at Northern West chester Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived at Finney Farm in CrotononHudson.

title: Krakora on Dance Board
description: Joseph L. Krakora has been named to the board of direc tors of the Foundation for American Dance as vice presi dent for development. The foundation, at 130 West 56th Street, is the parent organiza tion of the City Center Joffrey Ballet, which opens its fall sea son Sept. 29 at the City Center Theater.

title: ITALIAN PLEDGES NO DEVALUATION
description: ROME, Aug. 10  premier Emilio Colombo, making a formal appeal for a parliamen tary vote of confidence for his fourdayold coalition Gov ernment, promised today that he would not devalue the lira but would take prompt fiscal measure to stimulate pro duction and contain domestic demand.

title: Commonwealth Unit Ousts 2
description: SINGAPORE, Aug. 10 (Reu ters)  The Commonwealth Medical Association has ex pelled South Africa and Rho desia for practicing apartheid, or racial separation, in med icine. The association's presi dent, Dr. Gwee Ah Leng of Singapore, said the medical associations of the two coun tries refuse to mix blood from olacks and whites in trans usions and maintain separate hospitals, and medical schools for the races.

title: Michigan's Population Rises
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) Preliminary counts from the 1970 census show that Michi gan's population is 8,777,560, the Census Bureau said today. The state's population in 1960 was 7,823,194.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: A flyfishing leader that persists in twisting may be straightened by pulling It through a piece of rubber that is squeezed over the leader between finger and thumb. A twoinch square of old inner tube is good for this. (And while we're on the subject of inner tubes, you can impress your wife by using strips of them, at least two feet long and an inch and a half wide, as clamps to hold together oddshaped pieces of furni ture that are being glued or repaired. Tuck the end of the rubber strip under itself to hold it in place.)

title: CITY ENDS DELAY IN CUTTING RENTS
description: As an emergency measure the Lindsay administration has changed a housing regulation to permit the rent control of fice to reduce rents immedi ately in buildings lacking es sential services. The change eliminates a previous require ment giving landlords a seven day notice before such a rent reduction.

title: STAR CLASS SERIES CAPTURED BY FLYNN
description: SEA CLIFF, L. I., Aug. 10 Mike Flynn of the Niantic, Conn., fleet captured the At lantic Coast Star Class cham pionship today with his second victory in the threerace series.

title: TANNER ADVANCES THROUGH DEFAULT
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Ave. Aug. 10 (AP)  Gene Scott of New York, Tom Leonard of Los Angeles and Charles Owens of Tuscaloosa, Ala., led the seeded players into the second round of the United States grass court amateur ten nis championships today. A field of 64 began play today at the Meadow club.

title: VETO NOT EXPECTED FOR EDUCATION BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 White House sources said to day that President Nixon had decided not to veto the $4.4 billion education appropriation bill that is $453million above his budget request.

title: FRAZIER TO GIVE FOSTER TITLE BOUT
description: STATELINE, Nev., Aug. 10 (AP)  Joe Frazier, the world heavyweight boxing champion, will give Bob Foster, the light heavyweight titleholder, a shot at his crown, Frazier's manager said today.

title: Article 9  No Title
Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: FORTUNE CLARIFIES ARTICLE ON PENNSY
description: Fortune magazine said yes terday that in its reference in its August issue to accounting practices of the Penn Central Company it had been in error in some instances.

title: Article 6  No Title
Football Waivers
description: NATIONAL CONFERENCE

title: United Aircraft Corp. Reports Gains in Earnings for the Quarter
3 Costly Musicals Get Set for Season
description: Ever since I can remem ber, Fve been hearing that Broadway musicals are dead, said Richard Rodgers. And with that he sat back and watched the beginning of rehearsals for Two by Two, his musical version of Clif ford Oclets's The Flowering Peach, starring Danny Kaye as Noah. The show is sched uled to open at the Imperial Theater on Oct. 29.

title: To Rescue the Environment
description: Long strides have been made in public awareness of the environmental crisis and in Government programs to cope with it in the five years since President John son summoned a White House conference on the coyly named subject, natural beauty. One proof of progress is that there is now in the Office of the President a threeman Council on Environmental Quality modeled on the Council of Economic Advisers.

title: BRITON IN UGANDA: A TANGLED DRAMA
description: LONDON, Aug. 10The tan gled drama of Brian Lea, a mi nor British diplomatic official in Uganda, has taken another turn before a fascinated public audience and an embarrassed Government.

title: Charts of Races at Saratoga
Bronx Legal Aides Sworn In
description: Eight criminal law investi gators and an assistant dis trict attorney were sworn in to office yesterday by Bronx Ditrict Attorney Burton B. Roberts. Criminal law investi gators, law school graduates who have not yet been admit ted to the bar, assist in prep aration of cases. Upon admis sion to the bar, they become assist district attorneys. Sworn in as an assistant district at torney was Arthur L. Altman, 27 years old, of 261 Seaman Avenue.

title: CIVIL PANEL REJECTS 2 MYLAI TRIAL PLEAS
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 10 (UPI) A threejudge Federal panel re fused today to take jurisdiction in two murder trials stemming from the alleged Mylai mas sacre of Vietnamese civilians two years ago.

title: HOUSE UNIT VOTES AID TO EXPORTERS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 The House Ways and Means Committee approved today a new Administrationbacked tax incentive for exports but also voted for a provision that could lead to numerous re strictions on imports.

title: House Grants District Delegates to Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP)  The House passed today separate bills to give the District of Columbia non voting representation in Con gress.

title: Olympade Joins Athletes Drinks
description: Gatorade and Energade are now being joined by Olym pade in the ranks of thirst quenchers geared particularly, but not exclusively, for the athletic set. But only Olyrnpade offers this superspecial exclusive: use of the red, white and blue interlinkingring trademark of the United States Olympic Committee.

title: 2 Stationmasters in Spain Arrested in Rail Collision
description: BILBAO, Spain, Aug. 10 Reuters)Two stationmasters were arrested today after a collision of two trains caused the deaths of 33 persons and njured 136.

title: HOGAN IS BUOYED BY A COOLER DAY
description: TULSA, Okla., Aug. 10 (UPI) Ben Hogan, who had com plained of the 100degree heat during a practice round, toured Southern Hills Country Club in the mild 90degree weather today and said if the weather stayed that cool he definitely would play in the Professional Golfers Association champion ship.

title: Thamar Tessier to Be a Bride
description: Miss Thamar Tessier may still make it to Iran and Geneva, where she has close friends, but Cyprus, Greece, Turkey, the Sudan and other stops have been canceled from the roundtheworld tour she started after resign ing her 18year post as train ing officer for United Na tions tour guides.

title: S. L. VIGILANTE, 79, OF PUBLIC LIBRARY
description: OSSINING, N. Y., Aug. 10 Sylvester L. Vigilante, the re tired chief of the New York Public Library's American His tory Room in the Fifth Avenue building, died here last night. He was 79 years old and had homes here and in Moretown, Vt.

title: Executive Changes
description: Harry Heltzer has been named chairman and, chief executive officer, 3M Company, succeeding Bert S. Cross who is retiring. Raymond H. Herzog succeeds. Mr. Heltzer as president.

title: GOODELL, OTTINGER CALL FOR REFORMS
description: Senator Charles E. Goodell called for increased appropri ations for prison reform yes terday while his Democratic opponent, Representative Rich ard L. Ottinger called for new programs to reduce unemploy ment.

title: Flushing Bank Elects
description: George C. Byrnes has been elected president of the Flush ing Savings Bank. He has been executive vice president since he joined the $60million insti tution on Jan. 1, 1970. Mr. Byrnes was previously presi dent and organizer of the Sav ings Bank of Rockland County, Monsey, N. Y.

title: Dr. James M. Rosen, 74, ExCity Hospitals Aide
description: BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., Aug. 10Dr. James M. Rosen, a former assistant to the New York City Commissioner of Hospitals and former president of the Metropolitan and New York State Nursing Home Asso ciations, died yesterday, appar ently of a stroke, at his home here. He was 74 years old.

title: Cubiculo Staging an Anthology Of the Past Year's Dance Works
description: Success. and failure are twin growths in an experimental garden and each must be al lowed full opportunity to be seen. It is even arguable that the chance to fail is the most important privilege that can be granted to the creative artist. For the past two years The Cubiculo, the experimental art center of the National Shake speare Company, has provided danders the chance to work and experiment without the pres sure of commercial consider ations.

title: Theater Yale's Cops and Horrors
Article 8  No Title
Twin Cities Lead Nation in Soaring Prices
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 7The Twin Cities of Minneapolis and St. Paul, which proudly look on themselves as the big leaguers of the North, now have the dubious honor of being the na tion's champions in cost of liv ing increases.

title: Article 2  No Title
SUSPECT HITS JUDGE ON HEAD WITH SHOE
description: A robbery suspect leaped to the bench of a Criminal Court judge yesterday and hit the judge on the head and should ers with his shoe.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Eleven days after Dan A. Mitrione was kid napped by urban guerrillas, the body of the chief United States police adviser to Uruguay was found yesterday in an automobile on A Montevideo street. President Jorge Pacheco Areco described the murder of the con sultant as the greatest attack this country's political institutions have faced in this cen tury. (Page 1, Columns 12.]

title: Broadening Job Insurance
description: With national unemployment back at the 5 per cent level, President Nixon's signature of a bill extending the coverage of the Federalstate unemployment insur ance system to 4.7 million more workers is a much needed step toward economic justice. The tragedy that the additions still do not include one group des. perately in need of protectionmigratory farm labor ers, always the excluded in the laws that establish minimal standards to safeguard the great bulk American workers.

title: World Parley Warned Of Short Food Supplies
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10A somber picture of prospects for feeding the world's rapidly mul tiplying population was limned today as several thousand nu trition specialists of some 50 nations met in the Third In ternational Congress of Food Science and Technology.

title: Bill Rates Show an Advance At Treasury's Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 Treasury bill rates advanced at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.

title: DART HANOVER DUE FOR YONKERS RACES
description: YONKERS, Aug. 10  Dart Hanover, the Americanbred trotter who campaigned throughout Europe after he raced at Yonkers Raceway last November, will leave Milan, Italy, tomorrow morning on A flight to this country.

title: SAIGON SAYS FOE THREATENS BASE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 10 (AP)  Fighting be tween North and South Viet namese forces was reported to day in the mountains near an abandoned United States artil lery base named Ripcord in the northern part of South Vietnam. More than 1,000 enemy soldiers were believed to be massing for an attack on a South Viet namese base.

title: In The Nation: Nerve Gas and National Security
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10In all the remarkable circum stances of the nerve gas affair, the least of the available evils may be the Army's plan to ship 3,000 tons of the deadly stuff through seven Southern states, then dump it in the ocean 283 miles off Florida. Even so, the gross offensiveness and latent risks of the scheme suggest what a mess the nation has got itself into.

title: 14,872 See Title Win Silver Anniversary Dash by a Head
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 10 (AP)  Claiborne Farm's Title and W. C. Partee's I'm for Mama made it a twohorse race and dominated the $20, 000 added Silver Anniversary Stakes at Atlantic City today.

title: War Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) The following servicemen from the New York area were identified by the Defense De partment today as having been killed in the conflict in South east Asia:

title: Misses Walsh, Newberry Win 2dRound Net Matches
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 10 (AP)Sharon Walsh, the de fending champion from San Rafael, Calif., defeated Daryl Gralka. of Houston, Tex., 62, 60, today in the second round of the United States girls  18 andunder grass court tennis championship at the Philadel phia Cricket Club.

title: President Signs Bill Extending jobless Pay to 4.7 Million More
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) President Nixon signed today a bill extending unemployment insurance coverage to 4.7 mil lion more workers and said that it would cushion the move from a wartime to a peacetime econ omy.

title: An Upset Alphabet In New Phone Books Baffles the British!
description: LONDON, Aug. 10In a quick response to public pro tests, the Post Office announced today that it would take an other look at a new system of listing names in British tele phone books.

title: Cornfeld Is Facing I.O.S. Proxy Fight
description: GENEVA, Aug. 10The bat tle for control of Investors Overseas Services was joined today with an announcement by the management that it would wage an allout proxy fight with Bernard Cornfeld, ousted founder of the ailing mutual fund complex.

title: Problems in New England
description: BOSTON, Aug. 10 (AP)Wil liam I. Cowin, chairman of the Massachusetts Department of Public Utilities, recommended today that a regional agency be created for New England to cope with increasing electric power problems.

title: W. GermanySpain Net Final Will Be Played on Asphalt
description: DUESSELDORF, West Ger many, Aug. 10 (UPI)  West Germany will play Spain on an asphalt court and not on grass in their Davis Cup interzone final next woekend, the German Tennis Federation said today.

title: ADIOS STAKE GOES ON TV SATURDAY
description: Eighteen stations across the country, including Channel 9 (WOR) in New York, will tele cast the Adios Stake from The Meadows harness track in Meadow Lands, Pa., on Satur day night. This will mark the first live network offering of a harness race.

title: Cokes Stops Perez in 7th
description: DALLAS, Aug. 10 (AP) Curtis Cokes, a former world welterweight champion, stopped Danny Perez of New York to night in the seventh round of a scheduled 10round middle weight bout. Cokes, 161, hit Perez, 157, with a solid right hand and a barrage of punches at the close of the sixth round. Perez failed to make the bell for the seventh. He suffered cuts inside his mouth.

title: Attorneys for the Poor
description: In what'was once regarded as a citadel of rigidity, there are new stirrings on behalf of the legally deprived in the United States. At the annual meeting of the American Bar Association in St. Louis, the fifth anni versary of the Office of Economic Opportunity's legal services program as well as the fiftieth anniversary of the National Legal Aid and Defender Association are being celebrated today. The fact that the A.B.A. is choosing to honor these lawyers and programs for the poor is a symbol of their acceptance in the courts.

title: Blues Festival Ends With a Surprise
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Aug. 10Two unscheduled per formers at the Ann Arbor Blues Festival yesterday Junior Wells, the harmonica player and singer, and Johnny Winter, the guitar ist and singerproved to be just what the audience had been waiting for.

title: Bridge:
William Robert Miller Dead; A Writer on Christianity, 43
description: William Robert Miller, who wrote on Christian thought and philosophy, died yesterday after a heart attack in his home at, 13419 166th Place in Jamaica, Queens. He was 43 years old.

title: G.M. Vehicles Recalled; Brakes May Be Defective
description: DETROIT, Aug. 10 (AP)The General Motors Corporation has announced the recall of about 16,500 mediumduty trucks and school buses for correction of possible brake defects.

title: ProSihanouk Cambodians Seize Embassy in Prague
description: PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 10 (Reuters)  A Cam bodian diplomat and a group of Cambodian students seized their embassy here today on behalf of the Pekingbased exile gov ernment of Prince Norodom Si hanouk.

title: Federal Court Sets Trial In Atomic Waste Dispute
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 9  A case that may produce a land mark decision on the disposal of radioactive wastes has been set for trial on Oct. 5 by a Fed eral District Court here.

title: Film: Diary of Mad Housewife Bows
PANEL HEARS PLAN FOR CHARTER JETS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10  The chairman of the Civil Aero ???autics Board testified today that a proposed regulation to curb illegal charter flights would not automatically ban large groups, such as the Amer ican Legion or the Knights of Columbus, from chartering jets to Europe.

title: Radio and TV Accompany G.I.'s Into the Battle Area in Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 10  A dozen soldiers in combat gear lounged in a sandbagged bunker at Phuloi, north of Saigon, watching the opening segment of Burke's Law on their portable televi sion set. On the grass outside lay their grenades, ammunition beits and rifles.

title: MICHAEL STRAUSS, TRUMAN AIDE, 73
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) Michael W. Strauss, commis sioner of the United States Bureau of Reclamation in the Truman Administration and a strong advocate of public power and irrigation projects, died yesterday of a heart attack in Chamberlain, Me., where he was visiting a friend. He was 73 years old.

title: Yonkers Drivers
Article 10  No Title
Open Interest
Excerpts From Burger's Talk
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 10Fol lowing are excerpts from an address by Chief Justice War ren E. Burger today before the opening assembly of the American Bar Association convention:

title: Lindsay Honors Mobutu, Here on a Business Hunt
description: Joseph Desire Mobutu, Presi dent of the Republic of the Congo, was the guest of honor at a reception given last night by Mayor Lindsay on the front lawn at Gracie Mansion.

title: Article 4  No Title
Senate Approves Alcoholism Attack Backed by Hughes
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) The Senate passed today a bill authorizing $395million over the next three years for an at tack on problems of alcoholism.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week Ended Aug. 4, 1970:

title: Kathy Linney Gains Medal In Jersey Amateur Golf
description: PLAINFIELD, N. J., Aug. 10 Kathy Linney of the host club, recent winner of the Eliza beth Goss roundrobin, carded a 42, 3981 today to win the qualifying medal for the 45th New Jersey women's amateur championship.

title: Shoemaker, on 4 Winners, Raises His Total to 6,004
description: DEL MAR, Calif. Aug. 10 (AP) Bill Shoemaker, who became the second jockey in history to win 6,000 races in a career last Saturday, rode four winners, including Daryl's Joy in the feature race at Del Mar today.

title: Ford Starts Production Of 400,000 Small Autos
description: DETROIT, Aug. 10The Ford Motor Company plans to build 400,000 Pintosits new mini carin the coming model year, setting the stage for a fierce fight between Ford, Chevrolet and Volkswagen for the small car market.

title: Jersey to Help City Prosecute Parking Violators
description: New York City will open a drive against New Jerseyans who ignore parking tickets here. The city will get their names from a Jersey computer and if necessary, sue them in their home state.

title: 307 PLAt 1ST ROUND OF U.S. CHESS OPEN
description: BOSTON, Aug. 10A record attendance of 307 chess play ers competed in the opening session of the 71st annual United States Open Champion ship in the Parker House here last night. The event is a round Swiss system.

title: Gretel II, Repairs Completed, Is Readied for Cup Sea Drills
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 10 (UPI)Gretel H, the Australian challenger in the America's Cup races, was launched today and prepared for her first tests afloat since being damaged in an unloading accident.

title: Robert Emmet, GailPutnam Plan Marriage
description: MILTON, Mass., Aug. 10 Dr. and Mrs. Robert Mitchell Putnam have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gail Putnam, to Robert Emmet, son of Mrs. Richard Stockton Emmet of Glen Head, L. I., and the late Mr. Emmet and a descendant of Thomas Addis Emmet, broth er of Robert Emmet, the Irish patriot.

title: Estep and Seewagen Gain In Moscow Net Tourney
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 10 (AP) Two Americans advanced today in opening matches of a Mos cow international tennis tour nament.

title: VICTOR PAYS $8.80, WITH CORDERO UP
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 10  The Saratoga Spe cial emphasized conviviality to. day with Three Martinis and Raise Your Glass finishing one, two in the sixfurlong sprint for 2yearolds. Angel Cordero, hack from a 10day suspension, steered Three Martinis to a head triumph over Raise Your Glass in the field of six.

title: McSorley's Admits. Women Under a New City Law
description: McSorley's Old Ale House opened its doors to women yes terday for the first time in its 116 year history and within two hours had its first coed fight.

title: Burger Warns New Issues May Overload U. S. Courts
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 10Chief Justice Warren E. Burger said today that delays in Federal courts had become so acute that the burden on the courts should be taken into consideration whenever reform legislation was proposed.

title: Johnson Sponsors Seminar
description: FREDERICKSBURG, Tex., Aug. 10 (AP)A seminar for about 200 businessmen Aug. 28 in the LBJ State Park will be sponsored by former President Lyndon B. Johnson. Mr. John son will act as moderator for a question and answer period, it was announced by Harold Stehling, cochairman of a pro gram Aug. 29 to mark Mr. John son's 62d birthday and the for mal opening of LBJ Park.

title: Allis in Siemens Tie
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 10 (UPI) The AllisChalmers Manufac turing Company and the Sie mens Corporation of West Ger many have signed a licensing agreement permitting Allis Chalmers to sell Siemens prod ucts to the public utility and industrial markets.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Money and Desire

title: Senseless Killing in Uruguay
description: One sensation stands out beyond even those of shock and horror over the killing of Dan A. Mitrione by the Tupamaro terrorists in Uruguay: the utter senseless ness of this murder. Only diseased minds could see in the gunning down of this father of nine from Indiana the weakening of the capitalist system or the advance ment of social revolution in the Americas.

title: HORSES &
description: SELLING OUT!

title: Banks Is Still Disabled
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 10 (AP) Ernie Banks, will remain on the Chicago Cubs disabled list for two more weeks, the club an nounced today. The slugging first baseman was placed on the list three weeks ago be cause of an arthritic left knee.

title: MORE SOVIET CITIES CLOSED IN EPIDEMIC
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 10 (AP)A cholera epidemic that broke out in Soviet Central Asia appeared to be spreading in the European part of the Soviet Union. Travel was restricted to cities as far north as the Ukraine and warn ing signs sprouted in Moscow's fruit and vegetable markets.

title: Designer for Merrick Show
description: Oliver Smith, the coproducer and set designer for last sea sous Indians, will design the setting for Four on a Garden, the new David Merrick produc tion starring Carol Clianning. The comedy, which will open on Broadway Nov. 26 at a theater to he announced, was written and will he directed by Abe Burrows.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON HAVE MIXED DAY
Reenlistment No Longer Assures G.I.'s in Vietnam of Safe Duty
description: PHUBAI, South Vietnam, Aug. 5Faced with increasing, shortages of infantry riflemen, the United States Army com mand has suspended a long standing policy of permitting frontline troops to reenlist in exchange for transfers from battlefields to rear areas.

title: Retail Chains Sales Increased for July, Led by Lane Bryant
description: Six leading retail chains re ported yesterday increased sales in July over the year earlier month.

title: Lawyer for Detective Ejected From Trial Room for Outburst
description: Deputy Commissioner Ben jamin Ward, a Police Depart ment trial officer, ordered the lawyer for a suspended detec tive ejected from the trial room yesterday and threatened him with arrest.

title: Rev. Bertrand Campbell, 74, Led Francisan Province
description: The Rev. Bertrand Campbell, provincial of the Franciscan Holy Name Province here from 1943 to 1949, died Sunday at Frances Schervier Home and Hospital in the Bronx. He was 74 years old.

title: New Sultan of Oman Outlines Sweeping Reforms
description: MUSCAT, Aug. 10Sultan Qabus bin Said of Oman, who overthrew his father's rule 18 days ago, yesterday changed the name of his country, invited exiles to return, inveighed against Communism and an nounced a long list of reforms and development plans.

title: Shooting Across Jordan River Reported
description: AT THE ALLENBY BRIDGE, Jordanian Side, Aug. 10  Jordanian informants said to day that Jordanian troops and perhaps Arab commandos  had exchanged fire with Israeli soldiers across the Jor dan River for the last two days.

title: Record Spending Listed by A.T.&T. For Improvements
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yes terday that during the first six months of the year it had spent more than ever before and more than any ether corpora tion to improve and expand service.

title: Mystic Names Curator
description: The appointment of J. Re vell Carr, as cuartor of Mys tic Seaport was announced yesterday by Waldo C. M. Johnston, director.

title: HEALTH LIMITS RACE BY ABORTION BACKER
description: AUBURN, N. Y., Aug. 10 (UPI)Assemblyman George M. Michaels, Democrat of Auburn, announced today that he was still a candidate for reelection but that because of ill health he would not campaign ac tively.

title: Police Picket on U.N. Again
description: The policemen of the East 67th Street Station, who ob ject to duty in front of United Nations missions, picketed outside police headquarters at 240 Centre Street yesterday for the fifth consecutive Mon day. Several of the 30 picket ing policemen carried signs of protest. One read: I want to be a copnot a doorman. Another said: Let us do our thingguard the public.

title: Draft Offices Firebombed
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 10 (UPI)  Oregon's Selective Service headquarters was firebombed for the fourth time in six months early to day. The Federal Bureau of Investigation is working on the case. Officials said dam age was kept to about $1,000 because an alert building em ploye used fire extinguishers to put out blazes in two of fices where bombs had been thrown through windows.

title: SCHOOL CASE JUDGE BARS STORM REPAIRS
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Aug. 10 (AP)A Federal judge ordered the Corpus Christi School District today not to make major repairs of damage from Hurricane Celia.

title: Remnants Shop Where a Lot of Washington Fashion Starts
description: WASHINGTON  Mrs. Edward M. Kennedy's dress maker... the wife of David Lloyd Kreeger, the philan thropist... the wife of Robert S. McNamara, presi dent of the World Bank... the wife of Senator Karl E. Mundt... the wife of Rich ard M. Helms, director of the Central Intelligence Agency  almost anyone in Washington Who goes Out a lot eventually drops in at the G Street Remnant Shop to see what's available.

title: Grace to Build in Canada
description: W. R. Grace & Co. said yes terday it planned to build a new plant for the manufacture of sodium nitrilotriacetate in On tario, Canada. The chemical is used as a phosphate replace ment for detergents and as a chelating agent for other in dustrial and agricultural uses.

title: Faucet Leak Cuts Power In E.E.C. Headquarters
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 10  The headquarters of the European Economic Community here was knocked out for more than five hours today when a faucet flooded the under ground power plant.

title: PRICES SLIP AGAIN IN AMEX TRADING
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange continued to drop yesterday in the slowest trading in almost four years.

title: HAROLD B. DORSEY OF ARGUS IS DEAD
description: HARRISON, N. Y., Aug. 10 Harold B. Dorsey, founder and board chairman of the Argus Research Corporation, an influ ential advisory service for brokerage firms, mutual funds and banks, died yesterday, ap parently of a heart attack, at his home here. He was 70 years old.

title: U.S. Plywood in Cutback
description: U.S. PlywoodChampion Pa pers, Inc., will reduce opera tions at its Hamilton. Ohio, paper mill during the last half of August and part of Septem ber because of a drop in orders. The work week will be cut from seven to five days. About 360 temporary workers and 50, permanent employes out of a total force of 2,000 will he laid off.

title: Article 3  No Title
New Jersey Offers Racing Fans Another Daily Double as Atlantic City and Freehold Open
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., Aug. 10 For those with the will and the wherewithal, harness racing doubleheader time rolled round again today with the reopening of Freehold Raceway. With mat inees set here for 2 o'clock each afternoon and night action available at Yonkers Raceway, about 70 milles from here, a trotting and pacing fan, by step ping lively, could make both spots in the same day.

title: Governors Doubt Large Republican Gains in 1970
description: OSAGE BEACH, Mo., Aug. 10 If the nation's Governors are competent as political pundits, 1970 is not destined to be a year of sweeping Republican, gains.

title: ExCongressman on Parole
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Aug. 10 (AP)Thomas F. Johnson, former Democratic member of the House of Representatives from Maryland, was released on parole today from the United States Medical Center here. On April 23, he began serving a sixmonth sentence for accepting $17,500 to per suade the Justice Department to drop a mail fraud charge against a savings and loan officer.

title: Rovals Activate Martinez
description: KANSAS CITY, Aug. 10 (UPI) John (Buck) Martinez, a catcher, was activated today by the Kansas City Royals and Jim Campanis was optioned to Elmira of the Eastern League. Martinez, recently returned from Fort Benning, Ga., after 4 months of military duty, batted.229 Iast year in 72 games. Campanis, also a catcher, was hitting.143 in 28 games this season.

title: Those Foreign Cars In Subway Need Paint
description: New York's subway cars are giving five states in the union some unaskedfor pub licity, because the Transit Authority's painting program lags.

title: Garelik and Beame Challenge Lindsay on Ethics
description: City Council President San ford D. Garelik and Controller Abraham D. Beame charged yesterday that Mayor Lindsay had not gone far enough in implementing the Board of Ethics recommendation that publicity of the substance of consultant contracts is desirable in the public Interest.

title: Mitchell Sets Rules Limiting Subpoenas Issued to Newsmen
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 10Attor Iney General John N. Mitchell issued guidelines to the Justice Department today in what he described as a move to limit the discretion of Government lawyers to subpoena newsmen to testify in criminal cases.

title: U.S. Says It Didn't Press Uruguay to Yield
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10A State Department spokesman said today that the United States had not pressed Uruguay to meet the demands of the kid nappers of Dan A. Mitrione.

title: Kidnapped U.S. Official Found Slain in Uruguay
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 10The body of Dan A. Mitrione, chief United States police adviser to Uruguay, was found today in an automobile parked in a Montevideo street 11 days after he kid napped by urban guerrillas.

title: Clouds to Obscure Meteors
description: Amateur astronomers in the East who are hoping to watch the summer's densest meteor shower tonight, will , get no help from the weatherman. Forecasts for the region from the Midwest states to the coast, according to the United States Weather Bureau here, is mostly cloudy, with a chance of showers in some areas. The Perseid meteor shower appears annually in August as the earth passes through a storm of dirt, dust and rock particles which orbit the sun in an elliptical path.

title: Team Headed by Kretchmer To Run Sanitation Department
description: Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday a major revamping of the Sanitation Department by creating a new policymaking and operational team and naming Jerome Kretchmer, the Environmental Protection Ad ministrator, as acting Sanita tion Commissioner.

title: Eight Marine Reservists Demoted Over Long Hair
description: SAN DIEGO, Calif., Aug. 30 (UPI)Eight Marine Corps re servists who refused to get militarystyle haircuts were sentenced yesterday to forfeit ure of pay and reduction in rank.

title: Stage to Get Bob and Ray
description: Bob and RayThe Two and Only, starring the radio and television performers Bob El liott and Ray Goulding, will go into rehearsal Aug. 24 at the Golden Theater, with Joseph Hardy directing. The show, produced by Joseph I. and Johnna Levine in association with Hy Saporta, will play pre views from Sept. 10 to Sept. 23, and will open on Sept. 24.

title: U.S. WINS 7 EVENTS AT COLOGNE TRACK
description: COLOGNE, West Germany, Aug. 11 (AP)Americans won seven events  five in men's competition and two in wom en's  at a track and field meet before 20,000 spectators tonight.

title: Theater: Come as You. Are, Comic Report on Sex
description: LONDON, Aug. 11Few things can be harder to achieve in contemporary drama than the sex comedy. Today we all know what comedy is; but, in our in creasingly permissive society, we are naturally a little doubtful about things that may be too near the truth to be funny.

title: Mayor Urges State to Take Sentenced Prisoners
description: Mayor Lindsay declared yes terday that a corrections cri sis here demanded that the state provide facilities Wt. sen tenced prisoners and that the courts clear up the backlog of Prisoners awaiting trial.

title: MARLU PRIDE 45 IN $106,700 TROT
description: YONKERS, Aug. 11  The owners of only eight of the 39 colts eligible for the 16th annual Yonkers Futurity Trot, to be contested at Yonkers Raceway Friday night, saw fit this morning to make the $2,000 starting payments on be half of their respective charges.

title: 22 Seized in Louisville
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 11 (UN)  Twentytwo welfare demonstrators were arrested last night when they refused to end a sitin at the office of a state public assistance offi cer. The demonstrators were demanding more clothing for their schoolage children and additonal meetings with repre sentatives of the State Depart ment of Economic Security.

title: CONNECTICUT G.O.P. IN PRIMARY TODAY
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 11Re publican candidates for Gover nor of Connecticut and the United States Senate cam paigned hard today on the eve of the state's first statewide primary.

title: Britain Yields to Critics Of New Phone Listings
description: LONDON, Aug. 11 (Reuters) The British Post Office to night bowed to a volley of criticism and withdrew its latest brain childtelephone directories that do not list names alphabetically.

title: French Reds Ask Brandt to Lift Ban On German Party
description: PARIS, Aug. 11The French Communist party has asked Chancellor Willy Brandt to lift the 14yearold legal ban on the Communist party in West Ger many.

title: FRESH AIR APPEAL GIVES FARM TOUR
description: Don't tell me popcorn grows on trees! exclaimed, Chris Warme, a 9yearold Fresh Air Fund camper from the Bronx, as she and four of her cabinmates walked among the tall stalks of corn on Sharpe Reservation's model farm.

title: In Memoriam
description: COOKESelma Hagen, departed August 12, 1969. In loving memory of beloved wife, mother, and grandmother. Your memory is always with us.

title: Democracy in Ocean Hill
description: Assemblyman Samuel D. Wright, in his welltimed warning to obstructionists in Ocean HillBrownsville, left no doubt that the local community school board intends to open all the schools in the embattled Brooklyn district on schedule. As the duly elected chairman of the local board, he speaks with the full authority of a community representative and an offi cial in the decentralized system.

title: Utility Orders Nuclear Fuel
description: The General Public Utilities Corporation said yesterday that its Jersey Central Power and Light subsidiary had contracted for $27million of enriched nu clear fuel from the General Electric Company and the Jer sey Nuclear Company. The four reloads of nuclear fuel are for its Oyster Creek nuclear gen erating station.

title: China Picks Belgrade Envoy
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 11 (AP)Communist China has appointed an Ambassador to Yugoslavia in another move to ward improving relations be tween the two countries, which were strained for more than ten years. The Yugoslav press agency Tanyug reported from Peking that the new envoy was Tseng Tao, who served earlier as Ambassador in Al gerai.

title: Paper Links Red Teacher To Gun in Coast Court Raid
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 11 (AP)A rifle and pistol used in the fatal escape attempt by three convicts at San Rafael last week were originally pur chased by Angela Davis, the Communist instructor, The San Francisco Examiner reported to day.

title: Threat in Broken German
description: BONN, Aug. 11The bomb threat that delayed the take off of Chancellor Brandt's plane was telephoned at 1.05 P.M. to the air traffic safety center at Bonn airport.

title: Miss Bruce Heads Qualifiers In Junior Golf With 80 for 163
description: RYE, N. Y., Aug. 11Louise Bruce of La Mesa, Calif., won the 36hole net qualifying medal in the 22d annual United States Golf Association junior girls championship today.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: U. S. Mideast Stakes

title: Stop Con Ed Movement Is Begun by a New Group
description: Leading environmentalists and medical authorities joined forces yesterday to oppose the expansion of Consolidated Edi son's power plant in Astoria, Queens, on the ground that it would add intolerable levels of air pollution.

title: King Yields Top Job at Colorado Corp.
description: John M. King, the Denver oil man who gained worla prominence in his unsuccess ful bid to gain control of In vestors Overseas Services, sur prised the financial world yes terday by disclosing that he would step down as chairman of the Colorado Corporation, an oil development company he largely owns.

title: Tate Witness Tells Murder Jury of Thinking She Was a Witch
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 11 Linda Kasabian testified today that she thought she was a witch at the time of the seven killings for which Charles M. Manson is on trial here.

title: UPSTATERS TAKE SEARS CUP LEAD
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 11 The Central New York Yacht Racing Association crew, rep resented by David Penfield of the Willow Bank Yacht Club of Cazenovia, took a 3point lead today in the first three races of the Area B semifinal series of the North American junior sailing championship off the Riverside Y. C.

title: Prosecution Rests in Panther Trial in New Haven
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 11 The prosecution rested its case this afternoon against Lonnie McLucas, a Black Panther party member who has been on trial here in connection with the killing last year of Alex Rack ley.

title: Medina Says Vietnam Police Killed 2 Linked to Him
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Aug. 11Capt. Ernest L. Medina, expanding his version of events surrounding the alleged mas sacre of South Vietnamese at Songmy says that two of the murders he is charged with were committed by the South Vietnamese national police.

title: Getty Oil Co. Announces Organization Realignment
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug 11 (AP) The Getty Oil Company said today it was making a major organizational realignment.

title: City Ballet Will Open 2Week Season Aug. 25
description: The New York City Ballet will present 18 ballets from the repertory in a special twoweek season at the State Theater from Tuesday eve ning, Aug. 25, through Sun day afternoon. Sept. 6.

title: Storm Victims Get Trailers
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UPI)George Romney, Secre tary of Housing and Urban De velopment, said today that arrangements had been made with manufacturers to provide free mobile homes to 350 Texas families left homeless by Hur ricane Celia. The storm victims can use the homes until they are able to rebuild their own premises.

title: A Listing of New Books
description: Japan in Postwar Asia, by Law rence Olson (Council on Foreign Relations: Praeger, $10).

title: BRANDT IN SOVIET FOR PACT SIGNING
WORKERS RETURN AT UNITED PARCEL
description: United Parcel workers, wear ing American flag emblems in their lapels, returned to their jobs throughout the metropoli tan area yesterday, ending a twoweek dispute over the wearing of lapel buttons that had disrupted service.

title: PROFIT MARK SET AT NORTON SIMON
Coast Gasoline Bill Rejected
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 11 (AP)A state Senate com mittee has killed a billstrong ly opposed by several major oil companies that would have banned antiknock lead compounds from gasolines sold in California by 1977. The bill would have set a national trend in forcing oil companies to de velop lowlead and nolead gasolines, said Assemblyman Peter F. Schabarum, the bill's author.

title: A Real Hamburger a Success in London
description: LONDON, Aug. 11The great American Disaster has struck London. Berkeley co eds, Boston hippies and even the British stand on Fulham Road to push into the tiny, woodpaneled restaurant that offers Great American Milkshakes, Great Amer ican Apple Pie and, of course, the Great American Hamburger.

title: Files Earns Job as Giants No. 1 Middle Linebacker
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., Aug. 11For the second season in a row the Giants appeared to have struck it rich with their first draft choice. Jim Files, the country boy from the University of Oklahoma, has everyone in the C. W. Post training camp satisfied with his work at middle line backer.

title: Train Tickets on Sale Today For GiantJet Game Aug. 23
description: Football fans will be able to take a special train to New Haven for the GiantJet game Aug. 23, the Penn Central Rail road said yesterday.

title: Engineer Is Injured in Stoning Of Penn Central Train in Bronx
description: A fivefootlong cardboard tube filled with stones was hurled through the windshield of a northbound Penn Central train in the Bronx yesterday afternoon, cutting the 52yearold engineer about the eyes,

title: A Pioneer Company of Space Age Retires
description: DENVILLE, N. J., Aug. 11 One of the first and once one of the biggest of the space age companies, Reac tion Motors, will be nothing by tomorrow night except a string of empty plants and a few abandoned concrete test standswhere giant rocket engines used to flare and roar, shaking foundations for miles around at all hours of the day and night.

title: 46 DRUG SUSPECTS HELD IN JERSEY RAID
description: PLAINFIELD, N. J., Aug. 11 (AP)  A predawn drug raid, conducted by the state and lo cal police in three counties, resulted today in the arrest of 46 nersons.

title: U.S. LINES EXTENDS ITS CONTAINER RUN
description: When the 700foot container ship American Astronaut sails from Port Newark on Sept. 10 for San Francisco, Honolulu, Hong Kong, Kobe and Yoko hama, it will be a new depar ture for United States Lines in more than one sense.

title: Two Springer Papers Disclose Text of Treaty Ahead of Time
description: BONN, Aug. 11Two morn ing newspapers of the conserv ative publisher Axel Springer published today the text of the SovietWest German treaty, which is to be signed in Mos cow tomorrow and has not been officially made public.

title: 2 BY GIBBS MARK A 14HIT ASSAULT
description: Ralph Houk's uptown coop, otherwise known as the New York Yankees, accepted con tributions from all sides yester day to defeat the Chicago White Sox, 71, at Yankee Stadium.

title: Bridge Walkers Find Free Way to Get A way From City
description: It is early morning on the Brooklyn Bridge. The harbor glistens, and overhead thick white clouds are suspended as though giants had splattered spoonfuls of whipped cream against the light blue sky. Far in the distance an airplane's jetstream unfolds behind the Statue of Liberty and, for a startling moment, it seems as though the lady's torch is smoking.

title: Injured Bombing Suspect Is Arraigned in Hospital
description: A former college student who lost both arms and a leg in a bomb explosion in Manhattan last March was arraigned yes terday in Bellevue Hospital on an indictment accusing him of one bombing and an attempted bombing in the Bronx one week before he was injured.

title: Costello Is Given a Petition Protesting Reactor in City
description: A petition with 1,000 signa tures protesting Columbia Uni versity's plan to install an atomic reactor on its campus near 120th Street and Amster dam Avenue was presented yesterday to Deputy Mayor Tim othy W. Costello.

title: F.T.C. Submits Ad Curbs On Insect and Weed Killers
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission proposed restrictions today on advertisements for insect and weed killers, including the posting of a prominent health warning.

title: CORNELIUS C. MOORE, NEWPORT LAWYER, 85
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 11 (AP) Cornelius C. Moore, lawyer, banker, philanthropist and long time power in Democratic cir cles, died today at his home here. He was 85 years old.

title: Atlanta Dormitory Burns
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 11 (AP)A fouralarm fire destroyedv a dormitory of Spelman College here early today, but the lone occupant of the building es caped without injury.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT

title: HAROLD HERMAN, 68, EXSUPERVISOR ON L.I.
description: NEW MILFORD, Conn., Aug. 11Harold P. Herman, former presiding supervisor of the Town of Hempstead, L. I., died on Sunday at his summer home here, apparently of a heart at tack. He was 68 years old and lived also at 34 Hamilton Place, Garden City, L. I.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: ECONOMIC AND

title: Advertising: Y.&
description: Wall Street had its paper work explosion in 196768 and we all know what that led to  backoffice snafus, shortened trading hours and many administrative foulups that continued until the cur rent market decline.

title: NERVE GAS TRAINS AT CAROLINA PORT
description: SUNNY POINT, N. C., Aug. 11 (AP)The first of two heavily guarded trains carrying lethal nerve gas rolled into this mili tary port tonight, with the sec ond close behind.

title: CECYLIA B. ROTHER
description: Cecylia B. Rother, executive secretary of the National Insti tute for Architectural Educa tion, died Saturday at French Hospital. She was 72 years old and lived at 150 East 37th Street.

title: 2 Bronx Policemen Held in Shakedown Of a Store Owner
description: Two Bronx patrolmen were arrested yesterday in connec tion with an alleged $15 shake down of the owner of a shoe repair shop who had com plained that he was being asked to pay in return for having minor traffic violation over looked.

title: Mario Bernardi Shows His Skill As a Conductor
description: The best conductors cre ate a sense of design in mu sic. Hearing them one feels a mind at work, shaping, bal ancing, setting details in place in a grand, developing structure.

title: JUDGE ORDERS STAY ON DISMISSING CADET
description: A Federal judge ordered the Army yesterday not to take any further steps to a West Point cadet from the United States Military Acad emy until a court can pass on his attempt to get a discharge as a conscientious objector.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Theater

title: M'SORLEY INCIDENT DISTURBS OFFICIAL
description: Mrs. Eleanor Homes Norton, the city's Commissioner of Hu man Rights, issued a statement yesterday calling reports that, one woman was subjected toll unusual harassment by the management and patrons of Mc Sorley's Old Ale House very disturbing.

title: RISE IN NET LISTED BY UTILITIES CORP.
description: The report of the Interna tional Utilities Corporation dis closed yesterday a record net income of $8,234,000, or 57 cents a share for the second quarter, up from $5,264,000, or 38 cents, last year.

title: Palestinians Regard Truce as a Betrayal
description: KARAMEH, Jordan, Aug. 10Even in the searing sun, with dust on his shirt and his skin after a long morning in the fields of the Jordan Valley, the farmhand named Khalil had strength to vent his wrath.

title: Radiation Researcher Opposes Nuclear Plants in Urban Areas
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Aug. 11  A leading health physicist who is a pioneer in radiation protection research told an in ternational gathering of atomic energy experts today that he opposed the installation of nu clear power plants in or near large urban areas.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON EASE IN SLOW DAY
LUDDY IS RETURNING GIFTS FOR CAMPAIGN
description: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 11 William F. Luddy, the West chester County Democratic chairman, announced today that he was returning a third of the contributions to his campaign for reelection because he didn't need the money after all.

title: Uruguayans Will Erect A Memorial fo Mitrione
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 The State Department an nounced today that Uruguay planned to erect a memorial in Montevideo to Dan A. Mit done, the American slain by Uruguayan terrorists, and to name a street there after him.

title: ExChief of Jersey's National Guard Is Indicted
description: TRENTON, Aug. 11  Maj. Gen. James F. Cantwell, the former chief of the New Jer sey National Guard and the current president of the Na tional Guard Association of the United States, was indicted to dgy on charges of having used state employes to make addi tions to and improvements on his home.

title: ARMY SETS HEARING FOR SONGMY FIGURE

title: Nixon's Inflation Alert
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11The first inflation alert from Pres ident Nixon's Council of Eco nomic Advisers did not send anyone. running for the bomb shelter. Chairman Paul W. Mc Cracken told the press that he thought there is some evidence that after a long period here we are beginning to see some things shaping up in the price area that gives some hope that we are going to make some real progress in the period ahead. Was Mr. McCracken's optimism not shaken by Ford's announcement of a price increase on both cars and trucks? No, he replied, his optimism was based on the totality of evidence.
