description: It doesn't pay to be a glamour stock these days.

title: Elizabeth Shepherd Signed
description: Elizabeth Shepherd has been signed for the female lead in Barry England's play, Conduct Unbecoming. The Donald Al hery and Roger L. Stevens pro duction is scheduled to open Oct. 12 at the Ethel Barrymore Theater.

title: Censorship in Israel
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 12  Military censorship has been in effect in Israel since the forma tion of the state in 1948. It is said to concern only military information affecting the secur ity of the state. Israeli as well as foreign correspondents fall under the regulations.

title: 13 IN JAIL ESCAPE REMAIN AT LARGE
description: ROCHESTER, Aug. L2 (UPI) A countywide manhunt was on here today for the remain ing prisoners who escaped from the Monroe County penitenti ary yesterday by chipping the mortar from the walls of the preCivil War structure. By this atternoon authorities had rearrested nine of the 24 fugitives.

title: KODES AND NASTASE ADVANCE IN TENNIS
description: HAMBURG, Germany, Aug. 12 (UPI)Jan Kodes of Czecho slovakia and Die Nastase of Rumania scored easy victories today in the West German ten nis championships.

title: Sports of The Times
description: I wake up smiling, said Jim Bouton the other day. As a player you can't allow yourself the luxury of that kind of feeling. You'd never stay tough. As a player, you're always judged on your next performance. The year I won 21 games I felt great. But by the next spring training, it was all ancient history and I had the nagging feeling that I might not be able to do it again. After I won my first World Series game I knew I would have to win another in three days or the first wouldn't count at all. But a book lasts longer, there's more of a glow, and people aren't expecting another one too soon. Besides, if you write a book big enough you can smile the rest of your life.

title: Charles B. Crockett, Headed HarperAtlantic Sales Arm
description: DEDHAM, Mass., Aug. 12 Charles B. Crockett, who re tired as chairman of the board of HarperAtlantic Sales, Inc., in 1965, died yesterday in Bos ton. He was 70 years old and lived here.

title: WEICKER, MESKILL WIN IN PRIMARIES
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 12 Con necticut's two Republican mem bers of the House of Repre sentatives won their party's nomination for Governor and United States Senator by wide margins today in the first state wide primary election in history here.

title: ScrippsHoward Purchases Daily Tabloid in San Juan
description: ScrippsHoward Newspapers said yesterday that it had com pleted the purchase of the San Juan (P. R.), Star from Cowles Communications for $9,750,000 in cash.

title: MRS. CHESTER L. BROWN
description: SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Aug. 12 Mrs. Alice Cover Brown, wife of Chester L. Brown, a retired investment banker, died yester day at East Orange General Hospital. She was 70 years old and lived on Forest Drive.

title: CocaCola Upgrades 300 Working in Florida Groves
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 12 (AP) The CocaCola Company an nounced today that it had es tablished new job classifica tions and granted wage in creases averaging 23 per cent to about 300 workers employed in the company's citrus groves. in Florida.

title: GOVERNORS SEEK SHIFT IN FUND USE
description: OSAGE BEACH, Mo., Aug. 12 The nation's Governors closed their 62d annual con ference today by urging Con gress to let them spend a part of their Federal highway aid for other transportation proj ects such as urban transit.

title: 4 in New Mexico Charged In Death of Bronx Man, 25
description: LAS VEGAS, N. M., Aug. 12 Murder charges were filed here today against four men accused of slaying a 25yearold New Yorker described by authorities as a resident of a hippie commune.

title: Negro Leaders Are Jailed as Racial Turmoil Comes to Homer, La.
description: HOMER, La., Aug. 8Calvin Willis turned off the alarm clock and lay back in bed. It was 5 A.M., an hour and a half before daylight.

title: N.E.T. TV Project Seeks Young Audiences for Opera
description: The best hope for the de velopment of a new audience for opera among young peo ple is to develop a species of antiopera, said Peter Her man Adler, who has been pre occupied with the art in a major part of his 70 years.

title: PRICE COMPETITION ON OIL IS HELD SLIM
description: LAS VEGAS, Aug. 12Price competition in the oil industry is practically nonexistent be cause of the concentration of most of the market in the hands of few large companies, an official of the Federal Trade Commission said today.

title: DEAN SCHEDLER, 55, A.P. WAR REPORTER
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) Dean L. Schedler, a World War II reporter for The Asso ciated Press, died here today after a long illness. He was 55 years old.

title: A Listing of New Books
description: A Murder of Crows, by Patrick Buchanan (Stein & Day, $4.95). Superstition and greed combine in murder.

title: 2 Horse Troughs Found In City Storage Center
description: Two drinking troughs, relics of an era when the city's streets resounded to the rhythmic clop and clatter of hooves rather than the roar of engines, have been found in a Highway Department storage facility near 159th Street and the West Side Highway.

title: First Lady Visits 2 Camps
description: POINT LOOKOUT, Md., Aug. 13 (AP)Mrs. Richard M. Nixon visited today two sum mer camps for underprivileged children from Baltimore and Washington. The First Lady flew 200 miles aboard the Presi dent's helicopter for a tour of Camp Concern, in Bainbridge, Md., and the D. C. recreation camp in Scotland, Md. Most of her day was spent greeting the children and discussing with them topics ranging from long hair to drugs.

title: Bengals Face Loss of Cook
description: WILMINGTON, Ohio, Aug. 13 (UPI)The Cincinnati Bengals quarterback, Greg Cook, will undergo surgery to correct a muscle tear in his throwing arm. Coach Paul Brown said today. Brown said Cook prob ably would be lost for the season. He said Sam Wyche would be the No. 1 quarter back.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Israel's Defense Minister, Moshe Dayan, told parliament yesterday that Israelis had seen Soviet antiaircraft missiles being moved closer to the Suez Canal shortly after the Middle East ceasefire went into effect. He asked the United States, which had prom ised Israel that no military change would result from the halt in fighting, to arrange for the withdrawal of the missile batteries. [Page 1, Column 4; Text, P. 6.]

title: Nerve Gas Move Is Barred Till Judge Hears All Views
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13A Federal judge ordered the Army today not to move a ship laden with nerve gas from her North Carolina berth until all possi bilities for disposing of the lethal cargo had been consid ered by the court.

title: Bills Here to Go Up 4%
description: ALBANY, Aug. 13The Pub lic Service Commission today authorized $90million in rate increases for Con Edison, an amount $29million less than the company had originally re quested.

Honorary pallbearers in cluded members of the St. John's team that won the Na itional Invitation Tournament for Mr. Lapchick in 1965, the ???car he retired.

title: ECONOMIC GAUGES INDICATE AN END TO BUSINESS LAG
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13A group of new figures on recent economic activity, reported to day by Government agencies, all supported the thesis that the business downturn had ended or was ending.

title: DAYAN URGES U.S, TO COMPEL EGYPT TO RESPECT TRUCE

description: PORTLAND, Me., Aug. 13Robinson Verrill St., a lawyer prominent in Maine Republican politics for many years, died in a hospital here today after a long illness. He was 73 years old.

title: U.S. Five to Play in Moscow

The Americans are young players who could play for the United States in the 1972 Olympics at Munich. The quintet won two games in Finland and two in Poland.

description: Seven selfproclaimed paci fists were arrested yesterday when they dumped 14 gallons of steers blood from plastic jugs on the stone steps of the United States Court House in Foley Square. Marshalls held them on Federal charges.

title: REID CALLS FOR CURB ON NEWS SUBPOENAS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (UPI) Representative Ogden R. Reid, Republican of Westches ter, introduced legislation today to protect newsmen from being compelled by Federal courts or agencies to disclose their confi dential sources of information.

title: Those Symbols and Images He Designs Look Like Shoes
description: If this story had been writ ten last week, it would have been about a shoe designer. This week, after an encounter with Albert Van Slyke, a selfstyled neurotic non stop talker from California, one knows there is no such thing as a shoe designer. As a matter of fact, there is no such thing as shoes. That, in ef fed, leaves us back with Mr. Van Slyke who is  what? I am a creator of non verbal symbols and images, he said, in as straight. forward a manner as one can from behind glasses the color of strong consomm. I say something different, he added. I use a directional, conceptional and diagnostic approach. Exactly. But, nonetheless, the objects on display looked precisely like what used to be called shoes.

title: House Sends Nixon Bill With Controls He Does Not Want
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) The House sent to President Nixon today a bill giving him standby authorization to freeze wages and prices temporarily authority that he has said he did not want and would not use.

description: RESEARCH TRIANGLE, N. C.A dozen years ago, this spot on the earth looked essentially as it did when Richard Hakluyt, an 18th century English historian, called it the goodliest land under the cope of heaven.

title: KOREANS SOFTEN STAND ON CUTBACK
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 13The South Korean Govern ment is prepared to start seri ous talks on United States plans to withdraw about one third of its troops as soon as iron clad assurances have been provided for modernizing the South Korean armed forces.

title: Viral Meningitis Outbreak Stirs Concern in City
description: More than 100 additional cases of viral meningitis, some more than a week old, have been reported to the city since Wednesday, and the De partment of Health said yes terday that while its figures were scattered and far from complete, it was certain that every borough was affected.

title: GLAMOURSTOCKS LOSE MORE GROUND
description: The stock market witnessed yesterday another battering, of glamour issues with high price earnings ratios.

title: Washington: Communist Policies and Economies
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13The reaction here to the So vietWest German nonaggres sion treaty is very calm. The old fears of another Rapallo at the expense of the West have scarcely been mentioned. There is no excitement, no exaggerat ed claims or anxieties, but rather a mature tendency to watch and wait before reach ing any thumping historic conclusions.

title: Cigarette Cargo Hijacked
description: Three gunmen hijacked a truck with $41,400 worth of cigarettes on the Clearview Ex pressway in Queens yesterday, the police said. The driver of the truck, owned by the Mod ern Tobacco Co., Port Chester, N. Y. escaped after the truck was Y., to a stop. The driv er's helper was forced into the gunmen's car but released un harmed a short time later. The police said the driver was Joseph Proeta and the helper, Frank Santiago, both of Port Chester.

title: 5 COMPETITORS LEAD IN U.S. CHESS OPEN
description: BOSTON, Aug. 13  Five competitors, each with a clean sweep of 4 to 0, led the players after the fourth round of the 71st annual United States Open Championship at the Parker House here last night.

title: Blacks in Boston Protest Dropping of a TVProgram
description: BOSTON, Aug. 13 (AP)A group of blacks today protested at the offices of the Boston Ed ucational Television station, WGBHTV over an announce ment it would drop an allblack program Say Brother after a final rerun on Aug. 27.

title: Witness Says Manson Gives Off Vibrations in the Courtroom
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 13Linda Kasabian testified today that she believed in reincar nation, had experienced extra sensory perception and could (communicate with animals and that Charles M. Manson was giving off vibrations in the courtroom.

title: CONTINENTAL PHONE SHOWS PEAK PROFITS
description: Record revenues and profits were reported yesterday by the Continental Telephone Corpora tion, the nation's thirdlargest independent telephone system.

title: Mitchell Will Bolster Staff for School Rights Suits
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13Attorney General John N. Mitchell said today that the Justice Department would. reinforce its legal staff in the South if necessary to handle problems of desegregation this fall, and he gave a Sen ate committee assurance that citizens with complaints would be able to ask for action without fear of retali ation. If there is any thought of retaliation, we will take the swiftest and most dra matic action available, Mr. Mitchell told the Senate Se lect Committee on Equal Educational Opportunity. He said his department would augment its civil rights staff with 50 lawyers if they should be needed. The number is half that mentioned last month by Assistant Attorney General Jerris Leonard as a force planned for the purpose. Mr. Mitchell later disavowed the plan cited by Mr. Leonard and repeated his disavowal to day. However, under question ing by Senator Birch Bayh, Democrat of Indiana, the At torney General said that the 50 lawyers would be in addition to the 28 lawyers in the division specializing in desegregation cases.

title: MARY BUDKE GAINS JUNIOR SEMIFINAL
description: RYE, N. Y., Aug. 13  Mary Budke of Dayton, Ore., 16yearold Western junior champion, led the way into the semifinal round of the 22d annual United. States Golf Association's girls junior championship today.

title: Bridge:
Canadian Bill Rate Falls
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 13 (Reuters)The average yield on today's weekly issue of $150million in 91day Government of Canada treasury bills declined to 5.72 per cent from last week's 5.77 per cent. The average price rose to $98.593 from $98.583. On the weekly issue of $40mil lion in 182day bills, the aver age yield rose to 5.94 per cent from last week's 5.87 per cent.

title: Pentagon's Inner Sanctum: An Ominous Clock and Lots of Candy
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13The last hot line message to Moscow this morning was a poem by Robert Frost. The Joint Chiefs of Staff munch gobs of candy in their secret deliberations. And an ominous clock on the wall will light up if the Pentagon implements the seoarate Plan for China.

title: 1,000 Riders Stranded As Queens Subway Stalls
description: More than 1,000 subway rid ers were stranded yesterday just outside the East River tun nel in Queens as a EE train was stalled for 35 minutes dur ing the rush hour.

title: LOMBARDI RECEIVES TRIBUTE IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) Members of the House of Representatives paid tribute to day to Vince Lombardi, the Washington Redskins coach, and wished him well.

title: LOEB WANTS U. S. TO RUN GAMBLING
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13Carl M. Loeb Jr., president of the National Council on Crime and Delinquency, recommended today that the Federal Govern ment legalize, computerize and run gambling at all levels to de prive organized crime of a major portion of its income.

title: Political Kidnappings Spread Insecurity Through Latin America
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 12The spread of political kid nappings in Latin America is shaking governments and forc ing embassies to spend more time worrying about security than about foreign relations. In the nearly unanimous opin ion of officials, no solution is likely to be found, short of eliminating all terrorists.

title: Agnew Plans to Visit Four Nations in Asia
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13Vice President Agnew will make a second visit to Asia this month to reassure United States allies of President Nixon's continuing personal interest in that part of the world, the White House an nounced today.

title: LANGLEY PLANS SALE OF BIG BOARD SEAT
description: W. C. Langley & Co., an old line member of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday that it would sell its seat on the exchange, dissolve its general partnership and form an investmentbanking firm.

title: ARMS TALKS CLOSE. VIENNA ROUND TODAY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13The United States and the So viet Union plan to issue a sevenparagraph communique tomorrow to end the Vienna round of the talks on the limi tation of strategic arms.

title: BARGE CARGO BILL PASSED BY HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (UPI)The House has passed by voice vote a bill to nullify an Interstate Commerce Com mission ruling affecting com modities carried by barge on most inland waters.

title: Alvarez, Gardner Gain Semifinals in Grass Court Tennis
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 13The decline of organized amateur tennis in the United States has begun, and you need look no further than the na tional court championships to see its sagging state.

title: FreeFloating Merchant Marine
description: The United States Lines, which has drawn more than a halfbillion dollars in Federal operating sub sidies in the last three decades, is about to go off Uncle Sam's welfare rolls. When the cargo ship Pioneer Crusader leaves New York for Japan on Sunday, it will be starting the last subsidized run for this giant of the American merchant marine.

title: Brandt, Throat Sore, Tries Russian Remedy
description: MOSCOW, Aug 13Chan cellor Willy Brandt, who has been suffering from a sore throat, said today that Soviet doctors had introduced him to a Russian home remedy.

title: Opera by Berio Is Given Premiere in Santa Fe
description: SANTA FE, N. M., Aug. 13 Now Luciano Berio, one of the heroes of the interna tional avantgarde, has com posed an opera. With pristine simplicity he has named it Opera, though the title is not to be construed as opera opera. Rather it is the plural of opus. It received its world premiere here last night, and I am afraid that nobody liked it.

title: Kemperco Reports a Decline In Earnings for First Half
description: Kemperco, Inc., reported yes terday that earnings in the first half fell to $2,163,000, or 48 cents a share, from $2,298,000, or 54 cents a share, a year earlier. Excluded is a realized capital loss of 13 cents a share in this period, contrasted with a gain of 3 cents a share last year.

title: Sports of
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 13When the New York Turf Writers Associa tion has its annual dinner dance at the nostalgically attractive Canfield Casino here on Saturday night, the main awards will be distributed VS Charles Engelhard, the romantically named platinum king; to Paul Mellon, the internationally known philanthropist and art patron; to Elliott Burch, trainer par excellence, and to John ny Rotz.

title: CONFEREES SPEED TV SPENDING CURB
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13House and Senate conferees agreed today to make the spending limits on political broadcasting effective in this year's election campaigns, but they appeared to have lost their Republican support for the re form measure in the process.

title: NUTRIENTS DRAWN FROM SEA IN TEST
description: Cold water on the ocean bot tom in the tropics that is ex tremely rich in nutrients is being piped by Columbia Uni versity scientists to a research station in St. Croix in the Vir gin Islands to determine whether it can be used to pro mote increased seafood production.

title: ExInmates of Tombs Recall It as Brutal
description: In 1954 Prentiss Williams spent two days at the Tombs awaiting transfer to the state prison at Comstock. It was his first experience with incarcer ation in an adult facility and the 38yearold man remembers the Manhattan House of Deten tion for Men as a haunting place.

title: SECRETARY SLAIN ON THE EAST SIDE
description: A 31yearold medical secre tary was found shot to death early yesterday morning in her apartment at 145 East 35th Street.

title: Minority Construction Firm Awarded Airport Contract
description: The Federal Aviation Admin istration and the Small Busi ness Administration yesterday awarded a $299,600 contract to a minority construction firm.

title: War Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) The Defense Department to day listed the names of the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Southeast Asia.

title: Judith I. Dresher Becomes a Bride
description: Miss Judith Illene Dresher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard,Dresher of Brooklyn, was married last night in the East Midwood Jewish Center in Brooklyn to Jonas M. Rosenthal, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Rosenthal of New Milford, N. J. Rabbi Harry Halpern performed the ceremony.

title: House RollCalls on Vetoes
Senate Passes Stock Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (UPI) The Senate passed and sent to the House today a bill to in crease from $300,000 to $500, 000 the amount of a stock issue that may be exempted from certain Securities and Exchange Commission registration re quirements.

title: 170 Policemen in Newark Reassigned in 2d ShakeUp
description: NEWARK, Aug. 13 (UPI)Ten lieutenants and 160 other men in the Newark Police De partment were transferred to day in the second major shake up initiated by Police Director John L. Redden.

title: BOARD APPROVES BANK ACQUISITION
description: Directors of the Chemical New York Corporation, parent company of the Chemical Bank, approved in principle yester day the acquisition of the Tap pan Zee National Bank of Ny ack. N. Y.

title: BIG 4 LEADERS PLAN TO SPEAK AT THE U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 13  President Nixon, Prime Minister Heath of Britain, Premier Jacques ChabanDelmas of France and Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union are tentatively scheduled to speak at the 25th anniversary session of the General Assembly this fall.

title: Great Northern Paper Co. Plans To Raise Prices, Effective Oct: 1
description: Price changes were an nounced yesterday for metal and paper products.

title: Credit Markets: Prices of Bonds Drop
description: Corporate bond prices de clined yesterday as more fi nancing plans were made pub lic, partly as a direct result of the decline in interest rates that took place in June and July.

title: Weekend Fishing and Boating
description: AREA AA dry northeast er with winds of up to 40 miles an hour on Tuesday halted fishing for two days in this area, but with the re turn of good weather yester day, the reports are opti mistic. Blues and flukes in the 3to5 pound class were being taken in plentiful'num bers yesterday by party boats a few miles off the New Jersey coast. Larger blues were available further out. Tuna, from 8 to 15 pounds, were biting about five miles north of Barnegat Inlet, with a few bonito mixed in the catch. Churned up water from the north easter has left bottom fisher men hoping for clearing con ditions.

title: U.S. WAR DEATHS INCREASE IN WEEK
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 13 (AP)  The United States command reported to day that 85 Americans were killed in action in Indochina last week, seven more than the previous week and the highest weekly toll since before Ameri can ground forces withdrew from Cambodia on June 30.

title: Record Company Here Makes Album by Stokes
description: Flying Dutchman Records an nounced yesterday that Mayor Carl Stokes of Cleveland had completed the first album for the company under a longterm contract.

title: Television for Candidates...
description: By a gratifyingly onesided vote the House of Representatives has passed a historic bill to reduce the onesided use of television campaign funds. It is a breakthrough in the complex field of election finance because it effectively deals with the medium that candidates find at once the most effective and the most forbiddingly expensive. Unlike the Senate bill, it includes campaigns for governor and, even more important, it applies to primaries as well as general elections.

title: New Addiction Agency Chief
description: What the Mayor had laid out as the requirement, ex plained Deputy Mayor Rich ard R. Aurelio, was a man with an open mind, who wasn't committed to any methods, wasn't in any of the schools.

title: COLLEGELIVING FUND GIVEN FOSTER CHILD
description: An 18yearold foster child from Queens who won a tuition scholarship to the State Univer sity of New York at Buffalo has been awarded $2,500 a year from a private organization so that she can live in an on campus dormitory instead of boarding in a new foster home.

title: Theater: A New Play by Piri Thomas
JOHN W. MANSON
description: ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 12 Jhn W. Manson, advertising and sales promotion director of Greenwood Mills, Inc., New York textile manufacturers, died at a hospital here today. He was 57 years old and lived in Short Hills.

title: RAILTON MILEAGE SHOWS A 2.9% DIP
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13Freight traffic on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage last week were both below the volume in the corre sponding week of 1969.

title: Nicklaus and Miller Shoot 2UnderPar 68's and Lead P.G.A. by Stroke
description: TULSA, Okla., Aug. 13On a day when the temperature on the course was over 100 de grees, Jack Nicklaus cooled off a bit after yesterday's practice round of 64, and scored a 68 today to share the lead in the Professional Golfers Associa tion championship.

title: Deaths
Yonkers Drivers
Deficit Is Erased
description: The General Dynamics Cor poration showed a sharp re covery in the second quarter and first half of this year with profitable operations in con trast to deficits in 1969, the mid year report of Roger Lewis, president, disclosed yes terday. Directors, however, omitted dividend action on the common stock for the second quarter. A quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share had been maintained since 1965.

title: Euphoria in Europe
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 13Con tented, relaxed and affluent, Western Europeans have turned their faces to the summer sun and their backs on the East West conflict and the anxieties of a quarter of a century. Only a few thousand start cancers and diplomats stuck in cheer less offices are immune to the general euphoria. They sit and pon der the difference between the So viet Union's su perficially concili atory attitude, as evidenced by the new BonnMoscow treaty, for example, and the realities of increasingly massive military power in the East. The politi cians, they comment wearily, know the score. But politicians are sensitive to national moods and apparently recognize that warnings would be disregarded in the current atmosphere.

title: Berlin Wall 9Years Old and Unyielding
description: BERLIN, Aug. 13The Ber lin wall, that symbol of East West hostility, ended its ninth year today, outwardly as for bidding as ever.

title: NoFault Car Insurance Measure Signed by Sargent on Television
description: BOSTON, Aug. 13 (AP)Gov. Francis W. Sargent, on a state wide television hookup tonight, signed a bill giving Massachu setts the first nofault automo bile insurance plan in the nation.

title: Heat Forces Reduction
description: Consolidated Edison cut its voltage 5 per cent yesterday aft ernoon as the demand for pow er rose sharply with the tem peratures in the low 90's

title: HOUSE SEARCHES STIR URUGUAYANS
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 13 (AP)  Student dem onstrations and bombings add ed to the tension today as thou sands of policemen and troops, ignoring the protests of home owners, continued a houseby house search for two kid napped foreigners.

title: Transport News and Notes
description: BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., Aug. 13 (AP)A spot check by state police and Federal highway inspectors of more than 50 charter buses has re sulted in summonses for 26 drivers and five buses being ordered off the road, authori ties disclosed today.

title: Market Place:
description: It wasn't too long ago that oil stocks, beset by a wide variety of problems, were battered down to their low est levels since the early nine teensixties. Petrophbia was the, way one Wall Street ob server described the situation.

title: Open Mind on Drugs
description: Drug abuse spreads; youngsters continue to die; the utter ineffectiveness of New York City's drug program has long made plain the need for a searching appraisal of present policies and a thorough overhaul of the Addiction Services Agency. The agency's relationship with the private Phoenix House Foundation, which owns most of the city's treatment facilities, also re quires careful review.

title: FREED ARABS REACH CAIRO FROM ATHENS
description: CAIRO, Aug. 13 (Reuters)Seven Arab commandos freed by Greece last night arrived here today, according to the Middle East News Agency.

title: Clean Air Panel in House
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) Fifteen House members an nounced today the formation of an informal Congressional Clean Air Committee and jointly in troduced a series of stiff anti smog amendments.

title: Nixon's Veto Strategy
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 The decision by the House to day to sustain President Nixon's veto of the independent offices appropriations bill but override him on the education money bill would appear on its face to be an even split. But inside the White House this afternoon there was much satisfaction at the outcome. Most of Mr. Nixon's po litical strategists believe that he emerged from his latest and perhaps most delicate confrontation vuoith Congress with his reputa tion as a defender of the dollar against a profligate Congress not only intact but also en hanced.

title: Spain Said to Forbid U.S. Use Of Bases in Any Mideast Crisis
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13The United States cannot use its three air bases in Spain for military operations during any crisis involving the Arab states and Israel, informed military sources said today.

title: FLEET OF 22 SAILS FOR BLOCK ISLAND
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., Aug. 13 A fleet of 22 cruising yachts sailing in two divisions began the Storm Trysail Club's Gover nor of Rhode Island race from off Larchmont Yacht Club this evening in a sevenknot south erly breeze. A. M. Bretschger's new 48foot sloop, Enzian, sailed as highest rated yacht for the 100mile passage through Long Island Sound, around the Watch Hill, R. I., fairway buoy and across to Block Island. Jacob Isbrandt sen's new 60foot sloop, Run ning Tide, is listed at scratch.

title: Marna Rothenberg Prospective Bride
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 13  Mr. and Mrs. Arthur S. Rothenberg have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marna Lois Rothenberg, to Jerome Edward Sag, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Sag of Valley Stream.

title: Lifeguards in 2 Areas Say Strike Is Set for Saturday
description: Unionized lifeguards at the Palisades Interstate Park and Taconic Park Commission's lakes and pools announced last night they would go on strike at 8 A.M. Saturday in a bid to gain wage parity with Long Island State Park Commission lifeguards.

title: Metello 1Length Victor in Saratoga Hurdles
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 13  Metello, owned by Milton Ritzenberg, moved to the front early and stayed there almost all the way to score a surprise victory in the $17,750 Lovely Night Hurdle Handicap today. The event, raced for the 14th time, attracted a field of nine, and Metello covered the 116 miles in the good time of 3:43 45. He was ridden by Doug Small and returned a mu tuel price of $40.60 for $2.

title: Magnus Bredenbek, Editor And Assemblyman, Dead
description: EAST ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 13Magnus Bredenbek, a for mer managing editor of The Newark Ledger and a Demo cratic Assemblyman from. Hud son County early in the cen tury, died in an automobile accident at Silver Beach, near Point Pleasant, Tuesday night. He was 86 years old and lived at 40 South Munn Avenue.

title: Norlin of Sweden Captures Half Ton Yachting Trophy
description: SANDHAMN, Sweden, Aug. 13 (AP)Peter Norlin, a Swed ish sailmaker, won the inter national Half Ton Cup, sailing trophy today for the second straight year.

title: Novelist Tells Panel on Unrest Government Represses Blacks
description: JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 13A Negro poet and novelist told the President's Commission on Campus Unrest at its final Mis sissippi session today that black Americans were under repres sion from the state, local and national governments.

title: Kennedy Auto Scrapped
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) The automobile that Senator Edward M. Kennedy was driv ing when it ran off a bridge on Chappaquiddick Island, Mass., in the summer of 1969 has been scrapped, a spokesman for the Senator said today. David Burke, the Senator's assistant, denied a published account that the car, an Oldsmobile, had been sunk at sea.

title: How Cornfeld Lost
description: TORONTO, Aug. 13  Al though Bernard Cornfeld was a management nominee for the board of directors of I.O.S., Ltd., 822,336 shares controlled by management were not voted for him, according to a Toronto lawyer, Harold Margles, who examined the ballots after the June 30 stockholders meeting here.

title: 2 Retarded Girls in New Haven Slain and Man Is Beaten Badly
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 13Two retarded young women were slain here late last night and a retarded young man was severely beaten.

title: Lawyers Turn to Middle Class, Clients They Admit They Forgot
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 13 Lawyers are discovering a for gotten client  the middlein come, middleclass man or family. And they are beginning to concede, sometimes with em barrassment and sometimes with excuses, that they have failed him.

title: Pennsylvania's Film Law Is Ruled Unconstitutional
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13 (UPI)A panel of three Federal judges ruled yesterday that Pennsylvania's new law forbid ding the showing of previews of Xrated movies in theaters when family films were showing was unconstitutional.

title: ... and Television for Congress
description: On another sector of the political front, the latest Federal Communications Commission rulings are a partial and unsatisfactory response to the problem of fair access to television. The F.C.C. has upheld a sta tion's refusal to sell spot advertisements to Business Executives Move for Vietnam Peace and, by implica tion, to, any other organization which wants to buy time to engage in public controversy.

title: ADM. CHARLES FERRITER
description: GREENLAND, N. H., Aug. 13 (AP)Rear Adm. Charles A. Ferriter, retired, who won deco rations during action in the Philippines in World War II and Korea, was found dead Thurs day in a gravel pit near his home. He was 69 years old. A medical officer said death was due to natural causes.

title: BRITISH ARMS POLICY OPPOSED IN CAPITAL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13A Bipartisan group of Congress men has written the Secretary of State William P. Rogers, ex pressing strong opposition to British arms sales to South Africa.

title: STECK AND WISE WIN JUNIOR YACHT TITLES
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 13 Cort Steck of Port Washing ton (L. I.) Yacht Club sailing Redbank Avenger won today's sixmile race in a mild and fading easterly on Long Island Sound off Indian Harbor Yacht Club to win the Division I Lightning Class title of the Junior Yacht Racing Associa tion's annual race week with 23 points. He had been second yesterday.

title: CRIPPLE A SUICIDE BY FIRE IN QUEENS
description: A crippled Queens woman, who neighbors said had been despondent recently, commit ted suicide by igniting her tur pentinesoaked body yesterday morning, the police said.

title: London Bomb Site Forms a Backdrop For the Young Vic
description: LONDON, Aug. 13 (Reuters) London's newest theater, builton a shoeString budget of $144,000 opened yesterday behind an abandoned butcher shop in south London.

title: GARBAGE BURNED IN LENOX AVENUE
description: A band of 400 youths armed with brooms pushed heaps of uncollected garbage from curb side onto Lenox Avenue be tween 138th and 139th Streets in Harlem late yesterday after noon to protest what they termed the failure of the Sani tation Department to make collections in the area in the last two weeks.

title: Hollomon Comes to Jets for Gordon
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 13 On his way to breakfast this morning Cornell Gordon was intercepted by Coach Weeb Ewbank and told that his career with the Jets was over.

title: Court Stays Order Banning Sale of Flight Life Insurance
description: A Manhattan Supreme Court justice stayed yesterday a state agency's order that would have barred the sale of life insurance for a plane flight at current rates after Sept. 1.

title: CANADA SETS RULES FOR ARCTIC PIPELINE
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 13The Government announced a set of guidelines today to safeguard Canadian interests on any pipelines to take oil and natural gas out of the North west Territories, the Yukon and Alaska.

title: Roundup: A Leadoff Bunt Spoils Bosnian NoHitter
Police Surprise Gem Thieves at Work
description: A gang of five jewelry thieves believed responsible for 40 burglaries that netted $1 million here in the last year was chased through the halls and stairways of a Broadway office building late Wednesday by police detectives who an ticipated the thieves precision timing tactics and spoiled their latest job.

title: J.W. Nichols Fiance Of Miss Alexander
description: SANDS POINT, L. I., Aug. 13Mr. and Mrs. Eben Roy Alexander have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Hollis Wil liams Alexander, to Joseph William Nichols, son of Col. Howard F. Nichols, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Nichols of Whispering Pines, N.C. A Sep tember wedding is planned.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Film

title: Disputed Permits Are Given To Mitchel Field Squatters
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Aug. (UPI)The Nassau County Real Estate Division today issued permits to 15 welfare families living in the countyowned former Mr Force barracks in Mitchel Field.

title: LEON FRENGUT
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Aug. 13 Leon Frengut, a violist, who had played for the Philadelphia, Minneapolis and Cleveland Or chestras and the National Broadcasting Company Sym phony Orchestra under Arturo Toscanini, died today at his home. He was 66 years old and lived at 21 Ascot Ridge.

title: Berlin Progress Expected
description: BONN, Aug. 13Chancellor Brandt returned from Moscow today and reported indications that the Soviet Government might make concessions to the West in improving the situa tion in divided Berlin.

title: Box Scores
School Dropout, 16, Held In AxandHammer Killings
description: A 16yearold school dropout from the BedfordStuyvesant section in Brooklyn was ar rested yesterday and charged with homicide in the slaying last week of two sisters in a Brooklyn apartment.

title: Councilman Challenges City's Use of Consultants
description: The chairman of a seven member City Council subcom mittee investigating consultant contracts said yesterday that these contracts raise basic is sues as to how the city man ages its affairs and now they should be managed.

title: Football Transactions
description: NEW YORK JETSTraded Cornell Gordon, cornerbackto Denver for Gus Holleman, safety.

title: GOLDBERG TO SEEK OUTOFSTATE AID
description: Arthur J. Goldberg disclosed yesterday that he would invite leading national Democrats to stump for him in the New York gubernatorial campaign.

title: MONEY EXPANSION CONTINUES BRISK
description: Money and bank credit ex panded at a brisk pace in the last few weeks, banking data published yesterday by the Fed eral Reserve System showed.

title: I.T.T. UNIT PLANNING VENTURE IN SUMATRA
description: International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation yester day announced the establish ment of a multimilliondollar subsidiary company to develop largescale timber concessions in Sumatra, its second recent major development project in Indonesia.

title: Singer of Dodgers Injured
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 13 (AP) Bill Singer, a righthander suffered two lineal fractures of the right index finger while trying to bunt last night and will be lost to the Los Angeles Dodgers for two to three weeks, it was announced today.

title: 1776 Adds a Troupe
description: The musical 1776, the Tony Award and Drama Critics prize winner by. Sherman Edwards and Peter Stone, has announced that ,a second national touring company will open in Scranton, Pa., on Sept. 18. Directing the company will be Gordon Hunt, the 41yearold brother of Peter Hunt, the show's original direc tor.

title: Boys in Band to End Run
description: The Boys in the Band will celebrate its 1,000th perform ance on Saturday night, Sept. 5, and then end its run at Thea ter Four the following day with a matinee and evening per formance. The play by Mart Crowley was produced by Rich ard Barry and Charles Wood ward.

title: Carl Guy Grace, 63
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Aug. 13Carl Guy Grace, vice president and general manager of the toilet articles division of the Colgate Palmolive Company in New York from 1957 until his retirement in 1966, died yes terday. He was 63 years old and lived in Winter Park.

title: Israeli Charges Violation of Truce
James Driscoll, Miss Peterson To Be Married
description: SIMSBURY, Conn., Aug. 13 Hans P. Peterson has an nounced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Kristin Peterson, to First. Lieut. James W. Driscoll, U.S.M.C., son of Mr. and Mrs. ,Thomas H. Driscoll of Swampscott, Mass.

title: GIL HANOVER 31 IN $106,770 TROT
description: YONKERS, Aug. 13 Billy Haughton, the man who has driven more winners and whose horses have earned more money than those of any other harness reinsmaii since 1939, when the United States Trot ting Association Went in for record keeping, has enjoyed overwhelming success with pacers.

title: U.S. Open Tennis Added To Grand Prix Tourneys
description: The United States Open ten nis tournament, set for Forest Hills, Queens, Sept. 213, be came the 19th major event is the Pepsi Grand Prix of tennis yesterday, when tourney offi cials agreed to contribute $16, 000 of the United States Open prize money to the Grand Prix pool.

title: MISS POTTER VICTOR IN ONEMETER DIVE
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 13 (UPI) Cynthia Potter, a 19yearold Indiana University student rep resenting the Bloomington (Ind.) Swim Club, captured the wo men's onemeter springboard event for the second straight year with 419.25 points in the National Amateur Athletic Union diving championships to night.

title: Rites Held for Edgar Greene

title: Dilemma on Kidnapping
description: The murder of Dan A. Mitrione in Uruguay again focuses attention on a threesided dilemma for which there are no easy solutions. There is the dilemma of the individual diplomat, the dilemma of the gov ernment that sent him to a troubled area, and the dilemma of the government where political kidnap pings occur.

title: John G. De Graff Jr., Pace '68, To Marry Margaret A. Baer
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y. Aug. 13Miss Margaret Ann Baer and John Garrett De Graff Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Clinton De Graff of Scarsdale and Clinton Corners, will be married in October.

description: UNITED NATIONS. N. Y., Aug. 13Knowledgeable diplo mats here suggested today that the mission of Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, Secretary General Thant's special representative for the Middle East, was mark ing time.

title: King Resigns Post
description: John M. King, the flamboy ant chief executive officer of the King Resources Company, and a onetime major campaign contributor to President Nixon, resigned his post yesterday in the midst of what he termed a liquidity problem.

title: Elderly to Display Art
description: Art of the Elders of Brook lyn, the second annual exhi bition of arts and crafts by more than 50 elderly persons, will open at the Brooklyn Mu seum's Community Gallery Sun day and will continue through Sept. 20. The museum, which

description: A receiver has been appointed to administer the funds of the First International Art Show, an event at the Coliseum that closed last Sunday displaying the work of several hundred artists. The event included a $100,000 open art competition.

description: Ralph Nader, who became famous as a critic of automo bile safety standards when a private investigation of him by General Motors backfired in 1966, got $425,000 from the company yesterday in an out ofcourt settlement of his suit for invasion of privacy.

title: Liberals in Council Split in a Dispute Over Leadership
description: The four Liberals on the City Council appeared yesterday to be splitting apart after only six months of bickering partner ship.

title: BOYD TAKES LEAD IN RIFLE SHOOTING
description: CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 13 (UPI)Marine Warrant Officer David I. Boyd of Quantico, Va., took the lead today in the na tional smallbore rifle position championships by the margin lof a point.

title: Celanese to Buy Its Stock
description: The Celanese Corporation an nounced yesterday that it would buy 500,000 shares of its own common stock for use in acquisitions and conversion op tions in the next 12 months.

title: U.S. Polo Team Gains Final
description: DEAUVILLE, France, Aug. 13 (Reuters)  The Boca Raton, Fla?? ?? t??m moved into the final of the Paris polo cup to day with a hotly contested, 1211, victory over the Italo Argentine Stupinigi team.

title: Agreement Is Sought
description: GENEVA, Aug. 13A truce in the fight for control of In vestors Overseas Services be tween its management and Bernard Cornfeld, deposed founder of the mutualfund complex, was observed today as they sought a peaceful set tlement.

title: Frazier's Pilot Denies Bout Is Set With Clay in Atlanta
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 13 (AP)Promoters said today that the way was virtually clear for a Joe FrazierCassius Clay heavyweight title fight in At lanta, but Frazier's manager immediately branded the state ment as nonsense.

title: 2 Philadelphia Workers Die In Fall of a 6Ton Slab
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13 (AP)Two workers were killed today and another was injured critically when a six ton concrete slab fell 10 stories from a crane at a construction site across the street from City Hall, the police reported.

title: Arts in Italy a Magnet for U.S. Youth
description: ROME, Aug. 13An or chestra of 70 young Amer icans turned a peripatetic, chattering crowd of 3,000 Romans and tourists into at tentive and appreciative mu sic lovers here last night with a concert offering works by American and Italian com posers and played in honor of Rome's first 100 years as the capital of a unified Italy.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON SHOW A DECLINE
description: Prices made a solid advance in early trading on the London Stock Exchange yesterday only to retreat in late profit taking.

title: Ulster M.P.'s Back Prime Minister on HardLiner
description: BELFAST, Northern. Ireland, Aug. 13Prime Minister James ChichesterClark moved today to quell a hardline revolt in the Unionist party challenging his leadership and opposing the reforms to which he is com mitted.

title: Early Rock Treasures To Be Auctioned Here
description: Rock fans who might he interested in such memorabil ia as the rose petals Mick Jagger threw to the audience at Madison Square Garden last Thanksgiving Day are in vited to an auction Oct. 12 at Fillmore East, for the benefit of peace candidates.

description: Governor Rockefeller yester day offered the city the use of 800 vacant cells in a deter orated cell block at the Os sining Correctional Facility, formerly known as Sing Sing, to relieve overcrowding at city prisons.

description: Harold B. Foner, a lawyer who was ejected from the trial room at Police Headquarters Monday, filed a complaint yes terday against the trial commis sioner.

title: Exodus of 200,000 To South Vietnam Ending in Cambodia
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Aug. 13The exodus of more than 200,000 South Vietnamese from Cambodia entered its final stage early this morning as 5,400 of the last refugees in camps began a journey down the Mekong River toward a country few of them had ever seen.

title: Contempt of Congress Seen
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) Contempt of Congress pro ceedings against a United States Communist party official for re fusing to testify on his con nections with the New Mobiliza tion Committee to End the War in Vietnam were recommended today by the House Committee on Internal Security. The recom mendation for the House to cite Arnold Johnson, the party's public relations director, was approved unanimously.

title: MAYOR FILLS POST ON ANTIDRUG UNIT
description: An urban affairs specialist who Mayor Lindsay said he had been trying for the last five years to capture for his ad ministration was named yester day as Commissioner of the City's Addiction Services Agency.

title: Records Link Head. Of Eatontown Bank To Realty Concern
description: EATONTOWN, N.J., Aug. 13 (AP)The president of the in solvent Eatontown National Bank, arrested Tuesday on a charge of misapplying $5mil lion in funds, and a vice pres ident and cashier of the bank are officers in a Monmouth County real estate concern that operated a local restau rant and hotel for a year, ac cording to state records.

title: Life in City Sends Some Back to the Farm
description: OAK GROVE, Mo.David Loory is a tobaccochewing country boy who loves life on the farm.

title: Xuan Thuy Will Return To Peace Talks in Paris
description: PARIS, Aug. 13North Viet nam announced today that it was sending its chief delegate to the peace talks back to Paris.

title: Jews Fear AntiZionism of New Left
description: Hostility to Israel in the New Left has aroused in creasing concern among many American Jews, some of whom are convinced that such animosity is a conven ient mask for a resurgence of antiSemitism.

title: The Screen: Gangland French Style:An Elaborate 'Borsalino' Opens at Cinema I
description: If filmmaking were just a decorative art, and if mis-en-scene included no more than setting the scene, then "Borsalino," which opened yesterday at Cinema I, might have some small claim to being a good movie.Given the limitations of its time and place (the Marseilles underworld of the early 1930's), "Borsalino" is one of the most elaborately, even pedantically detailed period reconstructions I have ever seen. But given the possibilities of its time and place, of its genre, of at least some of its cast, of the medium itself"Borsalino" is a failure of stupefying proportions.The story concerns two punks (Jean-Paul Belmondo and Alain Delon) who, by enterprise and luck, work their way up through the Marseilles protection rackets to emerge finally in lonely eminence as kings of local gambling, prostitution, and wholesale meat and fish.Along the way they kill a little, love a little, fight a little, and do in more or less regular order everything that is expected of the heroes of gangland cinema  before they learn that the fruits of their struggle have turned to dust and ashes, and that the price of success is death.Anybody who goes to the movies will be able to fill in the details, give or take a few dozen, and, by moving the action back from Marseilles to, say, Prohibition Chicago, will be able to call to mind several good and some great films of the past.Where "Borsalino" fails is not so much in the hoariness of its plot as in the lassitude of its pacing (it is, I think, meant to be funny in a subtle, wry, fist-in-the-guts way) and its numbing subordination of scene, movement and gesture to costume and dcor.The interiors, whether seedy or sumptuous (especially a gambling casino in the Chinese style) display the paraphernalia of their period as meticulouslyand in their very completeness, somehow as inauthenticallyas any museum reconstruction. The exteriors are if anything even more completeto the degree that some rather elaborate scenes seem to be held beyond all dramatic need so you can see that the next car around the corner, the next walker on the block, will be, down to the last particular, genuinely of the period.Jacques Deray's direction seems not so much to lead, as to accede to the demands of the scene designer and the costumer. There are, indeed, six costume credits. But where he has his way, he is equally indulgentphotographing the sunlight through what looks like layers of scrim, introducing gratuitous motor trips simply as you may admire the cars, staging fist fights and beatings that manage to be both dull and unusually brutal at the same time.In this context, it is impossible to speak well of performances. Delon and Belmondo smoke endless cigars, wear the broad-brimmed hat for which the film is named, saunter (the way punks do) rather than walk, and pose in the clothes and with the objects that are intended to express them.The result is not a characterization, but rather a collection of affectationswith which Belmondo seems uncomfortable, but not Delon, who comes more and more to look and act like an inanimate object of the 1930's.There is a real difference between costume drama and costume display, between films that playfully court decadence (for example, "Performance") and "Borsalino," which really is decadent because it is so deliberately drained of vitality.Much talent has been wasted in this film (in major parts, Michel Bouquet and Catherine Rouvel, among others), and neither the rooms nor the cars look as if anyone had really lived in them.

title: Emily Kwoh Brings Her Mandarin Fare to Long Island

This is the latest venture of Mrs. Emily Kwoh, the redoubtable owner of several Chinese res taurants in Manhattan, in cluding the Mandarin House in Greenwich Village; the Mandarin East and the Great Shanghai.

title: IRA MARION, WRITER FOR RADIO AND TV
description: Ira Marion, a radio and tele vision writer, director and pro ducer, died yesterday at Mt. Sinai Hospital after a long ill ness. He was 60 years old and lived at 222 West 83d Street.

title: Leary Asks Washington to Help In Protecting Consulates Here
description: Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary yesterday called for Federal assistance to guard for eign consulates and missions here because local protection was placing a burden on the taxpayers and a manpower drain on the police depart ment.

title: SUGAR FUTURES HAVE ACTIVE DAY
description: For sugar brokers and deal ers yesterday it was a tele phoneringing, newsbreaking day.

title: U.S. Assessing Complaint
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 The United Stateswas reported to have raised with the United Arab Republic today Israel's charge that the Egyptians had violated the ceasefire by mov ing missles closer to the Suez Canal after the truce started.

title: BIG BOARD LISTS LIQUIDATING FIRMS
description: The New York Stock Ex change disclosed the names yes terday of the 10 member firms that either formally or infor mally are in liquidation and once again attempted to reas sure investors that the resourc es of its Special Trust Fund were adequate to protect cus tomers of the 10 firms.

title: Panel Approves Trade Measure
description: WASHINGTON, Aug, 13The House Ways and Means Committee gave its formal ap proval today to legislation dras tically revising the nation's trade laws. The final vote was 17 to 7.

title: Kunstler Is on Stand in New Haven Panther Trial
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 13The defense began its case in the Lonnie McLucas trial today by calling William M. Kunstler, the civil rights lawyer, and four other witnesses to the stand in a concentrated effort to undermine the testimony of a key prosecution witness.

title: At This Camp, the Lore That's Taught the Youngsters Is Chinese
description: SYRACUSE, Ind.The two fishermen were so intent on their sport that they were oblivious to the water skiers flash ing by or to the mower buzzing un evenly as it chopped off the grass on a hill; even, for a long moment, the bell summoning them to lunch.

title: AMEX PRICES SLIP AS TRADING GAINS
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange yesterday moved mostly downward in slightly steppedup trading.

title: Israeli Jets Attack Base In Jordan as a Reprisal
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 14 (AP)Israeli planes crossed into Jordan today to attack a guer rilla base in reprisal for rocket attacks yesterday on a Jewish frontier settlement, the military command reported.

title: HOUSE OVERRIDES ONE FUNDS VETO, UPHOLDS ANOTHER
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 The House of Representatives overrode today President Nix on's veto of an education ap propriation bill but sustained his rejection of another money measure for housing, veterans, space and scores of other pro grams.

description: CINCINNATIRecalled Mel Behney, left. handed pitcher, from Indianapolis of the American Association. Optioned John Noriega, righthanded pitcher, to Indianapo lis.

description: Kansas City at New York (8 P.M.) Drago (611) vs. Peterson (137).

title: HOUSE UNIT BACKS TOUGH DRUG BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UPI)  The House Commerce Committee approved today tough drug abuse legislation that would double most penal ties for pushers and provide for a Presidential commission to review the legal and medical controversy over marijuana use.

title: Walinsky Scores Laws Prohibiting Flag Desecration
description: SYRACUSE, Aug. 14 (UPI)The Democratic candidate for State Attorney General Adam Walinsky, called flag desecra tion laws utter nonsense to day and said he would take a dim view of enforcing them if he is elected in November.

title: CITY EXPEDITING BUS COOLER REPAIR
description: The Transit Authority said yesterday that it was making a vigorous effort to repair bro ken airconditioning equipment on the city's buses following complaints by many riders.

title: TWO MUSIC FIRMS WILL JOIN FORCES
description: A multimilliondollar music publishing deal, involving the American rights to the Beatles songs, has been announced in London. Apple Records, the Beatles recording company, is not affected.

title: DRUG AGENCY LAPSE IS NOTED BY BEAME
description: Because city narcotics agency officials were not fully aware of the provisions of a contract they signed with the state, New York City stands to lose more than $1million, Controller Abraham D. Beame said yester day.

title: Administration Game Plan...
description: The House has voted to override President Nixon's veto of the $4.4billion education bill but has upheld his veto of the $18billion money bill for housing and other programs. Neither vote was surprising. In fact, Mr. Nixon's initialdecision had been to sign the educa tion bill because it was so clear that he would be overridden; the conventional political wisdom is that a President should husband his prestige and not waste it on lost issues.

title: Lockheed Electronics Gets $8,100,000 Army Contract
description: WASHINGTON, Aug: 14 (UPI) The Lockheed Electronics Company, a division of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, received an $8,100,000 Army contract for scientific, engineer ing and other services for the Fort Huachuca electromagnet environmental test facility.

title: Prague Holds Upstate Man, 27, Incommunicado on Spy Charge
description: PRAGUE, Aug. 14 (Reuters)  The Czechoslovak secret po lice have arrested a 27yearold American on charges of espionage, the United States Embassy said today.

title: Ox Ridge Wins in Polo, 62
description: DARIEN, Conn., Aug. 14 Lyle Graham scored five goals tonight to lead the Ox Ridge Hunt Club's polo team to a 62 victory over Westport.

title: RIC AND UNIT CURBED ON PRESS RELEASES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP)The Securities and Ex change Commission said today it asked for and received a Federal court injunction against a Dallas company and its Florida subsidiary after alleg ing that they touted their stock and issued a misleading press release.

title: TODAY'S PROBABLE PITCHERS
description: Kansas City at New York (2 P.M.) Bunker (07) vs. Stottlemyre (1110).

title: News Summary and Index
description: Israel, underlining her contention that Jordan makes Palestinian guerrilla attacks possible, bombed and strafed several Jor danian Army posts yesterday in the first announced attack on Jordanian bases since the ceasefire went into effect a week ago. Jordan has said that she cannot be respon sible for the acts of guerrillas based on her territory. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Subway Workers Group Says Transit Aide Creates Tension
description: A group of subway workers called yesterday for the ouster of a Transit Authority execu tive who, they said, had cre ated racial tension among transit employes.

title: Buchan of U.S. Wins Title In World Star Class Sail
description: MARSTRAND, Sweden, Aug. 14 (AP)William E. Buchan, 36yearold building contractor from Mercer Island, Wash., won the world Star Class yachting championship today.

title: JAPAN STUDYING OWNERSHIP CURBS
Tenants Talk With City Aide And End a ThreeDay SitIn
description: Agroup of tenants from the Bushwick section of Brooklyn ended a threeday sitin at an office of the city's Housing and Development Administra tion yesterday after a meeting with Deputy Administrator Rob ertG. Hazen.

title: PERSONALITY WINS RACE AT SARATOGA
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 14  Personality success I fully met a determined challenge from Loud in the Jim Dindy stakes today and won the $30,050 onemile event by a head. The eighth running of the stakes for 3yearolds drew a field of eight, but it really developed into a duel between Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs's formid able campaigner and William Haggin Perry's runnerup. In third place, three lengths be hind the winner, came George D. Widener's Plymouth.

title: Mark Sugarman, Developer In Real Estate and Mining
description: Mark Sugarman, a real estate and mining developer and a philanthropist, died yes terday at his home at 75 East End Avenue. He was 85 years old.

title: U. S. to Pull Out 15,000
description: SAIGON, Aug. 14 (AP)In move to turn over the major fighting role in the provinces around Saigon to South Viet namese forces, about 15,000 United States soldiers will be sent home and the remaining combat units will play support roles, official sources said to day.

title: Radio Signals Aimed
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 A space agency official has invented a stationary com munications satellite whose broadcasts can be focused on a specific area of irregu lar shape. For ex ample, the radio or television sig nals can be con fined to the Unit ed States without reaching either Canada or Mexico. Such an arrange ment is expected to permit this country to allot the required frequency channel itself, and to avoid the inter national negotiations other wise required.

title: Cuba Buying Bulldozers
description: TOKYO, Aug. 14 (AP)The Komatsu Mdnufacturing Com pany said today it will export about 50 large bulldozers to Cuba. A spokesman said the 20ton bulldozers would cost Fidel Castro's Government about $2.8 million. The com pany is giving the Cubans cred it for five years at 7.5 per cent interest because Japan's Ex portImport Bank would not provide financing.

title: Borman Sees Warsaw Aide
description: WARSAW, Aug. 14 (AP)Frank Borman, the former as tronaut who is now a special representative of President Nix on, held a halfhour meeting at the Polish Foreign Ministry today on American prisoners of war in Vietnam. He said the re sponse was full of sympathy and understanding of a difficult situation. He leaves Warsaw for Stockholm Saturday and plans to visit Paris and Geneva.

title: MRS. FISCHER SETS PACE IN OHIO GOLF
description: CINCINNATI, Aug 14 (AP)  Mrs. Andy Cohn Fischer hit 14 greens and went on to post a fourunderpar 68 today and took the firstround lead in the Buckeye invitation golf at the Royal Oak Racquet and Coun try Club.

title: Youths Jam Arrivals Building at Kennedy
description: They carry guitars and sleeping bags and wooden shoes from Amsterdam, and stream out of the Kennedy International Airport customs area in a current that seems to run 24 hours a day.

title: Books of The Times
description: It was Randall Jarrell, I believe, who remarked that he could never quite get over the ease and nonchalance with which his students came to a reading of Eliot's The Waste Land, a poem that in spite of its familiarity still made him wary. That these students had stood on the shoulders of giants, including his, was a fact he must have been aware of. Nevertheless, what had remained a battle for him had become a victory for them.

title: Black Nationalists Distribute Leaflets Attacking Vorster
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, Aug. 14AntiGovernment leaflets were scattered by small explosive devices in major South African cities last night.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON SHOW DOWNTURN
description: Stock prices in London drifted lower in dull preweek end trading.

title: APARTMENT SALES LAID TO SQUATTERS
description: Some of the 200 squatters who have taken over vacant apartments in various buildings in Manhattan have sold their apartments to other homeless families and moved out, accord ing to reports received by the City Relocation Department.

title: Bendel's New Shop: Limit Is $100
description: It's selfserve, there are no salesgirls and the merchan dise is put into shopping bags. True, the bags are an elegant brown and white stripe, but why not? The supermarket approach to fashion is the latest develop ment, at Henri Bendel, a store so chic that the whole place shudders delicately when Shop a size 14 walks Talk in. This season, the Bendel's cus tomer, a micro cosm of the true fashion spirit, is being offered a whole new approach to shopping. The fourth floor has been opened up, renamed, re decorated and radicalized. Merchandise is displayed in row upon row of racks and shelves, and nothing is over $100. This maximum price will not appear modest to some, but to others it is the next thing to cutrate.

title: Laver and Gimeno Reach Toronto Tennis Semifinals
description: TORONTO, Aug. 14 (Cana dian Press)Topseeded Rod Laver and secondseeded Andres Gimeno won their matches to night and advanced to the semifinals in the $23,000 Cana dian open tennis champion shins.

title: DR. HENRY DARGAN
description: Dr. Henry McCune Dargan, Willard Professor of Rhetoric and Oratory at Dartmouth Col lege from 1946 to 1957, died Thursday at the Home for Old Men and Aged Couples, 1060 Amsterdam Avenue. He was 81 years old.

title: N.Y.U. Group Gets Grant For a Heart Attack Study
description: A study to determine more precisely when heart attacks and strokes will occur in likely victims was announced yester day by the New York Univer sity Medical Center and the John A. Hartford Foundation. The foundation has, made a 1$149,640 grant to support the project.

title: 2 Oil Companies to Acquire Land in the Canadian Arctic
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 14 (Cana dian Press)  BP Oil & Gas, Ltd., of Calgary and BP Oil, Ltd., of Montreal have an nounced plans to acquire an in terest in 337,909 acres of Feder al permit land in the Canadian Arctic held by Pacific Petrole um, of Calgary and the King Resources Company of Denver.

title: Winds of 60 Miles an Hour
description: MIAMI, Aug. 14 (UPI)  A dangerous tropical depression, which could develop quickly into a hurricane, whipped up 60mileanhour winds today and threatened to move into the western Bahama Islands and Florida over the weekend.

title: GIBBS'
description: The New York Yankees, who must be feeding Jake Gibbs cat nip up there in the Bronx, de feated the Kansas City Royals, 32, last night when Gibbs hit the fourth pitch of the 10th inning into the rightfield seats.

title: Palestinians and Peace
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 14Although many of the 1.5 mil lion Palestinians outside Israeli control stand to gain from a settlement in the Middle East, not one prominent Palestinian has spoken out publicly in favor of an agreement.

title: F.C.C. ORDERS TV TO SET PRIME TIME FOR WAR CRITICS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14The Federal Communications Com mission said today that Presi dent Nixon had made such ex tensive use of television to de fend his conduct of the war in Indochina that the networks must now give opponents a chance to present critical re plies on prime time.

title: Witness Says Manson Had Weapon Near Murder Site
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 14 Linda Kasabian testified today that she saw Charles M. Man son stick a gun or a sword in his pants as he left a car parked near the home of Mr. and Mrs. Leno LaBianca the night they were slain last Au gust.

title: FINANCING TALKS HOLD LINKS TO I.O.S.
description: GENEVA, Aug. 14  Robert L. Vesco, president of the In ternational Controls Corpora tion of New Jersey, announced tonight that he was holding preliminary discussions on the possibility of refinancing the Commonwealth United Corpo ration and its subsidiary, the Seeburg Corporation.

title: US PLANS TO AID THAIS WHO FIGHT INSIDE CAMBODIA
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 The State Department confirmed today that the United States had reached a tentative agree ment on American aid to the 5,000 troops being recruited or trained in Thailand for service in Cambodia.

title: Colombian Mine Accord Regarded as PaceSetter
description: BOGOTA, ColombiaA $100 million contract for exploiting the Cerro Matoso Ferronickel deposit in northern Colombia contains provisions widely regarded here as models for future treatment of foreign pri vate investment capital in de veloping countries.

title: GOLDBERG URGES CONVENTION SHIFT
description: Arthur J. Goldberg called yesterday for a new formula to apportion Democratic Na tional Convention delegates among the states in an effort to discourage Wallacetype defections.

title: $103,000 IS STOLEN FROM LENOX HILL
description: A lone, apparently unarmed, thief strolled into the paymas ter's office at Lenox Hill Hospi tal Thursday night and, without forcing a door or a lock, made off with $103,506 in cash from the office safe.

title: Roundup: Doctored Pirates Carry On
description: A news item from Pitts burgh reported that a tight shoulder muscle had forced Dock Ellis to miss his sched uled pitching turn last night against the San Diego Padres.

title: FUND ROLE TAKEN BY MERRILL LYNCH
description: Merrill Lyncn, Pierce, Fen ner & Smith, Inc., the giant securities concern that until last year had steadfastly re fused to do any business in mutual funds, has taken per haps its most significant step into the fund arena.

title: Seoul Urging Steps Toward Unification
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Satur day, Aug. 15  President Chung Flee Park said today that South Korea would be willing to take epochal and more realistic measures toward the peace ful reunification of Korea if North Korea renounced the use of force.

title: Lanceless Chargers Do Battle With Giants Tonight on Coast
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 14  A tourist would feel cheated if he got to Florence and found the Uffizi Gallery closed, or if he got to San Francisco and found the cable cars not running.

title: SAMUEL A. SCHONBRUNN
description: Samuel Alexander Schon brunn, president of S. A. Schon brunn & Co., in Palisades Park, N.J., packer of Savarin, Brown Gold and. Medaglia d'Oro cof fees, died yesterday in his apartment at the Croydon Hotel, 12 East 86th Street. His age was 92.

title: 5 LIONS FIELD GOALS SET BACK BILLS, 226
description: BUFFALO, Aug. 14 (AP)Errol Mann kicked five field goals and Mel Farr scampered for a touchdown tonight as the Detroit Lions posted a 226 victory over the Buffalo Bills.

title: CITY OPERA LISTING 9 DEBUTS FOR FALL
description: Six singers and three con ductors will make debuts with the New York City Opera dur ing the company's fall season at the New York State Theater, opening Sept. 9.

title: Group Pledges Support to State Republican Ticket
description: Governor Rockefeller and his Republican state ticket re ceived the support yesterday of a group of businessmen, civic leaders and others banded together as Associates of the Rockefeller team.

title: Happening Set Tomorrow
description: Stevie Wonder will head a list of entertainers, including Ronnie Dyson, the Main Ingre dients and the Dreams, when the Parks Council presents its Happening in the Park Pro gram tomorrow from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M. The program, for Harlem youngsters, will be held at the 106th Street Play Circle at Central Park West.

title: Market Place
description: The New York Stock Ex change ticker tape continued to poke along at an agoniz ingly slow pace yesterday, producing some more fur rowed brows among Wall Street stockbrokers.

title: NIXON REASSURES SOUTH ON SCHOOLS
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 14President Nixon flew here to day to reassure the South that he was at once firm and reason able in his approach to the next big round of school desegrega tion this fall.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
ROTATION'S EFFECT IN SPACE WEIGHED
description: DOWNEY, Calif.  Space scientists are literally going around in circles here to determine how effectively men can work in future orbiting vehicles that will be continuous ly rotated to create artificial gravity.

title: Ulster Clergymen Sentenced
description: CANTERBURY, England Aug. 14 (Reuters)  Two mili tant Protestant clergymen from Ulster who interrupted a Roman Catholic mass were sent to prison today for refusing to agree to keep the peace.

title: Bayh Calls for Nixon's Support As Senate Gets Electoral Plan
McGrath Approves Sing Sing Cellblock for City

East Germans, Citing Pact, Ask Recognition by Big 3

The Colts won, 173, by intercepting the Chiefs passes over and over.

title: Dark Show to Close Aug. 22

Mr. Papp thanked New York State for recent grant of $50,000 that en abled the festival to extend its run of Shakespeare's The Wars of the Roses.

title: Chain Acquiring Family Stores
description: We wound up in our store with a men's wear res taurant, a lingerie restaurant and a sportswear restaurant, all because we used a res taurant designer instead of a store designer when we de cided to remodel, said Sid ney S. Good Jr., president: of L. S. Good & Co., a Wheeling, W. Va., department store.

title: A BARGE SPILLS OIL IN SOUND AT GROTON
description: GROTON, Conn., Aug 14 (AP) Thick oil spilled from a barge near the mouth of the Thames River here today, spreading out into long patches in Long Is land Sound and dotting sandy beaches alone the way.

description: It was a hectic day  cor respondence to clear up, fre quent telephone interruptions, visitors stopping by  as Cyril D. Tyson finished his last day yesterday as Commissioner of the city's Manpower and Career Development Agency.

description: BOSTON, Aug. 14 (AP)Boston College yesterday can celed a rock festival planned for today, after it was unable to come up with arrangements acceptable to the City of Boston.

title: Charges Traded at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 14  The Jordanian delegate, Dr. Muhammad H. elFarra, ac cused Israel today of deliber ately blocking the start of peace talks, while Yosef Tekoah, the Israeli delegate, said the cen tral problem was the alleged deployment of groundtoair missies by the United Arab Re public, a grave violation of the ceasefire.

title: OUSTED RED TEACHER REPORTED IN CANADA
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 14 (AP)Angela Davis, whom the authorities want to question about guns used in the San Ra fael courtroom raid last Friday that resulted in the death of a judge and three others, was re ported today to have gone to Canada.

title: Upstate Lifeguards Plan To Strike Today Over Pay
description: Union lifeguards at the Pali sades Interstate Park Commis sion's and the Taconic Park Commission's lakes and pools were scheduled to go on strike at 8 A.M. today in a bid to have their wages raised to the level of Long Island State Park Commission lifeguards.

title: 2 in Separate Areas Shot By a Brooklyn Youth Gang
description: Members of a gang of five youths shot and wounded Brooklyn man and a Long Island University student last night, neither seriously.

title: FILM ON MOZART IN U.S. PREMIERE:Camera Technique in Movie Shows Lack of Imagination
description: "The Life of Mozart," a film given its American premiere on Thursday night at Philharmonic Hall as part of the Mostly Mozart Festival, is as descriptive, honest and dull as its title. It can be respected for its respect toward its subject, admired for sticking to pictorial fact, praised for a few imaginative flashes of appropriate imagery. It is still dull.It begins with the moving of Mozart's parents to Salzburg, where he was born. Two hours and 20 minutes later, after countless shots of streets, houses, palaces, countrysides, portraits, manuscripts and performances by contemporary musicians, it ends with the composer's death.This is the nature of biographical documentaries, although rigid chronological order is not necessarily part of it. Yet a creative film artist could have given depth and vitality, not just coverage, to the material.Molto AdagioTempo and rhythm, so beautifully, and subtly handled by Mozart in his music, had little counterpart in the camera work. For most of the time it moved at an adagio pace in and out of rooms, across a landscape, closing in on a picture, scanning a letter. Once, quickly alternating shots of Gluck and Piccini suggested the fight between their Parisian factions. Again, the camera swayed drunkenly to Mozart's music for Vienna's winebibbers.There were a few visual metaphors  Notre Dame Cathedral's gargoyles for references to Paris's hostility to the adult composer, a Greek temple to go with excerpts from his three great final symphonies. These were too few to help.To the film's credit, the narration often ceased for the performance of complete musical sequences. Even here, the shots of instrumentalists and singers were conventional, and some of the operatic singing and acting was embarrassing. In this respect, the Salzburg Marionettes in a bit of "The Magic Flute" came off best.The English narration, at least, was literate, often nicely tinged with irony. A great many distinguished ensembles, conductors and solo performers furnished the sound track. A German film, "The Life of Mozart" was made in 1966 by Hans Conrad Fischer. It drew a capacity audience, several of whose members could be seen dozing during its progress.

title: ARMS DISCUSSIONS END VIENNA PHASE
description: VIENNA, Aug. 14The Unit ed States and the Soviet Union concluded the Vienna phase of the strategic arms limitation talks on a hopeful but incon clusive note today and agreed to resume negotiations in Helsinki on Nov. 2.

description: BOSTON, Aug. 14Lubomil Kavalek a grandmaster of Washington and a former chess champion of Czechoslovakia, and John Grefe of Oakland, Calif., won their games in the fifth round of the 71st annual United States Open Champion ship last night to become the only competitors with five straight victories.

title: Antidrug Demonstration Here Ends With a Protest by Blacks
description: Hundreds of young people accompanied by officials from the city and suburbs marched up the Avenue of the Americas to a Central Park rally yes terday to dramatize the prob lem of drug abuse. But after the rock music and speeches by politicians faded, black speakers rose to denounce the demonstration as a racist sell out.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UPI) The Defense Department to day listed the names of the, fol lowing servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Southeast Asia:

description: DEPOE BAY, Ore.When you're invited to an In dianstyle salmon bake at Dr. Wayne E. Kuhn's beach house here, you must be prepared to help catch the dinneras well as eat it.

description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 14Wherever Rupert the rhino goes, he is not alone. A painless opera tion has put him on the air. The secret is a builtin radio transmitter with a homing call.
