description: From its origins in the Johnson Administration, the Safeguard ABM system has been a missile in search of a mission. The public rationale for antiballistic missile defense has been chosen, and repeatedly al tered, in terms of what makes the best sales pitch to Congress.

title: MAJORETTE STAKES TO SHE IS GORGEOUS
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 17 (AP)Slie Is Gorgeous won Arlington Park's $30,100 Majorette Stakes for 2yearold fillies today be fore a crowd of 13,264.

title: RAIDERS PASSES TOP EAGLES, 3019
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17 (UPI) Ken Stabler, a rookie for three years who finally is getting a crack at a pro quar terback's job, threw three sec ondhalf touchdown passes to night to carry the Oakland Raiders to a 3019 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles in a National Football League pre season game.

title: BODIES FROM CRASH IN PERU ARRIVE HERE
description: The bodies of 14 of 49 teen agers killed in a plane crash on Aug. 9 in Peru were sent yesterday from Kennedy In ternational Airport to their home communities or other airports, airline officials said

title: Police Try Distinguishing Patch
description: Nearly 300 New York City policemen will be wearing new shoulder patches during the next month in an experi ment designed to eliminate confusion in distinguishing them from other city and pri vate lawenforcement agents.

title: Moscow Is Rushing Into an Era of Traffic Congestion
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 17"I'm sorry, there was an accident, said a 35yearold Soviet de signer explaining why he was late for an appointment the other day.

title: Substitute Bill Is Planned On Equal Rights for Women
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. dis closed a substitute today for the proposed constitutional amend ment approved by the House a week ago to guarantee equal rights for woman.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Louis Ryan Fiance Of Miss Hartshorn
description: LAKEVILLE, Conn., 17Mr. and Mrs. Fletcher Wake field Hartshorn have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pru dence Elwell Hartshorn, to Louis Farthing Ryan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Anthony Ryan of Richmond. The couple plan to be married here on Sent. 5.

title: L. I. Crash Kills Man, 25
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., Aug. 17 (UPI)A 25yearold Manhattan man was killed early this morn ing when the car in which he was riding struck the rear of a truck on the Long Island Ex pressway near here. The man was identified by the police as Richard Botts of 32 Arden Street.

title: RentaCongressman
description: An old scandal has resurfaced on Capitol Hill. Two years ago, this newspaper reported that the major automobile companies were leasing luxury cars influential members of the House and Senate at nominal charge. Now, two reporters for United Press International have again examined this curious prac tice and come up with fresh details. Familiarity has not made the practice less contemptible.

title: Biracial Suit Backs Capital Plan That Buses Blacks to a Suburb
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17A Federal court was asked to day to bar Congressional at tempts to block a voluntary busing program that has trans ported black elementary school students from downtown Wash ington to a white community in the Maryland suburbs.

title: Martha Wilkinson and Mary. Everard Lead U.S. Amateur Golf With 75's
description: DARIEN, Conn.. Aug 17Despite thunderstorms that stopped play for 15 minutes this morning and for 25 minutes in midafternoon the first quali fying round of the 70th annual United States Women's Ama teur golf championship was completed today.

title: Girls at Wee Burn Scratch Heads, Scold Putters and Peer Under Bangs
Cup Yachts Paired
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 17When you get into the final trials, George Hinman said today, I find that almost every thing the boat did before is usually forgotten.

title: PRESIDENT SIGNS BILL ON CONTROLS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17President Nixon reluctantly signed today a bill that autho rizes him to freeze wages, nrices and rents.

title: U.S. SURVEY WARNS OF IMPURE WATER
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17A Government survey warned to day that millions of Americans were drinking water of haz ardous or inferior quality.

title: 91Day Bill Discount Increases As 182Day Rate Shows Decline
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 Treasury bill rates moved in opposite directions at today's auction from last week's lev els, the Government reported) late this afternoon.

title: Japan Moves to Let Foreigners Invest in More of Her Concerns
description: TOKYO, Aug. 17 (Reuters)Japan moved today to open up many companies to foreign in vestment but left enough bar riers to annoy business critics abroad.

title: CHOLERA SPREAD TO WEST DOUBTED
description: GENEVA Aug. 17 (UPI)The World Health Organization said today that there were no indications that a cholera out break was spreading westward from the Soviet Union.

title: TOMBS PRISONERS BOYCOTT HEARINGS
description: Ninetyfour prisoners in the Manhattan Men's House of De tention  half the total sched uled for court appearances refused to leave their cells yes terday as the protest over con ditions in the institution, known as the Tombs, changed from rioting to passive resistance.

title: U. S. WILL CHECK ON CHARTER BUSES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (UPI)  Transportation Sec retary John A. Volpe, citing a bus wreck in Pennsylvania that killed seven children and injured 39 others, announced today a Government inspection program to check 5,000 buses in the next two months  12 times the number inspected last year.

title: Charges of Egyptian Truce Violations Straining AmericanIsraeli Relations
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 AmericanIsraeli relations were more strained tonight than at any time since midJune, when the United States started its initiative for a Middle East ceasefire and a new round of ArahIsraeli negotiations.

title: FOOTBALL FUTURE CALLED CLOUDED
description: They were academic All Americas, the players who scored in the classroom as well, as on the field, and they articu lated about their twoweek trip to Vietnam, and a summer with the hard hats, and Texas poli ticians, and their fears about the potentially big problems that await college football this fall.

title: Reserve in a Double Move To Spur Supply of Money
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17The Federal Reserve Board, in a move that was partly technical, and partly expansionary for the economy, imposed for the first time today reserve require ments against commercial paper issued by banks and simultane ously reduced reserve require ments against ordinary time and savings deposits.

title: ADVISER TO NIXON CITES EXPANSION IN U.S. ECONOMY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 The Government's top econo mist said today that there is some evidence that the econ omy may have begun expanding again, though at only a mod erate pace.

title: Lonborg, Arm Ailing, To Miss Rest of Season
description: BOSTON, Aug. 17 (AP)The Boston Red Sox an nounced today that Jim Lon borg, the sorearmed pitcher who was sent to the minor leagues two weeks ago, con tinued to have arm trouble and would sit out the rest of the season.

title: Senator Hart Seeks F.T.C. Investigation of Gasoline Industry
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 Senator Philip A. Hart asked the Federal Trade Commission today to investigate the gaso line industry for possible viola tions of the antitrust laws in halfdozen areas.

title: Witness Calls Manson the Devil And Says She Is God's Emissary
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 17Linda Kasabian testified today that she believed that she was an emissary from God and that Charles M. Manson was the devil.

title: Other Obituaries on Following Page
U.S. Sues to Uphold 18YearOld Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 The United States brought suit today in the Supreme Court against Arizona and Idaho, ask ing the Court to uphold the constitutionality of the new Federal statute that grants the vote to 18yearolds and out laws literacy and residency re quirements of more than 30 days for voting.

title: Does It Feel Like Baking Time Yet?
description: By late August even the most dedicated members of the fruit only for dessert group would welcome some thing from the oven. The rec ipes that follow offer three distinctively different style desserts that would even tempt calorie counters.

title: Tombs Controversy Facts
description: Following are facts and figures in the dispute over con ditions in city prisons, which has centered on the Manhattan House of Detention for Men, popularly known as the Tombs:

title: Khrushchev, in Letter for Archives, Extolled John Kennedy as Statesman
description: On June 29, 1964, Nikita S. Khrushchev, then the Soviet Premier, wrote a warm tribute to the memory of an American with whom he had engaged in several battles of will.

title: Miss North Wins Bowling
description: FLINT, Mich., Aug. 17 (AP) Bobbe North of Downey, Calif., won the $2,000 first prize in the 11th annual Pro fessional Women Bowlers Association national champion ship at Flint yesterday.

title: Giants Return From Coast
description: EROOKVILLE, L.I., Aug. 17 The New York Giants, smart ing from a lastminute defeat at the.hands of the San Diego Chargers Saturday night, re ported back to camp at C.W. Post College this afternoon and had what amounted to a second straight day off.

title: RACISM IS CHARGED AT ATLANTA CENTER
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 17 (UPI)African doctors who charged racism at the Center for Disease Control went looking for new quarters today, bolstered by an increase in their daily living allowance from the State De partment.

title: Lagos Clarifies Directive On Biafran Aides'
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Aug. 17 (Reuters)The Nigerian Gov ernment said today that it would not use its new powers indiscriminately to punish pub lic officials for antiGovernment acts between Jan. 15, 1966, and the end of the Nigerian civil war last Jan. 15.

title: BRAZIL ADAMANT ON COFFEE PRICES
description: LONDON, Aug. 17 (UPI) Brazil said today that she would stand fast in her dispute with the United States over instantcoffee prices.

title: TV Executive Moves
description: Richard M. Lobo, former gen eral executive for WCBSTV News, was named yesterday as program director of WORTV, Channel 9. He had been asso ciated with WCBSTV News since 1963. He is 33 years old, a graduate of the University of Miami in Coral Gables, Fla., and lives with his wife, Patricia, in Emerson, N. J.

title: NAVY WILL DUMP NERVE GAS TODAY
description: ABOARD U.S.S. HARTLEY, at Sea, Aug. 17 (AP)The weather cleared tonight, opening the way for an aging Liberty ship and her 418 vaults of lethal nerve gas to be scuttled to morrow in the Atlantic.

title: BROKERAGE HOUSE SUES CLOSED BANK
description: A New York brokerage con cern sued the defunct Eaton town (N. J.) National Bank for $638,000 yesterday, alleging that securities in that amount had been ordered and paid for by the bank with worthless cashier's checks.

title: Sales Total $621,800 For RacingAge Horses
description: SARATOGA, Aug. 17 (AP) Fasig Tipton Company, Inc., sold 88 horses of racing age in its sales ring at Saratoga today for a total of $621,800.

title: Clay Continues Fight For Ring License Today
description: Muhammad Ali, who as Cassius Clay once held the world heavyweight title, will move in Federal Court this morning against the State Athletic Commission's request to dismiss his suit for a license to box.

title: Screen: Fable of Beasts
Television
description: Morning

title: Excerpts From Agnew Talk on Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17Following are excerpts from a speech today by Vice Presi dent Agnew before the con vention in Miami of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, a copy of which was made available here!I would like to speak to you today of a rising threat to everything our servicemen have fought to accomplish in Southeast Asiaa threat embodied in the Hatfield McGovern amendment.

title: U.S. Will Let Advisers Bring Wives to Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 17 (AP)The United States mission in Vietnam, in a move aimed at encouraging civilian advisers to serve here, has quietly dropped the fiveyearold prohibition against the advisers bring ing their wives to Vietnam.

title: SIMON FABIAN, 71, THEATER BUILDER
description: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 17 Simon H. Fabian, former presi dent of the Stanley Warner Corporation, the motion picture theater concern that became conglomerate, died at White Plains Hospital yesterday after suffering smoke inhalation from a fire in his summer residence here. He was 71 years old and lived at 785 Fifth Avenue New York.

title: Clarity on ABM
description: An Administrationcreated haze hangs over the vote the Senate will take today on the Brooke amendment. The White House, in opposing the amendment, is still leaning on the chief argument it used last week to defeat moves to suspend expansion of the Safeguard ABM system beyond its present two Minuteman sites. But that argument has no real pertinency to the Brooke amendment.

title: Footnote to Kidnappings
description: The Most Rev. Helder Camara is called the Red Bishop because he fights for social justice in Brazil's impoverished northeast, criticizes military dictator ships in his own and other countries, and often sup ports radical reform causes in Latin America.

title: KOREA UNITY MOVE DEBATED IN SEOUL
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 18President Chung Hee Park's overture for a peaceful reunification of Korea in a speech last Saturday has led to lively public discussion on a question that few South Ko reans dared to debate openly in the past.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Senate Votes to Tighten Corporate TakeOver Law
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 The Senate passed today with brief debate and no record vote legislation tightening the pro visions of the corporate take over law. That law, passed in 1968, requires disclosures of the identities and intentions of those who acquire 10 per cent of the stock of publicly held corporations.

title: MRS. LOIS SEVAREID
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18, (AP)Lois F. Sevareid, former wife of Eric Sevareid, the news commentator, died yes terday after suffering a stroke. She was 59 years old.

title: Article 1 No Title
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) A State Department spokes man described today as untrue charges that the United States has moved South Vietnamese troops into southern Laos.

title: Film Success Spurs Langella's Career
description: For eight years Frank Langella has been working steadily off Broadway, at Lin coln Center and in regional theaters. Even without ever appearing on Broadway, he is recognized at the age of 30 as one of America's finest young stage actors.

title: Executive Changes
description: Clement E. Sutton Jr., a vice president of the General Electric Company, has been named group executiveindustrial group.

title: Bufano, Coast Sculptor, Is Dead
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18Beniamino Benvenuto Bufano, the largely misunderstood Italian artist who wandered like a medieval gnome through the 20th century creating titanic sculptures of stone and steel, was found dead in his workshop here today. He was 72 years old.

title: INMATE'S BEATING CALLED RIOT SPARK
description: Five black inmates of the Manhattan Men's House of De tention were escorted from their cells to a legislative hear ing yesterday and testified that a major cause of the disorders there last week was the beat ing of a black prisoner by white guards.

title: FAVORITE SCORES, WITHKUSHKA NEXT
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 18  Alfred Gwynne Van derbilt met the Mayor of Sara toga, Saito Smaldone, after the running of the feature race on today's card. The race was sixfurlong filliesandmares purse named the Saratoga Springs and it was Vanderbilt's happy task to accept the vic tory trophy from the Mayor.

title: Death in the Mines
description: Coal mining remains a dangerous and bloody trade. One hundred and one men lost their lives in the mines in the first six months of this year. Unless safety procedures are radically improved, it is only a matter of time until there is another disaster in which scores of men will die.

title: PRICES IN LONDON SHOW FIRM TONE
3 FOREIGN EXPERTS TO STUDY SUBWAYS
description: The Metropolitan Transporta tion Authority announced the appointment of a threeman panel of foreign transit experts yesterday to try to improve New York's subway system.

title: IRAQ INDICATES ARMY WILL AID GUERRILLAS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 18 (UPI)Iraq has placed her 12,000 troops in Jordan at the disposal of the Palestinian guer rilla movement, the Baghdad radio said today, commenting an talks in Baghdad between the guerrilla leader, Yasir Ara fat and Iraqi officials.

title: FLORIE DESIMONE
description: NORTH PROVIDENCE, R. I., Aug. 18 (AP)Florie DeSimone, father of Attorney General Her bert F. DeSimone, died early today at Zambarano State Hos pital. He was 76 years old.

title: 3 to Fill Race Secretary's Post At Yonkers for Injured Parker
description: YONKERS, Aug. 18  Tedi Gibbons, Larry Mallar and Carl Miller will handle the racing secretary duties at Yonkers Raceway until Ed Parker re covers from an automobile ac cident which hospitalized Park and his wife, and in which the Parker's 3yearold son, Michael was killed yesterday morning.

title: WATER DEFENDED AS SAFE TO DRINK
description: Westchester County officials said yesterday that water that was called potentially hazard ous in a nationwide Federal survey made public Monday had been cleared up and was safe for drinking.

title: UNIT OF AMAX SIGNS BIG COAL CONTRACT
description: American Metal Climax, Inc., announced yesterday that its Ayrshire Coal Company divi sion had signed a $500million agreement with the Public Service Company of Indiana calling for Ayrshire to supply 80 million tons of coal to the utility over a 30year period.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To the Editor:

title: CORNFELD PLANNING A TRIP TO NEW YORK
description: GENEVA, Aug. 18Bernard Cornfeld, fighting to regain major voice in the Investors Overseas Services mutual fund complex he founded, intends to fly to New York tomorrow.

title: COMISSIONA LEADS A MOSTLY MOZART
description: The Mostly Mozart concert series at Philharmonic Hall this month has become quite a test ing ground for relatively un known and relatively young conductors. Monday night it was the turn of Sergiu Comis siona, born in 1928 in. Rumania and now conductor of the Baltimore Symphony, to show New York audiences what he can do with the crack New York Chamber Orchestra.

title: Television
Mrs. Elizabeth Farmer Married
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18Mrs. Elizabeth Becker Farm er, a news producer here for the Columbia Broadcasting System, was married this noon to John Midgley, Wash ington correspondent of The Econoniist of London. The Rev. Walter Fauntroy per formed the ceremony at the New Bethel Baptist Church.

title: Advertising: Miller Beer Goes to McCann
description: McCannErickson has nabbed a big one, its biggest since it acquired the Buick account in 1958 and about the largest piece of new business taken on by any agency in many a moon.

title: U.S. Quintet Triumphs
description: ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Aug. 18 (AP)Jim McDaniels scored 22 points and George McGinnis 21 to give a United States college basketball squad a 92 88 victory over Yugoslavia last night.

title: PAPERS, DELIVERERS PUSH TALKS ON PACT
description: Negotiators for the city's four major daily newspapers and the Newspaper Deliverers Union continued their bargaining ses sions yesterday in an effort to reach an agreement that would avert a strike threatened for tonight.

title: Enemy Said to Attack Saigon's Forces West of Hue
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 18 (AP)North Vietnam ese troops were staid to have attacked a South Vietnamese force near a fire base 27 miles west of Hue today, but heavy rains reduced ground action elsewhere in South Vietnam's northernmost provinces.

title: JAIL GUARDS PUSH PLAN ON SECURITY
description: Members of the Correction Officers Benevolent Associa tion demanded last night that they be allowed to go through the city jails section by section to repair broken locks on cell doors, return inmates to their cells and search for contraband and homemade weapons.

title: Bridge:
description: BOSTON. Aug. 18  The two youngest teams ever to reach the final of the Spin gold knockout team cham pionship met today in the top event in the American Contract Bridge League's summer national tournament at the Boston Sheraton Hotel.

title: Import Program Challenged
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) President Nixon's decision to keep the oilimport control program was also challenged today by Democratic Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine.

title: PATMAN ASSAILS MOVE BY RESERVE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (Reuters)  Representative Wright.Patman, chairman of the House Banking Committee, today called yesterday's an nouncement by the Federal Re serve Board of a cut in reserve requirements highly misleading concerning its effects on the housing market.

title: Steigerwald Captures Lead In U.S. Thistle Class Sail
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 18 Charles (Chuck) Steigerwald of Columbus, Ohio, sailed into is 4point lead for the 25th an niversary Thistle Class national (championship today when the first two races for all divisions were sailed on Long Island Sound off Cedar Point Yacht Club. Steigerwald had fourth and second places for 6 points.

title: 2 BigBoard Firms Draw Suspensions on Finances
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that its board of governors had suspended Charles Plohn & Co. and the First Devonshire Corporation because they were in unsafe financial condition.

title: Army Drafts Bronco Rookie
description: DENVER, Aug. 18 (UPI)Jim McKoy, Denver Bronco rookie quarterback. was drafted by the Army today.

title: They've Got a Little List
description: Do you reach for the pile of mail your postman has brought, thinking eagerly of letters from family and friends, of an invitation to join some pleasurable profitable venture, or perhaps a tax refund? And do you find all too often that what you have instead is collection of gaudy and unwanted sales pitches for everything from Florida real estate to cutrate toma toes featured at the local supermarket?

title: Ford Assails Demands For Impossible Change
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Aug 18Henry Ford 2d assailed today irresponsible demands and un informed criticism in the air pollution and auto safety fields and said the changes needed in cars will not come one moment sooner because of dead lines which command the im possible.

title: Stephanie Hoar To Be the Bride Of T. P. Einstein
description: Miss Stephanie Bradford Hoar, who is with the Con servation Foundation in Washington, and Thomas Paul Einstein, director of business affairs for A. B. C. International Television here, plan to be married in the fall.

title: Zsa Zsa Gabor Robbed Of Jewels in Elevator
description: Zsa Zsa Gabor was robbed at gunpoint early this morn ing of jewels whose value she estimated at $625,000, the police said.

title: RAVEN CLASS SERIES IS LED BY HOLMDEN
description: BABYLON, L. I., Aug. 18David Holmden of the Niagara Sailing Club was the leader after two races today in the Raven Class national sailing championship.

title: Diphtheria, Once a Dread Killer, Affects. Only a Few in U.S. Now
description: Diphtheria, which has reached socalled epidemic proportions in San Antonio, Tex., this week, is a childhood disease that used to kill thousands of American youngsters each year. Now it affects only a few hundred each year and only rarely kills.

title: Fog Puts Off Title Sail
description: CASCAIS, Portugal, Aug. 18 (AP)A thick fog and virtually no wind today caused a last minute postponement of the second day's race in the 15th Finn Class Gold Cup world championship.

title: A Correction
description: On Monday's society page, photos of Miss Stephanie Marie Moore, who was wed to Charles Thorndike Ladd, and of Miss Gloria Ann Mac caro, who became the bride of Lieut. Brian Jay Carmines, U.S.A., were inadvertently transposed.

title: Hromadka Wins Second Sail Of Luders16 Class Series
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 18  The second race of the Luders16 Class championship series, held at the Chicago Yacht Club, today, was won by Ben Hro madka of the Pacific Coast fleet. Second was Leroy Suth erland, also of the Pacific fleet. Sutherland led Hromadka yesterday. They are both tied with 23 points. Chip Stuart of Sodus Bay, N. Y., led on the windward leg and then on reach, followed by Sutherland, Hromadka and Dan Killeen of New Orleans.

title: Article 2 No Title
Bolshoi Opera, to Make First U.S. Visit in April
description: TOKYO, Aug. 18.The Bol shot Opera Company of Mos cow will open a fourweek engagement at the Metropoli tan Opera House in Lincoln Center, New York, next April 15, Sol Hurok announced here today. It will be the 532 member company's first visit to the United States.

title: Hoaxers and Cranks, Exploiting Bomb Scare, Keep London on Edge
description: LONDON. Aug. 18A rash of explosions and discoveries of arms caches have generated a bomb scare that is keeping the police busy and providing the popular newspapers with big headlines.

title: MOSTWANTED LIST ADDS ANGELA DAVIS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP)  Miss Angela Davis, avowed Communist and former instruc tor at the University of Cali fornia at Los Angeles, was named today to the F.B.I.'s list of 10 mostwanted fugitives.

title: Clipper Sextet Buys Cates
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 18 (AP)The Baltimore Clippers of the American Hockey League today purchased Paul Cates, a de fenseman, from the Quebec Aces of the same circuit.

title: Front Page 2 No Title
Foe of Marijuana Says G.I.Threw a Grenade at Him
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UPI)  A former Marine sergeant told a Senate sub committee today that his objec tions to marijuana smoking so infuriated men under his com mand in Vietnam that one tried to murder him with a hand grenade.

title: White House Praises Capital's Mayor
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18The White House praised Walter E. Washington today and said that President Nixon had no plans to replace him as Mayor of the District of Columbia.

title: Library's Tapes Detail Luce's Ambivalent Relationship With John Kennedy
description: In 1940, Henry R. Luce wrote that if John Kennedy is char acteristic of the younger gen erationand I believe he ismany of us would be happy to have the destinies of this Republic handed over to his generation at once.

title: Booming Tanker Business Buoys Baltic Exchange
description: LONDON, Aug. 18A con tinuing tanker boom with 700 per cent profits on some voy ages and a shipbuilding spree by Communist China are buoying the Baltic Exchange.

title: Robert S. Henry, Historian, Dies; ExOfficer of Rail Association
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Aug. 18 (AP)Robert Selph Henry, au thor, historian and retired rail way executive, died today. He was 80 years old.

title: Sports of
COMPANIES PLAN PRICE INCREASES
description: Price increases affecting im portant consumer items were announced yesterday by number of companies.

title: 3Man Panel Scores Education For SpanishSpeaking Students
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18A panel of Spanishspeaking edu cators said today that past pro grams and policies for providing equal education for Spanish American children were a fraud. The educators questioned inte eration as a solution.

title: Vote Is Postponed
description: GENEVA, Aug. 18 (UPI)The United States assured a United Nations committee to day that the disposal of nerve gas in the Atlantic could not endanger human life and would have a minimal effect on ocean organisms.

title: Outgoing Passenger and Mail Ships
U.S. COURT BACKS FUND'S GIVEUPS
description: BOSTON, Aug. 18 (AP)A Federal judge ruled today that Fidelity Fund, Inc., an invest ment company with assets ex ceeding $800million, did not violate the law in its pre1969 practice of placing its portfolio brokerage business with stock brokers who split their com missions with other brokers also selling shares of the fund.

title: Shift at Career Academy
description: Kenneth M. Parelskin has re signed as president and director of Career Academy, Inc., the company announced yesterday. The board chairman, Wesley D. Pavalon, will assume Mr. Parel skin's post.

title: Police Raid Car Wrecking Yard And Break Up Stolen Auto Ring
description: A raid by six members of the police auto squad yesterday morning on a Brooklyn auto wrecking yard resulted in the finding of 10 stolen autos and the recovery of $150,000 in auto parts that the police be lieve were from more than 100 stolen and dismantled cars.

title: G.O.P. AIDE MOCKS WILLIAMS CANDOR
description: TRENTON, Aug. 18The dep uty chairman of the Republican National Committee ridiculed today as a great revelation the public disclosure by Sena tor Harrison A. Williams Jr. last May that he once had had a drinking problem.

title: Jockey Club Adds Two
description: The jockey club added mem bers, James B. Mosely of Ham ilton, Mass., and William S. Farish of Houston. The latter has a string of thoroughbreds under the training of Del Carroll andhas raced mostly at Dela ware and Hialeah. He also has broodmares at the Marshall Jenney Farm in Upionville, Pa. Mosely is establishing a breed ing operation in Kentucky. He recently acquired Drumtop, the 4yearold Daughter of Round Table,with earnings of $189, 544. Drumtop includes victory in the Edgemere handi cap among her accomplish ments.

title: Youths Seized After Bomb Damages Police Callbox
description: Two 16yearold youths were arrested last night after they allegedly planted an explosive device that went off in a police, callbox in Brooklyn, at Union and Portal Streets, where the Crown Heights and Brownsville section meet.

title: POLICE SHIFT STAND IN HARTFORD KILLING
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 18Efrain Gonzalez; a 26yearold Puerto Rican who was fatally shot during recent North End riots, probably was slain by police weapon, according to Police Chief Thomas J. Vaughan.

title: Market Place:
description: Can an attractive young woman and a computer find happiness in the stock mar ket? In the case of Penny Kaniclides and her Sigma 7 computer, the answer would appear to be a definite yes.

title: Housing Unit Elects Gomez
description: Aramis Gomez was elected yesterday as vice chairman of the New York Housing Author ity. He succeeds Ira S. Robbins, who retired last week after 12 years on the authority. Mr. Gomez, who was appointed to the threemember authority earlier this year, was born in Puerto Rico, and is a former director of the concentrated employment program in East Harlem.

title: Goldberg Says Laird Erred on Middle East Reports
description: NORTH TONAWANDA, N.Y., Aug, 18Arthur J. Goldberg said today that he thought Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird had made a very bad mistake in dismissing Israel's intelligence reports of vio lations of the ceasefire in the Middle East.

title: Radio
description: 9:30Noon, WRVR Just Music: Mendelssohn Chamber Music. Sextet; Cello Sonata No. 2; String Quartet No. 5; Trio No. 2; String Quartet No. 6, Men delssohn.

title: Thant Terms Further Aid Needed for Arab Refugees
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 18As efforts continued to get Middle Eastern peace talks under way, Secretary Gen eral Thant warned all United Nations members today that unless more money was forth coming for Arabrefugee aid, the refugees would present added problems.

title: In Harvard Square, Street People Are Challenging Liberal Ideas
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 18  Thousands of young street people, wearing fad ed blue jeans and long hair, low on money and looking for others like themselves, have come to Harvard Square this summer. They are con fronting the Cambridge com munity with a challenge to its liberal ideals.

title: NARCOTICS ARRESTS RISE 109.3% IN CITY
description: There were 109.3 per cent more narcotics arrests in the city last June than in June, 1969, Police Commissioner How ard R. Leary announced yester day.

title: 22 Cukor Films Will Be Shown In Museum Fete
description: A fiveweek tribute to the directorial career of George Cukor will be presented start ing Aug. 27 at the Museum of Modern Art. The program of 22 films starts with the 1930 film The Royal Family of Broadway, which Mr. Cukor codirected, and goes to The Chapman Report (1963). The following year Mr. Cukor won an Oscar for My Fair Lady.

title: Yugoslav Bank Robbed
description: BELGRADE. Yugoslavia, Aug. 18 (UPI)Thieves broke into a south Yuvoslav bank during the weekend and made off with an estimated $12000 in what the police termed Yugoslavia's theft of the century, it was. reported today.

title: JOHN E. GRIFFIN
description: NEPTUNE, N. J., Aug. 18John E. Griffin, an assistant vice president in the interna tional department of the Chemi cal Bank of New York, died at Jersey Shore Medical Center here yesterday after a short ill Iness. His age was 62.

title: New Labeling Rules Set For ForeignMade Watches
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commis sion ruled today that all watches comprised of 50 per cent or more foreignmade parts must be labeled of foreign origin.

title: HUBERT GREIST, LED MACHINE COMPANY
description: BRANFORD, Conn., Aug. 18 Hubert M. Greist Jr., former president of the Greist Manu facturing Division of the Mite Corporation, died here yester day. He was 59 years old and lived at 21 Island View Avenue. He was with the family com pany from 1934 until his retire ment in 1968.

title: FIRE IN WOODSIDE DESTROYS 11 STORES
description: A four alarm fire, which burned out of control for more than three hours, ruined 11 stores and a banquet hall in blocklong section of Roosevelt Avenue in Woodside, Queens, yesterday.

title: COACH UNWILLING TO TAKE CHANCES
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 18The unpredictable Joe Namath, an absentee from the Jets first 11 training days and two ex hibition games, rejoined his teammates this afternoon but still was expressing uncertainty about his football future.

title: M'GEE RENOMINATED IN WYOMING PRIMARY
description: CHEYENNE, Wyo., Aug. 18 (AP)Senator Gale McGee, a backer of United States policy in Vietnam, defeated a peace candidate i the Democratic pri1 mary today to win renomina tion to a third term.

title: STATE U. STUDENTS FORM ASSOCIATION
description: An association representing student governments at col leges in the State University has been formed to try to avert campus violence.

title: Ship That Carried Gas Bore Name of Educator
description: The rusting, obsolete Lib erty ship that took 2,675 tons of nerve gas to the bot tom of the sea yesterday car ried the name of an awk ward, shy educator who wrote operettas.

title: Walinsky Demands State Act on Migrant Conditions
description: ROCHESTER, Aug. 17Citing dozens of healthcode violations in migrant camps in a three county area near here, Adam Walinsky today demanded that the state empanel a special grand jury to seek out the private citizens and public of ficials who violate the laws which protect the migrant wor kers.

title: BURCH CLARIFIES TV REPLY RULING
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18Dean Burch, chairman of the Federal Communications Com mission, emphasized today that the agency's order requiring the television networks to give primetime exposure to critics of the Administration's policy in Vietnam was not a grant of equal time to match Pres ident Nixon's appearances.

title: Books of The Times
description: No doubt people, like George Christian and Louis Heren, who weathered the direct blasts of Lyndon B. Johnson's personality, will not soon forget him. (Mr. Heren tells the archetypal Johnson story in his de scription of how the former President once made extensive use of Heren's knee and lower thigh to illustrate a comparison of the Vietcong to a young man trying to seduce a girl.) But for those of us who experienced nothing more of Lyndon Johnson than the wooden TV performances and the graceless rhetoric, all sense of the man has faded with remarkable speed. And since surely (common sense tells us) he could not have been as awful as devil theorists and angry caricaturists once made him out to be, one approaches these two books with an open, if not quite blank, mind and a high quotient of curiosity.

title: Japan's Private Ambassador Leaves Peking After 12 Years
description: PEKING, Aug. 18 (Agence FrancePresse)The man whom many Japanese consider their country's private ambassador to China, Kinkazu Saionji, left here today to return to Japan by way of Canton and Hong Kong after living here for 12 years, trying to improve re lations between Japan and Com munist China.

title: Gas Developed by Nazis, Who Weighed Using It
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18Hitler once considered attack ing Britain with nerve gas ex actly like the GB gas that the United States dumped in the Atlantic today, according to Joseph Borkin, a Washington lawyer and publicist who is writing a book about the de velopment of nerve gas.

title: Boulez Named Adviser Of Cleveland Orchestra
description: Pierre Boulez, principal guest conductor of the Cleve land Orchestra through the 197172 season, has been named to serve as the or chestra's music adviser through that period. The or chestra's musical director, George Szell, died last month.

title: TEACIERS TO SEEK BANON INJUNCTION
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 18  A nationwide campaign to pro hibit state courts from issuing injunctions against strikes by public employes where public safety. is not involved was begun here today by the American Federation of Teachers.

title: Yemen Gets Heavy Rainfall
description: CAIRO, Aug. 18 (UPI) Yemen has received her first heavy rains in 10 years, the Middle East News Agency said today. Reporting from Sana, Yemen's capital the agency said a fourhour rainfall, however, had fallen too late to help the nation's farmers and immedi ately alleviate the lot of the nation's 1.8 million people, many of whom are reported to be near starvation.

title: NEW CORN DISEASE INVADES MORE AREAS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UPI)  Federal experts re ported today that a new type of corn blight had spread from Texas to Florida in the South and up to Minnesota and Wis consin in the North. But it said it was too early to estimate the potential damage to the na tion's $5billion corn crop.

title: Gardner Initiates A Citizens'
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP)  Former Welfare Sec retary John W. Gardner form ally initiated today a nation wide, nonpartisan political movement called Common Cause, which he says will be citizens lobby to force action on reform of the political sys tem and solution of national problems.

title: BLACKS DEMAND ACTION ON POLICE
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., Aug. 18After four nights of racial violence, black citizens in Broward County, Fla., pre sented the Pompano Beach City Commission today with list of demands, one of which called for the prosecution of white policeman who shot and Idled a Negro Saturday night.

title: ROCKEFELLER OPENS CAMPAIGN OFFICES
HURLER'S SUCCESS A BOON TO TEAM
President, Here, Strolls on East Side
description: President Nixon took an impromptu sidewalk poll on the Upper East Side last eve ning and said that he found that people were more opti mistic about peace in the world.

title: 26 Transferred, 50 Penalized For Stoppage at Attica Prison
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Aug. 18Twentysix prisoners who were leaders in a threeday work stoppage last month at the At tica Correctional Facility have been transferred to other penal institutions, and about 50 men have been disciplined by the loss of time off for good be havior, Superintendent Vincent R. Mancusi said today.

title: British Soccer Results
Thoroughbreds Test Westbury Synthetic Track
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 18 Roosevelt Raceway's syn thetic rubber surface, over which standardbreds turned in seven sub2minute miles during the recent harness racing meeting, was given its first test by thoroughbreds today. With numerous offi cials from various tracks on hand, about 25 flat horses jogged. galloped and breezed. The reaction of the officials, in the main, was favorable.

title: Doris Hustedt Is Wed on L.I.
description: BELLMORE, L. I., Aug. 18 Miss Doris Hustedt, a cum laude graduate of Harpur College, was married here this evening to Richard W. Kessler, a Colgate Univer sity graduate who is attend ing the University of Penn sylvania Law School.

title: Steps Called Wise in Paris
description: PARIS, Aug. 18 (Reuters)Banking sources here described the Reserve's moves as econom ically wise. But they foresaw little reaction ensuing either way on Wall Street and only minor adjustments resulting in prevailing United States and Eurodollar interest rates.

title: ROCK FETE FINDS HAVEN IN CAPITAL
description: Unable to put on their Powder Ridge Rock Festival in Middlefield, Conn., last month, the producers have scheduled a concert to be held next Tuesday in the Robert F. Kennedy Me morial Stadium in Washington.

title: Texas Officer Reprimanded In PhotoClipping Incident
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex. Aug. 18 (AP)The commanding gen eral of Lackland Air Force Base said today that a public information officer who de cided a photo should be slashed from 10,000 copies of the base newspaper had been reprimanded.

title: Young Wins South Bay Title Despite a Broken Halyard
description: SHINNECOCK, L. I., Aug. 18 Peter Young of the Babylon Yacht Club overcame trouble in today's first race and went on to capture the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's junior singlehanded champion ship.

title: Operation Bungle
description: As the old Liberty ship sinks to the ocean floor off Florida carrying its cargo of 67 tons of nerve gas, one of the most extraordinary stories of human ignorance, arrogance and confused blundering comes to an end. Codenamed by the Pentagon as Operation Chase (cut holes and sink em). it might better have been called Operation Bungle.

title: Bonn Delays Final Decision On Two Atom Power Plants
description: BONN, Aug. 18 The West German government has post poned its final approval of two nuclear power projects that were originally scheduled to get under way this year.

title: Fisher Files for Bankruptcy, Lists Debts of $916,300
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Aug. 18, (UPI)Eddie Fisher, the singer, filed a petition of bankruptcy yesterday in United States Dis trict Court.

title: Roundup: Spiezio's Slam Is Grand for the Padres
description: From the time Russell E. McKelvey hit the major leagues first home run with the bases loaded for Indian apolis in 1878, the subject has proved to be among the most glamorous statistics in the record book, including Lou Gehrig's 23 career grand slams, Ernie Banks's five in a season, Jim Northrup's three in a week and Jim Gentile's two in the first two innings.

title: Woman Testifies in New Haven That McLucas Wept After Rackley's Murder
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 18De scribing Lonnie McLucas as my man or as you would say, my boyfriend, a young woman in the Black Panther party tes tified at his trial today that he wept after the murder of Alexi Rackley.

title: CLAY WINS ROUND IN COURT BATTLE
description: Cassius Clay's lawyers told a Federal judge yesterday that more than 90 convicted felons, whose crimes ranged from em bezzlement to rape and mur der, had been licensed to box in recent years by the New York State Athletic Commis sion, which suspended Clay aft er he refused to be inducted into the armed services.

title: Firemen Climb 46 Flights To Put Out Times Sq. Blaze
description: Firemen were forced to walk up 46 flights of stairs last night to combat a fire in the Astor Plaza building in Times Square.

title: Refugee Rally in West Berlin Loses Its Government Backing
description: BERLIN, Aug. 18Bonn an nounced today it would provide no public funds for a gathering in West Berlin next month of the associations of those ex pelled from Germany's former eastern provinces.

title: JERSEY BANK JURY HEARS WOMAN AIDE
description: NEWARK, Aug. 18  Mrs., Betty Kennedy, vice president of the defunct Eatontown (N. Natiorial Bank, testified) for an hour today before a Federal grand jury here inves tigating the affairs of the bank.

title: MARAVICH EXCITES CAMPERS UPSTATE
Moves Seen as Neutral
description: LONDON, Aug. 18 (Reuters) The latest moves by the Fed eral. Reserve are regarded as neutral by American banks here. However, they have prompted speculation that the recent suspension of ceilings on 3089day large certificates of deposit may now be a per manent rather than a tempo rary phenomenon.

title: Lebanese Report Border Raid by Israelis
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 18Lebanese officials reported to day that an Israeli force crossed into southern Lebanon early in the day and blew up three houses.

title: FUTURES PRICES SLUMP ON GRAIN
description: What went up came down yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade as grain futures con tracts dropped sharply follow ing Monday's acrosstheboard limit advance.

title: Priceless Painting, Stolen in Church, Recovered in Rome
description: ROME, Aug. 18  The police today recovered a priceless 13th century painting stolen from a church here three weeks ago. They said its theft and that of many other masterworks in Italy was the work of organ ized criminals who steal on commission for private collec tors.

title: Negro Loses in Mississippi
description: WEST POINT, Miss., Aug. 18  Former Mayor Barnes Mar shall easily defeated a black antipoverty worker, John Buf fington, today in a runoff elec tion for Mayor of this north east Mississippi city. The un official totals showed Mr. Mar shall with 1,764 votes to Mr. Buffington's 617.

title: MONTREAL JET FIRE BRINGS LANDING HERE
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 18 (AP)An Air France jet carrying 174 passengers from Montreal to Paris was diverted to New York's Kennedy International Airport early today after one of its engines caught fire.

title: SENATE UNIT ASKS CUT IN I.L.Q. FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug 18 A Senate Appropriations subcom mittee was reported today to have cut $3.7million from funds for the Genevabased In ternational Labor Organization.

title: Surgery for Rockefeller 4th
description: John D Rockefeller 4th, West Virginia's Secretary of State, was operated on for a slipped disk yesterday. A spokesman for ColumbiaPres byterian Medical Center said his condition was good. Mr. Rockefeller, who is 33 years old, is a son of John D Rocke feller 3d and a nephew of Gov. Rockefeller of New York and Gov. Winthrop Rockefeller of Arkansas.

title: NAVY RECRUITING OF BLACKS LAGS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) Despite efforts begun three years ago to recruit more blacks, the Navy officer corps remains a virtual lilywhite ganization, with Negroes ac counting for less than 1 per cent of the Navy's 80,000 of ficers.

title: Moscow Fans Savor Play in Yiddish
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 18  Two thousand Moscow Jews dem onstrated last weekend that there still is an audience here ror Yiddish theater.

title: Cleanup of Vacant Lots Is Begun in East Harlem as Mayor Watches
description: A grim Mayor Lindsay spent an hour yesterday morning walking through several rundown blocks of East Harlem.

title: NIXON TO SEND BAN ON CHEMICAL WAR TO SENATE TODAY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18After 15 months of debate within the Administration, the White House will send the Geneva Protocol of 1925 to the Senate tomorrow for approval.

title: JUSTICE UNIT BACKS PAROLE REFORM BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 The Justice Department en dorsed today, a senate bill that would authorize the assign ment of persons on parole on probation to community treat ment centers run by the Bu reau of Prisons.

title: Marine Takes Rifle Lead
description: CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 18 (UPI)A marine warrant of ficer, Robert L. Goller of Key ser, W. Va., moved into the lead today in the battle for the national highpower rifle cham pionships with a twoday total of 792 points of a possible 800.

title: RAHIM SETS BACK GORMAN IN TENNIS
description: HAVERFORD, Pa., Aug. 18The ninepoint sudden death tiebreaker, receiving its first test on grass in the Pennsyl vania lawn tennis champion ships, decided a thrilling three set match today between Ha foon Rahim of Pakistan, the United States amateur grass court champion, and Tom Gor man of Seattle.

title: Mrs. Ernest Byfield Jr. Is Dead; Active in Many Society Benefits
description: Mrs. Ernest Byfield Jr., a prominent society woman and the wife of an advertising executive, died yesterday at her home. She was in her 50's and) lived at 930 Park Avenue.

title: News Summary and Index
description: InternationalJoseph J. Sisco, Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Af fairs, told the Israeli Ambassador, Itzak Rabin, yesterday that the United States Government did not feel the Egyptian viola tion of the Middle East ceasefire was serious enough to warrant any further delay in negotiations. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: France and U.S. Reinforcing Mediterranean Narcotics Staff
description: PARIS, Aug. 18France has nearly quadrupled her force of narcotics agents covering the Mediterranean coastal region and Corsica in the last month, and plans to add more in the fall. These are the principal areas for refining drugs from Turkey and other Middle East ern regions and transshipment to the United States.

title: New Carburetor Rule Results in Far Fewer Engine Failures
description: It is possible, it seems, to go faster by going slower. Sunday's Yankee 400 stock car race at Michigan Interna tional Speedway proved the point as Charlie Glotzbach raced the 400 miles at an average speed of 148 miles an hour, 5 m.p.h. faster than the previous record. It was the first race in About which the Nation al Association for Stock Car Auto Racing (NASCAR) tried its new car buretor rule to curb the dangerous speeds of the Grand National class. A metal plate with a 1inch hole is installed between the carbu retor and the intake manifold. This has the effect of reduc ing the normal 1 11/16inch Venturi opening in the car buretor itself.

title: State Department PressAide
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18Arthur J. Olsen, a journalist and foreign correspondent, was named today as director of the Department of State's Office of Press Relations. He has served for four years as head of the Office of Public Affairs in the Bureau of European Affairs. He had been bureau chief for The New York Times in Warsaw, Bonn and Buenos Aires and a diplomatic correspondent for The United Press in Washing ton.

title: WILLIAM O. BEACH
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 18William O. Beach, deputy man ager of Brown Brothers Harri man & Co., New York bankers, died in a hospital here today. He was 64 years old and lived in Valley Stream.

title: Police Defend Actions in Wall St. Confrontation
description: The Police Department defend ed itself yesterday against charges by Mayor Lindsay that it had failed to handle properly the violent skirmishes last May between construction workers and students protesting the United States involvement in Cambodia.

title: Procaccino Calls Goldberg Hypocrite for Delegate Plan
description: Former Controller Mario A. Procaccino, the unsuccessful Democratic candidate for May or of New York last year, assailed Arthur J. Goldberg as a political hypocrite yester day.

title: RollCall on Veto
TODAY'S PROBABLE PITCHERS
Jobs Were Scarcer, but Students Wanted Ones With. Relevance
description: Summertime, and this year the liv ing's not so easyfor college students. With tuition, room and board fees soar ing, an ever increasing number need summer jobs to help pay their expenses. bat with the economy in the doldrums, there are fewer jobs to be had.

title: U.S. GYPSUM CUTS BRITISH HOLDING
description: The United States Gypsum Company announced yesterday it had sold 4,974,179 ordinary shares of its holdings In BPB Industries, Ltd., London, pro ducers of buildine materials.

title: Old People Underfed, Panel Told
description: Widespread malnutrition among old people living here without friends or relatives and fearing to leave their rooms was reported yester day at a legislative hearing.

title: Cleaver and Black Panther Group Attend Hanoi Observance
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Aug. 18 (Agence FrancePresse)In the presence of a delegation from the American Black Pan ther party led by Eldridge, Cleaver, North Vietnam cele brated an international day of solidarity with the black peo ple of the United States today.

title: A Correction
description: The New York Times on June 21 erroneously reported the death of Harold Seroff of West field, N. J., the president of the Intercontinental Growth Plan Inc., a division of the Intercontinental Life Company of Newark.

title: LARSEN STILL AHEAD IN U.S. CHESS OPEN
description: BOSTON, Aug. 18 Grand master Bent Larsen of Denmark retained the lead after the eighth round of the annual United States Open Chess Championship by splitting the point with Robert Byrne, grandmaster of Indianapolis, at the Parker House here last nieht.

title: DIVISIVENESS HELD TOP U.S. PROBLEM
description: Divisions in society be tween rich and poor, young and old, white and black and the elite and nonelite are at the top of a list of major prob lem areas for the United States for the nineteenseven ties and nineteeneighties, ac cording to a National Indus trial Conference Board survey released yesterday.

title: Ellen M. Carlstein Fiancee of Lawyer
description: Miss Ellen Martha Carl stein, a lawyer with Cad walader, Wickersham & Taft here, and Stephen Harold Roth, a lawyer with Clapp & Eisenberg in Newark, plan to be married Aug. 30.

title: BROWN BROS. NAMED AS VICTIM OF THEFT
description: The private banking firm of Brown Bros., Harriman & Co. was identified yesterday as the victim of a $1.56million theft of Treasury bills.

title: From Cloche to Brims, Hats Are Back
description: Fashion may still be in a state of flux about hemlines but there is no uncertainty about hats. They are back and there's scarcely a de signer of readytowear, who isn't stressing their impor tance. One of the nicest things about the current mil linery revival is that there is almost no wrong shape. There are, how ever, shapes that are more right than others. Two Shop Talk of them are the large brimsome straight, some floppy but all with purity of lineand the small, wraparound cloche or turban that hugs the head.

title: John Darcy Is Fiance of Nancy Hill
description: Miss Nancy Hill and John M. Darcy, who met at the State University at Stony Brook, L.I., where they are doctoral students in psycho biology, will marry Aug. 29.

title: Australians to Withdraw A Battalion From Vietnam
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Aug. 18 (Reuters)The Government said today that it would with draw a battalion of troops from South Vietnam, but would offer Saigon a direct grant of 3.3 mil lion Australian dollars (about $3.6million) as defense aid.

title: HARDWICK MOSELEY
description: DEDHAM, Mass., Aug. 18Hardwick Moseley, a retired director of the Houghton Mifflin Company, publishers, died in a nursing home here yesterday after a long illness. He, was 69 years old.

title: Consulate Is Picketed
description: NASSAU, the Bahamas, Aug. 18 (Reuters)Members of the militant Bahamian Youth Or ganization picketed the home of Sir Francis Cumming Bruce and the United States consulate to day to protest the dumping of the nerve gas into the Atlantic off the Bahamas.

title: Rules on Catholic Orders to Be Eased
description: ROME, Aug. 18An eight point decree, approved by Pope Paul VI last June but still not officially published here, re laxes outdated restrictions on some 1,250,000 Roman Catholic nuns and monks.

title: Times Sq. Shuttle Is Trip to Pandemonium
European Parley in 1971 Now Seems Likely
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 18  A European security conference involving the North Atlantic, alliance, the Warsaw Pact na tions and neutral countries is regarded as quite likely in 1971 by authoritative sources in the North Atlantic Treaty Organi zation.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX SHOW ADVANCE
description: The American Stock Ex change yesterday turned in its best performance in three weeks as most prices rose in steppedup trading.

title: State Gift to Finance Park Dance Concerts
description: A grant of $35,000 to the New York Dance Festival by the New York State Council on the Arts was announced by Governor Rockefeller yes terday.

title: PATHET LAO ACCUSES U.S. AND SOUVANNA
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 18 (Reu ters)  The proCommunist Pathet Lao leader, Prince Souphanouvong, has accused the Laotian Government of Pre mier Souvanna Phouma of in troducing South Vietnamese troops into Laos.

title: Chamberlin to Be No. 2 at Channel 13
description: Ward B. Chamberlin Jr., who played a key role in setting up the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, after Congress authorized creation of the body to advance noncommercial radio and television, will become ex ecutive vice president of the Educational Broadcasting Cor poration, operator of Channel 13.

title: Transcontinental Investing
description: The report yesterday of the Transcontinental Investing Company showed a sharp drop in earnings for the quarter and first half this year.

title: General Reduced to Colonel
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP)An Army review board has endorsed the reduction of a brigadier general to colonel, and his retirement, for failing to maintain a high degree of pesronal and professional in tegrity, a service spokesman said today. The retirement at rank of colonel for former Brig. Gen. Earl C. Cole means that he will draw an annual retire ment pay of $15,041.76 instead of $17,120.76. A lawyer for the officer, who lives in Alexandria, Va., said the action would be fought.

title: A Street Gang Leader Gives Up At Chicago Newspaper's Office]
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (AP)Charles Edward Bey, second in command of a Negro street gang, turned himself in to the authorities today, and the po lice continued their hunt for three other gang members wanted for questioning in the sniper slaying of a Chicago de tective.

title: City Investing Raises Quarter Profits
description: The City Investing Company showed a sharp increase in profits in the second quarter and a more moderate advance for the half year, the report showed yesterday.

title: Jersey Lottery Date Set
description: TRENTON, Aug. 18 (UPI) New Jersey's first staterun lot tery will begin about Dec. 1, Senate Majority Leader Harry L. Sears announced today.

title: J. BYRON M'CORMICK, LED U. OF ARIZONA
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Aug. 18 (UPI)Dr. J. Byron McCor mick, former president of the University of Arizona, died yesterday at St. Joseph's Hos pital here. He was 75 years old.

title: Amusements for Children
description: STORY OF A PATRIOT and True Story, of the Civil War at 2:15 P.M. today at the NewYork Historical Society, 170 Central Park West at 77th Street 8733400.

title: Italians Pressing Drive Against Drugs
description: ROME, Aug. 18Italy's sum mer campaign against narcotics users is sending longhaired young foreigners fleeing from a country they once found com pletely hospitable.

title: Olin Invents Device to Measure Mercury
description: The Olin Corporation, one of many chemical companies that have been accused of contain Mating the environment, an nounced yesterday that it had developed an instrument that can automatically, detect and measure minute amounts of mercury in air or water at rapid pace.

title: Christopher Robinson to Wed Miss Terry Taffinder on Oct.
description: MIDDLETOWN, R. I., Aug. 18  Comdr. Sherwoode A. Taffinder, U. S. N., retired, and Mrs. Taffinder have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Terry Anne Taffinder, to Christo pher Heathcote Robinson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis C. Robinson of London. The wedding will take place here Oct. 3 in the chapel of St. George's School.

title: Wide Economic Reforms Follow Ecuador's Devaluation of Sucre
description: QUITO, Ecuador, Aug. 18Sweeping and revolutionary economic reforms have been approved by the Government in conjunction with its devalu ation of the surce from 18 to 25 to the dollar last Sunday.

title: Washington: The Role of the Vice President
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18For many months now, the Nixon Administration has been debat ing privately the best way to make the South Vietnamese take over the defense of their country and speed up the with drawal of the American expedi tionary force. Should the Saigon regime be assured of Washing ton's support indefinitely, or should it be told, publicly or privately, that the American troops would be called home by a certain date?

title: 2 Bonn Aides Unharmed In Office Shooting Here
description: A 76yearold Polish immi grant who said he had lost about 250 relatives in World War II was arrested on a charge of trying to murder two vice consults in the West German Consulate at 460 Park Avenue, near 57th Street, yesterday.

title: Probable NaturalGas Find Off Netherlands Announced
description: The Royal Dutch Shell Group and the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) announced yes terday a probable commer cial natural gas discovery in the North Sea 53 miles north west of the town of Helder in the Netherlands. The well is jointly owned.

title: ERNST LEMMER, 72, IN BONN CABINETS
description: BERLIN, Aug. 18Ernst Lem mer, cofounder of the Christian Democratic Union. after World War II, and a ranking politician in the earlier years of the Bonn Republic, died here today fol lowing an operation for a stom ach ailment. He was 72 years old.

title: Foe Seizes Rice in Cambodia
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Aug. 18Communist forces am bushed a Government food con voy bound for Pnompenh yes terday and made off with a rather important number of truckloads of rice, the Cam bodian command said today.

title: YIELDS GO DOWN IN BOND MARKETS
description: The Federal Reserve's deci sion to cut reserve require ments against savings deposits dowered interest rates sharply on shortterm funds employed to finance public housing and state projects.

title: Jersey Layman President Of World Methodist Council
description: GENEVA, Aug. 18Charles C. Parlin, a Wall Street lawyer, today became the first layman to be elected President of the World Methodist Council since it was formed in 1881.

title: Bridal in September Is Set by Miss Wylie
description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert Haw thorne Wylie of the Bronx have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Alexandra Pearson Wylie, to Norbert A.. Copsidine 3d, a 1969 graduate of the Univer sity of Pennsylvania, where his fiance was graduated this year. The wedding is planned for next month.

title: Excerpts From Hatfield's Senate Speech Replying to Agnew
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18Following are excerpts from the text of Senator Mark 0. Hatfield's floor speech today replying to Vice President Agnew:

title: Leisure Corp. Dividend Set
description: Fred Benninger, president of the International Leisure Cor poration, announced yesterday that the board of directors had approved a cash dividend of 28 cents a share.

title: Music.
description: LENOX, Mass., Aug. 18In the last half dozen years there has been no more sig nificant development in mu sic than the appearance of imposing numbers of young performers who are both will ing and able to play new works whose difficulties would have been beyond the reach of renowned virtuosos a generation ago.

title: AFRICAN LEADERS MEET IN ETHIOPIA
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 18A series of meetings of the Organization of African Unity got under way today, with Ni geria participating for the first time in two years.

title: Soviet Dismisses Charges By Israel on Suez Missiles
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 18  The Soviet Union today dismissed as fabrications Israeli charges that the United Arab Republic had violated the Middle East ceasefire by moving Soviet missile installations near the Suez Canal.

title: Head of the Draft Board in Dubuque Lobbies in Capital for Ending of Draft
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18The head of the draft board in Dubuque, Iowa, came to Wash ington today to support legis lation that, its sponsors say, would do away with the draft.

title: BIG BOARD CLIMBS IN BRISK TRADING
description: The stock market, feeding on some morsels of good news for a change, bounded ahead yesterday in brisk trading.

title: ExPrisoner at Tombs Feels Close to Cellmates
description: At 2:30 last Monday after noon, after seven months of de tention, Julio Senidez was re leased from the Tombs when his family put up $150 bail.

title: Japanese Welcome Actions
description: TOKYO, Aug. 18 (Reuters)Banking sources said they welcomed the local actions taken by the Reserve. They saw the reduction of reserve requirements as reflecting a consistent policy of gradually easing the money supply.

title: Front Page 1 No Title
description: The squatters who occupied Ellis Island for 13 days this summer have been given permission to return to the island and turn it into a rehabilitation center for 2,500 nar cotics addicts, former con victs and their families. cotics addicts, former con victs and their families.

title: Quake Felt in Alaska
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Aug. 18 (UPI)A strong earthquake rattled a wide area of south central Alaska this morning, but no injuries or property dam age were reported. The Envi ronmental Services Administra tion said the quake registered 6 on the Richter scale and was cenutered about 150 miles east of Anchorage.

title: Importers Concur On a Coffee Quota
description: LONDON, Aug. 18 (AP)Consumer coffee nations agreed in principle today with the In ternational Coffee Trade on set ting a 58millionbag quota for 197071 coffee year at a meet ing of the International Coffee Agreement.

title: SENATOR KENNEDY SCORES OIL QUOTA
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UPI)  Asserting he was shocked and disappointed by President Nixon's decision to retain the present oilimport quota system, Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today he will hold Senate hearings on the decision at the earliest op, nortunitv.

title: U.S SAYS IT FINDS NO MAJOR BREACH OF TRUCE BY EAR.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18The United States informed Israel today that it could not conclude that there had been a serious enough Egyptian violation of the Middle East ceasefire to warrant any further delay in ArabIsraeli negotiations, and urged Israel to proceed with the talks, officials reported.

title: Songmy Suspect Wants His Case Tried in Vietnam
description: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Aug. 18 (UPI)The military attorney for Pvt. Gerald Srhith, charged with murder and indecent as sault in the alleged massacre of Vietnamese civilians in Songmy in 1968, asked today that his case be tried in Viet nam.

title: Young &
description: The latest example of di versification by agencies took place yesterday when Young & Rubicam said that it had made an offer to acquire some assets and operations of the J.K. Gill Company. Gill owns 11 stores in Oregon and Washington that sell books, gifts, art supplies and office equipment.

title: FORD STILL WEIGHING A DEAL WITH SOVIET
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev. Aug. 18The Ford Motor Company still is considering doing business in the Soviet Union, but Moscow has not responded to Ford in quiries, Henry Ford 2d, the company chairman, said today.

title: SENATE OVERRIDES SCHOOL FUND VETO BY 77T016 VOTE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18The Senate today decisively overrode President Nixon's veto of the $4.4billion education ap propriation bill, completing en actment of the measure despite White House disapproval.

title: Toll Takers Strike At 7 City Crossings
description: Toll collectors at five bridges and two tunnels in the city abruptly walked off their jobs last night, surprising both their supervisors and their own union leaders.

title: FLORIDA 12METER BEATS WEATHERLY
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 18Heritage seems to be a much faster boat now than she was last month.

title: Pilotage Fees Suit Adds to Woes of Ticketed Ship
description: The troubles of the 715foot liner Caribia, now illegally berthed between two piers at the edge of the Upper West Side, were compounded yester day when harbor pilots sued the ship for an unpaid pilotage bill.

title: Bob Ross, 61, Originator Of TV's Mayberry R.F.D.
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Aug. 18 (UPI)  Bob Ross, originator and producer of the television series Mayberry R.F.D., died !aft night of a heart attack. Mr. Ross, 61 years old, was stricken while watching a sum mer rerun of the show, which will begin its third season this fall.

title: WEBSTER TERMS GAME IMPORTANT
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., Aug. 18  Someone involved with the GiantsJets football game finally admitted that this con test at Yale Bowl Sunday was more than just an exhibition game. It was Alex Webster, coach of the Giants, who said he wanted to win this game more than he wants to win most games.

title: San Antonio Fights Rise in Diphtheria
description: AAN ANTONIO, Tex., Aug. 18 (AP)Thousands of people fined up today for shots in this city's worst diphtheria outbreak in a decade as two new cases were confirmed, raising the ?otal to 22 for this month and 52 since Jan. 1.

title: 4 Killed in Filming Of Movie Air Battle
description: DUBLIN, Aug. 18Two Americans were among four persons killed near here to day in a collision between a biplane and a helicopter dur ing filming of a dogfight in the movie Zeppelin

title: Crusader for Prison Reforms
description: State Senator John Richard Dunne had no sooner arrived on Cape Cod last week for his first vacation in two years when rioting erupted among prisoners at the Tombs.

title: Manson Witness Terms Testimony Repentance
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 18 Linda Kasabian said today on the witness stand that her tes timony was her repentance for the slaying of Sharon Tate, the actress, and six other per sons last August.

title: CONNECTICUT VOTE TO BE HELD TODAY
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 18Con necticut Democrats will go to the polls tomorrow in the party's first statewide primary election to select a candidate for the United States Senate.

title: NATO Remains Eager to Preserve U.S. Force Levels
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18Members of the North Atlantic alliance remain eager for the United States to maintain pres ent troop levels indefinitely in Western Eurone.Administration officials said this desire had been conveyed to Washington in recent days through diplomatic channels and by State Secretary Egon Bahr of West Germany. Mr. Bahr conferred here yesterday with White House and State Depart ment officials on Bonn's recent negotiations with the Soviet Union.

title: Ellis Island Squatters Get Permit to Develop Center
Hamlet Devastated by Vietcong Is Almost Rebuilt in 2 Months
description: THANHMY, South VietnamIn June this small community was only a dark smudge on the earth after a Vietcong massacre.

title: Special Stolen Car Alert
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., Aug 18All Elizabeth patrolmen and members of the department's auto squad were ordered today to keep a sharp lookout for one particular stolen car. The car belongs to their chief, Michael D. Roy.

title: Conflict of Interest
description: Conflict of interest. The very term has a troublesome connotation. No one, it would seem, can be expected serve effectively interests that are opposing. But at the same time, it is clear that overlap ping and possibly conflicting relationships are commonplace throughout American business. One man may be a director of two competing banking organi zations, a role that until recent ly J. Peter Grace played at First Na tional City Corpo ration and Marine Midland Banks, Inc.

title: Women's Liberation Unit Gives Details of Its Nationwide Protest
description: The coordinators of next week's Women's Strike for Equality announced plans yes terday for nationwide demon strations ranging from baby ins to marches and rallies to dramatize their goal of achiev ing the unfinished business of our equality.

title: Twins Win in 9th as McDaniel Yields TwoRun Single to Holt
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 18The mileage on the flashy red convertible in the bull pen went up tonight, but Yankee spirits dipped as Minnesota edged New York 87, on Jim Holt's pinchhit, tworun single in the ninth inning.

title: Martha Wilkinson's 75 for 150 Wins U.S. Women's Golf Medal
description: DARIEN, Conn., Aug. 18Martha Wilkinson of Whittier, Calif., won the qualifying medal in the 70th United States women's amateur golf cham pionship today by adding oneoverpar 75 to a firstround 75 for 150.

title: Article 3 No Title
description: Are you a housewife and have the time to earn extra money while enjoying a change of pace? A temporary job may be the answer. See The New York Times Help Wanted columns under the specific job category, such as clerks, secretaries, typists, or under the heading temporary.

title: Film:
2 BRIEF WALKOUTS ARE ENDED BY C.W.A.
description: Two brief work stoppages in the communications industry ended yesterday with employes returning to their jobs at both Western Union and the long lines division of the American Telephone and Telegraph corn any.

title: ISRAELIS DISPLAY PHOTOS AS PROOF OF U.A.R. BUILDUP
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 19Israel made public tonight photo graphs of what was described as an Egyptian missile buildup on the western bank of the Suez Canal that started a few hours before the Middle Eastern cease fire and military standstill.

title: NO GAS PERIL FOUND AT SITE OF DUMPING
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (Reuters)Navy tests indicate that the dumping of 418 vaults of nerve gas in the Atlantic apparently caused no wide spread contamination in the area, Defense Department of firials said today.

title: Louise Hemingway Is Fiancee Of F. H. Statton, Publicity Aide
description: CHESHIRE, Conn., Aug. 19  An October wedding is planned here by Miss Louise Dorsey Hemingway and Francis Harbert Statton, who is in charge or advertising and public relations for the General American Develop ment Corporation, a land de velopment company in San Francisco.

title: FORMER SERVICEMEN TESTIFY ON DRUG USE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UPI) Masked and unidentified to unsure anonymity before tele vision cameras, former service men testified today of near tragedy resulting from the use of marijuana and other drugs in the United States, Vietnam and Korea.

title: Buffalo Five Enlists Citizens
description: BUFFALO, Aug. 19 (AP)The Buffalo Braves of the Na tional Basketball Association announced the formation of a citizens advisory board today in keeping with plans to in volve the residents of Western New York. John Galvin, vice chairman of the Marine Mid land Bank of Western New York, was named board chair man.

title: Duffey SoftPedaled Peace
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 19  The Rev. Joseph Daniel Duffey, who won the Democratic primary for the United States Senate tonight, was thought of as the peace candidate when he started campaigning last fall.

title: Advertising: A 50Year CannonAyer Tie
description: When a clientagency rela tionship continues uninter ruptedly for 50 years, you've got to notice it. And today one of these relationships will be officially noticed at a luncheon in the Hemisphere Club atop the Time and Life Building.

title: Front Page 1 No Title
U.S. Allows G.E.'s Sale of Computer Business to Unit of Honeywell
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 The Justice Department an nounced today that, subject to certain conditions, it would per mit the General Electric Com pany to go ahead with its plan to sell its computermanufactur ing business to a new company controlled by Honeywell, Inc.

title: John Bellanca, 84, Builder Of Early Airplanes, Is Dead
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Aug. 19 (AP)  John Bellanca, an aviation pioneer who began manufacturing airplanes in 1919, died here yesterday after a long illness, at the age of 84.

title: A Listing of New Books
description: Blue Movie, by Terry Southern (NAL Book: World, $6.95). Those involved in the making of an erotic movie.

title: SHELVING OF SST IS URGED BY PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 A subcommittee of Congress's Joint Economic Committee said today that the supersonic trans port should be shelved because of hidden cost burdens to both the Government and consum ers and because of imponder able hazards to the environ ment.

title: YOUNG LUTHERANS OPEN CONVENTION
description: About 16,000 teenagers members of the Luther League of the American Lutheran Church  opened the first working session of a sixday convention at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

title: $4.2Billion Is Needed to Clear State's Waters, Governor Says
description: LIVERPOOL, N. Y., Aug. 19Governor Rockefeller estimated today that it would cost $4.2 billion to rid the state's water ways of municipal and indus trial waste.

title: Sentences of 6 Students Are Upheld in Britain
description: LONDON, Aug. 19 The Court of Appeal today upheld prison and reformatory sen tences for six Cambridge stu Aents who took part in a riotous protest in February against the Greek Government.

title: STUYVESANT TOWN SEEKS RENT RISE
description: Stuyvesant Town has asked the city for permission to raise rents by more than half  to $56.61 a room.

title: Nixon Asks Senate to Back Germ War Ban
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19President Nixon urged the Sen ate today to approve the 45yearold Geneva protocol ban ning the first use of chemical and biological weapons in war.

title: South Africa Slightly Eases Apartheid Rule for Chinese
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 19The South African Government loosened its apartheid rules slightly to day to allow members of the Chinese community of Port Elizabeth to continue to share sports facilities and attend places of entertainment re served for whites.

title: PERGAMON PROFIT IS FOUND TOO HIGH
description: LONDON, Aug. 19An inde pendent audit has produced fig ures showing the profits and assets for Pergamon Press in 1968 far below those in the company's audited accounts for that year.

title: Roundup: 11 Runs in 9th Give White Sox Overkill
description: Luis Aparicio and his Chi cago White Sox teammates were guilty of overkill yes terday as a recordequaling 11run ninth inning gave them a 135 victory over the Red Sox at Boston.

title: 5 Candidates'
description: Representatives of five can didates for Governor and the United States Senate met yes terday to discuss a voluntary limitation on radio and tele vision campaign spending, but Governor Rockefeller's cam paign manager, R. Burdell Bixby, refused to attend.

title: Peace Medal CourtMartial
description: FORT RILEY, Kan., Aug. 19 (AP)Maj. Gen. Robert R. Lin vill, commanding general of Fort Riley, ordered today that Specialist 4 Emil Schaffer, 30 years old, of Brooklyn, N. Y., be courtmartialed on charges of refusing to obey an order of a superior officer to remove a peace medal from his uni form.

title: Arab Death Sentences Commuted in Israel
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 19The first death sentences against Arab guerrillas were imposed by an Israeli military court in Nablus this morning, but a few hours later the military governor commuted the sen tences to life imprisonment.

title: Radio
description: 1.5:30 P.M., WRVR: Just Music: Glen Carlo Menotti. Amelia Goes to the Ball; Concerto in F; Maria Golovin; To This We've Come; The Unicorn, The Gorgon and the Manticore, Menotti.
