description: WHO would have thought that America's resident theatersso resolutely noncommercial, so artisticallypure  who would have thought that so soon after their development they would be eagerly sup plying Broadway with new, and some times very profitable, material? And who would have thought that Broadway pro ducers, who are inclined to define a stock company as anything 50 yards from Shubert Alley, would be scouring the country's resident theaters for pro ductions they could import to New York?

title: Marine Pleads Not Guilty In Deaths of 16 Vietnamese
description: DANANG, South Vietnam, Aug. 22 (UPI)A young Okla homa marine pleaded not silty today to charges he ordered the killing of five Vjetnamese women and 11 children in the village of Santhane last February.

title: No Improvement
description: The tragic wave of parathion poisonings in the South, mostly of children, raises some extremely pressing questions for the Federal Government: If the use of DDT is to be discouraged or banned altogetheras we emphatically believe it should bedoesn't the United States owe its cotton, tobacco and fruit growers the most authoritative advice on safe substitutes? Doesn't it, in fact, owe them what ever financial aid they may need to make up the difference in cost?

title: Ad Man Weds Gale Sanson
description: WAYNE, Pa:, Aug. 22Miss Martha Gale Sanson, daughter of Mrs. M. DeWitt Sanson, of Bryn Mawr and Henry Bright Sanson of West Hartford, Conn., was married here this afternoon to Alan Lynn Antik, son of Mrs. M. Clark Antik and Alain Ana tole Antik, both of Los An geles.

title: DR. OSCAR GOLDSTEIN
description: Dr. Oscar E. Goldstein, a spe cialist in internal medicine at 150 Boulevard, Passaic, N. J., died yesterday in Memorial Hos pital. His age was 53.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To the Editor:

title: House Plea for P.O.W.'s Set
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP)  Representative Roger H. Zion, Republican of Indiana, said today he will fly to Paris on Monday with an appeal signed by 406 of the 435 House members for more humane treatment of United States prisoners of war. He is sched uled to deliver the letter to the North Vietnamese delegation after a brief talk with the chief United States negotiator at the Paris peace talks, David K. E. Bruce.

title: Bridge
Hawaii Historians Warn Of Looting by Helicopter
description: LIHUE, Kauai, Hawaii, Aug. 22 (AP)Hawaiian historians have called on the state to police commercial helicopter flights into remote areas of the islands to curb the loot ing of ancient temple sites.

title: Two novellas on black themes: under the masks, humanity prevails
description: Is there any laughter, bitter or otherwise, to be found to day? Can a black man in a white country, for example (or a poor white in an affluent society, or a drunkard or junkie in an alien land) see the absurdity behind the dance of life? Most of our literature is, perhaps rightly so, a cele bration of the triumph of trag edy. Yet there is that other dimension, that other level of experience that stems from our common humanity. Some writ ers can tap this source, take the horror of the everyday and temper it with passion and pain. Ronald Fair is one of these. Where most contem porary black writing is pre occupied with blackness, Fair's work speaks to us from the depths of an involvement we all share. Yes, the scream is there  but the laughter of life is first. society, or a drunkard or junkie in an alien land) see the absurdity behind the dance of life? Most of our literature is, perhaps rightly so, a cele bration of the triumph of trag edy. Yet there is that other dimension, that other level of experience that stems from our common humanity. Some writ ers can tap this source, take the horror of the everyday and temper it with passion and pain. Ronald Fair is one of these. Where most contem porary black writing is pre occupied with blackness, Fair's work speaks to us from the depths of an involvement we all share. Yes, the scream is there  but the laughter of life is first.

title: Water: Some of It Is Not Safe To Drink
description: Most Americans take it for granted that water from the household tap is as safe and wholesome as homemade pie. That assumption should no longer be made, according to a nationwide study on the quality and safety of commu nity water supplies released by the Government last week.

title: Mideast 3: A Lebanon Firster Takes Over
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Drown ing out beggars cries and the purr of limousines, the sound of gunfire spread across Beirut last week. It was not triggerhappy Arab commandos, but jubilant Lebanese: Lebanon had just cho sen an improbable new Presi dent for this sybaritic old capital  and thereby given a small but possibly important nudge to the movement of events in the Middle East.

title: Bizarre? Have You Looked Around Lately?
description: STRATFORD, Ont. SPENDING one evening at the world premiere of Slawomir Mrozek's Vatzlav and the following after noon at a mixed bloodandmeringue revival of Shakespeare's rarely revived Cymbeline made it perfectly clear to me  if it hadn't been clear before  why Shakespeare's most bizarre and broken backed plays no longer seem the least bit bizarre or brokenbacked to us. The back of our world has been broken, we have heard the snap, whatever we see as we turn the next corner will in itself be as bizarre as a Bosch or a Swift could wish it. Our contemporary playwrights, eager to project the image, have pressed it, extravagantly and abstractly and with malice aforethought, directly into our faces. Shall Shakespeare be accused of absurdity, then, because, in such a play as Cymbeline, he stretches a lovely girl out beside the headless body of her lover and sees to it that she bathes her face in the neck's blood? It will give her color, the lovely Imogen says bitterly, as she streaks her face scarlet and waits to see what the next horror shall be.

title: Samuel Jay Bush, ExJockey And Trainer, Is Dead at 81
description: Samuel Jay Bush, a former jockey and trainer, died last Monday at Knickerbocker Hosnital. He was 81 years old.

title: The Helpful Americans: In Peru No
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22The Govern ment of Peru has accused two leading American construction companies of fraud and conspiracy in connection with the collapse of an important United States foreignaid venture.

title: 3 WOMEN AHEAD IN GOLF ON 143'S
description: KANSAS CITY, Aug. 22 (AP) Margee Masters joined Kathy Whitworth and Shirley Engle horn in leading the $20,800 Southgate open golf tourna ment today after the second round. Each had a oneunder par 143.

title: Glenn Howard Jr. Weds Mary A. Heller
description: FRANKLIN, Va., Aug. 22Miss Mary Angela Heller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Heller of Severn, N. C., was married here to day to Glenn Willard Howard Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. How ard of Glen Cove, L. I. The ceremony in St..Tude's Ro man Catholic Church was performed by the Rev. Philip Farrell.

title: Lee W. Jones, Teacher, Weds Nancy Stevens
description: GUILFORD, Conn., Aug. 22 Miss Nancy Amsden Stev ens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Woodruff Stev ens of New York and Sachem's Head, was married here this noon to Lee Whittlesey Jones, son of Mr. and Mrs. F. L. Lee Jones of New York. The Rev. Brad ford Locke performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church.

title: The High Price in Lives of Dominican Reform
description: SANTO DOMINGO  At the National University here the students have put up a wall sized display of photographs and newspaper clippings entitled Balaguees educational reform. The photographs are all of dead people, mainly young opposition activists lying in their own blood in the street where they were shot down by police.

title: Sgt. Brown Takes Trophy In Camp Perry Rifle Match
description: CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 22 (AP)Army Sgt. 1/C Myles G. Brown of Honolulu scored 491 of a possible 500 points today to win the national trophy in dividual rifle match.

title: Simpson Is Voted Greatest of Sixties In College Football
description: O. J. Simpson, the piston legged running back who be came a Heisman Trophy win ner and Consensus AllAmerica while at the University of Southern California, has been adjudged college football's greatest player of the nineteen sixties by National Collegiate Sports Services.

title: Anniversaries
description: FIOREMary Ann and Micky. Hearty con gratulations on your Fifth Wedding Anni versary In amide Queens! Love, brother, JIM.

title: Mrs. Court's Strength Adds to Net Skill
description: For the past decade, Mrs. Margaret Court of Australia has demolished opponents in all parts of the world and, in the United States Open championships on Sept. 2 through 13, she will attempt to complete a grand slam. If she adds the United States crown to the Australian, French and English titles she's already won, she'll be the first woman to complete the grand slam since Mau reen Connolly accomplished the feat in 1953.

title: Nixon Asks Western Editors To Foreign Affairs Briefing
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 22 (UPI)  President Nixon has invited some 50 newspaper and broadcast edi tors from 13 Western states to the Western White House on Monday for a briefing on for eign affairs, a spokesman said yesterday.

title: Pilgrim Medals Available to All
description: THE General Society of Mayflower Descend ants has announced that two medals issued to commemorate the 350th anniversary of the Pilgrims departure from England and their landing in America would be made available to collectors. The original plan of the society, according to Dr. Lee D. Van Antwerp, governor general of the or ganization, was to issue the commemoratives only for au thenticated Mayflower de Scendants. The society was founded in the 19th century and now has a membership of almost 14,000.

title: America: The Beautiful?
description: TIN cans, telephone wires and roadside service stations are inescapable parts of the contempo rary American landscape and many younger photographers, TIN cans, telephone wires and roadside service stations are inescapable parts of the contempo rary American landscape and many younger photographers, inspired, perhaps, by the ex ample of Robert Frank, do not shrink from this fact. There still exists, however, (and probably always will) school of romantic landscap ists whose evocations of pic turesque America are almost as remote from everyday re ality as Disneyland or the Williamsburg Restoration.

title: Was the trouble with Johnson the trouble with the job?; The Twilight of the Presidency; The President Steps Down
description: Why did Lyndon Johnson, an ob viously shrewd politician, end up a political failure? We have to thank George Reedy, who worked with him as press secretary and special as sistant before the heady climb and hapless fall, for posing the question as a vital issue of American govern ment and no longer just a biographi cal curiosity.

title: The Law Professor Behind
description: WASHINGTON, D. C.

title: CITY OPERA OPENS. SEASON ON SEPT. 9
description: The New York City Opera will open a 10week season at the New York State Theater on Sept. 9 with Boito's Mefisto fele. Norman Treigle will sing the title role and Carol Neblett will appear in the dual roles of Margherita and Elena, Beverly Evans as Marta and Nicholas di Virgilio as Faust. The con ductor will be Julius Rudel, general director of the company.

title: Job Turnover Is Problem on Jersey Shore
description: OCEAN CITY, N. J., Aug. 22 Last June, Jane MacMillan of Suffern, N. Y., was a $1.50 anhour chambermaid for a motel here.

title: The Cherry Tree gets its revenge
description: This is what Washington scholars would call a little hatchet job.  General Washington's coauthor ad mits as much. Now the Cherry Tree has had its revenge. Not only has Pfc. (Ret.) Kitman cut the Father of His Country down to size, he has undercut him: Washington's quality of mind compares favorably to the average big city banker of today. Just where this leaves you and the General depends upon how you feel about your banker. Kitman leaves little to chance however, for com parisons between the first General and the Eisenhower crowd are fre quent, irreverent, and also irrelevant.

title: UPSTATE SCHOOLS STUDY PROBLEMS
description: WHITE PLAINS. Aug. 22A regional educational survey designed to teach local school systems new ways of solving problems is being undertaken in Westchester and Putnam Coun ties.

title: Outback CloseUp And Billabongs Too
description: ADELAIDE, Australia  The Outback, Australia's sparsely settled inland re gion, is usually described as a thousand miles from nowhere. But people here are discovering that wild isolation can be found in areas fairly close to cities.

title: The Cool and the Chutzpah
description: LONDON

title: Cougar II Wins on Coast; Shoemaker Blanked Again
description: DEL MAR, Calif., Aug. 22 (AP)Cougar II held off fa vored Quicken Tree to win the $21,800 Cabrillo Handicap at Del Mar Turf Club today as Bill Shoemaker was blanked for the second consecutive day.

title: The Insect Hordes
description: By late August there is little doubt who possesses the earth. It is the insects, the chitinclad hordes. All the hot afternoon and well into the night they hum, buzz, rasp, fiddle, making the late summer air quiver.

title: Pop
description: STAGE FRIGHT: The Band (Capitol SW425). Like the Grateful Dead, the five piece group that is called, somewhat laconically, The Band, plays music that is not so much heard as experi enced. What one must bring to it is a frame of minda receptivitythat is colored by a knowledge of the group's long association with Bob Dylan, and a sympathy for the milieu of dusty trail ways and open fields that dominates the songs of com poser Robbie Robertson.

title: M.I.T. Tuition Raised $150
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 22 (AP)Massachusetts Institute of Technology will increase its tuition from $2,500 to $2,650 beginning with the summer ses sion of 1971. The rise was at tributed to inflation.

title: Koreans Assail Senate Action
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 22 South Korean officials re acted sharply to the United States Senate's call for a drastic cut in special allowances paid by the United States to South Korean and Thai troops in Vietnam.

title: PEACE GROUPS LOSE P.O.W. EXHIBIT PLEA
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) A judge has turned back, mo mentarily, an appeal by peace groups for equal space in the Capitol crypt next to a huge prisonerofwar display donated by a Texas millionaire.

title: MAYE FORESEES AID FOR FIREMEN
description: The president of the city's Uniformed Fire Fighters Asso ciation has predicted the in stitution of a steppedup na tional drive for improyed work ing conditions for firemen and for more sophisticated research on fire prevention.

title: Soviet Rocket Test Series Reported Ended in Pacific
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 22 (AP)The Soviet Union has completed a monthlong series of rocket weapons tests in the Pacific Ocean, several hundred miles off Kamchatka Peninsula, Tass, the, official press agency, an nounced today.

title: L.I. BENEFIT AIDS BLACKS IN SOUTH
description: WATER MILL, L. I., Aug. 22  Four hundred persons at tended a benefit here today for the Southern Elections Fund, an organization formed to help black candidates run lowbudget campaigns in small towns across the South.

title: ALBANIA EXTENDS DIPLOMATIC TIES
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 22 (UPI)The cocoon of isola tion surrounding Albania ap pears to be breaking.

title: Mary Crowley Wed To John T. Clark Jr.
description: NEEDHAM, Mass., Aug. 22 Lieut. Mary Ellen Crowley, U. S. N., daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Crowley of Needham Heights, was mar ried in St. Bartholemew's Roman Catholic Church here this afternoon to John T. Clark Jr., a former Marine lientenant who plans to at tend New York Law School.

title: ARMY HEARING SET IN BRIBERY CHARGE
description: HUNTSVILLE, Ma., Aug. 22 (UPI)A pretrial hearing into the courtmartial of M. Sgt. William A. Higdon, charged with irregularities in the opera tion of a servicemen's club in Vietnam, will be held tomorrow at the Redstone Arsenal.

title: WOMEN SURVEYED ON EQUALITY VIEW
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 22 According to a recent Gallup Poll, most American women hrlieve that they are treated as fairly as men. The survey, which focused on the attitudes of American women toward their role in life, interest in working and job discrimination, indicated that twothirds of American women believe that they get as good a break in the world today as men do.

title: Ozawa: I Do Not Like Interviews
description: LENOX, MASS.

title: 13 Killed in Egyptian Train
description: CAIRO, Aug 22 (Reuters) Thirteen persons including two children were killed and 54 in jured today wnen a car of an AswantoCairo express train overturned in Tamouh, a vil lage south of here, the Middle East News Agency reported.

title: Hockey Players Seeking More Ice
description: The most secretive of all sportsprofes sional hockeyis finally feeling the pres sure of exposure and that most dreaded of all individuals, the player's lawyer.

title: LAW AND ORDER, PEKING STYLE
description: (Jan. 20): Six prisoners were found guilty this week at a People's Court of political crimes, courterrevolution ary plotting against the masses and the state, and conspiring with the archrenegade, arch revisionist, ugly scab and traitor Liu Shaochi. They were found guilty of corruption, bribery and embezzle ment. After a public hearing of evidence, all pleaded guilty andamid shouts of Long Live Chairman Mao!'they were executed on the spot.

title: Long Islander Makes His Land a Neighborhood Showcase
description: MELVILLE, L. I. With in genuity, knowhow, a strong back and some ready cash, a homeowner in the Hunting ton Hills luxury housing de velopment here has managed to turn a relatively small piece of property into a neighborhood showcase.

title: Angela Davis: The Making Of a Radical
description: LOS ANGELES  Last fall, the photographs of Angela Da vis showed a tall black girl in a mod minidress lecturing to a philosophy class. In June, the newspapers pictured her dressed in denim and marching in a pick et line with a sign that said, Save the Soledad Brothers from Legal Lynching.

title: Law
description: First came the riots, then came the recriminations. There they all were, hour af ter hour: the prisoners, the guards, the commissioner, the politicians, each grasping at the microphone in the State Office Building, each eager to tell how bad it is to live in the New York jail known as the Tombs.

title: Fiber Producers Ready For HomeSewing Boom
description: Producers of manmade fi bers are jumping aboard the homesewing band wagon and the ride will cost them millions of dollars. The lead ing companies in the field have plans for extensive pro motion campaigns starting this fall and extending through next spring.

title: Business Index Falls in Week
description: The New York Times Weekly Index of Business Activity fell to 367.5 from 371.9 a week earlier. A year ago it was 363.1.

title: Pro Football on Television
description: The following National and American Conference games will be televised in New York. The network is determined by the visiting team: American Conference visiting team, Channel 4; National Conference visiting team, Channel 2. All Monday night games will be broadcast on Channel 7.

title: LARSEN IS WINNER IN U.S. CHESS OPEN
description: BOSTON, Aug. 22  Grand master Bent Larsen of Denmark, recent winner of the Canadian open, added another United States Open Chess Champion ship to his trophies last night as he defeated Norman Wein stein of Cambridge, Mass.; in the 12th and final round of the Swisssystem event at the Parker House here.

title: Prices for Wool Expected to Dip
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP)Shorn wool prices paid to growers this year prob ably will average moderate ly below the 1969 average of 41.8 cents a pound, ac cording to Agriculture De partment economists.

title: HUME TAKES FIRST IN SHIELDS CLASS
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 22 Thomas Hume won his eighth Shields Class race of the season today with Pantomime on Long Island Sound. He scored in the 31st championship regatta for Yacht Racing Association fleets of the Connecticut area based eastofRye, conducted by the Indian Harbor yacht club.

title: In the Mailbox
description: To the Editor:

title: 55,246 See Bench Blast Big Double With 2 Out
description: The Cincinnati Reds showed 55,246 persons in Shea Stadium and a national television audi ence what all the fuss was about yesterday when they scored two runs with two outs in the ninth inning and toppled the New York Mets, 32.

title: Stone Mountain On Sept. 19
description: WE'RE one nation now, despite some differences of opinion on various matters. However, more than a century ago the Washington Government under Abraham Lincoln, was fighting to overcome what it considered a rebellion of its southern states, which con sidered their withdrawal from the United States as a matter of state's rights. That internicine struggle, between the United States of America and the Confederate States America, ended after four bloody years in a reunification. On Sept. 19, to reflect Federal forgiveness, the United States will issue a stamp bearing the figures of three leaders of the Confederacy: Jefferson Davis, its president, and Robert E. Lee and Thom as J. Stonewall Jackson, two of its military heroes.

title: Brazil Proposes Subsidized Savings Plan
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 22President Emilio G. Medici has announced a plan designed to allow Brazilian workers to share in the benefits of the nation's expanding economy.

title: Lawrence, With Sonata II, Gains Star Class Honors
description: SEA CLIFF, L. I., Aug. 22Andrew Lawrence's Sonata II won Star Class honors today in the Hempstead Harbor compe tition, where 38 boats sailed with the Sea Cliff Yacht Club.

title: Fidelity Fund Case Hands Pomerantz a Setback
description: Abraham L. Pomerantz, the fabulously successful New York lawyer who has spent more than 35 years repre senting stockholders in suits against big business, suf fered a stinging reversal last week in a major battle with the mutualfund industry.

title: New Look for Welfare
description: President Nixon's family assistance plan inevitably rests on certain imponderables. It is designed to put a financial floor under lowincome families, including those who now work but receive inadequate wages, and to do so without destroying their incentive to get off welfare and become fully selfsupporting.

title: Criminals At Large
description: The appearance of a new Negro sleuth on the fictional scene invites comparison with John Ball's Virgil Tibbs. The title character in Ernest Tidy man's SHAFT (Macmillan, $4.50) is also blackbut his color and his protest are ob scured in a bloodandsex bath. Shaft (a private eye) merges facelessly with the bad guys. Somehow, he sells his services to Knocks Persons, the black man who runs Harlem's drug racket. Knocks has lost his daughter. Shaft tracks her downI'm not sure the details of her kidnapping make sense but the name of this book is violence for its own sake.

title: Attack on Nixon
description: When N.A.A.C.P. board chair man Bishop Stephen G. Spotts wood attacked the Nixon Admin istration as antiNegro last June, Whitney M. Young Jr., executive director of the Na tional Urban League, demurred. He said, I don't think there's been a conscious or deliberate policy of hating black people. And, he added, he might even consider a job offer from the President.

title: Namath and Atkinson Take a Friendly Ride
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 23When a stranger offered sev eral Jet's players a short ride in his car from their motel rooms to the team bus during today's noontime downpour, two who accepted were Joe Namath and Al Atkinson, the team's philosophical rivals.

title: Goodell Plans a Hearing On L.I.'s Unemployment
description: Senator Charles E. Goodeli announced yesterday that he would hold a hearing Aug. 31 to focus attention on the need for Federal action to increase employment on Long Island.

title: Michigan's Democrats Urge Amnesty to Draft Evaders
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 23 (UPI)Michigan Democrats endorsed today the concept of granting amnesty to all  per sons who have dodged the draft by either going to jail or leaving the country. The party's state convention passed the resolution less than 12 hours after it had passed another one calling for an immediate cease fire in Indochina and removal of all American forces by Christmas.

title: Foul Weather Curtails Practice
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 23 (UPI)Gusty winds and day long rain hampered practice sailing by France and Heritage, both of whom need a victory in tomorrow's America's Cup trials.

title: French Newsman Freed
description: PARIS, Aug. 23 Alain Cle ment, a French television tech nician, arrived here today tired and emaciated after a month and a half of captivity in Cam bodia.

title: Daniel &
description: Daniel & Charles, an agency with billings last year of about $29 million, scored an increase of about 25 per cent on Friday when it acquired Ban deotiorants.

title: KEY ISSUES FACING CONVENTION BODY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23The men and women who, among other things, organize conven tions will have their own con vention here this week, and there will be a somewhat new slant.

title: LUTHERANS DECLINE BY 16,058 IN THE U.S.
description: The Lutheran Church, the third largest Protestant de nomination in the United States, announced yesterday that it lost 16,058 members during 1969.

title: CLEMENTE PACES 23HIT ASSAULT
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 23 (AP) Roberto Clemente smacked three singles, a double and home run for his second straight fivehit spree as the Pittsburgh Pirates unleashed a 23hit bar rage today and trounced the Los Angeles Dodgers, 110, be hind Steve Blass's fourhitter.

title: SPURS, LANCERS REMAIN IN RACE
description: The Northern Division title of the North American Soccer League will not be decided until next Sunday, the last day of the regular season, as both con tenders, the Kansas City Spurs and the Rochester Lancers, failed to win in yesterday's games. The Spurs bowed to the St. Louis Stars, 21, while the Lancers tied the Washington Darts. 22.

title: TWINS TROUNCED BY SENATORS, 111
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 23 (AP)  Frank Howard and Del Unser hit threerun homers and Dick Bosman hurled a six hitter as the Washington Sena tors routed the Minnesota Twins. 111. today.

title: Personal Finance: Group Insurance
description: Insurance on cars and homes is increasingly difficult to buy in many areas, but more than 2,500 employes of the University of Pennsyl vaniafrom janitors and sec retaries to nurses and pro fessors are not only getting all the coverage they want on the payroll deduction plan but are also receiving an average 15 per cent group discount in the bargain.

title: GEORGE C. BUZBY
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23 George Carroll Buzby, chair man and chief executive of ficer of the Chilton Company, a businessmagazine and book publishing concern, died yes terday at his home. He was 73 years old.

title: Women's Drive Grows in Europe
description: LONDON, Aug. 23The rest lessly growing women's libera tion movement in Europe, which is attracting working class mothers and young radi cals, has stirred trade unions and governments in its drive for equal pay, equal jobs and equal rights.

title: Hulme Wins 3d CanAm Race in Row at MidOhio With Record 95.18 M.P.H.
description: MANSFIELD, Ohio, Aug. 23 (AP)Denis Hulme, leading all the way, scored his third straight victory in the 1970 CanAm series today by easily winning the Buckeye CanAm road race over the MidOhio Sports Car course near here.

title: Drag Racing Postponed
description: CENTER MORICHES, L. J., Aug. 23Rain forced post ponement today of the finals of the American Hot Rod Asso ciation nationals at National Speedway until next Sunday beginning at 2 P.M. Don Nicholson of Georgia broke the AH.R.A. super stock record in a qualifying run last night with an elapsed time of 9.78 seconds in a quartermile run.

title: Week's Votes in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23Following are the votes of dele gations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on thel major rollcalls in Congress dur ing the week ended Aug. 22.HR 17123. Military Procure ment Authorization, the fiscal year 1971. Proxmire (D., Wis.) amendment requiring that new weapons systems be thorough IV tested prior to their produc tion. Rejected 22 to 43: R., 822; D., 1421, Aug. 17, 1970. The President did not take a position on the amendment.

title: Fire at Poconos Resort
description: LAKE HARMONY, Pa., Aug. 23 (UPI)Fire destroyed the main building at Split Rock. Lodge in the Pocono Moun tains today and routed 200 guests. Leo Turley, innkeeper, said the resort would continue operations with 70 cottages un touched by the fire.

title: Union Miniere Plans Congo Comeback
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 23Belgi um's Union Minire Company, whose assets were nationalized by the Congolese Government in December, 1966, is preparing a comeback in the Congo.

title: Evelyn Tkach, Rockford Alumna, Is Married to Andrew S. Novins
description: Miss Evelyn Tkach and Andrew S. Novins were mar ried here yesterday afternoon at Temple Shaaray Tefila. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Phillip Schechter.

title: Walinsky Asks Lefkowitz For Series of TV Debates
description: Adam Walinsky, the Demo cratic candidate for Attorney General, yesterday challenged Louis J. Lefkowitz, the incum bent, tot a series of 10 televi sion debates.

title: U.S. Denies Policy Shift
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 23 (UPI)The White House said today that Vice President Ag new's remarks linking United States interests in Asia to the stability of the Cambodian Gov ernment represented no change in the Nixon Administration's policy.

title: Hall, Spitz and Kinsella Break World Marks as A.A. U. Title Swimming Ends
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 23The Amateur Athletic Union's national outdoor swimming championships ended tonight with some of the fastest and closest races ever. Almost inci dentally, John Kinsella, Mark Spitz and Gary Hall broke world records.

title: Agnew Reaches Seoul
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Mon day, Aug. 24 (Reuters)Vice President Agnew arrived here today.

title: Scarlett Leas's Debut Ball Is Gone With the Wind
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 23They came as Southern belles and Confederate Len erals, as Topsies and Evas and the girls of the Atlanta bordello& There was a Ku Klux Klansman in a perman entpress sheet. There were any number of wounded soldiers in inkspattered bandages, an occasional Union Officer and a few who seemed vaguely Napoleonic. These who hadn't been able to Concoct costumes came as thernserives and announced that they were poor white trash.

title: Moore's Resolute Triumphs In Rainy Cow Bay Regatta
Laver Conquers Emerson In Colonial Tennis Final
description: FORT WORTH, Aug. 23 (AP) Rod Laver overpowered his Australian countryman, Roy Emerson, 63, 75, today to re tain his title in the Colonial national invitation tennis tour nament.

title: GOLDBERG ASSAILS DECISION ON PLANT
description: Arthur J. Goldberg, the DemocraticLiberal candidate for Governor, attacked yester day, Mayor Lindsay's approval of an addition to an electric power plant in Astoria, Queens, and said he would seek to rescind approval if elected Governor.

title: England Leads Canada, 20, In Stevens Cup Senior Net
description: England took a 20 lead over Canada in Stevens Cup senior tennis competition yesterday at the River Club. The matches were moved indoors when heavy rains made the West Side Tennis Club courts in Forest Hills, Queens, unplay able.

title: Sensitive, SelfEffacing Diplomat
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y.Seldom has any man so nat urally and totally embodied the image of the discreet, selfeffacing, almost invisible diplomat as Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, under whose auspices longawaited negotiations on the Middle East are expect ed to open soon. Some time ago a report er was telling Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, the Under Secre tary General of the United Na tions, that Dr. Jarring had given him no more than a curt No comment to a question.

title: A Sunken Restaurant
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 23 (AP)  From now on, only scuba divers and fish will pat ronize the Riverboat Restau rant, formerly Louisville's only floating diner. The 43yearold converted steamboat lies 50 feet below the surface of the Ohio River a short distance up stream. She sank this month for the second time as she was being towed for repairs to a shipyard at Jeffersonville, Ind. The first submersion came about three months ago after vandals apparently shot the hull full of holes.

title: Balding's 282 Score Wins Canadian P.G.A. by Stroke
description: BRANTFORD, Ontario, Aug. 23 (Canadian Press)Al Bald ing of Toronto won the $25,000 Canadian Professional Golfers Association championship to day, carding a par 72 over the final 18 holes for a 282 total and a onestroke victory over Gary Bowerman, also of Toron to.

title: NEGRO CATHOLICS SAY CHURCH FAILS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23The first National Convention of Black Lay Catholics concluded this afternoon after adopting statement accusing the church of failing to respond to the needs of blacks.

title: EXCHANGE'S FUND SPURS QUESTIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23Figures that the New York Stock Exchange itself has pro vided to Congress are raising serious questions here about the adequacy of the exchange's special trust fund to insure cus tomers of all brokerage houses that are failing against losses.

title: CHASE AND CITY BANK PLAN UNITS ON COAST
description: The Federal Reserve Board has approved applications of New York City's two largest banksThe First National City Bank and the Chase Manhattan Bank  to open international banking subsidiaries in Los Angeles, the two institutions announced.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Special Committee on Co lonialism, Subcommittee on Pacific Ocean Territories3 P.M.

title: American Asks Women In Asia to Seize Power
description: TOKYO, Aug. 23 (AP)A leader in the United States women's liberation movement advised all women in Asia to day to gather force and seize power.

title: SHULA IS ERASING DOLPHINS'
description: Don Shula, the Miami Dol phins football coach, is glad he heeded the call to come on down.

title: American Reporter Freed in Cambodia
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Aug. 23Communist forces in Cam bodia today released Robert S. Anson, a Time magazine re porter, after having held him in the countryside since his capture Aug. 3.

title: Soviet Asks Seabed Arms Curb In Surprise Move at U.N. Parley.
description: GENEVA, Aug. 23The So viet Union has submitted a sur prise proposal to the United Nations Committee on the Peaceful Uses of the Seabed un der which all military uses of the seabed outside national jurisdiction would be prohibited.

title: Southern Metropolitan Areas Face Conflicts Over School Integration
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 23During the next three weeks, in a showdown with the Federal Government and the courts, 543 school districts in 11 states of the South are scheduled to desegregate fully for the first time. The will of the white Southerner to accept orderly social change will be tested as never before, and trouble is ex pected in several places.

title: Westfield's Bulldog Judged Best at Perkiomen Valley
description: GILBERTVILLE, Pa.  A 2 yearold bulldog, Ch. Westfield Flying Colors, was judged best in show over 910 other dogs today at the 22d annual Perkio men Valley Kennel Club event.

title: U.N. POLICE FORCE IN MIDEAST ASKED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23Senator J. W. Fulbright sug gested today that the United Nations might create an inter national police force to enforce a negotiated settlement of the ArabIsraeli conflict.

title: Black Soldier's Burial Is Held Up in Florida
description: FORT PIERCE, Fla., Aug. 23 (AP)A soldier killed in Vietnam, who was rejected by a cemetery because he was black, was given military and religious honors at an armory today and then carried to a mortuary.

title: KOBAYASHI RETAINS WORLD BOXING TITLE
description: TOKYO, Aug. 23 (UPI)Hiroshi Kobayashi of Japan, world junior lightweight cham pion, retained his World Boxing Association title tonight by scoring a unanimous 15round decision over Antonio Amaya of Panama.

title: WILLIAM CARLSON
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 23 William Carlson, president of the Carlson Foundation, which has contributed to universities, hospitals and other institutions here, died today at his home. He was 84 years old.

title: Pirates Win in 16th, 21
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 23 (UPI) Jerry May singled off Bill Sudakis's glove at third base to drive in Roberto Clemente from second base with two out in the top of the 16th inning Saturday night to give the Pittsburgh Pirates a 21 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: RAIN POSTPONES AVCO GOLF A DAY
description: SUTTON, Mass., Aug. 23Heavy rains forced postpone ment today of the fourth round of the $160,000 Avco Golf Classic. The Pleasant Valley Country Club course was de clared unplayable at 1:45 P.M., after several greens were in undated from the steady down pour.

title: Newport Puzzled Over France's Use of 2d Platoon
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 23 Major yachting developments are expected here tomorrow when the America's Cup trials resume on two fronts.

title: Rain Floods Many City Streets but Brings Relief from Heat
description: The first big rainstorm of August swept over the city, yesterday, leaving streets and highways awash in lowlying areas but bringing relief from the heat and nourishment to parched lawns and trees.

title: Swedish Rock Festivals Fnd
description: STOCKHOLM, Aug. 23 (AP)Two rival rock festivals wound up four days of music, love and peace today as the police re ported that a few of the several thousand youths present had been arrested but that there had been no problems with drugs or alcohol.

title: U.S. to Close Air Base
description: SAIGON, Aug. 23 (AP)In formed sources said today that the United States Air Force was closing a major fighter bomber base in South Vietnam withdrawing nearly 100 super sonic jets, and was planning to shut down another important base in Thailand.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Nixon's Strategy for Reaching the Public Largely Bypasses Washington Press Corps.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23The Nixon administration has come up with a new strategy for get ting its policies across to the American public: reaching out to metropolitan newspaper edi tors and regional television ex ecutives throughout the land.

title: Article 3  No Title
FREE GUERRILLAS, HUSSEIN IS URGED
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 23A leftwing Arab commando or ganization, As Saiqah, has de manded that King Hussein's Government release eight of its members who it said were im prisoned here.

title: Astoria Compromise
description: As an interim answer to a difficult problem requir ing immediate resolution, Mayor Lindsay's compro mise decision on the proposed generating plant in As toria has much to recommend it. Consolidated Edison has won permission to go ahead and build what it re gards as urgently needed capacity to meet this com munity's electricity needs. But those who opposed the project because of understandable fear of additional pollution can console themselves that the expansion will be only half that originally reauested.

title: Fair Access to the Air
description: The Federal Communications Commission's land mark interpretation of the fairness doctrineholding that it can be applied even to the President of the United States on such an overriding issue of contro versy as the Vietnam waris a logical and mature extension of a principle that goes to the heart licensed broadcasting in this country.

title: Dominican Policeman Killed
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Domini can Republic, Aug. 23 (UPI)A police captain was shot to death by three youths last night in Santiago de los Caballeros, the nation's second largest city, some 110 miles from Santo Domingo.

title: Hanoi's Negotiator Reported En Route To Talks in Paris
description: TOKYO, Aug. 23 (UPI) Xuan Thuy, North Vietnam's chief delegate to the Vietnam peace talks, left Hanoi last Wednesday for Paris, Hanoi's Vietnam News Agency said to day in a broadcast monitored here.

title: Bridge
description: Two decades ago almost all of America's topranked players, and the vast major ity of expert players in other parts of the world, were satisfied with natural bidding methods and a minimum of conventions. Now the picture has changed completely: most of the contenders for world championship titles play com plex methods that require careful study by their oppo nents.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Israeli Cabinet yesterday named For eign Minister Abba Eban chief delegate to the proposed IsraeliArab talks but desig nated Yosef Tekoah, the Israeli representa tive to the United Nations, as alternate delegate in a compromise with the Arab nations that have named their United Na tions delegates as negotiators. Mr. Tekoah is expected to represent Israel in the opening of the talks. [Page 1, Column 8.1

title: Brooklyn Man Dies in Fire
description: Roman Feduniak, 23 years old, of 2190 East Third Street, in the Sheepshead Bay area of Brooklyn, died yesterday as fire swept his home. Firemen found Mr. Feduniak in the second floor bathroom of the twostory house. He was dead on arrival at Coney Island Hospital, where his wife, Alba, 18, who is preg nant, was treated for shock.

title: 4 Elderly Tenants Saved By Firemen in the Bronx
description: A 195pound, offduty fire man carried a 235pound, 85yearold crippled man down a ladder from the third floor of a burning Bronx apartment building early yesterday while other elderly tenants in the same apartment were guided to safety by another fireman.

title: Taiwan Team Arrives in U.S. for Little League Series
Coast Workers Vote Strike At 27 Vegetable Ranches,
description: SALINAS, Calif., Aug. 23 (AP)Some 3,000 members of Cesar Chavez's United Farm Workers Organizing Committee voted today to strike at least 27 vegetable ranches tomorrow in a jurisdictional dispute in the fertile Salinas Valley.

title: Vatican Halts Convent Payments For Recruiting of Girls in India
description: ROME, Aug. 23A system that enabled Roman Catholic convents to pay high fees to bring poor and often unquali fied peasant girls from the Indian state of Kerala to under staffed institutions in Europe has been suspended, the Vatican said late tonight. The Vatican denied published charges that many such girls had been mal treated and forced to do menial work after their arrival.

title: Oman to Seek Guerrillas'
description: MUSCAT, Oman, Aug. 19Sultan Qabus bin Said of Oman said today that he would offer an amnesty to the guerrillas in the southern province of Dhofar and let bygones be bygones in hopes of ending their war fare

title: TARKENTON FLIPS 3 SCORING PASSES
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 23The New York Giants staggered to a 4point victory over the Jets in the Yale Bowl today, win ning, 2824. A threetouchdown rally in the final period was not enough for the Jets to overcome their early errors, which helped the Giants to a 280 lead after only 15 minutes 47 seconds of play.

title: Sammy Davis Hospitalized
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Aug. 23Sammy Davis Jr. is being treated at Sunrise Hospital here for pneumonia and exhaustion. The entertainer was described as acutely ill last night and was receiving oxygen, but a hospital spokesman said today that he should be released in 4 or 5 days. He became ill while making a television film at Lake Mead.

title: Greenport Fire Destroys A FishProcessing Plant
description: GREENPORT, L. I., Aug. 23Fire of undetermined origin that lasted throughout the night de stroyed a fish pro cessing plant here. There was no official esti mate of damage, but Police Chief Robert Walden predicted that the loss would run into hundreds of thousands of dol lars.

title: Cards Top Padres, 87
Booby Trap on a Water Tap Kills Israeli Arab at Frontier
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 23A booby trap on a water tap killed an Israeli Arab this morning. The man, a fortyfiveyearold father of nine, had been work ing in Dovev, an Israeli village some 150 yards from the Leba nese border.

title: Another Gabor Robbery
description: A burglar took $500 worth of costume jewelry from a Madison Avenue shop owned by the mother of actress Zsa Zsa Gabor yesterday but was seized shortly afterward by two patrolmen, the police re ported. The shop, belonging to Jolie Gabor, was allegedly broken into by John Colon, 50 years old, who was charged with burglary and possession of burglary tools. Last week Zsa Zsa Gabor was robbed by two gunmen in the Waldorf Towers of jewelry estimated to be worth $625,000.

title: ISRAELIS APPOINT EBAN AS DELEGATE TO MIDEAST TALKS
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 23Is rael's Cabinet today named For eign Minister Abba ban as this country's chief delegate to proposed peace talks on the Middle East. Yosef Tekoah, the nation's representative at the United Nations, was named al ternate delegate.

title: Fireman Grabs Suspect In West Side Mugging
description: A fireman who is a former state weightlifting champion ran from his West Side fire house Saturday night and captured a 6foot4inch, 240 pound mugging suspect.

title: Soviet Reported to Move Writer to Stricter Prison
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 23 (Reuters) Aleksander Ginzburg, a dis sident intellectual sentenced in 1968 for antiSoviet activities, has been moved from a labor camp to the apparently stricter conditions of a prison, it was learned here today.

title: In Summer, Cape May Forgets Its Worries
description: CAPE MAY, N. J., Aug. 23 We have a way of saving our controversies and differ ences for the off season, ob serves Alec Lyle, Cape May's chronicler and sageinresi dence. We talk them out in the winter. It shortens the wait for spring. A lepre chaun of a man, Mr. Lyle says he was brought here 75 years ago, a list less and feeble infant, hardly enough to make a dent in the pillow I was ?? on

title: A Correction
description: Performances at the two week New York Dance Festival, which opens Wednesday in Cen tral Park's Delacorte Theater, will begin at 8 P.M. The time was given incorrectly in the Dance Programs column in yesterday's New York Times. Tickets will be distributed at the Delacorte Theater at 6:15 the evening of each perform ance.

title: Black Panthers in Jordan
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 23 (AP)A Black Panther delega tion from the United States ar rived here today and pledged support of the Arab guerrillas in their stand against the Amer icansponsored ceasefire in the Middle East. The Black Pan thers support the Palestinian people in their fight to liberate their homeland, one member of the group who acted as spokesman said. It is a just struggle and peace will not be achieved until the Zionist entity is removed.

title: Homosexuals in Revolt
description: Steve Gerrie wears a wekl trimmed mustache, works as an accountant in a Wall Street brokerage and lives with his lover in a neat but threadbare apartment in the West Village here. His room mate, Jack Waluska, is a former welfare case worker now studying for a master's degree in sociology.

title: Dog Days for Economists
description: The Government's latest report on the high cost living shows things drifting as they have been for the last three months. Inflation is still cutting the value of the dollar at the rate of roughly a nickel a year. But, when seasonal factors are taken into account, the upsurge in prices may be easing a trifle.

title: TV: A Promising Life Caught in the Coils of Heroin
description: The show known as Like It Is, a production of WABC TV, had an unusual concept yesterday afternoon, some thing that came within min utes of personalizing the agonies of the drug scene with exceptional force. Un fortunately, it then veered from its goal and diluted what started out as a com passionate tribute to one of the station's assistant pro ducers.

title: Yanks Post 75 Victory After John of White Sox Wins, 20, on FourHitter
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 23  Less than three weeks ago, after he had won a not particularly well pitched game against Cleveland, Fritz Peterson of the Yankees said: At least I've gotten my luck back. It's better for me to be lucky than to be good.

title: Phillips Takes 10Mile Crown As National Bicycle Meet Ends
description: Bobby Phillips of Baltimore capped the fourday national amateur bicycle championships which ended yesterday, with a victory in the 10mile event on the rainslicked Kissena track in Flushing, Queens.

title: Tourism Rises in Spain
description: MADRID, Aug. 23 (AP)About 12.2 million tourists visited Spain during the first seven months of this yeara 9.1 per cent increase, Tourism Minister Alfredo Sanchez Bella said.

title: Editor Weds Miss Simon
description: Miss Margaret Esme Simon, daughter of Dr. Carol T. Simon of New York and George M. Simon of Albany, was married here yesterday to Brian Leslie Berger, son of Dr. and. Mrs. Harold Berger of Elizabeth, N. J.

title: G.E. Reports First Profit For Computer Business
description: The General Electric comput er components business that Honeywell, Inc., proposes to ac quire, last year operated in the black for the first time since the General Electric Company entered the computer field early in the nineteen sixties.

title: Proposals Anger Savings and Loan Industry
description: The $170billion savings and loan industry, which is the largest single supplier of funds for home mortgages, is facing its most basic structural re form in more than a generation and it is not at all happy about the prospect.

title: Body of Slain Executive Found in His L. I. Office
description: FARMINGDALE, L.I., Aug. 23  The police are investigat ing the slaying of an electron ics company executive who was found dead at his office desk here last night by his wife.

title: Shots at State Police Office Injure a Delaware Trooper
description: ODESSA, Del., Aug. 23 (UPI) An offduty Delaware trooper was wounded early today by shotgun blast fired through the closed front door of the State Police office here.

title: A Pilot Used to Danger Lands Jet Safely Here
description: El Al Flight Capt., Oded Abarbanell, flying the same Boeing 707 in which he was hijacked to Algeria two years ago, had another close call early today, landing at Ken nedy International Airport on two badly worn nosegear tires.

title: Czech Family Flees to Italy
description: GORIZIA, Italy, Aug. 23 (UPI) A Czechoslovak family of six crossed the Yugoslav Italian border last night and asked for political asylum in Italy, the police said today.

title: Chess:
HUNTER TITLE WON BY WINSOMORE
description: SPARTA, N. J., Aug. 23Winsomore captured his fourth championship in 10 starts in his first year in the ring when he won the regular working hunter title today at the Home stead Stables horse show.

title: Proposed Ford Factory Becomes Issue in French ByElection Involving ChabanDelmas
description: PARIS, Aug. 23The Ford Motor Company has become in volved in French politics as the result of an announcement yes terday by the Mayor's office in Bordeaux that the American concern had bought land in the area to build a factory.

title: Sports of the Times
description: Mickey Mantle, last seen endorsing men's cologne on television, returns to baseball next week as a Yankee coach. For some people there must be a kind of reassur ance in that: Mantle back in pinstripes, like Joe Louis busted and strung out and in need of charity benefits, Jack Dempsey sitting eternally in the front window of his Broadway restaurant are sports heroes who never truly succeeded outside the arena. There should be no shame this, nor any pride, either, yet the generation's two most controversial athletes, Joe Namath and Muhammad Ali, are attacked or defended precisely because each perceives that his value to himself depends on climbing out of the pit and making a life before all the juice is wrung out him. Namath, in recent weeks, has been threatening retire. He said he does not want to play football anymore, and even after he rejoined the Jets last week he said he doubted if he could play. Ali, exiled from the ring for more than three years now, appears closer than ever to fight after court rulings in favor of conscientious objection and of his suit for a boxing license in this state.

title: Lindsay's Endorsement
description: A year Mayor Lindsay, rejected by his own party, was fighting for political survival in the mayoral election.

title: Taiwan Moving to Preserve Endangered Wildlife
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Aug. 23Spurred by a forester, the Gov ernment is moving to preserve Taiwan's endangered wildlife. The Cabinet recently approved a list of 20 species to be pro tected from hunting and began considering a second group of 27.

title: TERRIER NAMED BEST IN BARRINGTON SHOW
description: GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., Aug. 23Jane Esther Hender son's 4yearold West High land white terrier, Ch. DeGo Hubert, topped the 1,165dug field at today's Great Barring ton Kennel Club show at the Butternut Basin.

title: FUTURE BRIGHTER FOR THEOFILEDES
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 23Harry Theofiledes, the shortest Jet quarterback, emerged as the tallest in stature of the four in attendance at today's 2824 loss to the Giants.

title: U.S. Says Japanese Bear Responsibility for Defense
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23A Senate subcommittee said to day that the United States had turned over to Japan the re sponsibility for defending her self against conventional mili tary attack.

title: Purchases of Steel Are Seen Lagging
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 23 Steel users are buying cau tiously.

title: Egypt and Iran to Resume. Ties After 10Year Break
description: CAIRO, Aug. 23 (Reuters)The United Arab Republic and Iran have agreed to end a 10year rupture in diplomatic re lations and reestablish them at the ambassadorial level, For eign Ministry officials aid here today.

title: SAMUEL L. ROCKOWER
description: Samuel L. Rockower, who retired in 1965 as a teacher of mechanical drawing, at the Aviation Trades School in Long Island City, Queens, died Satur day in Miami, where he lived. His age was 70.

title: Y. R. A. Races Won By Rowe and Lynn In Small Sail Fleet
description: RYE, N. Y., Aug. 23High winds, big seas and heavy morning rain all subsided by starting time for the Yacht Racing Association regatta on Long Island Sound this after noon.

title: Of Time and the Flivver
description: Henry Ford the Elder de scribed his first gasoline buggy as something of a nuisance, for it made a racket and scared horses. Its descendants make 75 per cent of the racket in our major cities and scare a lot more people than their forerun ner ever did horses.

title: INVESTORS CONCERN BUYS SHOP CENTERS
description: International Investors Group announced yesterday the pur chase of 12 shopping centers in the United States at a com bined price of $44,250,000.

title: Assurances from Sihanouk
description: PEKING, Aug. 23  Thiounn Prasith, Minister of Coordina tion in Prince Norodom Siha nouk's exile Government, af firmed yesterday that instruc tions had gone out to searoh for and liberate other newsmen re ported missing in Cambodia.

title: Goldberg Criticizes Proposal
description: Arthur J. Goldberg, the Dem ocratic candidate for Governor, yesterday criticized Senator Fullbright's proposal of an Is raeli withdrawal and a bilateral treaty guaranteeing her terri tory.

title: CAMBODIA REPORTS 500 OF FOE KILLED
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Monday, Aug. 24A Cambo dian military spokesman said today that allied air strikes had killed 500 North Vietnam ese and Vietcong soldiers in a sanctuary along the border with South Vietnam.

title: Phils Blank Astros, 40
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23 (UPI)Deron Johnson drove in three runs today with a single and his 24th homer of the sea son to lead the Philadelphia Phillies to a 40 victory over the Houston Astros.

title: Japan's Reds Winning Voter Support
description: TOKYO, Aug. 23The Japan Communist party, once consid ered an adjunct of Moscow or Peking or both, has created an image of itself as an independ ent party busily soliciting voter support on downtoearth issues such as housing, sewer aim and pollution.

title: Paris: Tarzan Returns in Full Swing
description: PARISThe most surpris ing best seller of the season has been Edgar Rice Bur roughs. The first four vol umes of the new edition of Tarzan's adventures have each sold 100,000 copies. As there are 22 volumes to go, one may easily surmise the editor's elation. He is Jacques

title: NIARCHOS COMPLAINT REJECTED BY ATHENS
description: ATHENS, Aug. 23 (Reuters) The Government today re jected a charge that a public prosecutor was hounding the Greek shipowner Stavros Niar chos over allegations that he fatally injured his wife, Eugenie.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To the Editor: Uprisings in city penal in stitutions reflect the times Conditions, never good, an made worse by overcrowding Well over 95 per cent of those awaiting trial are guilty of some kind of misdemeanor of crime.

title: David Wayne's Son Missing With a Friend in Canada
description: Timothy Wayne, 22 years old, the son of David Wayne, the actor, was reported missing while on a camping trip near the town of Yellow Knife, in the Northwest. Territory, Canada, his father reported yesterday.

title: BRITISH UNION HEADS URGE STRIKE CAUTION
description: LONDON, Aug. 23The Trades Union Congress warned a rest less rank and file today against indiscriminate walkouts that might hurt organized labor as a whole.

title: Eudora Welty Receives The MacDowell Medal
description: PETERBORO, N. H., Aug. 23Eudora Welty today re ceived the Edward MacDow ell Medal.

title: Al Unser Takes 200Mile USAC Race at Milwaukee
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 23 (AP) Al Unser of Albuquerque, N. M., easily captured the Tony Bettenhausen 200 here today, finishing more than three laps ahead of the field in a record time of 1 hour 44 minutes 59 seconds.Unser averaged 114.307 miles an hour on the onemile oval track at the Wisconsin State Fairgrounds to break the old USAC championship car record of 108.735 miles an hour set by Lloyd Ruby two years ago.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Royals, at Kansas City (RadioWHN, 8:30 P.M.)

title: Schuller Leads Tanglewood Into a Slavic Mood
description: LENOX, Mass., Aug. 23Tanglewood, which earlier wore the face of a contem porary festival, did a quick change at week's end and transformed itself into a small survey of older 20th century Slavic music. Paul Zukof sky, the avant garde's favorite violinist, took a look over his shoulder at the rarely heard Violin Concerto No. 1 of Szymanowski, a 1917 piece of considerable power in spite of some deep ly purple patches that might have been at home in a nick elodeon.

title: Books of The Times
description: Imagine the most significant and dramatic episode in a century of history. Then imagine that episode's most repre sentative figure stepping out of the past and presenting us with his version of the episode. And then imagine the book con taining that version fulfilling its every promisedescribing with the coolest ob jectivity all that one might hope it would describe, yet revealing be tween its lines what made its au thor so representa tive. Imagine all that and you will begin to under stand the impor tance of Albert Speer's Memoirs and the impact of reading them. Or, if you prefer, dis miss my premises. Argue that Hitler's Germany was an aberration, the final convulsion of a diseased 19thcentury body politic. Say that SpeerHitler's architect, Inspector General of Buildings, and Minister of Armamentswas an oddity, the only ra tional man performing on the stage at Charenton. In that case, Inside the Third Reich is merely an astonishing book, one of the most revealing and interesting yet to appear on a subject that has already attracted more than its share.

title: New Books
description: A Portion in Paradise and Other Jewish Folktales, translated by H. M. Nahmad (Norton, $6). A. book in The B'nai B'rith Jew ish Heritage Classics.

title: Sponsors of Nonprofit Housing Disturbed by H.U.D. Proposal
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23For the second time this year, sponsors of nonprofit housing are disturbed by indications that the Nixon Administration may impose what they consider to be repressive restrictions on their efforts to build homes for the poor.

title: Fruits and Vegetables Are the Basis for a New Line of Cosmetics
description: With almost all the new makeup collections attached to the names of wellknown beauties, Mrs. Jay Oringer of Oyster Bay, L. I., and Mrs. Norman Muller of Mgnhattan decided it was time for change. The two women are about to introduce a line of nat ural cosmetics, said to be the first complete line of its kind in the country.

title: Regazzoni Wins Auto Race
description: ENNA, Sicily, Aug. 23 (AP) Clay Regazzoni of Switzer land won the ninth Mediter ranean Grand Prix Formula Two auto race today in a Tecno Ford, beating a coun tryman, Jo Siffert, by three tenths of a second. Regazzoni won the first race In 44 min utes 8 seconds with Siffert second with a BMW, in 44:08.3, and the two tied for first in the second race with times of 43:55.2.

title: Educational Theater Group Meeting in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23More than 1,600 drama teach ers and students assembled here today for the opening ses sion of the American Educa tional Theater Association's annual convention.

title: White Magic
description: President Nixon and Attorney General Mitchell continue their wary policy of keeping within the letter of the law on civil rights while vigorously semaphoring the white South that all will be well. Every gesture to the black community is balanced by a gesture to segregationist opinion. The Adminis tration, in the words of Whitney Young of the National Urban League, has been consistent for its inconsistency. It's what I call white magic, you know, now you see it now you don't.

title: STEWART'S HOMER DEFEATS BEAVER
CEYLON SITE YIELDS STONE AGE OBJECTS
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, Aug. 23Tests of archeological samples excavated from a site in south central Ceylon have indicated that the area was settled by people of the late Stone Age about 10,000 years ago.

title: Amherst Official Says Applicants Don't Know What They're Looking For
description: AMHERST, Mass., Aug. 22College applicants, while better prepared today in a strict aca demic sense, are no more so phisticated about higher educa tion than they used to be, according to Eugene S. Wilson, who is often called the dean of college admissions deans.

title: Explorers Off Haiti Seek Wreck of Columbus Ship
description: CAPHAITIEN, Haiti, Aug. 19A search for the lost wreck of the Santa Maria, the ship from which Columbus first saw America, is centered on a coral formation that looks hauntingly like a sunken vessel below the luminous bluegreen waters here.

title: BOARD CLARIFIES RULING ON NOTES
description: The Federal Reserve Board, caught with an embarrassing er ror in the announcement of its decision to require a reserve against commercial paper sold by bank holding companies, is making a special effort to in form bankers that such unse cured notes sold with a ma turity of less than 30 days will carry a reserve of up to 17 per cent, and not the 5 per cent implied by the initial statement.

title: Jewish Veterans Elect
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 23 (AP)Al bert Schlossberg, a Navy vet eran from Boston, has been elected national commander of the Jewish War Veterans at the organization's 75th national convention. He will serve through 1971.

title: Retired Liner Queen Elizabeth Will Be Auctioned Next Month
description: The old Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth, a success for 28 years on the North Atlantic but a failure as a tourist at traction in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., since her retirement in 1968, will be sold at auction there on Sept. 9 and 10.

title: Midwest Exchange Elects
description: The Midwest Stock Exchange in Chicago has announced the election of Jack P. Nelson as senior vice president with re sponsibility for planing, budget ary control, personnel, admin istration and coordination and planning of the exchange's automation activities. Mr. Nel son formerly was president of the exchange's service corpora tion.

title: Cushing Not Quitting at 75
description: BOSTON, Aug 23 (AP)Rich ard Cardinal Cushing, Archbish op of Boston since 1944, cele brates his 75th birthday tomor row but says he has no plans to retire. While eligible for re tirement at 75, Cardinal Cushing said in a telephone interview today: I know nothing about retirement.

title: Building Supers Can Create Heaven or Hell
description: The building superintend ent is a person of extraordi nary power.

title: Quintero to Direct Gandhi
description: Jose Quintero has been signed as director of Gandhi, a new play by Gurney Campbell de picting the Indian leader's non violent struggle for his people's independence, which will open here this fall. Mr. Quintero directed the original Broadway production of Eugene O'Neill's Long's Day's Journey Into Night.

title: jumel Mansion Named Historic Site
description: The Landmarks Preserva tion Commission announced the designation yesterday of an area around the Morris Jumel Mansion in upper Man hattan as a historic district.

title: Engineer Weds Ellen S. Simonoff
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 23Miss Ellen Sue Simonoff, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Rob ert Simonoff of New Orleans, was married here today to Daniel Abraham Picard, son of Mr. and Mrs. JeanJacques picard of Stamford. The cere mony was performed at the Congregation Agudath Sho lom by Rabbi Joseph E. Ehren krantz.

title: C.A.P. Names Consultant
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 23 (UPI)Gen. John Paul McCon nel, former Air Force Chief of Staff, was named executive con sultant to the Civil Air Patrol, an official auxiliary of the Air Force, today.

title: Economical Recipes Emerge From a Cooking Course Offered for Older People
description: By demonstrating through adult education courses her enthusiasm for cooking, Mrs. Joseph Margiotta has encour aged hundreds of women to enjoy preparing meals.

title: Rev. Louis F. Hartman, Editor Of New Catholic Bible, Is Dead
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23The Rev. Louis Francis Hart man, a Redemptorist educator and Bible authority, who was professor of Semitic languages and former head of the depart ment at the Catholic University of America, died yesterday of a heart ailment. He was 69 years old.

title: Power Boat Prize to Miniea
description: BELOIT, Wis., Aug. 23 (AP) Mike Miniea of Fort Lauder dale, Fla., was awarded the overall championship today of the American Power Boat As sociation's Beloit Blue Ribbon stock outboard championships.

title: SUITS HELD THREAT TO CON ED'S PLANS FOR ASTORIA PLANT
description: The city's Commissioner of Air Resources said yesterday that the controversial Consoli dated Edison power plant ap proved by Mayor Lindsay on Saturday might never be built.

title: Cuellar Wins No. 19 As Orioles Down Angels in 9th, 65
description: BALTIMORE, Aug 23 (UPI)Paul Blair singled home Mark Belanger from second base with the winning run in the ninth inning today to give the Bal timore Orioles a 65 victory over the California Angels and Mike Cuellar registered his 19th victory of the season.

title: Colon Wins 5,000 Run Here
description: Tony Colon of the Long Is land Athletic Club won the 5,000meter run, sponsored by the Road Runners Club of New York, yesterday at Van Cort landt Park, the Bronx. The 18yearold Colon covered the rainsoaked course in 17 min nutes 32 seconds, finishing 200 yards ahead of John Garlepp of the MilIrose A.A. Garlepp was clocked in 18:01. Joe Burns of the United A.A. was third in 18:42.

title: $14.4MILLION GIVEN TO CITY FOR HOUSING
description: ALBANY, Aug. 23  Gov ernor Rockefeller announced today state approval of a $14.4million grant to New York City for construction and rehabilitation of 65,000 low income and middleincome apartments.

title: French Sub Reaches Port
description: TOULON, France, Aug. 23 (Reuters)The French subma rine Galatee, which received 40foot gash in her side in colliison with the South African submarine Thursday, arrived in Toulon under tow late today, maritime officials said.

title: Advertising: The Never Land of Promises
description: Slightly more than a year ago, John F. Small, a black advertising man, formed his own agency that was de signed from the start to operate as a fullline shop rather than as one concen trating on the ethnic market.

title: No Communique Issued
description: CAIRO, Aug. 23King Hus sein today ended talks with President Nasser on strategy against Israel and returned to Amman. The talks were sur rounded by tight secrecy, and no communique was issued.

title: Giants Subdue Jets, 2824, After 280 Lead Is Threatened by Late Surge
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 23I never look down at a vic tory, Fran Tarkenton said today. Also, I never take any future meaning out of a victory. We won today. That's good. That's what it means. We won today.

title: Oak Brook Wins Polo Title
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 23 (UPI) Tom Hughes scored two goals in the final chukker today in leading the Oak Brook (Ill.) Polo Club to its sixth national 20goal title with a 97 victory over the Tulsa Green Hill Farm Club. Joe Barry of Tulsa led the scorers with four goals. Dr. Billy Linfoot got three for Oak Brook.

title: MISS AHERN'S 211 WINS BY 3 SHOTS
description: LEAWOOD, Kan., Aug. 23 (UPI)Kathy Ahern, equalling Donna Caponi's secondround recordbreaking 5underpar 67, marked her first tournament victory in four years as she shot a 211 to win the $20,000 South gate open invitation tournament today.

title: VESPER OARSMEN TAKE U. S. TITLE
description: COLLINGSWOOD, N. J., Aug. 23A prenoon cloudburst fol lowed by an afternoon thunder and lightning storm proved no deterrent today as the National rowing championships were completed on the windblown Cooper River.

title: Optimism for a Rate Drop Mounting in Bond Market
description: Interest rates unquestionably will move downward this week.

title: Bail Waiver in Minor Cases Is Urged to Ease Jail Crisis
description: The chairman of the State Committee on Crime and Cor rection called on the city yes terday to release immediately the defendants accused of non violent misdemeanors who had not been able to post bail. He estimated that a total of 2,000 to 2,500 in this category were being held in city detention facilities.

title: Lake Michigan Heat Pollution Fought
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 23Environ mental protection groups in the Lake Michigan area are trying to force the setting of tough new standards to protect the lake from hot water that will be dumped into it by nuclear power plants now under con struction along the shoreline..

title: Dutch Lady Wins Title
Miss Nancy Lynn Fisher, Teacher, Is Wed on L.I. to Robert Englander
description: HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I., Aug. 23Miss Nancy Lynn Fisher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert B. Fisher, was married this afternoon to Robert Englander, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Englander of Kew Gardens, Queens. Rabbi Joel Zion of Temple Israel performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's par ents. He was assisted by Can tor David Benedict.

title: Italian Advocates Of the Divorce Bill In 15th Day of Fast
description: ROME, Aug. 23Three mili tant advocates of Italy's pend ing divorce bill finished their 15th day of a public fast in front of the Senate building here today, having Jost one companion yesterday while gaining four others hi the southern city of Bari.

title: 13YearOld Skipper Wins 420 National Junior Title
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 23Wally Corwin of the Amer ican Yacht Club of Rye, N. Y., won the 420 Class juniorna tional sailing championship to day. The young skipper who is 13 Years old had his cousin, Garry Corwin 3d, 12, as mate. He scored a first and a second in the final two races of the twoday regatta staged on Long Island Sound by the Greenwich Cove Racing As sociation from off the River side Y.C. Corwin had a total of 124 points.

title: Israel Breaks the Ground For Second Oil Refinery
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 23Israel broke ground today for her second oil refinery. It will rise at Ashdod on the Mediter ranean Coast, 10 miles north of the terminal of the Elath Ashkelon Pipeline.

title: Article 2  No Title
Calley Hearing Today
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., Aug. 23 (UPI)First Lieut. William L. Calley, the first of 12 men charged in the alleged Songmy massacre, will face a second pretrial hearing tomorrow. Lieu tenent Calley, accused of the murder of 102 Vietnamese civil ians, was to have been brought to courtmartial on the charges tomorrow, but the trial was postponed a week ago so that a military judge could hear de fense motions seeking access to prosecution material.

title: Hamilton Wins 500 Race in Alabama
LEGISLATORS ALTER BAY STATE CAR PLAN
description: BOSTON, Aug. 23 (UPI)The legislature passed without op position tonight a compromise bill to modify the nation's first nofault auto insurance law.

title: Homosexuals in Revolt
description: Steve Gerrie wears a well-trimmed mustache, works as an accountant in a Wall Street brokerage and lives with his lover in a neat but threadbare apartment in the West Village here. His roommate, Jack Waluska, is a former welfare case worker now studying for a masters degree in sociology.

title: City Studies Ways To Let Bet Parlors Cover All Sports
description: Howard J. Samuels, the chairman of the city's offtrack betting corporation, said yes terday that his agency was studying the feasibility of seek ing legislative approval to en able the legal parlors to take bets on other sports besides horse racing.

title: Timmerman Stops Rally
description: DETROIT Aug. 23 cUPI)Tom Timmerman came in with the bases loaded and nobody out in the ninth inning today and preserved Mickey Lolich's twohit performance by retiring the Milwaukee Brewers without a run and the Detroit Tigers triumphed, 10.

title: F.A.A. Withdraws Request On SmokeProtection Hoods
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP)The Federal Aviation Administration has withdrawn its plan to require airlines to provide smoke protection hoods for emergency use by passengers.

title: Ellen Beth Weis Becomes Bride Of Navy Officer
description: SUNBURY, Pa. Aug. 23Miss Ellen Beth Weis, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Sigfried Weis, was married this after noon to Lieut. Joseph Ira Goldstein; U.S.N., son of Mrs. Manuel Lande of Roosevelt, N. J., and the late Paul Gold stein. Rabbi Norman Intrator performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's par ents.

title: FRANKLIN PAYNE, 74; HEARST PUBLISHER
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 23 (AP) Franklin S. Payne, publisher of The Los Angeles Examiner from 1955 to 1962, died today of leukemia. He was 74 years old.

title: CASTRO CAUTIONS ON INVASION BASES
description: MIAMI, Aug. 23Premier Fidel Castro warned tonight of an invasion of any country that allows itsf lf to become a base for an expedition by ex iles against Cuba.

title: Aguirre Assails Puerto Rico Over Expropriation of Mill
description: The Aguirre Company, whose sugar mill operations in Puerto, Rico are being expropriated by the Puerto Rican Government, declared yesterday that it would cost the Government more to, operate by expropriation than it would have by leasing from the company, as had first been planned.

title: L.I. PARK COMMISSION PLANS MORE PARKING
description: BABYLON, Ie. I., Aug. 23A $20million program to expand parking at Jones Beach and Robert Moses State Park was announced today by the Long Island State Park Commission.

title: The K.G.B. vs. Tourists
description: The American Embassy in Moscow has properly pro tested to the Soviet Foreign Ministry against secret police treatment of some American tourists. The crude behavior of the K.G.B. toward the Americans involved must raise questions for other Americans contemplat ing visits to the Soviet Union.

title: United Pilots Reach Accord
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 23 (UPI)The Air Lines Pilots Association approved yesterday an agree ment with United Air Lines ending slowdowns that the pilots had called WOEWith drawal of Enthusiasm.

title: Thant Says Mankind Must Act To Avert Its Own Destruction
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 23Secretary General Thant of the United Nations told a congress of World Federalists tonight that mankind must soon solve its problems of rising population, increasing pollution and a mul tiplied capacity of destruction or perish.

title: Twister Hits in West Virginia
description: BRIDGEPORT, W. Va., Aug. 23 (AP)National Guardsmen and the state and local police searched this community of 4,000 persons today for victims of a tornado that destroyed 25 houses and cut all telephone and most electric service last night. One injury was reported. A 13yearold boy was treated for hand and foot cuts. Officials had no estimate of damage.

title: Watts Gains National Title In Rhodes18 Class Sailing
Radio
description: Music

title: Campus Unrest and Generation Gap
description: KENT, Ohio  The Kerner Commission said a very beauti ful thing, a black student named Robert S. Pickett told the President's Commission on Campus Unrest last week, which you guys could prob ably say, too.

title: Census Bureau Takes Another Check Here
Decline Reported in Social and Economic Background of Police Recruits Here
description: A portrait of the New York policeman, showing that there has been an increase in un skilled workers joining the force, has emerged from studies drawn together in a federally financed report.

title: Freed Bishop Flies to See Pope
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 23 (AP)The most Rev. James Edward Walsh, the Roman Catholic bishop who was freed July 10 by the Chinese Communists after 12 years in a Shanghai prison left Hong Kong tonight for Rome. He is scheduled to meet Pope Paul VI on Tuesday.

title: State Limits Import Of TaxFree Liquor To Quart a Person
description: The State Department of Taxation and Finance said yes terday that state residents, returning from abroad, begin ning Sept. 1, could bring in only one quart of liquor free of state taxes instead of the gal lon previously allowed.

title: Leon's Double Decides
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 23 (UPI) Eddie Leon's tworun double in the eighth inning snapped a 66 deadlock today and gave, the Cleveland Indians an 86 victory over the Oakland Ath letics and a sweep of their threegame series.

title: Indian Police Foil Attempt To Take Over Gandhi Farm
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 23 (Reu ters)The police today foiled an attempt by leftwing dem onstrators to seize Prime Min ister Indira Gandhi's farm near here.

title: Turner, 3 Others Complete Marlboro Open Net Field
description: The men's field for the $25,000 Marlboro open tennis championship was completed yesterday when Steve Turner of New York, Richard Russell of Jamaica, B.W.I., Brian Gott fried of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and JeanLoup Rouyer of France won qualifying matches.

title: Litter Cans Studied
description: New York City's sidewalk litter baskets are now being stolen as socalled camp art objects, after decades of be ing filched by wellmuscled householders for home ref use.
