title: GIANTS'
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 23 (UPI)Frank Johnson's bases loaded pinchhit single in the ninth inning today drove in two runs that gave the San Francisco Giants a 43 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

title: JOSEPH M. REGAN
description: PLAINFIELD, N. J., Aug. 23 Joseph M. Regan, a retired vice president of Douglas L. Elliman & Co., New York real estate btokers; died at his home here yesterday. He was 72 years old.

title: Marriages
description: WCLUGHJulius, of Dover, Delaware and Pauline G. Charal (Ms. David ?? of New York City were married on Aug. 18, 1970, in Wilmington, Delaware. Couple will reside in Dover, Del.

title: Courthouse Shootout Linked With Radical Movement and Killing of Black Inmates
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 23The shootout at the Marin County Courthouse did not grow out of a simple, ill conceived plan to free three convicts, some investigators now privately concede.

title: Tass Omits Some Details
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 23The So viet press agency Tass today reported favorably on Senator Fulbright's call on Israel to withdraw from all occupied Arab territory to her prewar borders. But it did not mention his criticism of the Arabs or proposal for a United States treaty with Israel.

title: ImpeachDouglas Plea Raises Constitutional Question
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23A dispute almost as old as the Constitution is moving to the forefront of the controversy over the call to impeach Jus tice William O. Douglas be cause of his offthebench ac tivities.

title: LAWN TENNIS FINAL POSTPONED A DAY
description: HAVERFORD, Pa., Aug. 23A heavy downpour an hour before playing time today forced a oneday postponement of the finalround match be tween Ray Ruffels of Australia and Jaime Fillol of Chile for the 71st Pennsylvania lawn tennis championship. The match will be played at 1 P.M. tomorrow at the Merion Crick et Club.

title: International Loans Listed for Week
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23The following is a list of loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international lending agencies here:

title: AGNEW SEES PERIL TO GI'S IN VIETNAM IF CAMBODIA FALLS
description: AGANA, Guam, Aug. 23Vice President Agnew warned today that it would be impos sible for United States combat troops to pull out of South Vietnam if the Communists overthrew the Government of Premier Lon Nol and took over Cambodia.

title: CITY DISPUTED ON WELFARE DATA
description: New York City's proportion of people on the welfare rolls far exceeds the ratio in most urban centers, according to comparisons offered in the latest episode of a running dispute between city officials and the Center for New York City Affairs of the New School for Social Research.

title: Weakened Tropical Storm Moves West in Caribbean
description: MIAMI, Aug. 23 (UPI)Tropical depression Dorothy, deflated after causing floods on the French Island of Mar tinique, meandered into the western Caribbean Sea today. Forecasters warned that it could reintensify.

title: Royals Sink Red Sox, 43
description: KANSAS CITY, Aug. 23 (AP) Bob Johnson pitched a two hitter and Bob Oliver clouted a tworun triple in the seventh inning today as the Kansas City Royals topped the Boston Red Sox 43.

title: 39 Elderly in a Chartered Bus Hurt in Crash in Pennsylvania
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., Aug. 23 (UPI)Thirtynine elderly per sons were injured today when a chartered bus carrying them to a religious shrine ran off a wet road and crashed.

title: Having Four Wives Is a Sign of Wealth
description: MANILABeauty is vain, the au thor of Proverbs observed 2,400 years or so ago. Just how universal is this rather waspish judgment can be con firmed by visiting with women of the national minorities, or tribal groups, in the Philippines.

title: MRS. PAUL STRATTON
description: COOPERSTOWN, N. Y., Aug. 23 (UPI)Mrs. Irene Russell Stratton, mother of Representa tive Samuel S. Stratton, died last night at Mary Imogene Basett Hospital. She was 86 years old. Mrs. Stratton was the widow of the Rev. Dr. Paul Stratton, former pastor of State Street Presbyterian Church in Schenectady.

title: DR. PAUL D. M'GEHEE
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 23 Dr. Paul Duncan McGehee of 4 Durham Road, a psychiatrist and psychoanalyst, died today in Phelps Memorial Hospital, Tarrytown, after a brief illness. His age was 53.

title: BRITISH NET TEAM GAINS TITLE ROUND
description: Britain earned the right to challenge the defending United States team in the international senior tennis team competition for the Stevens Cup yesterday. The British won the clinching doubles match from Canada and took a 30 lead in the elim ination final.

title: West Germans Are in No Hurry To Practice for. Davis Cup Final
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 24If West Germany is successful in its first Davis Cup challenge round this weekend, the Ger man team of Christian Kuhnke and Wilhelm Bungert will have done it with less practice at the site of the series than any challenger in recent history.

title: Chargers Register Two Late Scores, Def eat Bears, 149
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 24 (UPI)Dick Post, a halfback, cracked 14 yards off left tackle for a touchdown with 3 minutes 20 seconds left to give the San Diego Chargers a 149 come frombehind victory over the Chicago Bears tonight in a Na tional Fotball League preseason game.

title: BAY STATE REVISES NOFAULT INSURANCE
description: BOSTON, Aug. 24 (UPI) Gov. Francis W. Sargent today signed a major modification of the nation's first nofault auto insurance law designed to meet insurance industry objections to a provision for automatic policy renewals.

title: Franulovic Tops Alexander For Austrian Tennis Title
description: KITZBUEHEL, Austria, Aug. 24 (AP)Zeljko Franulovic of Yugoslavia won the Austrian tennis championship and the 26th Alpine Cup, when he beat John Alexander of Australia in the men's final today, 64, 97, 64.

title: Yellen Retires From Posts At Lorillard and Loew's
description: Manuel Yellen, one of the top salesmen in the tobacco field, has retired as chairman and chief executive officer of the Lorillard Company and as vice chairman of Loew's The atres, Inc., the parent company of Lorillard, it was announced yesterday.

title: CHALLENGES FILED ON 2 MINOR PARTIES
description: ALBANY, Aug. 24The Con, servative party has lodged for mal challenges to the Conserva tion party and the Courage party, both of which plan to field candidates for the Novem ber election.

title: BONN AND MOSCOW SEEK TRUCK DEAL
description: BONN, Aug, 24The West German Government said todaythat it was seeking an agree ment with Moscow for con struction of a giant truck fac tory in the Soviet Union.

title: AUSTRALIAN WINS BY 62, 76, 63
description: HAVERFORD, Pa., Aug. 24Ray Ruffels of Australia won the last 9 points of the match to take the 71st Pennsylvania lawn tennis championship, 62, 76, 63, from Jaime Fillol of Chile today at the Merion Cricket Club.

title: STEEL OUTPUT OFF BY 1.5% LAST WEEK
BUILDING IS RESUMED IN JERSEY DISPUTE
description: Construction was resumed in New Jersey yesterday pending efforts to resolve a contract dispute that had led to a strike and a lockout.

title: Rider Killed
description: PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Aug. 24 (AP)Robert Hundley, 38 years old, of Ossining, was killed to day when the car in which he was a passenger struck a tree on Oregon Road, the state po lice said. The driver of the car, identified as Frank A. Cavolo, 23, of Ossining, was treated at a hospital, then charged with criminally negligent homicide, driving while intoxicated and reckless driving, the police said.

title: Muslim Center Blends Business, School and Mosque
description: Five years after a dyna mite blast destroyed Muslim Mosque 7 in Harlem follow ing the assassination of Mal colm X, a new building, topped with a dome and a revolving star and crescent, stands on the site. Beneath these symbols of the uni versal flag of Islam, Muslim ministers, educators and mer chants are quietly working toward developing everything they say a nation needs to be successful.

title: Editor Is Named to Board
description: BOSTON, Aug. 24 (AP)The Christian Science Board of Directors announced today the appointment to the board of DeWitt John, editor of The Christian Science Monitor. Mr. John will succeed Inman H. Douglass, who will retire Oct. to devote full time to the teach ing and ?? of Christian ??.

title: Article 1  No Title
Aide of Nasser Charges Israel Violates CeaseFire
description: CAIRO, Aug. 24Mohammed Hassanein Heykal, Minister of National Guidance, accused Israel today of violating the ceasefire by building fortifi cations and military roads in the Suez Canal zone.

title: Goodyear to Build Plant In Congo for $16Million
description: Plans for the first tire plant in the Congo (Kinshasa) $16million venture  were an nounced yesterday by the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company.

title: JOHN H. FERGUSON, 55, AN EXAMBASSADOR
description: PARIS, Aug. 24John Haven Ferguson, former United States Ambassador to Morocco and a prominent lawyer in Washing ton and Paris, died today while vacationing with his wife near the southern Provenal town of Gordes. He was 55 years old.

title: London Police Find Arms In Hilton Hotel Checkroom
description: LONDON, Aug. 24  Five submachine guns and 5,000 rounds of ammunition were discovered today in the baggage checkroom of the Hilton Hotel on Park Lane here.

title: Tombs Study Said to Mislead Inmates
description: The state legislative hearings last week into disorders at the Manhattan House of Detention for Men were denounced yes terday by the Fortune Society, a group devoted to prisoner rehabilitation, as an exercise, in politics that had raised false hopes among inmates.

title: Little League World Series Opens With Twin Bill Today
description: WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 24 (UPI)The 24th annual Little League World Series, dominated for the last three years by Far East teams, opens tomorrow with Chiaya, Taiwan playing Chinandega, Nicara gua, and Campbell, Calif., meeting Nashville, Tenn.

title: GAS FIRED TO QUELL VIOLENCE IN CHILE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 24The center of Santiago was blanketed with tear gas for most of the day today, as the police sought to halt violence associated with the Chilean presidential election campaign. Many shops, banks and busi ness establishments were evac uated because of the gas.

title: Tydings Links Life Article To White House Sources
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 24Sena tor, Joseph D. Tydings of Mary land today characterized the publication by Life magazine of an article accusing him of using his public position for private gain as an act of high political vengeance. He said the article was planted in the maga zine by high White House sources seeking his defeat.

title: Hispanic Week Proclaimed
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 24 (AP)President Nixon today proclaimed the week of Sept. 13 National Hispanic Heritage Week in recognition of the gifts of people of Spanish origin

title: Drysdale and Carmichael Gain As South Orange Tennis Opens
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 24Cliff Drysdale of South Af rica broke service only one time, but that was enough in straightset victory over the United States No. I junior, Ros coe, Tanner, today in firstround play of the $25,000 Marlboro open tennis tournament at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

title: I.O.S. MOVES TO SEEK A CORNFELD ACCORD
description: GENEVA, Aug. 24 (AP)In vestors Overseas Services has delayed a formal solicitation of proxies in the hope of reach ing an accommodation with Bernard Cornfeld, who says he already has enough proxies to control the company, a spokes man for the mutualfund organ ization said today.

title: JERSEY OPENS BARS ON ELECTION DAYS
description: NEWARK, Aug. 24 (AP)New Jersey dissolved today its longstanding ban against liquor and beer sales on Election Day.

title: Gas Stations Shift Policy in Crime Areas
description: The sharp rise in night time robberies at gasoline stations has brought a rev olutionary shakeup in high crime areas. Many dealers are refusing to make change after 10 or 11 P.M. Customers are being forced to use either credit cards or to present the exact amount of cash.

title: Pepes, of Bronxville, Take Family Trapshooting Prize
description: VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 24 A Bronxville, N. Y., father andson team won the parent andchild event during they Class Day program at the 71st annual Grand American Trap shooting tournament today.

title: 23 GOLFERS QUALIFY FOR DOW JONES OPEN
description: EDISON, N. J., Aug. 24 (UPI) Twentythree golfers, eight of them under par, qualified today for the remaining berths in the Dow Jones open, which begins Thursday at the Upper Mont clair Country Club.

title: Soviet Bumper Crop Expected After Poor'69 Year
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 24  The Soviet Union, aided by good weather, appears headed to ward bumper harvests in virtu ally every agricultural sector this year, Western specialists said today.

title: Big Board Seat Price Is Up
description: The New York Stock Ex change reported yesterday that a seat on the exchange had been sold for $160,000, up $25,000 from the previous sale last Thursday. The exchange said prices currently being quoted for seats are $152,000 bid and $180,000 asked.

title: Greek Magistrate Receives Niarchos Case Documents

Those held were identi fied as Woodrow Jefferson Boles, 23 years old, of Soldotna, and David 0. Obermiller, 18, and Michael L. LeQuire. 18. both of Anchorage. Almost a ton of marijuana was seized by the state police in a barn near South Bend.

title: Screen: Eldridge Cleaver in Algiers
description: "Eldridge Cleaver," which opened, without warning, at Cinema II yesterday, is a generally intelligent, wholly sympathetic treatment of the thoughts and personality of Eldridge Cleaver in exile in Algiers. Its apparent aim is not so much to study Cleaver as to provide access to his thoughts and his voice, but in doing this it necessarily does study him. Insofar as Cleaver is the subject, the film is thoughtful, ironic, valuable. Insofar as Johnson, Reagan, Nixon, Agnew and the "crimes of American imperialism" are the subjects, the film is very tired and very ordinary propaganda.Directed by William Klein ("Mr. Freedom," "Float Like a Butterfly, Sting Like a Bee," an episode of "Far From Vietnam"), the film consists at its best of interviews with and scenes from Cleaver's Algerian exile. It includes excellent footage of the First Pan-African Cultural Festival, at which Cleaver spoke, and material from Vietnam, from protest marches and beatings in the United States. It is divided into thought-segments introduced by titles (for example, "Culture Is a Gun") flashed on the screen, in the manner of some recent Jean-Luc Godard propaganda movies.However, "Eldridge Cleaver" is sufficiently unassertive in its approach to the man to allow his mind and what he has to say essential controlto a degree, even undercutting the more strident rhetoric of some of its images. As he discusses the revolutionary aims and methods of the Panthers, contemplates exile (with rather too desultory a subjective camera exploring the alleys of Algiers), meets African nationalists, laments the captivity in Babylon (the United States)  he emerges as a man of considerable wit, grace, personal sadness and hard-headed realism.Although he advocates an orthodox revolutionary toughness ("So far as I'm concerned, the neutrals are part of the problem."), he rejects black racism in favor of an internationalism of the oppressed that, if short on analysis, is also short on the appeals to anti-American paranoia that seem so often to motivate "third-world" indignation.At one point, Cleaver is shown visiting the North Vietnam delegation in Algiers. Through an interpreter he exchanges friendly views. And before he leaves he poses for Klein's camera, holding hands with the Vietnamese, whom he dwarfs but with whom he seems formally at ease. It is a moment of shy warmth and slightly awkward good feeling, and it is not too atypical of the best film-making in "Eldridge Cleaver."

description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Aug. 24 (Agence FrancePresse)Eldridge Cleaver in a speech here has denounced what he described as President Nixon's doctrine of making Asians fight Asians.

title: Tropical Storm Downgraded
description: MIAMI, Aug. 24 (UPI)The National Hurricane center said today that a weak weak tropical wave is all that remains of Dorothy, the tropical storm whose 70 mileanhour winds and floodwaters killed at least 43 persons on Martinique and Guadeloupe last week.

title: Bank of America Unit
description: The Bank of America an nounced yesterday that the Federal Reserve Board had ap proved its previously reported application to open an inter national banking subsidiary in Chicago. The nation's largest bank said its new subsidiary would be called Bank of Amer ica International of Chicago with an initial capitalization of $2million.

title: Alworth's Lawyer Says Dispute on Pact Not Settled
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 24 (UPI)Lance Alworth, an all pro flanker, has returned to the San Diego Chargers training camp but his contract dispute with the National Football League team is not over, according to his lawyer, Don Augustine.

title: City Will Review Plan for Building Modular Housing
description: A public hearing on the first modular, or partly prefabri cated, housing in the city will be held by the City Planning Commission on Sept. 9.

title: Crew Chief, Favorite, Wins On Late Drive at Tropical
description: MIAMI, Aug. 24 (AP)  Fa vored Crew Chief caught Copi ous in the last 70 yards and won the feature race at Tropi cal Park today, drawing away to score by 1 lengths.

title: DIPHTHERIA CASES UP IN SAN ANTONIO
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Aug. 24 (UPI)More than 45,000 students went to school today in the midst of a diphtheria epi demic that found most of the city's 648,000 residents unpro tected.

title: BombPlot Suspect Loses $7.500 Bail on 2d Charge
description: Larry Grathwohl, a 23yearold Cincinnati man who was one of 13 radical Weathermen Indicted in Detroit last month on a charge of plotting to bomb public buildings across the country, forfeited a $7,500 bond yesterday for jumping bail on another charge.

title: GOLDBERG SCORES YOUTH DETENTION
description: Arthur J. Goldberg, the Dem ocratic Liberal candidate for Governor, labeled the Spofford juvenile detention center in the Bronx yesterday the Tombs for children and proposed fivepoint overhaul in the state's program for dealing with youth ful offenders.

title: Father of Bomb Victim Says His Son Didn't Like the War
description: MADISON, Wis., Aug. 24 (AP)The University of Wis consin physics scholar who died today when a bomb destroyed a building that had attracted antiwar protests was described by his father as a good teach er who would have listened to dissidents.

title: Reserve Allowed Ease in Credit To Calm MoneyMarket Turmoil
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24With the stock market collaps ing and other financial markets jittery, the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee decided on May 26 to concentrate for a while on keeping financial con ditions calm rather than achiev ing a target growth of the money supply, it was disclosed today.

title: Advertising: Agency Is Run From the Coast
description: Harry Pesin is president of a small New York ad agency and a man who decided that he'd rather live in California. So he pulled up stakes a couple of months ago, moved into a home in La Jolla and now runs his shop longdis tance style.

title: French Pretender Speaks Out for Unity
description: PARIS, Aug. 24Tomorrow is the 700th anniversary of the death of King Louis IX, better known as St. Louis, and today the occasion brought his most prominent living descendant, Henri, Count of Paris, pretend er to the French throne, out of political retirement to plead for justice and unity in France.

title: Cambodians Report Repulsing Enemy Attack Near Pnompenh
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Tues day, Aug. 25 (AP)A, military spokesman said an enemy force estimated at five batta ?? launched an attack nine miles northeast of Pnompenh fast night, but the spokesman said it had been driven back.

title: HEARINGS SOUGHT ON CON ED'S PLANS
description: Public hearings on the con troversial expansion of the Con solidated Edison Company's As toria plant were requested be fore the Board of Estimate and the City Council yesterday, and at least one hearing before an other panel was already sched uled.

title: Mother Sues for $4Million In Kent State Student Death
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 24 (UPI) The mother of one of the four students killed by National Guardsmen at Kent State Uni versity filed a $4million dam age suit today in Federal Dis trict Court.

title: Figure in Mercury Case Gets State Health Post
description: ALBANY, Aug. 24  Dr. Alan R. Hinman, a former of ficial of the United States Public Health Service, who headed the investigation into a mercurypoisoning case in volving an Alamogordo, N. M., family last December, will direct New York State's re search into poisons in the en vironment.

title: Mayor's Order Bans Sex Discrimination on Jobs
description: On the eve of the announced strike of aroused womanhood for feminine rights, Mayor Lind say has signed executive orders formally banning discrimina tion on the basis of sex or age in city employment and in the execution of contract work for the city.

title: Books of The Times
description: These three volumes represent the first appearance in English of two contemporary Brazilian writers of some reputation in their home country. Except that both fill out our knowledge of the poorer and less appetizing side of Brazilian life, they have on the basis of these bookslittle in common. Jose Veiga is a writer Of wider range, greater complexity and with a larger reach. He is dark in coloring and more somber in mood. Even his playfulness has a grotesque and macabre side. Vas concelos is relaxed, expansive, emotional. He plays on the heartstrings and is not afraid to push sentiment to the edge of sentimentality. Although there are children in Veiga's stories, none lives the carefree life of the urchin in My Sweet Orange Tree.

title: Live Plays Find Favor At a Resort
description: JACKSON, Wyo.  This touristswollen frontierfla vored town, which shares one of the world's most scenic valleysJackson Hole with Grand Teton National Park, has turned into a lively summertime theater center.

title: McCarthy, on Cape Cod, Repays a Debt From 68
description: WOODS HOLE, Mass., Aug. 24Tom Lehrer, the singing mathematician, began the after noon with a rendition of So Long Mom, I'm Off to Drop the Bomb.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. The President was at the Western White House in San Clemente, Calif.

title: WILLIAM H. WAECHTER
description: William H. Waechter, who retired in 1954 as executive secretary of the Flushing, Queens, Young Men's Christian Association, died yesterday in Booth Memorial Hospital, Flush ing, Queens. His age was 81.

title: Bahamas Views Given U.S.
description: LONDON, Aug. 24 (Reuters) Britain has expressed the concern of the Bahamas, but has not protested to the United Nations about the recent dump ing of nerve gas by the United States off the Florida coast. A British Foreign Office spokes man said today, We have brought the views of the Ba hamas Government to the at tention of the United States authorities. The concern was expressed through the British Embassy in Washington Friday.

title: FarberAbzug Campaign Opens on Flowery Note
description: In what may be an omen of a colorful campaign to come, a Manhattan Republican Con gressional candidate delivered to his opponent yesterday the customary debate challenge and a hardly customary dozen red roses.

title: URUGUAY REBELS SAY CAPTIVES ARE WELL
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 24 (AP)The Tupamaro guerrilla group broke a silence of 13 days by announcing to day that its two foreign host ages were in good health and had not been sentenced.

title: JAMES F. DONNELLY, LAWYER 68 YEARS
description: James F. Donnelly, a lawyer who specialized in litigation and appellate practice for 68 years, died Friday in Dublin. He was 93 years old and lived in Park Ridge, N.J.

title: A.B.C. Cancels Kennedy Film
description: The American Broadcasting Company has canceled a televi sion documentary, The Jour ney of Robert F. Kennedy, scheduled for tonight. A spokesman said the cancellation was made to avoid any pos sible charge of political parti sanship in such races as that of Senator Edward M. Kennedy for reelection as Democratic Senator from Massachusetts. Other candidates also appear in the film, and company law yers had advised that the show ing be canceled.

title: T.V.A. Will Build a Third Nuclear Power Plant
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 24 The Tennessee Valley Au thority disclosed today that it planned to build a third large nuclear power plant. The dis closure indicated that, with troubles over coal supplies, T.V.A. was giving more thought to nuclear power production.

title: 4.4 Million Working Days Lost in 749 Strikes in July
description: WASHINGTON, Aug 24 (UPI) The Labor Department said today that working time lost because of strikes in July amounted to 0.28 per cent of total working hours in private industry. It was a decline from 0.31 per cent in June and an increase from 0.27 per cent in July. 1969.

title: Israel Says Cairo Violates Provision on War Prisoners
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 24Israel complained to the United Na lions today over alleged Egyp lion violation of the ceasefire agreement provisions for treat ment of prisoners of war, charging the United Arab Re public with violating the 1949 Geneva Convention.

title: Louise Homer Stires Dies; Soprano, Daughter of Singer
description: GLENS. FALLS, N. Y., Aug. 24 Louise Homer Stires, a for mer singer and the wife of the Rev. Ernest Van R. Stires, died yesterday at Glens Falls Hos pital. She was 74 years old and had homes in Bolton Landing and in Sea Island, Ga.

title: Miss Susan Elizabeth Carhart Is Betrothed to Peter D. Bluhm
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., Aug. 24  Mr. and Mrs. Russell Newman Carhart have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Susan Elizabeth Carhart, to Peter Dwight Bluhm, son of Mrs. Heinz Bluhm of New Haven and of Wilton, N. H. and Mr. Bluhm of Chestnut Hill, Mass.

title: 20 Blacks Dispute South African Terrorism Charges
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 24The trial of 20 black Africans charged with ac tivities aimed at the violent overthrow of the South Afri can Government opened here today.

title: WMCA WILL SWITCH TO PHONEIN FORMAT
description: Radio station WMCA, which has a 20year tradition of em phasizing popular music, an nounced yesterday that it was adopting the format of ac cepting telephone calls from listeners on an almost fulltime basis, starting Sept. 21. Most recently the station has been dividing the day between rock music and talking with listeners.

title: Tile by Tile, a 165Foot Miro Is Born
description: GALLIFA, Spain  In the ?? 30 miles above Barce ??, work is being completed on a 30ton mural designed by Joan Miro and fashioned by Spain's master ceramist, Josep Llorens Artigas.

title: FREEHOLD MAN SUES IN DISPUTE ON FLAG
description: NEWARK, Aug. 24 (AP)A Freehold, N. J., man went into Federal Court here Monday seeking the right to speak at meetings of the Monmouth County Board of Freeholders despite his recent refusal to salute the flag at a Freeholder's meeting.

title: I.R.S. Seeks to End Delay Of Taxes on Bank Interest
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24The Internal Revenue Service issued today proposed regula tions that would bar deferred interest time deposits In banks and thrift institutions aimed at delaying taxes for the depositor. The regulation was adopted under a provision of last year's complex taxre form law.

title: Useful Mission to Mexico
description: If all Presidential trips abroad could accomplish as much in short order as Mr. Nixon's 28hour visit to Mexico, the case for personal diplomacy at the highest level would be unanswerable. Actually, the ground had been laboriously prepared for the agreement designed to resolve remaining boundary disputes between the United States and Mexico and to set up machinery for heading off such quarrels in the future.

title: Consolidated Foods Shows. Record Net
description: The Consolidated Foods Cor poration in the fiscal year ended June 27 set records in sales and earnings for the 15th consecutive year, William A. Buzick Jr., chairman reported, yesterday from Chicago head quarters.

title: Jets Trade Rookie Center
description: The New York Jets traded a rookie center, Bill Pierson, to the San Diego Chargers last night for an undisclosed draft choice. The Jets 12thround draft pick will be virtually go ing home. He played collegiate football at San Diego State.

title: Israel Terms Seized Algerian a Top Security Aide
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 24Israeli security officials interrogating two Algerian citizens taken off a flight from the Far East to Europe 10 days ago identified one of the detainees tonight as a senior official in the Algerian security agency.

title: STEPHEN ANGELL, 92, A REALTY EXECUTIVE
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Aug 24 Stephen Leroy Angell, a re alty executive and official vil lage historian of Scarsdale, died Saturday in a Greenwich, Conn., nursing home after an illness of two months. He was 92 years old.

title: William E. Palmer, 63, Dies; Official of Fawcett Printing
description: WESTFALL TOWNSHIP, Pa., Aug. 24Wiliam E. Palmer, vice president and national sales manager of the Fawcett Print ing Corporation, which has its sales headquarters in New York, died Saturday of a heart attack at his home here. He was 63 years old and also lived at 413 East 50th street in New York.

title: Prices on Floor Tile Raised 2% to 4% By Armstrong Cork
description: The Armstrong Cork Com pany announced yesterday that it would raise prices by about 2 to 4 per cent on selected lines of resilient floor tile, ef fective.Nov. I.

title: TURNOVER SLOWS IN CORN FUTURES
description: With the extent of the corn blight problem now the big question, trading on the Chi cago Board of Trade slowed somewhat yesterday although the disease continued as the prime topic of conversation in the nits.

title: Transport News and Notes
description: A new airconditioned ex press bus service between the Bronx and Manhattan was started yesterday. The service is being maintained Mondays through Fridays between the Parkchester section of the Bronx and midtown Manhattan.

title: Hunt for U.S. Pair Continues In the Northwest Territories
description: YELLOWKNIFE, Northwest Territories, Aug. 24 (UPI)The Royal Canadian Mounted Police said today that a week long search for Timothy Wayne, 22yearold son of David Wayne, the actor, and young Wayne's companion had been unsuccessful.

title: Excerpts From 2 Bibles
description: 23d Psalm

title: LongHaired Patrolman Gets A Department Trial Oct. 8
description: Patrolman John Bal, who contends that his long hair and ideas for police reform have irked his superiors, pleaded not guilty yesterday to depart mental charges of insubordina tion and unnecessarily convers ing with civilians. The 24yearold policeman was ordered to reappear Oct. 8 at Police Head quarters for trial on the charges.

title: A New Dimension: Menu by Computer
description: By now, dating by compu ter is old hat. But eating by computer?

title: Napanoch Inmates Protest Medical Treatment
description: NAPANOCH, N. Y., Aug. 24 Several hundred inmates at the Eastern New York Correc tional Facility here refused for nine hours today to return to their cells in a protest against what they called inadequate medical treatment.

title: Cheops'
description: CAIRO, Aug. 24One of the most exciting modern archeological attractions in Egypt, the funerary solar boat of the Pharaoh Cheops, was reported today to be deteri orating rapidly as a result of exposure to humidity and temperature changes.

title: Sale to Aid Jersey Arthritis Fund
description: The third Art for Ar thritis auction and sale for the benefit of the New Jersey chapter of the Arthritis Foundation will be held at Rod's Shadowbrook Restaur ant in Shrewsbury on Sept. 11.

title: AGEE'S HURT KNEE CONCERNS METS
description: Concern about Tommie Agee's left knee, which was Xrayed last night at Roosevelt Hospital, added to the worries of the New York Mets Yesterday. No firm diagnosis will be available until today when the Mets open a threegame series with the Atlanta Braves at Shea Stadium at 8 P.M.

title: W. F. Connor, Miss Kindred Plan Nuptials
description: KENILWORTH, Ill., Aug. 24Mr. and Mrs. Keith Kin dred have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Kathleen Kindred, to Walter Fischer Connor of Chicago and. Darien, Conn. He is, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Hayden Connor of Darien. The wedding is planned for October.

title: DR. REMA LAPOUSE, PSYCHIATRIST, 55
description: RYE, N. Y., Aug. 24Dr. Rema Lapouse, professor of community and preventive med icine and psychiatry at New York Medical College, died at her home here yesterday after a long illness. She was 55 years old and the wife of Dr. Milton Terris, professor and chairman of the department of community and preventive med icine at the college.

title: 2 WOMEN OVER 70 SHOT IN FT. GREENE
description: Two elderly women were shot yesterday for no apparent reason in the hardware store they own in the Fort Greene Section of Brooklyn.

title: CAR SALES DOWN BY 4.4% AUG. 1120
description: Sales of domestic passenger cars in the United States slumped 4.4 per cent during the middle 10 days of August, from the 1969 period, the four major auto manufacturers reported yesterday.

title: Murphy Gets Life Again
description: MIAMI, Aug. 24. (UPI)Jack Murphy, who stole the Star of India sapphire in 1964 and is serving a life term in Miami's Raiford Prison, was sentenced today to consecutive terms of life and 20 yearsthis time for armed robbery. Circuit Judge Carling Stedman said the 33yearold beach boy's many convictions disqualified him to ever again be in a free world with a law abiding society.

title: GIRL HELD UPSTATE IN BOMBING INQUIRY
description: BUCHANAN, N. Y., Aug. 24 An 18yearold girl allegedly found with a suitcase contain ing dynamite, blasting, caps, primer cord, a homemade bomb, fireworks and a switchblade knife, was arrested last night in Peekskill, the State Police here reported.

title: African Conference Opens With Attack on British Policy
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 24 (UPI)Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia opened conference of African foreign ministers today with a keynote speech deploring Britain's deci sion to consider resuming arms shipments to South Africa.

title: A Correction
description: An article in The New York Times on Aug. 14 reported that $500,000 paid for the film rights of Henri Charriere's book Papillon would be shared by the author and his American publisher, William Morrow & Co. The money will be shared by Mr. Charriere and Editions Robert Laffont, his French pub lisher, according to Rosalie Siegel, Laffont's New York rep resentative.

title: New Catholic Bible to Replace the Douay Version
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 Roman Catholics will get a new translation of the Bible in mod ern English next month to re place the Douay Version in use for 220 years, a team of its editors announced here today.

title: Mrs. AnneMarie Rockefeller To Be Married to Manufacturer
description: MADISON, Wis., Aug. 24Mrs. AnneMarie Rasmussen Rockefeller, whose marriage to Gov. Nelson A. Rockefel ler's son Steven ended in di vorce last June, will be married to Robert W. Krog stad of. Maple Bluff, a Madi son suburb, before the end of the year

title: Bishop Walsh Is Reunited With Two Sisters in Rome
description: ROME, Aug. 24 (AP)The Most Rev. James E. Walsh wasreunited today with two sisters who last saw him in 1948 when he went to China on a mission ary tour that ended with 12 years imprisonment there.

title: Britain Lifts Bar to Pets
description: LONDON, Aug. 24Britain will end a sixmonth prohibi tion on the entry of dogs and cats next month, the Ministry of Agriculture announced to day. It was imposed March 11 after two dogs from abroad died of rabies. Pets will still have to go into quarantine for six months and be vaccinated twice against rabies.

title: 229 ARE LAID OFF BY HONEYWELL UNIT
description: WELLESLEY HILLS, Mass., Aug. 24 (UPI)The dataproc essing division of Honeywell, Inc., has laid off 229 manufac turing employes at two plants in Massachusetts.

title: WELFARE LIST RISE AT 15MONTH NIGH
description: New York City's relief rolls have undergone their sharpest monthly rise since March, 1969, in what welfare officials say may be a reflection of national economic difficulties.

title: Kramer Off for Japan
description: Jack Kramer flew to. Tokyo yesterday to set up the $50,000 Pepsi masters tennis tourna ment. The event, scheduled for December, will be a playoff among the top Pepsi Grand Prix finishers.

title: It's Like Falling Asleep While Floating
description: Ellen Margaret Larsen, 9, bounced on the water bed on Bloomingdale's eighth floor yesterday and pro nounced it difficult to stand on, but fun to sleep on. Her father, who is part owner of the Copenhagen restaurant and who caters some of the store's executive dining room food, thought it was a great idea and would con sider buying one. The idea of a mattress filled with water intrigues anyone who has ever dreamed of falling asleep while floating on water. The King Koil Sleep Products Company is counting on insomniacs to snap up its bed at $600. Questions? Dozens of them were shot out to Mitchell Gelbard, the company's sales manager, who was supervis ing the inflating of the bed, and to Dr. Irving London, an internist and pediatrician, who is vice president of the concern.

title: Dow Surges 14.17 to 759.58 as Volume Tops 18 Million
description: Stock prices boomed yester day in the second straight ses sion with dramatic gains. The DowJones industrial average, moving upward steadily on heavy volume, closed at 759.58 with an upswing of 14.17 points.

title: Murder Hearing Delayed
description: FORT BRAGG, N. C., Aug. 24 (AP)  The Army announced today that testimony in the hearing into murder charges against Capt. Jeffrey R. Mac Donald would not resume this week so that Army psychia trists could observe the de fendant, A spokesman said the hearing officer, Col. Walter Rock, had decided that Captain MacDonald, a 27yearold Green Beret physician charged with killing his pregnant wife and two daughters, should be ob served by Army psychiatrists.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, the United Nations special representative for the Middle East, announced yesterday that talks between Israel, Jordan and the United Arab Republic would start today. He said he would begin by holding separate meetings with the United Nations representatives of the three countries, but added that he was hopeful that as progress was made, the talks could be raised to the level of foreign ministers for the group. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: N.C.A.A. PENALIZES FOUR COLLEGES
description: KANSAS CITY, Aug. 23 (AP)  Two colleges were placed on oneyear probation and two others were reprimanded by the National Collegiate Athletic Association today.

title: A.T.&T.'s Pay Raises Backed Despite Objections From Union
description: An arbitrator decided yester day in a dispute between the American Telephone and Tele graph Company and employes in its longlines department to uphold the company's contrac tual right to grant $6.5million in pay increases to employes not receiving top rates.

title: Cotillion in Rye Set for Sept. 4; 26 to Make Bow
description: RYE, N. Y., Aug. 24The Westchester Cotillion will take place for the 32d year Sept. 4 at the Shenorock Shore Club here. There are 26 debutantes, 20 fewer than at last year's cotillion.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To the Editor: Spiro Agnew's Aug. 17 re marks before the Veterans of Foreign Wars in Miami Beach are starkly illustrative of the brazenly immature attitude of the Nixon Administration. His reference to the HatfieldMc Govern amendment as a blue print for the first defeat in the history of the United States was a blatant appeal to the very worst of all those emotions which sometimes pass for pa triotism in this confused and troubled day.

title: Drive to Raise Food Urged
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Aug. 24The municipal government of Pnompenh has issued an emergency appeal to residents to begin raising some of theirs own food in the city to thwart the enemy threat to strangle the capital.

title: Nixon and 4 Aides Encouraged by Economic Signs
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 24 (UPI)President Nixon met today with the four top Govern ment economists and agreed with them that the nation's badly overheated economy had been cooled without prompting a recession.

title: Miss Bond Wed To Dr. Dunbar
description: Miss Jaqueline Turner Bond of New York, a vice presi dent of the Donner Advisory Corporation, was married here yesterday to Dr. Charles Robert Dunbar, an ortho pedic surgeon of Manhasset, L. I. The ceremony in the Library Suite at the St. Regis Sheraton was performed by Family Court Judge Joseph D. Caputo.

title: DR. ROALD N. GRANT OF CANCER SOCIETY
description: Dr. Roald N. Grant, a sur geon and vice president in charge of professional educa tion for the American Cancer Society, collapsed and died, ap parently of a heart attack, on a bus in Manhattan yesterday. He was 58 years old and lived at 315 Avenue C.

title: Calley Defense Asks Disclosure Of TopSecret Data on Songmy
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., Aug. 24 (UPI)  Defense attorneys sought today the disclosure of what they termed key and classified info nation that might shed further light on the alleged massacre at Songmy in 1968 and the secretive Oper ation Phoenix.

title: U.S. Backs Suit to Drop Racial Bar at Cemetery
description: MIAMI, Aug. 24 (AP)A suit supported by the Federal Gov ernment was filed in United States District Court today, seeking to force an allwhite cemetery in Fort Pierce, Fla., to allow the burial of a black sol dier killed in Vietnam.

title: Executive Changes
description: Henry R. Silverman, general partner in Oppen heimer and Co., has been named a director, presi dent and chief executive officer of the ITI Corpora tion, a New Yorkbased diversified industrial firm.

title: Park or Pit?
description: Hearings to be held this week in Sun Valley. Idaho, will go far to determine whether the country will have its 37th. National Park or a gaping openpit mine yield ing molybdenum that will not even be needed for decades to came.

title: Many Travelers Shunning Crowded Kennedy Airport
description: Air travelers by the thou sands are bypassing New York because of the harrowing traffic jams and congestion at Ken nedy International Airport.

title: Lindsay and Ribicoff Clash Over Dirt in City's Streets
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24Mayor Lindsay went before the Senate Finance Committee today to urge a complete Fed eral takeover of welfare costs and administration by 1976, but he also spent part of his time discussing why New York City's streets were so dirty.

title: Shuvee Captures Diana Handicap by a Nose at Saratoga
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 24Shuvee, Mrs. Whit ney Stone's champion filly, came through with a thrilling (success in the $49,100 Diana Handicap today. The 11/2mile event for fillies and mares at tracted a field of 12 contestants and Shuvee scored a nose vic tory over Reginald N. Web ster's Dark Emerald. Four langths farther back in third place came Native Partner of the Oxford Stable.

title: PARSONS REASSURES HIS BANK CREDITORS
description: DETROIT, Aug. 25Appar ently moving to assure his ma jor creditors that he can meet his loan commitments, Donald H. Parsons met today with rep resentatives of 17 major banks at his office in nearby Birming ham.

title: Topless Singers Open Edinburgh Music Fete
description: EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 25 (AP)Sergei Proko ficv's opera The Fiery Angel brought a capacity openingnight audience to its feet yesterday despite its controversial chorus of three actresses playing barebos omed nuns.

title: David H. Lee, Tufts Alumnus, Marries Stacey Lee Schneer
description: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 25 Miss Stacey Lee Schneer, a senior at Jackson College of Tufts University, was married here today to David Harold Lee, a 1969 graduate of Tufts. The ceremony at the Fenway Golf Club was performed by Rabbi Paul M. Steinberg, dean of the School of Sacred Music at the Hebrew Union CollegeJew ish Institute of Religion in New York.

title: CAMPUS RADICALS SAID TO SPLINTER
description: The radical leftwing student movement is collapsing into fragmented, embittered, com peting organizations, according to a survey of 50 colleges and universities by the League for Industrial Democracy.

title: Napoles to Fight at Garden
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 25 (AP)  Jose Napoles, the world welterweight champion, signed today to meet Pete Toro in a 10round nontitle bout Oct. 5 at Madison Square Garden. It will be Napoles's first New York appearance.

title: CENSUS IN QUEENS FINDS RISE OF 8.5%
description: The Census Bureau reported the population of Queens yes terday as 1,964,147, represent ing an increase of 154,569, or 8.5 per cent, since 1960.

title: Mrs. Donald R. Hassell, Taught Classics at Hunter
description: Mrs. Miriam W. Hassell of 32 Edgewood Road, Hartsdale, N. Y., a classicist who had taught Greek and Latin at Hun ter College, died Monday night at Memorial Hospital of cancer. She was 52 years old and the wife of Donald R. Hassel, a vice president of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust company.

title: Small Fires Set in Disturbance At Bronx House of Detention
description: Inmates set small fires and participated in disorders at the Bronx House of Detention for Men last night.

title: ARTHUR J. DORAN, 68, BANKRUPTCY LAWYER
description: YONKERS, Aug. 25Arthur J. Doran, United States District Court referee in bankruptcy, died today at St. Joseph's Hos pital after a long illness. He was 68 years old and lived at 264 Palisade Avenue.

title: Washington: The Official Worriers
description: WASHINGTONThe boss is away but the official mice are not playing in Washington. They are worrying about the endless frustrations of Vietnam, not so much about the military situation, but about the con sequences of what they regard as their growing successes in Southeast Asia.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Special Committee on Co;, lonialism, subcommittee on Indian Ocean Territories 10:30 A.M.

title: LAWSUITS EXPLAINED BY TRANS NATIONAL
description: Ellis E. Erdman, chairman of Trans National Communica tions, Inc., the New Yorkbased miniconglomerate in the sports and leisure field, issued a state ment yesterday seeking to bring shareholders up to date on several lawsuits in which the company is involved.

title: LYTTLE DRIVES IN CLINCHER IN 9TH
description: KANSAS CITY, Aug. 25A jubilant ovation from Kansas City fans in the ninth inning turned into a dejected silence tonight when Jim Lyttle singled in the run that gave the Yankees a 21 victory over the Royals.

title: Intrepid Beats Valiant, Leads Final Trials, 21
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 25With the America's Cup stage to themselves today, Intrepid and Valiant slugged it out for the third time in this final ser ies to pick a Cup defender. In trepid won by 3 minutes 24 seconds under almost ideal con ditions and took a 21 lead in victories.

title: GASPER IN DRILL FOR $300,000 GOLF
description: CLIFTON, N. J., Aug. 25Almost every big name in golf was on hand today at the Upper Montclair Country Club as practice for the richest tournament ever held  the $300,000 Dow Jones opencontinued.

title: Sandra Pierce Fiancee Of Kevin F. Macmanus
description: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 25  Miss Sandra Elizabeth Pierce, a granddaughter of the late Albert J. King, founder and first president of Ferncliff Cemetery and Mau soleum in Westchester, will be married to Kevin Francis Macmanus of White Plains. The ceremony will take place on Nov. 7 in St. Vincent Fer rer Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: 55 Prisoners From City Moved to Sing Sing Cells
description: OSSINING, N. Y., Aug. 25Fiftyfive prisoners from two New York City jails arrived at the Ossining Correctional Facility here today, the first contingent of nearly 700 who will be transferred here to re lieve overcrowding in the city's prison system.

title: Israel Declines Comment
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 25 (Reuters) An Israeli military spokes man declined to comment today on a Beirut report that Israeli troops raided a southern Leb anese village last night and destroyed several houses.

title: Cairo Aide Says Solar Boat Of Cheops Can Be Restored
description: CAIRO, Aug. 25A cultural official assured Egyptians today that restorative treatment of the deteriorating solar boat of Cheops would be completed in three months and that the craft would then he moved to a spe cial airconditioned museum.

title: FLAHERTY DECLARES HE'S IN RACE TO STAY
description: BUFFALO, Aug. 25Thomas P. Flaherty, the Democratic Liberal candidate for Repre sentative Richard D. McCarthy's Congressional seat, said yester day that he would stay in the race even though Mr. McCarthy has decided to run for reelec tion as an independent.

title: Souvanna to Go to Zambia
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 25 (UPI)The Laotian Premier, Prince Souvanna Phouma will attend a conference of non aligned countries next month in Zambia and later visit New York and Europe, official sources said today. According to the sources, the Premier will fly to New York to address the United Nations General Assem bly after the Zambia confer ence, scheduled for Sept. 2, then fly to Paris for his regu lar physical examination.

title: FAUBUS IS LEADER IN ARKANSAS VOTE
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Wednes day, Aug. 26 Former Gov. Orval E. Faubus ran up a wide lead over seven opponents in the Democratic primary for Governor yesterday, but he will have to face either Dale Bump ers, a Charleston lawyer, or Attorney General Joe Purcell in a runoff Sept. 8.

title: West German Trade Surplus
description: WIESBADEN, West Ger many, Aug. 25 (Reuters)West Germany's foreign trade surplus rose to 1.99billion marks in July from 1.13billion in June this year and 1.65bil lion in July last year, the Fed eral Statistical Office said to day.

title: Douglas Haring of Syracuse U., Anthropology Professor, Dead
description: SYRACUSE, Aug. 25Dr. Douglas G. Haring, professor emeritus of anthropology at Syracuse University, died today after a long illness. He was 76 years old.

title: Summer Revival: Alley Park
description: While the Lindsay adminis tration has virtually stopped building vestpocket parks, some East Side residents are trying to revive one that they first created five years agoa narrow, shaded alley off Lexington Avenue that ulti mately succumbed to the ravages of vandalism and litter.

title: Soviet Grants Credits to Peru
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 25 (UPI)The Soviet Union today con cluded an agreement with Peru granting credits worth $30mil lion for the purchase of Soviet machinery.

title: For the Lower Hemlines, Higher Heels
description: The woman who believes all she need do to be fashion able this fall is buy a few long skirts had better think again. If she embraces the midi at all, she'd better start budgeting for a new shoe wardrobe. Just as trying on a long hemline makes a woman instinctively stand up on her toes, so is it ob vious she'll need higher heels than she has been wearing for at lest five years.

title: Eban Discloses Instructions
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 25For eign Minister Abba Eban moved today to answer Opposition criticism in the Knesset by dis closing that Ambassador Tekoah had been instructed to raise the question of violations of the ceasefire at his meeting today with Dr. Jarring.

title: Neglect of Dying Patients Emotional Needs Is Linked by Doctors to Cultural Inability to Face Death
description: The American preoccupation with youth culture and inability to face death realistically have led the medical profession to neglect the emotional needs of the dying patient and his family, four doctors have concluded in a report.

title: 0.5% BONUS SET ON SAYINGS BONDS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) The Treasury Department, in a move designed to encourage people to keep savings bonds until they mature, today added a one half of 1 per cent bonus on bonds held five years or more. The increase brings the interest rale on Series E and H bonds to 5 per cent, the maxi mum allowed under a new law President Nixon signed in San Clemente, Calif., last night.

title: 7 Women Selected For Police Force For White House
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25Dr. Edgar F. Berman denied to night that he had ever told Democratic party group that women were inferior, but he opened a new attack on what he called the irrational worn en's libs.

title: Lowery Names Assistant
description: Fire Commissioner Robert O. Lowery announced the appoint ment of Paul M. O'Brien as his special assistant for public re lations yesterday. Mr. O'Brien, 43 years old, who will assume his duties in October, is now press secretary to Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson. Commissioner Low ery said Mr. O'Brien would help to bridge relations between the Fire Department and the city's communities.

title: Bomb Scare on BMT Halts Service During Rush Hour
description: Service on the Canarsie line of the BMT subway was halted for half an hour during the rush hour last night after the Transit Authority received a tip that a bomb had been placed on a train.

title: CORNETT IS VICTOR IN TITLE TRAPSHOOT
description: VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 25 (AP)Ralph Cornett of Sykes ville, Md., won the champion of champions event at the 71st annual Grand American trap shooting tournament today by breaking 100 straight targets in a delayed shootoff.

title: 7 Syracuse Blacks Mull Signing Code
description: SYRACUSE, Aug. 25Seven black Syracuse University foot ball players were undecided to night on whether to sign a six point statement, an action that would reinstate them to the squad. They have until tomor row, the start of practice, to sign.

title: CAMBODIAN FORCE BOLSTERS CAPITAL
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Aug. 25 (Agence FrancePresse)Most of the defense forces of Pnompenh were reported to have been shipped across the floodswollen Mekong River to day to oppose a suspected heavy concentration of North Vietnamese and Vietcong troops.

title: Xuan Thuy Due in Paris
description: PARIS, Aug. 25 (AP)Xuan Thuy, North Vietnam's chief ne gotiator at the Vietnam peace talks, will arrive here tomorrow from Moscow, his office an nounced today.

title: Stage: Troubles Abroad
description: CHICHESTER, England, Aug. 25Every festival has its troubles, but this year Sir John Clements, director of the Chichester Festival, must have felt like some Old Testa ment Job beset with boils. The only play to go off with out a hitch was Robert Bolt's Vivat! Vivat Regina! which I reviewed a few weeks ago.

title: Music: Leon Fleisher Makes Debut as Conductor
Upstate Man Killed in War
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) The Defense Department to day announced the names of nine servicemen killed in the war in Southeast Asia, one of whom was Pfc. Frank R. Fra tellenico of Chatham, N. Y., of the Army.

title: Lion Mauls Girl in Britain
description: LUTON, England, Aug. 25 (Reuters)A lioness leaped at the open window of a car with visitors to Woburn Park's re servation near here today, badly mauling a 5yearold girl, iden tified as Sian SymonsJones. She underwent an emergency operation for a leg wound.

title: Bridal Planned By Mrs. Lane
description: BUFFALO, Aug. 25  Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Chandley Burke of Buffalo and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., have an nounced the engagement of Mrs. Burke's daughter, Mrs. Jeanne Vallely Lang, to James Suydam Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Suydam of New York.

title: GOLDBERG SCORES RIVAL ON HUDSON
description: NEWBURGH, N. Y., Aug. 25 Arthur J. Goldberg accused Governor Rockefeller today of having permitted the Hudson River to become a cesspool.

title: Actor's Son Still Sought
description: YELLOWKNIFE, Northwest Territories, Aug. 25 (UPI)The Royal Canadian Mounted Police searched Lake Yellowknife yes terday with a plane and three boats for Timothy Wayne, the 22yearold son of the actor David Wayne, and young Wayne's companion, Malcolm Best. The rescue team has been looking for the men since Aug. 17. They were presumed miss ing on a camping trip after an overturned canoe was found on the lake shore near two float ing life jackets.

title: CONSPIRACY TRIAL IS GIVEN AS DRAMA
description: LONDON, Aug. 25Short of seeing Judge Julius Hoffman re enact his famous role in the film of the Chicago conspiracy triala film its defendants are hop ing to makeone could not ask for better casting than William Burroughs who presided at the onenight performance here of John Burgess's verbatim docu mentary Chicago/Conspiracy at the Open Space Theater.

title: 2 Convents in Britain Defend Practice of AidingIndian Girls
description: LONDON, Aug. 25 (Reuters) Two British convents tonight defended the practice of paying expenses for Indian girls to join them as novices.

title: Rep. Powell Meets Deadline for Filing As an Independent
description: The Board of Elections re ported yesterday that it had re ceived enough petition signa tures to designate Representa tive Adam Clayton Powell as an independent candidate for reelection.

title: RISES RESCINDED ON SHEET PRICES
description: Price moves announced late Monday by the Cannon Mills Company were followed yester day by other manufacturers of sheets.

title: Pop Fans Protest Fee
description: NEWPORT, England, Aug. 25 (Reuters)  About 100 fans broke into the 30acre arena of a pop music festival here on the Isle of Wight today and smashed down fencing and scaffolding. They said that mu sic is free.

title: Youth Sets Himself on Fire After Arguing With Parents
description: A 15year old youth angered over a family argument early yesterday morning, poured kerosene over himself and ig nited it, the police said.

title: Official Says Mrs. Niarchos Wrote Note Before Death
description: ATHENS, Aug. 25 (AP)The chief Athens coroner said today that Mrs. Stavros S. Niarchos wrote a note just before she took an overdose of barbitu rates last May 4.

title: Coroner Asserts Sharon Tate Was Still Alive When Hanged
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug: 25The Los Angeles County Coro ner testified today that Sharon Tate was suspended by a rope as she was dying.

title: DR. HARRY R. EPSTEIN
description: Dr. Harry R. Epstein, a physi cian who had practiced in Brooklyn for. 30 years before moving to Mahwah, N. J., seven years ago, died of Hodgkin's disease yesterday at Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 71 years old.

title: FATAL CRASH LAID TO A CONTROLLER
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP)  An air traffic control ler, mistaking one plane for an other on his radar scope, un wittingly sent a twinengine air craft with five occupants into the mountainous area in Cali fornia where it crashed, the National Transportation Safety Board said today.

title: A KENNEDY WILL AIDS FOUNDATION
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Aug. 25 (AP)The late Joseph P. Kennedy, former Am bassador and father of a Presi dent and two United States senators, left a will bequeathing the bulk of his vast estate to a foundation for the mentally retarded, named for a fourth son who was killed in World, War II.

title: 7 American Airmen Killed In Bus Crash in Thailand
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 26 (Reuters)  An express train traveling at full speed struck bus, killing seven American air men and injuring four others at a railroad crossing near Bang kok's Don Muang airport, police sources said today. The bus was taking the airmen to their head quarters from the airport 15 miles north of Bangkok last night when the collision oc curred at an unguarded cross ing, the police said.

title: Summer Court Closings Upheld as Unavoidable
description: State judicial officials said yesterday that the summertime schedule in which 11 of the 34 criminal parts of State Supreme Court here are closed for vacations was the only ar rangement possible because of staff limitations in the Dis trict Attorney's offices and the Legal Aid Society.

title: NEW BOOKS
description: Echoes of Celandine by Derek Marlowe (Viking, $5.95). Sus pense.

title: Rook and Soul Fete in Park Heard by 2,000 Youngsters
description: Two thousand slum young sters swayed, sang, cheered and sometimes booed yesterday as they watched their contem poraries give a rock and soul concert under the pleasant skies in the band shell area of Central Park

title: LEONARD VIETH
description: MORRISTOWN, N.J., Aug. 25Leonard Vieth, a former un derwater systems development engineer at Bell Laboratories in Whippany, died yesterday at Morristown General Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived on Round Top Road, Bernards ville.

title: Rally Is Staged Near Court in Support of McLucas
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 25While the final arguments were put before the jury in the trial of Lonnie McLucas, a rally in support of the Black Panther defendant at tracted 500 people to the Town Green, across the street from the Superior Court Building.

title: TaxCredit Bill Introduced
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (Reuters)  Senator Vance Hartke, Democrat of Indiana and a member of the Senate Finance Committee, introduced legislation today to restore the 7 per cent investmenttax credit for business. The credit was nullified as part of last year's taxreform bill.

title: Jets'
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 25The New York Jets sat around the Hofstra fieldhouse today watching films of Sun day's game between the Jets and the Giants.

title: Books of The Times
description: Louis Auohincloss's literary credo might be summed up as two cheers for life, duty and generosity. He is an inheritor, and his WASP inheritance is besieged. In his latest collection of short stories, Second Chance: Tales of Two Generations, the subtitle suggests the ubiquitous generation gap, but the typical Auchincloss drama is in the betrayal of the older generations by themselves. The young are present to be lectured. The Auchincloss heroes are gentlemen in the truest old sense of that now scorned word. His heroines are canny social navigators. They all know good form, and tragedy occurs when they don't measure up to it.

title: Penn Central Company Picks Chairman
description: The Penn Central Com pany's directors elected yes terday Gaylord P. Harnwell to the position of chairman, president and chief execu tive officer of the holding company. He succeeds Paul A. Gorman, who resigned on Aug. 11.

title: Shooting of Sisters in 70's Baffles Fort Greene
description: To her neighbors, Mrs. Ma ria Cappelli is something of a wonder.

title: PIER LOOT IS FOUND IN BROOKLYN RAID
description: Detectives raided a group of three stores in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn yesterday afternoon and recovered mer chandise stolen from piers and in truck hijackings that was valued at more than $500,000, the police said.

title: Bronx Ice Cream Man Held on Drug Charge
description: The police arrested a Good Humor vender in the Bronx yesterday who they said dou bled as a heroin dealer and a bookmaker.

title: Francis Love, Miss Barstow, To Wed Oct. 31
description: NORTH TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Aug. 25Mr. and Mrs. William Merrill Barstow Jr. have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Lorraine Lyle Barstow, to Francis Walton Love, son of Dr. and Mrs. Freeman Love of Brooklyn. The wedding is Planned for Oct. 31.

title: VALDO, 111, TAKES JERSEY TURF RACE
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 25 (UPI)Walt Blum piloted Valdo, an 111 outsider, to a photo finish victory over Dot Ed's Bluesky today in the feature race at Atlantic City.

title: Army Experts Sift Rubble for Bombing Clues at U. of Wisconsin Math Center
description: MADISON, Wis., Aug. 25Bomb experts sifted through rubble today for clues to an explosion at the Army Mathe matics Research Cnter on the University of Wisconsin campus early yesterday.

title: Bernstein, 52, Leaves For Japan on Birthday
description: Leonard Bernstein left for an 18day tour of Japan with the New York Philharmonic yesterday, his 52nd birthday. To mark the occasion, a cake was presented to the conduc tor by Pan American World Airways in its VIP Lounge at Kennedy International Air port.

title: Blazers and Slacks: New Police Image
description: LAKEWOOD, Colo.  They are called agents, not police men, and all of them, including the men directing traffic, wear Navy blue blazers and gray flannel trousers.

title: Army Ousts 50 Israelis in Arab Village
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 25  A band of about 50 Israeli ex tremists of the socalled Great er Israel Movement tried to day to establish an illegal Jew ish settlement in the Arab vil lage of Battir in the occupied area on the west bank of the Jordan River. The village was a Jewish stronghold of Biblical times. After two hours they were ejected by an Israeli Army patrol.

title: New Delhi Said to Ask B.B.C. To End Operations in India
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 25 (Reu ters)The Indian Government has asked the British Broad casting Corporation to end its its operations in India by Sat urday, authoritative sources said here today.

title: Drobny, Oakley Give Britain Tennis Sweep of Canada
description: Britain completed a 50 sweep of Canada in the international senior tennis team elimination finals yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens, when Jaroslav Drobny and Gerry Oakley won the last two singles matches.

title: Heinemann Flies to Berlin Despite Protests by East
description: BERLIN, Aug. 25 (Reuters)President Gustav Heinemann of West Germany arrived here to day in a United States Air Force plane despite protests rom East Germany.

title: Allstate's Net Up for Half; Underwriting Losses Rise
description: Allstate Insurance Companies reported yesterday that it sus tained an underwriting loss on property and liability insurance of $9.3million in the first half of 1970, compared with an underwriting loss of $5.1million a year earlier.

title: East German Bid to UNESCO
description: BERLIN, Aug. 25 (Reuters)East Germany has applied for membership of the United Na tions Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, the East German press agency A.D.N. re ported today.

title: Bombings in CrotononHudson Laid to a Local Band of Youths
description: CROTONONHUDSON, Aug. 25  The police investigating two bombings in this quiet riverfront villageone involv ing the home of the chief of policesaid today that they believed the incidents were the work of a local band of youths and not political radicals.

title: PLANS FOR CLAY BOUT WITH FRAZIER DENIED
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 25 (AP)A state senator who is promoting a fight between Cassius Clay and Joe Frazier said today he was confident the bout would take place Oct. 26, but Frazier's manager maintained no fight was contemplated.

title: Rockefeller Says Goodell Has Problems on War
description: TICONDEROGA, N. Y., Aug. 25 Governor Rockefeller said today that Senator Charles E. Goodell faced a diffi cult election campaign because of his strong criticism of Presi dent Nixons conduct of the war in Vietnam.

title: Met Gets Ready for Its 86th Season
description: The Metropolitan Opera is hastening now toward its rendezvous with its opening night audience, 20 days hence. Its 86th season opens at 8 P.M. on Monday, Sept. 14, at Lincoln Center in what one official identified as the earliest start in the company's history.

title: U.S. Practices Are Called Apartheid
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UPI)A witness testified at a Senate hearing today that there were more allwhite and allblack schools now than in 1954, largely because of housing discrimination. He said there was no real dif ference between segregation in the North and South.

title: HEARING SOUGHT ON MUSEUM PLAN
description: Sanford pr Garelik,president of the City Council, called yes terday for a public hearing be fore the City Council on the expansion plans of the Metro politan Museum of Art.

title: Princeton Urban Program
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 25 Princeton University an nounced today a new program that will allow 10 to 12 under graduates to live and work in Newark next spring while studying urban problems. The plan, which allows for full academic credit, has the co operation of Newark Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson. Under the program, the students, who will get a costofliving subsidy, will live in Newark for about four months, working on a non salaried basis for municipal agencies, antipoverty programs and nonprofit organizations.

title: NICARAGUA WINS FROM TAIWAN, 32
description: WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 25 (AP)  Nicaragua scored twice in the top of the final sixth inning today, then held off a late rally to topple the defending champion, Taiwan, 32, in the opening game of the Little League World Series. Sesco Paz, who pitched for Nicaragua, fanned 12.

title: Basketball Transactions
description: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION

title: ExMarine, in Sweden, Says He  Aided Vietcong
description: STOCKHOLM, Aug. 25 (AP)A young American who said he defected from the Marines and fought for the Vietcong arrived in Stockholm with a North Vietnamese passport today and asked for political asy lum.

title: DR. HERMANN KNAUS, FERTILITY EXPERT, 77
description: GRAZ, Austria, Aug. 25 (AP)Dr. Hermann Knaus, whose gynecological studies led, with the work of others, to the rhythm method of birth control, died of a heart attack Sunday. He was 77 years old.

title: AMEX ADVANCES INACTIVE TRADING
description: The American Stock Ex change scored its third consec utive advance yesterday as an afternoon rally put most issues into the plus column in active trading

title: ZIEGLER ASSAYS AGNEW'S REMARK
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Aug. 25For the third consecutive day, a remark by Vice President Agnew that the United States would do everything to in sure the survival of the Lon Nol regime in Cambodia touched off debate and ques tioning here today. The con fusion created by that comment was only partly resolved.

title: Hospital Director Named
description: ALBANY, Aug. 25 (AP)Dr. Hagop S. Mashikian, chief of training at King's Park State Hospital in Suffolk County, has been named the first director of the new Rockland Children's Psychiatric Hospital at Orange burg. Dr. Mashikian, appointed by Mental Hygiene Commis sioner Alan D. Miller, will be pajd $35,137 a year.

title: Guerrillas in Montevideo Bomb a Radio Station
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 25 (UPI)Five Tupamaros guer rillas, members of the organiza tion that is holding an Ameri can and a Brazilian as hos tages, raided a radio station here today, set off a bomb and fled.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Representatives of Israel, Jordan and the United Arab Republic expressed guarded op timism yesterday at the start of the first concerted diplomatic effort in more than two decades specifically intended, to bring a formal peace settlement to the. Middle East. The delegates met at the United. Na tions in separate sessions with Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Khrushchev Is Released After 3 Months in Hospital
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 25 (UPI)Nikita S. Khrushchev was de clared completely recovered to day from a heart ailment after having been kept hospitalized for nearly three months, mem bers of his family said.

title: Stockton, in Tourney as Replacement, Upsets Crealy in Marlboro Tennis
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 25Rod Laver and Ken Rose wall were the center of attrac tion, as expected, in the $25,000 Marlboro open tennis tourna ment today, but 19yearold Dickie Stockton of Garden City, L. I., stole the show at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

title: Defense Links Bus Crash to Soapy Air
description: LOWER MACUNGIE, Pa., Aug. 25Soapy matter wafted into the air by a factory in a copperrecovery operation may have contributed to a bus crash near here that killed seven children, defense lawyers ar gued today at a preliminary hearing into the accident.

title: Sihanouk Says His Forces Hold Twothirds of Country
description: PARIS, Aug. 25 (AP)Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the de posed Cambodian leader, said in an interview published here today that twothirds of Cam bodia was in the hands of his supporters.

title: Students Hold Bonn Envoy
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 25 (Reuters)The West Ger mAn Ambassador to Venezuela, Walter von Truckenbrodt, and three police guards with him were held captive for almost an hour today by leftist univer sity student in the Andean city of Merida, the Caracas police chief, Juan Martinez Echevar ria, said tonight.

title: Farm Pickets Arrested
description: SALINAS, Calif., Aug. 25 (UPI)At least 29 pickets were arrested today as striking farm workers tried to cripple the multimilliondollar produce harvest in the Salinas Valley. The Monterey County sheriff's office said the arrests were mainly for treaspassing, block ing traffic and obstructing ar rests.

title: 11MONTH LOW SET BY BRITISH POUND
description: LONDON, Aug. 25. (AP)The British pound dropped to an 11month low on the for eign exchange market today, but the close at $2.3837 was above the danger point that would threaten another de valuation.

title: Ballet:City Troupe Opens Short Stand
LEGISLATOR'S OFFICE LINKED TO TEXAS SPA
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UPI) The Capitol office of Repre sentative Olin E. Teague, Dem ocrat of Texas has been ad vertised for several days over a Washington radio station as a sales contact for a health spa operated by H. L. Hunt, the Texas oil millionaire.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON DECLINE SLIGHTLY
description: The London stock market eased slightly yesterday as early gains were lost on a lack of followthrough.

title: Supreme Court to Hear Vote Age Case Oct. 19
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP)  Chief Justice Warren E, Burger said today the Su preme Court would hear argu ments on the 18yearold vote case on Oct. 19.

title: REPERTORY GROUP PLANS 4 REVIVALS
description: Four revivals were announced yesterday for the new season of the Lincoln Center Repertory Company at the Vivian Beau mont Theater.

title: SENATE BARS PLAN DESIGNED TO BRING VOLUNTEER ARMY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25Discarding normal political and ideological alliances, the Sen ate rejected today a measure advertised by some of its sup porters as the amendment to end the draft.

title: Mrs. BowerMrs. Henry Post 76 For Shot Lead on Jericho Links
Striking San Quentin Prisoners Routed by Tear Gas
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 25Nearly a thousand inmates at San Quentin staged a strike to day to protest the shifting of Court proceedings to the prison.

title: Bridge:;Tribute Paid Three in Jersey On Women's Liberation Day
Miller Orchestra Finds Bus Theft Hard to Believe
description: Someone appears to have stolen the Glenn Miller orches tra's bus.

title: How Far on Cambodia?
description: Both White House and State Department insist that Vice President Agnew did not change Administration policy on Cambodia when he said: We're going to do everything we can to help the Lon Nol Government. But, when coupled with his implication that a Commu nist takeover in Cambodia would make it impossible to withdraw American troops from Vietnam, that assertion certainly bears scant resemblance to what Administration leaders have said before.

title: Nixon Issues Proclamation
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 25(AP)President Nixon, in proclamation noting the 50th anniversary of women's suf frage in the United States is sued today, asked Americans to recognize the great debt we owe to those who dedicated their life's work to the cause of women's suffrage.

title: TaxExempt State Bonds Register Drops in Yields
Hockey Transactions
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: Breathless Eyewitnesses
description: BOSTON, Aug. 25 (AP)New England television viewers who watched the Red SoxTwins game tonight had a birdseye view of the bomb scare.

title: ALFRED P. HAAKE JR.
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 25Alfred Paul Haake Jr., vice president of the Continental Illinois Na tional Bank and Trust Com pany, died yesterday apparent ly of a heart attack. He was 49 years old and lived at 1970 Spruce Drive, Glenview, Ill.

title: Foreign Experts Open a Survey of Subway Here
description: Transit authorities from Lon don and Toronto began an in vestigation of the subway sys tem here yesterday with a ride on the IRT line, interviews with transit employes and a request for accident and maintance statistics from the Transit Authority.

title: TRUCKER ACCEPTS UTILITY'S OFFER
description: The board of directors of the Pacific Intermountain Express Company accepted yesterday a previously announced offer by the International Utilities Cor poration to acquire the com pany.

title: BankersAcceptancesatPeak
description: Bankers dollar acceptances outstanding in the United States rose to close to $6billion in July, a record for the fourth consecutive month, the Federai Reserve Bank of New York re ports. Acceptances last month were up $124million from June. Acceptances financing United States imports showed the largest increase in July, rising to a record $2.3billion.

title: 7 Women First to Be Selected For White House Police Force
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 25 (UPI)The Secret Service, with President Nixon's approval, has selected the first seven women to serve on the White House police force since it was organized in 1922.

title: Olivares to Defend Ring Title
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 25 (AP)  Ruben Olivares of Mexico, the world bantamweight cham pion, will defend his title against Jesus Castillo in a re turn bout Oct. 16 at Los An geles Forum.

title: STARK SEAT SOUGHT BY ASSEMBLYMAN
description: Assemblyman George A. Cin cotta, Democrat of Brooklyn announced his candidacy yes terday for his party's nomina tion for Borough President, to succeed Abe Stark, whose resig nation becomes effective Sept. 8.

title: EXPORT SURPLUS FOR U. S. IN JULY FAR AHEAD OF 69
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25United States foreign trade showed a booming surplus of exports over imports in July for the second month in a row, the Commerce Department re ported today.

title: Sports of The Times
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 25For most of Tom Gorman's tennis life, instructors kept tell ing him, the serve was the biggest, most important stroke in the sport. Hold your serve in every game, they stressed, and you cannot lose.

title: New State Housing Agency
description: ALBANY, Aug. 25 (UPI)Formation of a State Housing Planning Bureau was an nounced today by Governor Rockefeller. The new agency will be headed by Donald Kline, former director of plan ning and construction for the Redevelopment Agency of Sacramento, Calif. Designed to help private and public de velopers increase production of lowincome and moderatein come housing, the bureau will be in the State Division of Housing and Community Re newal.

title: RollCall Vote on Raise for Military
SURVEY SEES RISE IN PLANT SPENDING
description: Capital appropriations for im provement of manufacturing plant and equipment are poised for an upturn in the third quarter, the National Industrial Conference Board said yes terday,
