description: As a man with a baby perched on his shoulder greeted Governor Rockefeller at they Franklin County fair in Malone this week, a photographer tried in vain to divert the baby's attention toward the Governor for the inevitable campaign picture.

title: 6 G.I.'s Killed and 26 Wounded In Ambush in Central Highlands
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam Saturday, Aug. 29 (AP)  A convoy of American infantry men was ambushed on a main highway in jungles in the Central Highlands and in nearly 10 hours of fighting 6 were killed and 26 were wounded, the United States command reported today.

title: Cyanide Price Rise Planned
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, Inc., announced yes terday that it would raise prices by 4 per cent on sodium cyanide products beginning Oct. 1. Sodi um cyanide is used in plating, heat treating, refining of metals and as an intermediate in the manufacture of chemicals.

title: Drug Death of TeenAger Shakes an Upstate Town
description: HOPEWELL JUNCTION, N. Y., Aug. 28  This tidy Dutchess County community does not have a serious unem ployment problem, a slum or even its own police force. But it has recorded its first teen age death attributed to nar cotics.

title: DR. A. JAY HERTZ, 77, DENTIST, PHILATELIST
description: Dr. A. Jay Hertz, a student of American postal history, primarily the development of Western mails, died of a heart attack on Wednesday at his home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 77 years old. Dr. Hertz, a dentist, formerly of New York, had retired some years ago.

title: U.S. WIDENS CURB ON USERS OF DDT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 The Agriculture Department announced today further re strictions on the use of DDT and hinted at still more crack downs against pesticides.

title: Topics: Youth and Politics 70
description: In the next two months the offyear. Congressional elections will produce the greatest out pouring of young political workers in our history. The Children's Crusade has not been decimated, far from it. The ranks of the young in poli tics have swelled and they are now fixtures in many cam paigns.

title: LAURENCE LEVI, 89, HEADED OIL CONCERN
description: Laurence B. Levi, former di rector of a concern that was to become the Mobil Oil Corpora tion, died Thursday night after a heart attack a the Harkness Pavilion of the ColumbiaPres byterian Medical Center. He was 89 years old and lived at 870 Fifth Avenue.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX CONTINUE UPWARD
description: The American Stock Ex change finished higher for the sixth consecutive session yes terday as advances outnum bered declines by more than a twotoone ratio.

title: CORN PRICES RISE ON STRONG BUYING
description: Although profittaking near the end of the session trimmed the advances somewhat, corn, wheat and soybeans futures prices rose again yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: A.D.A. Backs Mayor White
description: BOSTON, Aug. 28 (AP)Mayor Kevin White was en dorsed for the Democratic nomi nation for Governor today by the state board of the Massa chusetts chapter of Americans for Democratic Action.

title: William H. Chartener Is Dead; Held Commerce Post in Capital
description: William H. Chartener, an economist and a former As sistant Secretary of Commerce in both the Johnson and Nixon Administrations, died yesterday after a heart attack at his home in Port Washington, L. I. He was 45 years old.

title: Television
description: 5:30 (4) Modern Farmer

title: MRS. T. K. HIMELSTEIN
description: Mrs. Ruth Himelstein, wife of Dr. Theodore K. Himelstein, an orthopedic surgeon of 65 Cen tral Park West, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 59 years old.

title: Rights Panel Expected to Urge Fund Curb on White Suburbs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 The United States Civil Rights Commission is preparing to pro pose a total withdrawal of Fed eral funds from suburban juris dictions that remain all or largely white and are adjacent to cities with heavy concentra tions of blacks.

title: Wild Car Mounts Sidewalk And Strikes A.B.C. Guard
description: A security guard for the American Broadcasting Com pany was injured last night when he was struck by an out ofcontrol automobile on the sidewalk in front of the net work's studio at 7 West 66th Street.

title: PERSISTENCE WINS 2 HUNTER CROWNS
description: RHINEBECK, N. Y., Aug. 28 Persistence, owned and han dled by Naomi Blumenthal of Oran, N. Y., captured both the green and regular working hunter championships today as the Dutchess County Fair Horse Show ended a threeday runthe most successful in the his tory of the event.

title: DeLury Calls for Return to Hand Street Sweeping
description: John J. DeLury, president of the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association, said yesterday that street sweeping by hand was the only answer to the city's dirty streets.

title: Cleveland Press Names Aide
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 28 (UPI) James H. Couey Sr., 46 years old, of Honolulu, was named business manager of The Cleve land Press today. Mr. Couey has been executive editor and as sistant to the publisher of The Honolulu Star Bulletin for the last two years.

title: Screen: Italian Chiller
Market Place:
description: New and difficult questions are being asked about the obligations of stock exchange members and the evaluation of their memberships as a re sult of the current wave of brokeragehouse collapses on Wall Street.

title: U.S. Denies Beirut Report
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) The State Department denied today that the United States had put out feelers to Israel, Egypt and Jordan about the possibility of a joint United StatesSoviet security force in the Middle East.

title: Antiques: All Wedgwood
description: Wedgwood is a name found on a lot more than the deco rative pieces, with stark white relief ornament ap plied to a pale ground, which everyone knows.

title: 20 Flee Roller Coaster As Flames Engulf Frame
description: MOUNT ARLINGTON, N. J., Aug. 28 (UPI)  Twenty people took a harrowing walk to safety last night when fire broke out at Bertrand's Island Amusement Park, engulfing the roller coast er on which they were riding.

title: Goldberg Says M.T.A. Scorns Public on 2d Ave. Subway Plan
description: Arthur J. Goldberg charged yesterday that the forced dis closure by the Transit Au thority that only six stops were planned for the new Second Avenue subway from 34th to 125th Street was another in dication of the contempt in which the riding public is held by the State Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the T.A.'s parent body.

title: Niarchos Case Takes On Political Cast
description: ATHENS, Aug. 27While lawyers for Stavros S. Niarchos prepare a brief answering charges that the multimillion aire shipowner was responsible for the death of his third wife, Eugenie, on May 4, the case and the people involved are taking on political overtones, so that his accusers appear as heroes of the left and his defenders as rightwingers.

title: 10 Arrested in Drug Raid At Fairgrounds Upstate
description: BUFFALO, Aug. 28 (AP)Horseriding deputy sheriffs along with colleagues on foot, swept into the Erie County Fairgrounds in suburban Ham burg today and arrested 10 young men on drug charges.

title: Hoboken Remains Tense After Clash Between. Puerto Ricans and the Police
description: HOBOKEN, N.J., Aug. 28Tension lingered here today after a night in which several hundred Puerto Rican youths hurled rocks and bottles at po licemen, smashed store windows and set trash fires in the down town area.

title: Thieu Delivers First Titles In a Big LandReform Plan
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam Aug. 28  President Nguyen Van Thieu handed out the first land titles to peasants today under the landreform program he signed into law five months ago.

title: $102,770 Cane Futurity Pace Envisioned as TwoHorse Race
W.H.O. Hints Cholera Data Are Deficient
description: GENEVA, Aug. 28  The World Health Organization said today that the failure of some governments to report cholera cases was concealing the spread of the disease through the Middle East into Africa.

title: Executive Changes
description: Lewis C. Murdock has been named a senior vice president of the First National City Bank.

title: TWO CASES FILED ON REFRIGERANTS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) The Government moved to day to break up what it said was a 17yearold conspiracy to eliminate competition in the sale of refrigerant gas in viola tion of the Sherman Antitrust Act.

title: Express Subway
description: Although the proposed Second Avenue subway has certainly been far from an express up to now (its active planning stages began nearly twenty years ago), it may be an express when it finally begins service.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. In San Cle mente, Calif., President Nixon presented a certificate of commendation to Sugar Ray Robinson, the former boxing champion, in recognition of his exceptional service to others. Mr. Nixon saw a string of California callers and spent most of the after noon in staff meetings. The President held a reception for members of the Richard Nixon Foundation, who are making plans for his Presi dential library.

title: PARLEY ON COFFEE EXTENDED 48 HOURS
description: LONDON, Aug. 28 (AP)The Council of the International Coffee Organization decided to day to extend its meetings for 48 hours in a bid to break A deadlock over next year's ex port quotas.

title: U.S. BACKS PROJECT JOHNSON SUPPORTED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) The Nixon Administration, in a policy turnabout, has ap proved free Federal land and has tentatively approved $7.3 million in loan guarantees and interest subsidies for a nursing home project in Austin, Tex., that is supported by former President Lyndon B. Johnson.

title: Theater: The Tempest
description: LONDON, Aug. 28Jona than Miller is clearly a man of many parts, His talents as satirist, physician, writer and director, have gone far be yond that fringe where we all first found him. As a Shake spearean director, however, despite his growing reputa tion in Britain, he has, in my admittedly minority view, been somewhat disappointing.

title: DR. CHARLES R. DOWNS
description: VERONA, N. J., Aug. 28Dr. Charles Raymond Downs, chemist and a consulting engi neer in the field, died yester day in a nursing home at Cedar Grove at the age of 82.

title: Palestinian Parley Rejects Moves for Mideast Peace
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 28The Palestinian National Coun cil declared tonight that it cate gorically rejected the present efforts toward peace in the Middle East.

title: FirstRound Leader in the Dow Jones Open Falls Back Into the Pack
description: CLIFTON, N. J., Aug. 28At the front gate, there were pickets. Two stumpy middleaged men, their eyes narrow ing in the rising heat, shifted from foot to foot as they chatted with a state trooper. Their placards berated the establishment, today the Upper Montclair Country Club, for not properly paying its bar and restaurant help.

title: Article 3  No Title
Bomb Threat At 5 Stores
description: Four Alexander's Department Store branches and the main Gimbels store were searched last night after they had re ceived bomb scare threats. No bombs were found by the po lice and the stores were not evacuated.

title: JURY IS STILL OUT IN M'LUCAS CASE
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 28For the third day in a row, the jury in the Lonnie McLucas trial re tired this evening without having arrived at a verdict.

title: Candidate, at Door, Surprises Saigon Voters
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam Aug. 28In a dusty hamlet of a suburban district of Sai gon, with the usual abund ance of chickens, children, palm trees and flies, a candi date for the senatorial elec tion on Sunday came to meet and to sway the voters.

title: RollCall Vote in Senate On Military Fund Slash
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP)Following is the roll call vote by which the Senate rejected today an amendment to cut $5.2billion from the military authorization bill:

title: Yanks Sink Twins, 60, 21
description: The New York Yankees con solidated their own position in the East and undermined the Minnesota Twins position in the West last night by winning a doubleheader from the West ern leaders before 25,824 per sons in Yankee Stadium.

title: Article 2  No Title
Negro Legislator From South Rejects Tactics of Some Blacks
description: Julian Bond, the black state legislator from Georgia, re jected yesterday the strategies of blacks who preach separa tism and of young people who ignore problems at home while debating obscure matters.

title: Evans Clark
description: Long before Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal vastly expanded the nation's concepts of social re sponsibility, Evans Clark was helping to broaden the horizons of public thought on unmet needs in housing, health and other neglected areas. As a member of the editorial board of this newspaper and as director of the Twentieth Century Fund, he brought erudition and compassion to the illumination of social issues and still had time left over to indulge his private passion for collecting LatinAmerican folk records, shooting motion pictures and cheering on the Fire Department at dozens of big blazes.

title: Cosmetics Line Specially Designed for the Fashionable Woman of Colour
description: The ancient Phoenicians called her the goddess of love. An interracial group of businessmen and women hope she'll be known as the black Estee Lauder and have given her name, Astarte, to a new luxury brand of cos metics specially designed for the fashionable woman of colour.

title: Barbara Muller to Marry Sept. 20
description: LEVITTOWN, L. I., Aug. 28 Miss Barbara Gail Muller, who was graduated cum laude in June from the New York Institute of Technology in Old Westbury, and Keith W. Rouse, who received a B.F.A. degree in communica tion arts last year from the institute, will be married Sept. 20 at the First Re formed Church in New Hyde Park.

title: Kerala Matriarchs Still Reign, but Do Not Rule Much of Anything
description: POONJAR, India, Aug. 26 The bent old woman with the kindly, seamed face shuf fled slowly into the room to greet her grandson and the Western stranger he had brought.

title: Unblocking Welfare Reform...
description: The note of urgency President Nixon put into his latest plea for swift Senate action on his welfare reform plan is eminently justified. The existing wel fare system is a national scandal, and the Administra tion proposal represents the most imaginative effort in three decades to transform it into something socially useful.

title: Eskimo Craftsmen Now Eliminate the Middleman
description: NOME, AlaskaThe wood frame building is a converted storehouse for reindeer hides and the lights do not always work, but Eskimo House is alive and flourishing.

title: DAMAGE TO ECONOMY CONCEDED BY HANOI
description: HONG KONG. Aug. 28 (Reu ters)North Vietnam conceded today that war had heavily damaged its already very poor and backward economy but it gave no sign of retreating in the Indochina conflict.

title: U.S. Acts to End Dumping Of TV Sets by Japanese
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 The Treasury announced today a key step in a process that could lead to somewhat higher prices for imported Japanese television sets.

title: POWER RESERVE DROPS TO 5% HERE
description: Emergency power supplise ar ranged by the Atomic Energy Commission enabled Consolidat ed Edison to squeak through an other hot and humid summer day yesterday, although re serves were at a critcally low point of 5 per cent.

title: BANKS HERE EASE STUDENTS'
description: Stateguaranteed college edu cation loans are easier to get in the New York metropolitan area than they were at this time last year, bankers say, although some students in New Jersey are having trouble.

title: Radio
description: 12:05 P.M., WNCN: Opera High lights with Francis Robinson. Martha, Flotow.

title: Article 1  No Title
Biafra's Leader Lives in Lonely Exile
description: YAMOUSSOUKRO, Ivory Coast, Aug. 24Far from the land that he used to call Biafra, Odumegwu Ojukwu is leading a quiet and lonely life in exile.

title: 2D VICTORY GOES TO BARTHOLOMEW
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Oct. 28Randy Bartholomew in tlie Etchells22 Class, Gino Matkovic among the Resolutes, and Pierce McCreary among the Internationals were winners in a Manhasset Bay Yacht Club Race Week regatta that was saved today by a lateblooming southwester that was neither steadfast nor strong, but good enough.

title: Article 4  No Title
Pennsylvania Paper Struck
description: MONESSEN, Pa., Aug. 28Members of the Monessen unit of the Pittsburgh Newspaper Guild went on strike today at The Valley Independent, an afternoon daily newspaper. Members of the Monongahela Valley Typographical Local No. 504 of the International. Typo graphical Union crossed picket lines set up at the newspaper at 6 A.M. by the guild.

title: McLain Is Suspended For Dousing 2 Writers
description: DETROIT, Aug. 28 (AP)Denny McLain was suspended tonight for up to a month without salary by the Detroit Tigers general manager, Jim Campbell, for conduct un becoming a professional base ball player.

title: SENATE REJECTS $5BILLION SLASH IN DEFENSE FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28The Senate defeated today, 42 to 31 a proposal that would have cut more than $5billion from what the Nixon Administration wants to spend for the military this fiscal year.

title: I.O.S. LOSS IN HALF PUT AT 25MILLION
description: GENEVA, Aug. 28Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., report ed today a net loss of $25.86 million, including an operating loss of $12.53million, for the first six months of 1970.

title: Cotton Is No Longer King for Blacks
description: SOMERVILLE, Tenn. It's no longer a sharecrop per's shack but it sits there, wooden and rotting, on the edge of the cotton fields that survive along these dry, dusty roads.

title: Aquarium Expedition Hooks, Marks and Bleeds Sharks in Delaware Bay
description: CAPE MAY, N. J., Aug. 28 Using a kingsized hypo dermic syringe, Dr. Kenneth Sterling of Columbia Univer sity's* College of Physicians and Surgeons drew blood from a thrashing, fivefoot shark five miles at sea yes terday and came away with all 10 fingers intact. It was easy, Dr. Sterling said.

title: Miss Linda H. Leslie Becomes Bride on L.I.
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., Aug. 28  Miss Linda Hurd Leslie and Hutchinson DuBosque Jr. were married here this afternoon in the out door chapel of St. John's Epis copal Church by the Rev. Wil liam S. Spilman. A reception was given at the home of the bride's mother, Mrs. Clarissa Leslie of Mill Neck.

title: Cautious Chief of I.L.O.
description: GENEVA, Aug. 28  After Wilfred Jenks was elected Director General of the Inter national Labor Organization, he was asked what he liked to do when he was not work ing.

title: DAYCARE COURSES GIVEN JERSEYANS
description: For the last two years a total of 300 New Jersey residents have conic to New York each weekday for training in an ex perimental daycare program Ihat has been described as the only one of its kind.

title: Japanese Ease Curbs
description: TOKYO, Aug. 28 (AP)The Japanese Government said to day it had decided to liberalize importquota restrictions on 13 items and to raise the ceiling on direct foreign investment abroad by Japanese companies.

title: NEW N.L.R.B. CHIEF KILLS UNION PAY BID
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP)President. Nixon's new National Labor Relations Board chairman, in his first major case, swung the vole today against a union's demand for wage increases from a concern that had illegally refused to bargain.

title: Bullfrog Satellite Delayed
description: WALLOPS ISLAND, Va., Aug. 28 (AP)The proposed launch ing of a small satellite carrying two bullfrogs was delayed to day until next Tuesday. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said technical problems made it impossible to attempt a launching next Mon day, as planned.

title: Suzanne Grossman, Designer, to Wed
description: KINGS POINT, L. I., Aug. 28The engagement of Miss Suzanne Lynn Grossman to Stephen Arnold Goodman, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Goodman of New York, has been announced by the fu ture bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin B. Grossman.

title: West Berlin Mayor Is Hopeful on Curbs
description: BERLIN, Aug: 28  Mayor Klaus Schutz of West Berlin said today that the new Soviet West German pact had for the first time in years created conditions under which im provements for West Berlin have moved into the range of possibility.

title: Roundup: Angels Making Life Unhappy for Twins
description: The California Angels, driv en by Manager Lefty Phil lips, continued to make the Minnesota Twins uncomfort able atop the American League's Western Division last night.

title: ALLEGRI QUARTET SHINES IN DEBUT
description: Thursday night's Mostly Mozart Festival program aC Philharmonic Hall introduced to New Yorkers the Allegri String Quartet, a 16yearold London ensemble. As with many other foreign groups, it is already known here through a number of recordings on yari ous labels. Its members are Hugh Maguire and David Roth, violins; Patrick Ireland, viola, and Bruno Schrecker, cello.

title: Net Loss Is Shown At Data Processing
description: The Data Processing Finan cial & General Corporation in creased its gross revenues in the fiscal year ended May by 31 per cent, but a net loss of $4,255,593 was incurred in con trast to the net income of $8, 175,654, or $2.43 a share, realized in the preceding fiscal year, the company's annual re port disclosed yesterday.

title: ROSEWALL BEATS GIMENO IN 2 SETS
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 28Ken Rosewall of Australia and Bob Carmichael of France advanced to the semifinals of the $25,000 Marlboro open ten nis championships today in sharply played matches at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

title: Muskie Charges Pressure By Wall Street on Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) Senator Edmund S. Muskie charged today that some secur ities industry representatives applied pressure to force a de lay in a Senate subcommittee's scheduled action on proposed legislation for investor protec tion.

title: To Each His Own: Pants Legs'
description: They may be castigated as male chauvinist pigs, but New York's fashionliberated men cannot be called sheep when it comes to trouser lengths.

title: Negro Reformatory Chief Named to Head Ohio Prison
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 231 (UPI)  Bennett Cooper, 491 years old, superintendent of the State Reformatory at Mansfield, today was appointed Ohio Cor rections Commissioner. He be comes the highest ranking Negro prison official in the nation.

title: SovietAmerican Policemen
description: The White House suggestion that American and Soviet troops might join in United Nations peace keeping operations in the Middle East, after an Arab Israeli settlement, is an imaginative contribution bringing that settlement about.

title: Arturo G. Ramirez, Editor And Translator at the A.P.
description: Arturo G. Ramirez, a Cuban editor and drama critic who had fled the Castro regime, died yesterday at Jamaica Hos pital in Queens, after he had suffered a heart attack in his home at 8364 Talbot Street, Kew Gardens. He was 62 years old.

title: HEROIN RING SUSPECT IS SEIZED IN MADRID
description: A fourth suspect in an inter national heroinsmuggling ring that authorities said did busi ness exceeding half a billion dollars a year in street sales was seized yesterday by the po lice in Madrid.

title: Theo Sarapo, Singer, Dies; Was Husband of Edith Piaf
description: LIMOGES, France, Aug. 28 (UPI)Theo Sarapo, the last husband of Edith Piaf, died to day after an auto accident in Limoges. Four other persons in his car were injured.

title: Evans Clark, Writer, Is Dead; Director of 20th Century Fund
description: Evans Clark, writer on social issues and economic problems, died yesterday in Nyon, Switz erland. He was 82 years old.

title: FLORA SHORE
description: Flora Shore, administrative assistant in guidance at Mid wood High School, Brooklyn, until her retirement last June, died Aug. 20 in Zurich, Switzer land. She was 69 years old and lived at 75 Henry Street, Brook

title: Hickel to Spur Plan for Green Belts in City Streets
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 28 (AP)Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Rickel announced today a program to help cities across the na tion set aside streets in heavily populated, lowin come areas for a green belt closed to traffic.

title: Maryland to Monitor Air
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md. Aug. 28 (AP)Gov. Marvin Mandel said today that Maryland had contracted with Litton Sys tems, Inc:, of California for an air pollution monitoring sys tem. The system, to cost $450,000, will.consist of eight sampling stations around the state: Data will be transmitted by telephone lines to a central receiving station.

title: COLLINS GETS LIFE IN KILLING OF COED
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Aug. 28 (AP)  John Norman Collins publicly proclaimed his in nocence for the first time today just before he was sentenced to life imprisonment on a con viction of killing an Eastern Michigan University Coed.

title: Wallace Leaves Hospital
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 28 (AP)Former Gov. George C. Wallace has returned to his home in Montgomery after minor surgery at a Birmingham hospital. The Democratic gov ernship nominee had a growth removed from his left eye last Saturday.

title: 8 Blacks Defy Syracuse Edict And Are Dropped From Squad
description: Eight of Syracuse Univer sity's 10 black football players were suspended for the season yesterday when they did not appear at the first preseason practice at 9 A.M.

title: LYNN CAPTURES TAYLOR TROPHY
description: NOROTON, Conn., Aug. 28American Yacht Club of Rye, N. Y., represented by William H. Lynn Jr. as skipper, won two straight races off Noroton Y. C. today to defeat Seawan hakaCorinthian Y.C. of Oyster L. L, 3 races to 1, in the final round of the fifth annual Long Island Sound interclub matchrace championship re gatta. Lynn and the Seawan haka skipper, Herbert Gum precht, each had won once when the threeoffiverace final series for the William H. Taylor Tro phy began yesterday.

title: ALLAN SHELDEN 4th
description: Allan Shelden 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Shelden 3d of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich., died on Tuesday of cancer at the Harkness Pavilion of the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 25 years old.

title: Mauriac Seriously Ill
description: PARIS, Aug. 28  Francois Mauriac, the novelist, was re ported to be in serious condi tion today at a hospital. Family sources said the health of the Nobel Prize laureate in literature was cause for serious cern but that his condition re mained stationary. Mr. Mauriac who is 84 years old, broke his right shoulder in a fall last April and has never completely recovered. He entered the hos pital Iast Sunday.

title: SENATE PANEL BACKS FARM SUBSIDY LIMIT
description: WASHINGTON Aug. 28 (UPI) The Senate Agriculture Committee approved today threeyear farm support bill, including a $55,000acrop limit on subsidies to big farmers growing cotton, wheat and feed grains.

title: India Curbs Catholic Priest For Investigations on Nuns
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 28 (Reu ters)  The Indian authorities have impounded the passport of the Rev. Cyriac Puthenpura, a Roman Catholic priest involved in sending Indian girls to be come nuns in European con vents, it was announced today.

title: JOHN F. A. DAVIS
description: HINGHAM, Mass., Aug. 28John F. A. Davis, founder and chairman of the board of the American Sandpaper Company in Rockland, died Wednesday at his home here. He was 73 years old.

title: A Clarification
description: The Union Pacific Railroad has named John C. Kenefick chief executive officer of its Transportation Division. Mr. Kenefick is executive vice president of the railroad. In yesteday's New York Times it was stated Mr. Kenefick had been named chief executive of ficer of the railroad. That po sition is held by Frank E. Bar nett, chairman of the board.

title: Dave Hill Fails to Sign Card and Is Disqualified
description: CLIFTON, N.J., Aug. 28Dave Hill, runnerup for the United States Open title in June and winner of the Var don Trophy last year, went out of the Dow Jones open tournament at the Upper Montclair Country Club to day on a double count.

title: Agnew Tells Cambodians U.S. Won't Send Troops
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia Aug. 28Vice President Agnew told Premier Lon Nol of Cambodia today that the United States would supply his country with money and arms but would not send American troops to her defense.

title: CAPITAL GIRL NAMED MISS BLACK AMERICA
description: Stephanie M. Clark, 19 years old, of Washington, won the Miss Black America beauty pageant at Madison Square Gar den last night.

title: BREZHNEV URGES ALL TO COOPERATE IN MIDEAST TRUCE
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 28Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Communist party leader, gave strong Soviet back ing today to the current Middle East peace efforts and called on all sides for an honest ob servance of the 90day cease fire agreement.

title: 2 Interceptions and 2 Fumbles Help Redskins Rout Bills, 270
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UPI) Washington's defense came up with two interceptions and two fumble recoveries tonight to help the Redskins post 270 victory over the Buffalo Bills for their third triumph in four preseason contests.

title: Actor's Son Believed Dead
description: YELLOWKNIFE, Northwest Territories, Aug. 28 (AP)The Mounted Police said last night that Timothy Wayne, 22yearold son of the actor David Wayne, is presumed to have drowned while camping near here. An overturned canoe and two life jackets were found in the area where Mr. Wayne and Malcolm Best, :both of West port, Conn., were reported missing Aug. 18.

title: Thursday Night Fights
description: Copenhagen Tom Bogs, 163 pounds, Copenhagen, outpointed Chris Finnegan. 161, Britain. 15 rounds. Bogs retained European middleweight title. Rene Roque, 138, France, and Boerge Krogh, Denmark, 139, draw, 10.

title: U.S. Stand Hurting U.N. Labor Group
description: GENEVA, Aug. 28  The threat of a reduction in Ameri can contributions has forced the International Labor Organiza tion to undertake a severe economy program.

title: Giant Chimney to Ease Pollution
description: A giant chimney matching the height of the Empire State Building is being built by the International Nickel Company of Canada in an effort to curb the pollution problem at its Copper Cliff, Ont., smelter complex.

title: 2 JERSEY POLICEMEN HELD IN EXTORTION
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 28 (AP)Two patrolmen, one of them the president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Associ ation here, were arrested to night and charged with con spiracy and extortion.

title: Bridge:
description: The first stage in the play off matches to determine the American representatives in next year's world champion ship begins today in Phoenix, Ariz. Teams headed by Lew Mathe of Los Angeles and Dr. George Rosenkranz of Mexico City will play a match of 144 deals during the week end.

title: Buckley Honored at Dinner Sponsored by Suffolk G.O.P.
description: SHELTER ISLAND, L. I., Aug. 128James L. Buckley, Con servative candidate for the United States Senate, was the guest of honor here tonight at a dinner given by Suffolk County Republicans.

title: 9 POLICEMEN ADDED TO STAFF BY RUSKIN
description: Robert K. Ruskin, the city's Commissioner of Investigation, said yesterday that nine mem bers of the Police Department had been assigned to his office's investigational staff because of a substantial increase in the work volume over the last year.

title: City Aide Meets Boycotting Doctors
description: Dr. Joseph T. English, presi dent of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, met yes terday with representatives of 27 physicians who are boycott ing Lincoln Hospital in a dis pute with radical community groups.

title: HUDSON ROADWAY UP TO HIGH COURT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP)  The State of New York asked the United States Supreme Court today to over turn a lower court's decision banning construction of the Hudson River Expressway un til Federal approval is obtained for the construction of the dikes and causeway.

title: Forest Fire Is Halted 300 Feet From Village
description: WENATCHEE, Wash., Aug. 28 (AP)A forest fire moved to within 300 feet of the log ging village of Ardenvoir to clay before firefighters halted it with a protective fire line.

title: Books of The Times
description: Thomas McMahon's novel could have been predicted in the way a missing ele ment can be predicted in the periodic table. Virtually all the writing so far about the making of the atomic bomb has empha sized great visions, decisions in high places, complex and ingenious engineering, the clash of intellectual giants and heroic per sonalities. The dramatic possibilities of the task were so numerous and so built into the very grain of the enterprise that surely these stories will be told again and again. Like the discovery of the New World or the opening of the West, their glory will never fade.

title: British Bill Rate Rises
description: LONDON, Aug. 28 (Reuters) The average rate at today's tender of Treasury bills rose to 6.815 per cent from 6.812 per cent last week. This week's 250million offer of 91day bills met applications of 331 85million.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: U.S. COMPLETES SWIMMING ROUT
description: TURIN, Italy, Aug. 28 (AP)American swimmers made clean sweep of the five gold medals at stake in the World University Games today, bring ing their total to 13 in the threedayold competition.

title: Metroliner Crash in Station Hurts 10
description: At least 10 persons were in jured last night when a Penn Central Metroliner from Wash ington more than three hours behind schedule, hit the back, of another train in Pennsylvania Station.

title: New Books
description: A Winter in the Hills, by John Wain (Viking, $6.95). A loner's efforts to keep from becoming involved in a university town's affairs.

title: Paterson Landmark Burns
description: PATTERSON, N.J., Aug. 28 (AP)St. Ann's Roman Catho lic Church, a golddomed land mark here for 48 years was destroyed by fire early today.

title: FALCO USES COLORS TO SPARK DANCERS
description: Probably the chief merit of Louis Falco's choreography at this point in his career is the opportunity it affords us to see him and his superbly disci plined company. While it is modified pleasure, it is not one to be lightly dismissed. Last night at the New York Dance Festival in Central Park's Dela corte Theater, his company offered Huescape and Ca viar.

title: King Resources Is Sued For Defaulting on Note
description: The financial difficulties of the King Resources Company of Denver deepened further yes terday as the Delafield Capital Corporation of New York filed suit against the company on charges of default on a $2mil lion note due more than two weeks ago.

title: Street Cafe Lingerers Warned on Pollution
description: The City Department of Air Resources warned yesterday that all person with heart or respiratory illnesses should avoid spending long periods at sidewalk cafes.

title: Gretel II Wins 4th Straight Race, Gaining Role as America's Cup Challenger
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 28As expected, Gretel II of Aus tralia completed a 40 sweep of France today and became, the 21st America's Cup chal lenger,

title: PRESIDENT AGREES TO YEAR'S TESTING OF WELFARE PLAN
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug 28President Nixon agreed to day to allow a year of field tests of the proposed Family Assistance Program before it would go into full operation.

title: 2D NASA CONTRACT TO G.E. DISPUTED
Manson Trial Is Told Mrs. LaBianca Was Stabbed 41 Times
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 28A Los Angeles County deputy medical examiner testified to day at the murder trial of Charles M. Manson that Mrs. Rosemary LaBianca had been stabbed 41 times.

title: ExecutionerPass Catcher Entry Is 35 Choice in $130,950 Hopeful at Spa
Czechoslovak Leader Asserts Crisis Is Over, Outlook Is Good
description: PRAGUE, Aug. 28 (Reuters)The Czechoslovak Communist party leader, Gustav Husak, de clared today that the nation's crisis was over that a blood bath had been avoided, and that the outlook was good.

title: Lloyd's of London Lists 67 Loss of $3.84Million
description: LONDON, Aug. 28Lloyd's of London reported today that it lost $3.84million in 1967, the third consecutive underwriting year to close with a negative balance. Results for 1968 and 1969, for which accounts are not yet closed, should be more favorable, a spokesman said.

title: Iowa Trapshooter Captures Grand American Handicap
description: VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 28 (UPI)Charles Harvey a 30yearold salesman from Oska loosa, Iowa, defeated four other marksmen today in a shootoff and captured the coveted Grand American Handicap at the 71st Grand American trapshoot.

title: Two Ballplayers Buy Minneapolis Concern
description: Bob Allison and Harmon Killebrew of the Minnesota Twins announced yesterday that they had acquired C. R. Canfield & Co., a Minne apolisbased pharmaceutical concern.

title: HOGAN ACTS TO GET AUTHORITY ON ITKIN
description: District Attorney Frank S. Hogan moved yesterday in the United States Court of Appeals to overturn a lower court de cision holding that his office could not prosecute three in dictments involving Herbert Itkin, the Government informer.

title: FIVE ARE INDICTED IN BRONX BOMBING
description: A grand jury yesterday in dicted five Bronx men accused of the firebombing last month of a house inhabited by a wo man and her nine children.

title: Britain Bars Departure Of 4th Charter Flight
description: LONDON, Aug. 28 (AP)Hundreds of travelers have been stranded in London lately by a British Govern ment crackdown on what it has considered illegal charter flights.

title: New Chief Maps Plan For Pennsy
description: Question. You have said you expect to have the Penn Central making money within four or five years, possibly soon er. What are you going to do to accom plish this that your predecessors haven't already done? What are your plans?

title: Fair Ousts Prize Sculpture
description: ST. PAUL, Aug. 29 (AP)A sculpture that included an American flag with a dynamite box, a Molotov cocktail and a red flag was removed Thurs day from an exhibition preview at the Minnesota State Fair. The work, entitled The Spirit of '76, was given an honor able mention by judges of the art show.

title: Hulk Burns Daily To Train Seamen
description: BAYONNE, N. J., Aug. 29 Five days a week, billows of black smoke rise above the deck and bright red flames lick out of hatches and doors of the motor ship Fire Oueen.

title: The IPL Has Risen From the Ashes
description: THE International Piano Library was founded in 1966 to preserve, re produce and dissemi nate important historical piano recordings. Building its collection slowly after one or two sizable acquisitions, the IPL seemed a year ago on sure if modest footing. Im portant recordings were re leased (available to members only) which were of sufficient interest to warrant reviews in these pages over the years  rare recordings of Josef Hofmann, Ferruccio Busoni, Leopold Godowsky.

title: Judge Rejects Prison Suit
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 29 (AP)A Federal judge ruled yesterday that inmates of the United States penitentiary here did not have a constitutional right to minimum wages or Social Secu rity benefits. District Court Judge Albert E. Henderson Jr. said the inmates are not being denied any constitutional rights by receiving a nominal stipend for their work for prison in dustries.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Foreign Minister Thanat Khoman of Thai land, talking to newsmen yesterday after two days of meetings with Vice President Agnew, said he had been assured by Mr. Agnew that the Nixon Administration would do everything in its power to keep critics of its war policies from blocking American aid to Southeast Asian nations. In an ap parent allusion to doves in the United States Senate, he said, there are certain elements which would like nothing better than to push Southeast Asia into Communist hands. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Do you know what America is all about?
description: This book tells it like it was. And like it can be again!

title: Senate, Mansfield Tells Nixon, Will Act on Welfare This Year
description: WASHINGTON. Aug. 29 (AP) Mike Mansfield, the Senate majority leader, assured Presi dent Nixon today that the Senate would consider the Ad ministration's welfare reform plan before it quits this year.

title: Why France Fell
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 29Baron Bich's America's Cup challenge went to the guillo tine yesterday when he found himself lost in the fog in the fourth race between his France and the Australian boat Gretel II. The Baron was beautifully dressed for the execution and his sarto rial elegance prompted Jim Hardy's brother Tom to shout over to the skipper of Gretel II, Where are your gloves, Jim? just before the start.

description: TodayAmerican Hot Rod As sociation summer national drag racing finals at New York Na tional Speedway, Center Mor iches, L. I., postponed from last Sunday. 2 P.M.

title: Miss Zinsser, S. P. Armington Are Wed Here
description: Miss Katherine J. Zinsser was married here at noon yesterday to Stephen P. Arm ington.The Rev. Dr. Peter Denny of the First Unitarian Church in Beverly, Mass., performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's father and step mother, Dr. and Mrs. Hans H. Zinsser of 242 East 62d Street.

title: Influx of Soviet Weapons For Egyptians Reported
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 29There has been a surge in Soviet deliveries of weapons to the United Arab Republic in recent weeks, according to informa tion reaching here from author itative sources in Cairo.

title: Life in a City Cellar Ages a Single Girl
F. J. EMMERICH, 78, AN INDUSTRIALIST
description: HARRISON, N. Y., Aug. 29Frederick J. Emmerich, retired board chairman of the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation, died after a heart attack today at his home on Sunny Ridge Road. He was 78 years old.

title: Dr. Van Courtlandt Elliott, Classicist, Dies on Vacation
description: Dr. Van Courtlandt Elliott, executive secretary of the Medi eval Academy of America and editor of Speculum, its schol arly publication, died of a heart attack in Orbetello, Italy, Aug. 20, while on vacation. He was 66 years old and lived in Cam bridge, Mass.

title: Football Transactions
description: NATIONAL CONFERENCE LOS ANGELESReleased Jim Thomas, run nine bark.

title: Utility Men Score Con Ed's Failings
description: Many utility executives feel that the Consolidated Edison Company's problems this summer have given the in dustry a black eye.

title: Improvement Seen in Relations Between Nasser and Guerrillas
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 29Highly placed Palestinians said today that relations between the Arab commando leadership and President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Re public had improved markedly in recent days.

title: We'd Better Junk the PastWe'd Better Not
description: ALL nations examine their consciences in the the ater, but it is strange to see two contempo rary British plays doing just that and arriving at exactly contrary mea culpas. Alan Bennett's Forty Years On, which will be wrapping up the 1970 Shaw Festival this week in the charming little town of NiagaraontheLake, Ontario, spends all of its time, or nearly all of its time, be ing extremely high handed, and often very funny, about Britain's dismissable past. Gaily tossing everything from Oscar Wilde through Cham berlain and T. E. Lawrence and Virginia Woolf out the mullioned windows of an up perclass boys school, it raf fishly proclaims its clear mis sion: we are trying to shed the burden of the past. Ev erything prior to this mo ment in history must go, and go ridiculed; clear the decks so that the future can begin.

title: Baby It's Cold Inside
description: It can do no harm to tell it now. At the age of 15, this reviewer fell hopelessly in love with S. J. Perel man. It was from afar, for I was sit tingin Jackson (Miss.) High School, in Cicero class. While the others were studying How long, O Catiline, must we endure your orations? I was taking in 'Gad, Lucy, You're Magnificent! Breathed the Great Painter, drawing and caption by S. J. Perelman, from a copy of Judge on my lap. S. J. Perelman filled the whole copy of that now forgotten magazine every week  drawings, sketches, playlets. I didn't guess he was just a jump ahead of me in school himself at the time. I only knew what any child with a grain of prophecy would knowthat here Was one of the extraordinary wits of our time, who would come to be known, loved and feared by all. Well, it happened, and I didn't have to wait more than a minute.

title: Coins
description: EXHIBITS at the Ameri can Numismatic Asso ciation's convention in St. Louis were the rich est and most varied ever as sembled for this annual show. The spacious Exhibition Hall of the ChasePark Plaza Hotel served as headquarters for this 79th anniversary event and was the major center of attraction.

title: Robb Family Acquires Home Costing $59,500
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE. Va., Aug. 29 (AP)Mr. and Mrs. Charles Robb have moved into a $59,500 home near the University of Virginia, where Mr. Robb will attend law school this fall.

title: Plan for National Health Insurance
description: WASHINGTON  The United States is the only major nation that does not have some type of governmentdirected national health insurance system.

title: Kent State Plans to Honor Rollins, Michael, Munson
description: Kent State will honor its three American League players prior to the YankeeIndian game in Cleveland, Sept. 13.

title: U.S. Joins Salonika Fair, First Time in Five Years
description: ATHENS, Aug. 29  The United States has joined 19 other national exhibitors at the Salonika Fair, which opened to day. The American exhibit, the first in Salonika in five years, centers on the Apollo moon lendings. It includes one of the space suits used, a piece of moon rock and models of the lunar vehicles.

title: Lemmings Are on the Road
description: OSLO, Norway, Aug. 29 (AP)Roadsweeping machines were used today to clear roads in northern Norway of thousands of lemmings. The lemmings were so thick on the roads that vehicles were skidding on the animals bodies.

title: Bridal Held for Constance Dever
description: RIDGEWOOD, N. J., Aug. 29  Miss Constance Ann Dever and Douglas Alan Motz were married here this morn ing in Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church by the bride's cousin, the Rev. Anthony Wallace, who also cocelebrated the nuptial mass with the Rev. Mario Costa.

title: U.S. Swimmers Break FreeStyle Relay Mark
description: TOKYO, Aug. 29 (AP)An American 800meter free style relay team broke the world record with a time of 7 minutes 48 seconds in an ex hibition race at the allJapan swimming championships to day.

title: Blacks Get Equal Rights Even in Death
description: WASHINGTONThe Ameri can way of death has always included a considerable meas ure of racial segregation. Yet a ripple of indignation spread across the country last week when a black soldier killed in Vietnam was denied burial in a Caucasianonly Florida ceme tery.

title: Edward G. Gross, 58, Dies; Copy Editor on The Times
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 29 Edward G. Gross, a sports copy editor of The New York Times, died today in the Stam ford railroad station, apparently of a heart attack. He was 58 years old.

title: The Synthetic Hotfoot
description: The artificial turf on the infield of Cincinnati's new stadium gives the base runners more trac tion, Bench says. How ever, the synthetic grass has an appalling capac ity for holding the heat: The temperature of the outfield turf in Cincinnati was 134 degrees just above the surface and 160 degrees on it during one typical day game. (This quality was never discerned during the five years artificial turf has been used in the Houston Astrodome because the field is enclosed and airconditioned.) The turf's heatholding prop erty has not escaped Bench's expertise: He says that, since many of the great base runners in the league are outfield ers, they will have to stand through double headers in intense heat, their feet will sweat and swell and they will be even less inclined to try to steal bases against Bench's powerful right arm.W.B.F.

title: Dr. Ralph W. Sockman Is Dead; Preached on Air for 34 Years
description: The Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sock man, pastor emeritus of Christ Church, Methodist, died yester day in his home at 830 Park Avenue.

title: Miss Anne Purvis Bailey Wed To Stephen Hapgood Walters
description: WILTON, Conn., Aug. 29Miss Anne Purvis Bailey was married here today in the Wilton Congregational Church to Stephen Hapgood Waters. The Rev. William T. Joyner performed the ceremony.

Drummond of Darien. The ceremony was performed in St. Paul's Episcopal Church by the Rev. H. Arthur Lane Jr.

title: Mideast 2: For Israel The Goal Is Secure Future

Fot three years, politicians and citi zens have said they longed for the chance to negotiate a peace settlement with the neighboring Arab states. Now the chance is at hand, and no one seems to know how to cope with it.

description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 29  Babe Parilli, the New York Jets 40yearold reserve quar terback who was in danger of being cut from the squad, an nounced his retirement today as the Jets prepared to meet the Minnesota Vikings here to morrow night.

description: TodayAt Houston. TomorrowAt. St. Louis (n). TuesdayAt St. Louis (n). WednesdayAt St. Louis (n) ThursdayAt St. Louis. FridayAt Chicago. SaturdayAt Chicago.

title: Television
description: THE excitement and fun of an oldfashioned election night is not quite dead after all. A rare opportunity to see how a political contest might be reported on television without the presence of so norous talking heads and projections that take inter est out of the event recently came along in the first Con necticut state primaries. Nev er have the methods of the preelectronic era in politics seemed so bright and fresh on TV.

description: FREEHOLD, N. J., Aug. 29Jacqueline Coard is a pretty English girl of 23, already knowledgeable about the many phases of harness racing and training, who is over here on a sixmonth visa to learn all she can about the American way of doine things.

title: G.O.P. in New Hampshire Faces Strong Conservative Challenge

description: MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 29The right of 15 welfare families to make their homes in the former barracks building at Mitchel Piela IN scheduled to be tested in court next week.

description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 29 (Reuters)  Craig Stadler, 17, years old, of La Jolla, Calif., won the third annual world junior golf championship today, by five strokes.

description: SEQUOIA NATIONAL PARK, Calif., Aug. 29 (AP)Mount Whitney, the second tallest mountain in the nation, is gain ing a dubious reputation as America's highest trash can.

The ceremony, writ ten by the couple, was per formed outdoors before a large boulder by the Rev. Dr. Donald S. Harrington of the Community Church of New York, Unitarian Universalist.

These cups float in wa ter and do not break up or dis integrate, said Capt. Charles B. Bishop, commander of the Naval Undersea Research and Development Center, in an or der banning the cups.

description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Aug. 29 (Agence FrancePresse)Cambodia is planning to drop French as a foreign language in primary schools and to place more emphasis on English.

title: The Big Trek to the Great Smokies
description: GATLINBURG, Tenn.Great Smoky Mountains National Park, which spans the crest of the Appalachians between Tennessee and North Carolina, has con sistently led the nation's 33 national Parks in attendance figures. This sum mer has been no different: In July alone 1.33 million people were counted, and the sevenmonth total through July 31 was 3.68 million.

title: On Plant Collecting
description: PLANT collecting as a science goes back to the 16th century. It was about 1530 that Luca Ghini of the Univer sity of Bologna found that plants dried under pressure and mounted on heavy paper could be preserved almost indefinitely. His methods soon became popular and within a few years had soread throughout Europe. Herbaria as collections of such dried plants are called, were established in univer sities and botanical museums. Some of the early herbariums still survive. An example in this country is the western flora brought back by Lewis and Clark in 1806. It still is in a good state of preserva tion at the Academy of Nat ural Sciences in Philadelphia.

title: McLain Apologizes to Reporter, But Is Angered at Suspension
description: DETROIT, Aug. 29 (AP)Denny McLain entered the sec ond day of his latest suspension today having pologized to one of his icewater victims but still angered at the action taken by the Detroit Tigers general manager, Jim Campbell.

title: FORDHAM TO FACE 8 FOOTBALL FOES
description: Fordham's athletic director, Peter A. Carlesimo, has an nounced that the Ram varsity football team  the first in 16 yearswill have an eightgame schedule this fall.

title: POLITICS TO BESTIR UNION CONVENTION

title: Gen. Alfred G. Tuckerman Dies; Commanded the 77th Division
description: Maj. Gen. Alfred G. Tucker man of the Army Reserve, a management consultant and former president of the Na tional Horse Show, died yes terday at his home. He was 68 years old and lived at 125 East 74th Street.

title: NEW SOVIET BOOK TRACES U.S. TIES
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 29Lyud mila A. Gvishiani, the daughter of Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin, asserts in a book just published that United States policy in Vietnam had its roots in the early American relations with the Soviet State.

title: BlAck G.I. Buried in White Cemetery
description: FORT PIERCE, Fla., Aug. 29A black soldier who died in Vietnam and lay in a cof fin while lawyers battled over his funeral was buried in an allwhite cemetery to day as some white grave owners threatened to remove their relatives bodies.

title: Management Advice Sought Here by Japan
description: A leading figure in Japan's mass communications field joined with the American Management Association last week to speed the process of introducing western man agement techniques to his country.

title: Miss Lacoste Wed to Chilean

title: Caddie mould Have Been Proud
description: ON JULY 4, 1970, I participated in the dedication of the Caddie Woodlawn Memorial Park in western Wisconsin. The park is a sixacre tract that was formerly a part of the 160acre home stead of my greatgrandfather, John V. Woodhouse. It is located on State Route 25 about 12 miles south of Menomonie, four miles from Downsville and near the site of what was formerly the town of Dunnville.

title: CITY GIVES REPORT ON A.D.C, WELFARE

title: Irrational Backlash
description: Edward F. Zigler, the new director of Project Head Start, has criticized the program's policy of excluding the majority of middleclass youngsters. It is easy to sympathize with his view that we can't continue to send poor kids to one place and rich kids to an other without aggravating polarization along racial and class lines. If the goal of education is to bring together children of diverse backgrounds, an ideal system would make preschool education available to all children whose parents seek it for them.

title: TeenAger Pierces When 49ers Cut
description: Mark McFadden will be busy tomorrow. Mark, the 18yearold son of George Mc Fadden, public relations di rector of the San Francisco 43ers, has been a staff assist ant at the team training camp since he was 15. Mark is a hard worker and is popular with the players, except on Mondays between 8 and 9 A.M. That is the usual time when the players who have been cut are notified. Mark is the one who notifies. I knock on their doors and say, Coach Nolan wants to sec you. And bring your play book. That's all I say, but they know what it means. The players call me the As sassin, Hatchet Man, Hinshu, Terrible Turk.

title: American Notebook
description: Anyone who can keep his ear tuned amidst the trumpet ings of the publishers fall an nouncements may discern an optimistic tune running through the ruffles and flourishes. It is axiomatic, of course, that each new season is officially the best ever; still an objective observer can defend the propo sition that there are an unusu ally large number of books worth looking forward to be tween now and Christmas. At the center of this optimism is the fact that there are a hand ful of blockbuster books scheduled  books of impor tance, impact, even literary merit.

title: Music
description: THIS is a family newspaper, and certain matters need be approach ed only with the greatest of de licacy. Especially is this true when the writer happens to be so unworldly and innocent a person as the conductor of this column. He lives surrounded by books, immersed in music, floating embryolike in his quiet world, altogether inexperienced in the ways of man. Thus it was with Sir Thomas Burton, who in his Anatomy of Melancholy (Part III, Sect. II, Mem. II, Subs. IV, in the chapter entitled Artificial Allurements) listed certain sexual habits before abandoning the field in fright. But what, he wrote, have I to do with this?

title: Education
description: Old historical myths die hard. The authority of books and theories studied by generations of students and teachers is dif ficult to shake and revise. It is only when past misstatements and omissions become a politi cal issue that effective revision has any chance at all. The most striking case in point is the treatment of the Negro past in American history.

title: Small Help From Some Allied Troops in Vietnam
description: SAIGON  The security sit uation in Lainghi hamlet has de teriorated seriously since the withdrawal of its Revolutionary Development team and Popular Force platoon. With the excep tion of eight Popular SelfDe fense cadrethere are no forces whatsoever in this hamlet at night. Although the hamlet is situated immediately in front of the ROK [Republic of Korea] battalion access road and com pound, the Koreans apparently contribute nothing to the ham let's security.

The ministers represented Syria. Egypt, Irag, Jurdan. ?? kuwait and Saudi Arabia.

title: U.N. GROUP URGES ANTICRIME PLANS
description: KYOTO, Japan, Aug. 26Defense against crime should be an integral part of national planning, a United Nations congress on crime prevention has concluded.

title: When hatred was turning to pity
description: Negro is the most ambitious anthology on blacks ever attempted. It covers practically every aspect of black life: history, literature, educa tion, law, racial injustice, theater, art and music. It examines not only black life in the United States, but also in the West Indies, South Amer ica, Europe and Africa. At the time when the book first appeared, 1934, the inferiority of blacks was still an unquestioned assumption among whites, except for a small minority of artists and intellectuals. Nancy Cunard was one of the latter, and her purpose in compiling, editing and publishing this anthology at her own expense was to prove that there was no superior race, merely cultural differences, that racism has no basis whatsoever. The result is a book that is unashamedly didactic and, in great part, polemical, expos ing the persecution of blacks through reportage on chain gangs, lynchings and the case of the Scottsboro boys, and proving the equality of blacks through essays on their intellectual and artistic accomplishments. It is a book that was valuable and neces sary for its time. Today it is a histor ical artifact, but a fascinating one.

title: Golf Battle of Sexes Listed Tuesday

description: I have remarked that the English have made murder in academia their special fictional province. Even more truly Eng lish is death in a preparatory school setting, from, for ex ample, James Hilton's only contribution to our genre, Mur der in School (originally pub lished as by Glen Trevor, 1931 and, two years later, as Was It Murder? in the U.S.), to the present A TERRIBLE THING HAS HAPPENED TO MISS DU PONT (McCall, $4.50) by Polly Hobson.

description: PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 29Three persons have been ar rested on gunlaw violations after an arsenal was uncovered in a raid on White Panther headquarters here, the police said today.

title: Through Ireland On Pat Donegan's Trail: The GreatUncle Hunt
description: BOTH MY. MOTHER, Anne Patricia, and I were named for my greatuncle on my mother's side, Patrick Donegan. His name was one of the few solid things I knew about him. Family legend and lore had over the years also added these possibilities: He was a big bluff typical Irishman who emigrated to New York City to join his three sisters some time before World War I. At one point he worked in a grocery store in upper Man hattan. In the early 1920's his brother John died and reluctantly he returned to work the family farm somewhere in County Sligo, northwestern Ireland.

title: YOU DON'T HAVE TO BE IRISH..
description: The following tips on how to find a longlost relative abroad are based on our experience as well as on a talk with Mrs. Frances Hoffman, director of the Academy of Genealogy, who has over the past 20 years helped hundreds of Americans to locate kin overseas.

title: Protest March by Homosexuals Sparks Disturbance in  Village
description: Several hundred youths roamed through Greenwich Village streets last night and early this morning after a demonstration by homosexual organizations ended. They smashed windows in at feast two, stores, set several minor fires and overturned two auto mobiles.

title: DIVISION LEADER WINS 5TH IN ROW
description: LONDON, Aug. 29 (Reuters) Leeds United defeated Burn ley, 30, today to register its fifth successive victory and maintain its 2point lead in the English Soccer League First Division.

title: A New Car Ferry With a Difference
description: PORTLAND, Me.  A new sea route links this Down East port with Yar mouth, Nova Scotia. The Prince of Fun dy, a 387foot car and truck ferry, com bines its working schedule with many of the pleasures of an international cruise ship  smorgasbord, live music even a small casino.

title: J. M. Barrie
description: A new fullkale biography of Sir James Barrie? There can hardly be said to be any very pressing need for one. Peter Pan still flourishes, In London at least, as part of the an nual Christmas ritual, but Barrie's other plays are little more than a fading memory, while his novels have dwindled to a footnote in literary history. Nor, despite his rise from a weaver's cottage to West End fame and affluence, were the outward events of his career particularly dramatic.

description: ASPEN, Colo., Aug. 29The prevailing mood in the West is clearly conservative, but here, as elsewhere, thoughtful men and women are challenging many of the popular assump tions that have long been taken for granted in America.

title: For the Right to Wear Our Hair Long
description: IF there is one thing we are all agreed on today, it is that, we are agreed on nothing: the nation is united only in the belief that the nation is disunited. The words Establishment and AntiEstab lishment may not sum it all up, but they come as near to doing so as any such dualities of former times ever didRed and White in Russia, Northerner and Southerner in this country, Roundhead and Cavalier in Britain. And it is time to see the problems of theater art, not merely in the terms of Broadway and Off, or even Offoff, terms which tend to triviality, but in the larger and more dynamic context of a general socral conflict, namely, the total national destiny.

title: Pop
description: ONSTAGEFEBRUARY, 1970: Elvis Presley (RCA Victor LSP4632). Wow, talk about the wheel of fortune. Imagine, if you can, Elvis Presley croon ing Lennon & McCartney's Yesterday. Or how about Creedence Clearwater Reviv al's Proud Mary. Skeptical? Well, they're both here, both overdone, and both misunder stood by the Memphis Bull of the fifties. Presley still sings better than most of his imitators, but the insistence upon presenting him with the kind of overstaged accom paniments that might be ap propriate to a Las Vegas pro duction of the Old Testament isn't exactly the best way I can think of to showcase his skills.

title: Megg Carleton Picoli Bride on L. I.

However, each of them, in its own way, suggests that competence without creativity is an ar tistic dead end.

Then you look past the hair and the bushy sideburns that drop below the ears, look into the locker, and you see the burgundy shirt hanging next to the striped bellbottom slacks, the pink stripes and the lavender stripes, the green and the orange.

title: Black, Star Apprentice Jockey, Nephew of Boulmetis, ExRider

title: Who is the victim, who is the executioner?; The Three Trials Of Manirema; By Jose J. Veiga. Translated by Pamela G. Bird. 154 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $4.95.; The Misplaced Machine
description: Manirema is one of those sleepy towns in the heart of Brazil where nothing ever hap pens, where everybody knows everybody and reality goes through monotonous cycles. But one night, on the outskirts of the town, the inhabitants hear the arrival of a band of invaders. They are strangers who plant their tents and make no effort to establish contact with the townspeople. The in vasion hardly affects the stag nant surface of the town or the lazy curiosity of its inhabi tants. But little by little, the foreigners begin to make their increasingly ominous presence felt. They impose little tasks upon some of the workers, threaten those who don't obey immediately with unspecified punishments, let loose their dogs and their cattle upon the town, and finally they kidnap and rape a girl. Very few of the inhabitants resist, none of them understand what's hap pening. Until one good day the invaders leave, as mysterious ly as they arrived.

description: CLIFFSIDE PARK, N. J., Aug. 29Miss Donna Marie Burgers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. title: Search for Clean Car, Page 10
description: There are some 90 million automobiles in the United States, and with few excep tions they run on internal combustion engines fueled by gasoline. They are the larg est single cause of air pollu tion, For that reason, among student engineers and gov ernment and even some in dustry researchers there is a move to see if the exceptions could become the rule.

description: BARCELONA  When you walk along the streets of this Catalan metropolis, they suddenly leap out at youastonishing, bizarre, often shocking. They are the archi tectural creations of the controversial genius Gaudi, and they have become for Barcelona what the Eiffel Tower is for Paris and the Statue of Liberty is for New York.

title: The Environment
description: The question on the dozen college campuses I visited last April was: Is the environmental crisis merely a fad? Not only students were asking; academia reflected the national un certainty and exacerbation, Congress was swamped with antipollution bills, the Executive grappling with a traumatic reorganization of environ mental bureaus, the public reluctant ly facing one more category of taxes, spending, restriction and conflict. Then suddenlyschool was out. The killing at Kent and the war in Cam bodia cooled the issue overnight. In dustry came out of its P.R. bunkers. Maybe the crisis was, as Ramparts charged, a flash in the pan engi neered by Senator Gaylord Nelson with the collusion of statusquo seekers.

title: Consumer Still Reluctant Despite Uptrend
description: Economists can make a good case for business re covery with the slowing down of inflation, increase in exports, a drop in whole sale prices and an increase in manufacturing orders. But they have yet to receive a favorable signal from the consumer segment.

title: Dance
description: OF THE live performing arts, only dance seems to have a future; pov erty stricken, true, but still a future. Its creativity is flourishing and good tech ticians are legion; any corps girl can dance rings around primas of but a generation ago. Live music, in the form of rock, is certainly active, but the audience is a bare percentage of the record con sumers, and concert attend ance is based on recording popularity. Opera is dead save for occasional postmor tal twitches. Theater has been done in by film, finally; when television took the movies place as the purveyor of me diocre entertainment, film ex panded in boldness and es thetic experimentation and is now the medium of drama.

description: DANANG, South Vietnam, Sunday, Aug. 30 (AP)  Pvt. Randell D. Herrod of the United States Marines was acquitted today of murder in the deaths of 16 South Vietnamese women and children.

title: That Ray alone killed him

title: Enid Bagnold's Autobiography
description: Almost everyone's childhood is boringexcept one's own and Enid Bagnold's. At 80, she has written a splendid memoir, which seethes with a fledgling's energy, lunging back and forth among the decades. As a small girl, the future author of Serena Blandish, National Vel vet, The Loved and Envied and eight plays, including The Chalk Garden and The Chinese Prime Minister, was tropically over developed by early years in Jamai ca, rowdy with health. Descended from sea captains, with a greatuncle Who saw flying saucers, she hated church, which made her howl like a dog. Still, I rested my teeth on the wood of the pew in front as I knelt and prayed: God, make me famous.  In her teens, she nearly murdered a German headmistress who accused her of lifting a leg to attract men.

title: 224 Hours In Space
description: THE Soviet Union, which launched the first un manned earth satellite on October 4, 1957, and issued a stamp to com memorate the event, and which has issued more than 160 stamps honoring its as tronauts and their accomp lishments, has added another stamp to the seriesthis one (shown at right, above) is for the flight of Suyoz 9, July 1 19, 1970. It is inscribed (in Russian) 424 Hours in Orbit Around the Earth.

title: Deadly Math Behind the Missile Race
description: WASHINGTON  Phase II of the United StatesSoviet Stra tegic Arms Limitation Talks (SALT) has ended at Vienna but the missile race continues. Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird announced last week that a new multiple warhead devel opment was observed northwest of Midway Island. The Soviet SS11 ballistic missile, a liquid fuel version of the American Minuteman, splashed down three warheads in the Pacific.

title: American Party Acts to Get A Candidate in Connecticut
description: NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 29 The American party, which hacked George Wallace in the last Presidential campaign, is circulating petitions to place. Mrs. Eileen Emard, a local housewife active in conserva tive causes, on the ballot for the race for the rourth Con gressional District seat.

title: MARCOS TO BE HOST TO PONTIFF IN FALL

title: Afghanistan Aided in Inquiry Into Slaying of U.S. Nurse
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Aug. 29 (UPI)An American detective arrived from New Delhi today to help the police investigate the slaying of a 35yearold Pennsylvania nurse whose body was found in her home last Monday.

title: RUBY QUALIFIES FOR ONTARIO RACE
description: ONTARIO, Calif., Aug. 29 (AP)Lloyd Ruby staked an early claim to the California 500 pole position today when he flashed a 10mile average of 177.567 miles an hour as two days of qualifying opened for the Sept. 6 race.

title: Twentyfive years ago
description: TWO wars and 100,000 American lives ago, we thought the occu pation of Japan was gleaming like a star In an ugly sky of politics. Goliath had slain David, and now he was redeeming his soul. It was a heyday for nearly amillion Americans on and off, lasting from Aug. 28, 1945, when the advance party of 150 menfor whom I was interpreterlanded, 22 days after the dropping of the atom bomb over Hiroshima, until April, 1952, when the peace treaty was signed.Those six years and eight months of ours cost the Japanese a hefty $490million, for they were required in 1962 to reimburse us for our expenses in salaries, housing, transportation, food and facilities during that time. (Originally, we asked for $1.8billion.)

title: Who Makes Music
description: CONCERTS TODAY

title: Article 12  No Title
description: A $1.25million library building that juts from a rocky outcropping on a grassy knoll will be opened next month on the campus of the Fieldston School in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. The building was the last design of the late Eugene Mackey of the St. Louis firm of Murphy a 1 Mackey Architects, and was planned by Dr. Ellsworth Mason, director of library services at Hofstra University, in coopera tion with Fieldston's librarian and faculty. The newTate Library, which can accommodate 350 students, compared with 60 in the old library, is on the west side of the school's quadrangle. It is named for Luther Tate, principal of Fieldston from 1940 until his death in 1967. The exterior is of reinforced concrete faced with fieldstone, and has large expanses of glass, affording views of the campus from almost all parts of the interior. Cuzzi Bros. and Singer of Mt. Vernon served as general contractors.

title: ASHE, RICHEY WIN
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 29The United States won the first two Davis Cup tennis matches from West Germany today without losing a set, and the challenge round appeared headed for another early ending.

title: Germans Get Esso Ship Pact
description: BREMEN, West Germany, Aug. 29 (AP)The Weser ship yard announced today it had received a $109.28million con tract to build two tankers for Esso, Inc., of New York. The 250,000deadweightton ships are to be delivered in i973 and 1974. The shipyard has already built 11 tankers for Esso.

title: Landlords Ensnared In Rent Paperwork
description: In a mood of resentment and be wilderment landlords are crowding into dingy city offices at 280 Broadway these days to pick up stacks of new rent forms. The landlords are trying to figure out how to do the complex paper work to get rent increases under the city's new rent control law.

description: THERE'S quite a mess in volved with the stamps of Fujeira, about which we went to some lengths on July 19 when we discussed proliferation of stamp issues.

title: Hunger Doctor in South Carolina Is Fined $500 for Improper Drug Records
description: BEAUFORT, S.C., Aug. 29Dr. Donald Gatch, South Caro lina's hunger doctor, has been fined $500 after pleading guilty to maintaining improper records of drugs dispensed in his office.

title: South Africa's Nonwhites Anger Whites by Cheering Rugby Rivals
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, Aug. 29 (AP)South Af rica's nonwhites think the All Blackswho are not all black are beautiful.

title: 48 Hurt in Riot at Peace Rally on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 29 (AP) Rioting broke out today among 7,000 persons at a MexicanAmerican antiwar rally in East Los Angeles. Demonstra tors burned buildings, smashed store windows and injured policemen.

title: The Isla Vista WarCampus Violence In a Class By Itself
description: ISLA VISTA, Calif.

title: Classifying Marijuana
description: AS the legal and medical controversy over marijuana continues to swirl like sweet, befuddling smoke, American youths continue to be arrested under old laws containing harsh penalties. The nation deserves better answers to the questions about pot. Is it really harmful? Should the law continue to treat it in the same manner as heroin?

title: Golfing Clinic Today
description: The socalled squareto square golf swing, now being advocated by many of the country's top teaching profes sionals, will be explained and demonstrated at 4 this after noon at Aspetuck Valley Coun try Club in Weston, Conn. Dick Aultman, editor of Golf Digest magazine and author of the bopk, The SquaretoSquare Golf Swing: Model Method for the Modern Player, will con duct the clinic. The public is invited.

title: Volunteer Army Doubted
description: SPRINGFIELD, III., Aug. 29 (UPI)The Selective Service director, Dr. Curtis W. Tarr, says there is little chance the country will move to an allvolunteer military force before the end of the Viet nam war. I think it would be prudent not to attempt an allvolunteer force until we have withdrawn all of our forces from Vietnam, he told a news conference yesterday on a brief visit to the Illinois Selec tive Service headquarters here.

title: Charts of Races at Saratoga
Agnew Is Salesman In Asia For Nixon Doctrine
description: BANGKOK, Thailand  Ac cording to an old proverb, After a rainfall, the soil is firm. Thus philosophized Vice President Spiro T. Agnew in one of his airport speeches as he swung through Asia last week. When he said it, at Kimpo Airport in Seoul, South Korea, mud still mottled his green trousers and caked his brown galoshes.

title: Miss Hogan Upsets Mrs. Court
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 29Patti Hogan of La Jolla, Calif., and Bob Carmichael of France registered major upsets, today in the semifinals of the $25,000 Marlboro open tennis championships at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

title: A Fighter for Men's Minds Now Studies Their Brains
description: ARTHUR KOESTLER (Darkness at Noon, The Yogi and the Commissar, The Ghost in the Machine) is 65 this week. In the following interview with him in Paris, the editors of L'Express drew him out on a life spent seeking a universal explanation, a key to every thing Communism in the thirties to harmonizers for man in the seventies. The translation is by Stanley Hochman.

title: Remarkable Calm in South on Integrated Schools
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  On they came, moving along Broad Street without attracting much atten tion, an irregular band of women and children carrying miniature American flags and looking ter ribly selfconscious as they sang God Bless America and On ward, Christian Soldiers. A boy with a bugle puffed out a squeaky version of The Star Spangled Banner, and a matron in purple slacks and green sweat er led the small group in the Pledge of Allegiance.

title: In Brazil's Parched Backlands, Work Projects Keep Families Alive
description: RECIFE, Brazil, Aug. 26Across the gray backlands of northeastern Brazil 392,000 men and boys are digging ditches, clearing brush and building roads by hand to avoid starv ing to death with their fam ilies.

title: Editorial Cartoon 1  No Title
Miners in W ales Despair As Coal Industry Shrinks
description: BARGOED, Wales, Aug. 27 Men in woolen caps sit in the square along the High Street, gazing at the gray and white smoke rising from chimneys in the Rhymney Valley. By midday, the Han bury Arms pub is packed with unemployed miners.

title: Copenhagen's Tamed Barbary Coast
description: COPENHAGEN  The first thing one hears about Nyhavn is that it has changed. Time was when this strip of harbor bars was Copenhagen's Barbary Coast, its London Chinatown, its Hell's Kitchen, heavy on narcotics smuggling and midnight robbery.

title: Cleveland Cuts School Spending by $3.1Million
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 29Faced with a budget deficit of more than $5million, the Cleveland Board of Education has reduced the hours of more than 2,000 nonteaching employes by at least 20 per cent until Dec. 31.

title: Miss Jonsson Wed to Robert Love
description: Miss Margaretha Jonsson and Robert Lee Love were married yesterday afternoon in the Church of Seglora in Stockholm by the Rev. Stefan Andree.

title: Dispute on Ford Plant
description: French Premier Jacques Cha banDelmas is running for a seat in the National Assembly in a byelection in Bordeaux.
