Last week, the Ford Motor Company announced it had chosen Bor deaux as the site for a new fac tory for its European cars. The combination of the two facts produced an uproar on the French political scene.

title: Britons Relaxing on Holiday Amid Signs of Economic Trouble
Is It True What They Say About Orson?
description: ACOUPLE of weeks ago, a wellmeaning book called The Films of Orson Welles was published, and a sympathetic review of it appeared in Newsweek. Both authors wrote glowingly of Welles workthey clearly consider him, and rightly so, among the great American filmmakersyet as a direct result of the two, a wouldbe backer's interest in a Welles movie project cooled, then disappeared. Another, whom he's been wooing for several months, became increasingly reluctant.

title: Wind Tunnels Utilized in New Ways
description: Wind tunnels, long a tool of aerospace companies, have found their way into a maze of new uses.

title: Troops Parade in AlmaAta
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 26 (Reuters) Soviet troops took part to day in a parade in AlmaAta, in the Soviet republic of Ka zakhstan, which is marking its 50th anniversary.

title: Best Seller List
description: GENERAL

title: Barbara McClain Livingston Is Married
description: SUMMIT, N. J., Aug. 29Miss Barbara McClain Living ston and Robert Frederick Howarth Jr., son of Mrs. Fatig Howarth of Newark, Ohio, and Robert Frederick Howarth of Columbus, Ohio., were married here this after noon in Calvary Episcopal Church.

title: British Airline to Have InFlight Secretaries
description: LONDON, Aug. 28 (Reut ers)Secretarial services are to be provided for the travel ing businessmen from Nov. 1 by British United Airways, Britain's largest private air line.

title: Ballads, Blues and Rock Spice a Folk Festival
description: UPPER SALFERD TOWN SHIP, Pa., Aug. 29Folkmusic fanciers were streaming toward a field on a gentle slope near the Perkiomen River yesterday and today to attend the ninth annual Philadelphia Folk Music Festival. The festival, a three day event sponsored by the Philadelphia Folksong Society, began last night at Old Pool Farm, a 100acre plot in the rolling, wooded country mid way between Philadelphia and Reading.

title: Most Foreign Stars to Leave U.S. Golf Tour After Dow Jones
description: CLIFTON, N. J., Aug. 29Most of the foreign golf pro fessionals, who are regularly on the United States circuit, are heading for home or for other golfing areas after the Dow Jones tourney ends here tomorrow.

title: Army Officer Wins Conscientious Objector Discharge Basing Case Solely on Roman Catholic Tenets
description: Although the Roman Catho lic Church does not categori cally oppose war, an Army offi cer who Is a Catholic has won a discharge as a conscientious objector on purely Catholic re ligious grounds.

title: India Closes B.B.C. Office Over Documentary Series
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 29The British Broadcasting Corpora tion closed down its operation in India today by a Govern ment order.

title: 21 Women Will Rehearse for Nov. 26 Gotham Ball
description: The 21 young women to be presented at the Gotham Debutante Ball at the Plaza on Nov. 26, will attend a rehearsal tea in the hotel's Grand Ballroom on Sept. 10. The rehearsal for the annual New York Foundling Hospi tal benefit is always held the Thursday after Labor Day, before the debutantes go away to school.

title: Girl Says That She Worked Like a Slave for Convent
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 29 (Reu ters)An Indian girl, reported to have fledfrom an Italian convent where she was sent to learn nursing as a novice nun, was quoted by a newspaper to day as having said that she had been made to work like a slave washing wards and pa tients in a mental hospital near Rome.

title: CITY OPERA SETS MALAMOOD DEBUT
description: Verdi's La Traviata and Rossini's La Cenerentola will reenter the New York City Opera's repertory during the second week of its current season at the State Theater. In addition, there will be one debut; Herman Malamood, New York City tenor, will apear in Madama Butterfly on Sept. 20. Casts and conductors for the week beginning Sept. 15 follow:

title: Bich Angered Over Failure to Halt Race
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 29Gallic ire over yesterday's fog bound loss to Gretel It contin ued to wash ashore at the America's Cup trials when Baron Marcel Bich angrily an nounced today he would not come back to challenge for the Cup.

title: DEMOCRATS GAIN IN A GALLUP POLL
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 29 The Democratic party, has a substantial lead over the Re publicans among those taking sides in a Gallup Poll as the party best able to handle the top problem of the United States.

title: VOTE IN MOROCCO, BACKS MONARCH
description: RABAT, Morocco, Aug. 29Official figures published today give King Hassan H a majority of over 90 per cent in Moroc co's new parliament in voting that ended last night.

title: Recordings
description: WHILE Duke Elling ton was being hailed throughout the world during he year following his 70th birthday on April 29, 1969at the White House and on tours in Australia and throughout Europe  there was a strange silence from the recording industry with which he had been closely associated for more than 40 years.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Modern Legal Test on Insanity Attacked by One of Its Drafters
description: NEW HAVEN  When Dr. Joseph Goldstein in 1954 helped draft the Durham Rule, one of the juridical landmarks that broadened the use of in sanity defense, he did not dream that one day he would oppose the basic concept of such a defense.

title: SHIELDS SAIL WON BY O'NEAL'S SLOOP
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Aug. 29Patrick O'Neal, at the helm of the Shields Class sloop, Theresa; James M. Mertz, with the Etchells22, Shillalah II, and Mathias J. Burgraf's Eaglet in Class S, were winners of 9.8 mile races on Long Island Sound today, They competed in the season's 30th Yacht Racing Association champion ship regatta.

title: Ulbricht Mixes Bullying With Flexibility
description: BONN Ever since the reign of Frederick the Great, 300 years ago, the rulers of the sandy Brandenburg Plain that used to be called Prussia have preferred to bully, concessions out of neigh bors rather than to negotiate them. Walter Ulbricht, the chief tain of Prussia's successor state, Communist East Germany, is no exception to this rule. Over the last 25 years he has proved to be a master of abtrotzenliter ally to spite something out of an opponent, in the sense of bullying.

title: MINE ACID KILLS FISH IN THE SUSQUEHANNA
description: WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 29 (AP)Thousands of dead fish floated up along 150 miles of the Susquehanna River Sat urday, killed by what officials said were massive amounts of mine acid polluting the waters.

title: At Braniff, That Feeling of Deja Vu
description: DALLAS  Oldtimers at Braniff Airways say they have been through it all be fore, but the experience does not appear to help any this. time around.

title: Without Them, Greek (or Frence, Japanese)
description: Now that more foreign plays are being staged in their original form for American audi ences, simultaneous transla tion has assumed consider able importance. It has, as well, stirred up some con troversy. The problem, like withdrawing from Vietnam or being all things to all men, is of labyrinthine complexity. How, in short, can an Amer ican audience understand plays from Japan, France, Poland, Russia, Thailand?

title: Mideast 1: Jarring In Delicate Search for Peace
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y.After the three fullscale wars and incessant border strife that have marked the 22 years of ArabIsraeli relations, the two sides were finally brought to gether at the United Nations lest week to begin the search for peace.

title: Crash Kills Race Driver
description: READING, Pa., Aug. 29 (AP) Jack E. Evans, a 37yearold Miami, Fla., racing driver died last night after his modified stock car hit a retaining wall and flipped several times at Reading Fair Grounds.

title: No Bandwagon Expected For NoFault Insurance
description: The nation's first nofault auto insurance law has just gone into effect in Massachu setts with mixed reaction from insurance companies. But the prospect that other states will adopt similar legislation in the near future seems remote.

title: Bunny Bid Leads Qualifiers
description: RUIDOSO, N. M., Aug. 29 (UPI)Bunny Bid, a 2yearold speedster from Chillicothe, Tex., sped to a 19.91 seconds clock ing yesterday to lead the 10 qualifiers for the $670,000 All American Quarterhorse Futurity to be run Sept. R at Ruidoso Downs.

title: GUS HALL ASSAILS KUNSTLER AS BAITER
description: Gus Hall, general secretary of the Communist Party, U.S.A., has made public an 800word attack on William M. Kunstler, a defense lawyer in the Chicago 7 conspiracy case and for numerous radicals, for alleged redbaiting.

title: Headliners
description: For five years, 28yearold Prince Qabas bin Said of the oilrich Arabian sultanate of Muscat and Oman was held prisoner by his father the Sultan in a fourroom house in Salala, a remote town without a telephone or a post office and surrounded by barbed wire. Last month a coup sent the Sultan fleeing to Britain and installed his son his place. Last week, in his gleaming white waterfront palace in Muscat, the new Sultan, a Sandhurst graduate, discussed plans for the country, renamed Oman. Restric tions imposed during his father's 38year rule would be lifted. Oman's 750,000 citizens would no longer need per mission to buy a car, a bicycle or a radio. They could travel freely. An amnesty was promised for the country's 1,500 guerrilla rebels if they gave up.

title: Andrew Lockhart Jr. Marries Miss Susan Barret Shepardson
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., Aug. 29The marriage of Miss Susan Barret Shep ardson to Andrew Alexander Lockhart Jr., son of Mr. Lockhart of London and Mrs. Lockhart of Harrow, Eng land, took place in St. John's Episcopal Church here this afternoon.

title: MOORE CAPTURES RESOLUTE CLASS
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 29Brilliant weather and moderate winds out of the northwest were enjoyed by everybody involved in the Man hasset Bay Yacht Club Race Week sailing today.

title: EDGE IS 2 SHOTS
description: CLIFTON, N. J., Aug. 29Labron Harris Jr., who has a master's degree in mathematics, and Bobby Nichols, who was using a putter he bought six years ago for $5, shared the 54hole lead in the $300,000 Dow Jones tourney today at 207.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox
description: About Tennis Umpiring To the Editor:

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Miss Lowrey Becomes Bride Of D. C. Reiser
description: ST. LOUIS, 29Miss Mar here to David C. Reiser, son of garet Ann Lowrey was married Mr. and Mrs. Neil Reiser of Riverdale, the Bronx, New York, this evening at the home of the bride's stepfather and mother, Mr. and Mrs. John G. Goessling.

title: Point of View
description: All over suburbia houses are getting emptier and emptier as our children go off to college, or to work, or get married. This leaves empty rooms by the thou sands standing idle. At the same time a shortage of apartments is driving apart ment rentals skyward, out of reach of the newly married and senior citizens alike.

title: Reader's Report
description: The Methuselah Enzyme

title: Formula A Cars Head for Lime Rock
description: The Continental Champion ship of the Sports Car Club of America will make its first appearance of the season in this part of the country on Labor Day on the 1.53mile road course of Lime Rock Park in COnnecticut. The main event, as usual, will be for Formula A carsthe high wing, openwheel racers with a single seat in an open cock pit and powered by massproduced V8 engines of 305 cubic inches displacement.

title: Mrs.NancyNickersonlsWed To William Murchie Riegel
description: DALTON, Pa., Aug. 29Mrs. Nancy Bailey Nickerson of Duxbury, Mass., was mar ried here today to William Murchie Riegel, executive vice president of the Riegel Paper Corporation in New York: The Rev. Byron Kel ham, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at Candletree Farm, the home of Mr. and Mrs. Edson K. Green, stepfather and mother of the bride.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: TodayRockland County K.C. allbreed and obedience, Platzl Brauhau, Call Hollow Road, Ladentown, N. Y.; 1,182 entries; 9 A.M.

title: PERU GAINS CONTROL OF U.S.LINKED BANK
description: LIMA, Peru, Aug. 29 (AP)Peru's military Government has bought all foreign shares and has taken control of the Con tinental Bank.

title: Elorde Stops Andrade in 5th For 4th Comeback Victory
description: MANILA, Aug. 29 (UPI)Gabriel (Flash) Elorde of the Philippines knocked down his opponent in the first, second and fourth rounds tonight en route to a fifthround technical knockout victory over a Mod can lightweight, Chico An drade, in a scheduled 10round bout.

title: 100 CRAFT TO SAIL IN VINEYARD RACE
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 29 About 100 auxiliary sailing yachts are expected to compete in the Stamford Yacht Club's annual Vineyard Race, which starts Friday. The race of ap proximately 260 miles will be gin at Cow's Buoy (Bell 32), go around Buzzards Bay Light house and return.

title: Commette Captures Crown In U.S. Duck Boat Series
description: MANTOLOKING, N. J., Aug. 29Pete Commette of the Man toloking Yacht Club won the National Duck Boat champion ship today with 7 points. Com mette triumphed in three of the four races over a twoday span.

title: A Revisionist View
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 29Cynics are calling this Davis Cup challenge round between the United States and West Germany the Avis Cup be cause of the absence of the top players, the contract pro fessionals, from the competi tion.

title: PICTURE CREDITS
description: 1CURT GUNTHER FROM CAMERA

title: SOCCER WEIGHING ITS POINT SYSTE
description: The North American Soccer League will conclude its not sosuccessful regular season today and the big question in the league is whether officials will keep the point system that has been used in the last three years.

title: Dorothy Job Wed To T. M. Donoghue
description: RIDGEWOOD, N. J., Aug. 29Miss Dorothy Louise Job, executive director of the Business Council on Enviorn ment of the New York Board of Trade, was married here today to Thomas M. Donog hue, a consultant in environ mental problems for the American Petroleum Institute in New York.

title: Davalillo Ties Record
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 29 (AP) Vic Davalillo of the St. Louis Cardinals tied the National League record of 22 pinch hits in a season with a seventh inning triple in tonight's game against the Los Angeles Dodg ers. The mark was set by Sam Leslie of the New York Giants In 1932 and equaled in 1962 by Red Schoendienst of St. Louis.

title: 4 STAKES CARDED AT BELMONT PARK
description: The New York Racing Asso ciation's program shifts back to Belmont Park tomorrow, fol lowing a successful 24day meeting at Saratoga. The Bel mont Park meeting will run 42 racing days through Oct. 17 and then the final 43 days of the New York season will be at Aqueduct from Oct. 19 through Dec. 7.

title: Dance: Londoners Like Kirov Best
description: LONDON, Aug. 28Pos sibly every great ballet com pany has some emblematic adjective that might be at tached to its name. The Bolshoi is clearly the most passionate, Britain's Royal Ballet the most urbane, and New York City Ballet the most creative. By the same token, Leningrad's Kirov Bal let must be allowed to be the most elegant.

title: DR. SAMUEL HEMLEY
description: LAKE GEORGE, N. Y., Aug. 29Dr. Samuel Hemley, Pro fessor Emeritus of Orthodontics at the New York University College. of Dentistry, died at his home here today. He was 72 years old.

title: Laraine Silver Is Bride Here
description: Miss Laraine Harriet Silver, a Columbia Law School stu dent, and Peter Jay Rothen berg, a lawyer with the New York firm of Paul, Weiss, Goldberg, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, were married here last night at the Plaza by the Rev. Dr. David J. Seligson of the Central Synagogue.

title: Editorial Cartoon 2  No Title
CHLOROFORM SOURCE IS SOUGHT IN SLAYING
description: MINEOLA. L. I., Aug. 29 (UPI)Nassau County detec tives questioned drugstore and hospital employes today in an effort to determine where the chloroform used in the killing of a North Valley Stream housewife, Mrs. Joan Holder, might have been obtained.

title: Nets Pick Garden City As Training Camp Site
description: The New York Nets will open training camp at St. Paul's School, Garden City, L. I., on Sunday, Sept. 13, it was announced by the bas ketball team's general man ager and head coach, Lou Carnesecca.

title: Most Happy Fella 1Length Winner In $102,770 Cane
description: YONKERS, Aug. 29Stanley Dancer, a reinsman who rarely errs, made no mistakes tonight as he drove Most Happy Fella to a comparatively easy victory in the $102,770 Cane Futurity Pace in trackrecord time for a 3yearold at Yonkers Raceway.

title: Sicilian Convicted in Death of 7 Is Seized Here for Deportation
description: Tornaso Buscetta, described as one of the top leaders of the Sicilian Mafia, was captured last week in New York and isi being held for deportation by the Federal Immigration and Naturalization Service, officialsi said yesterday.

title: Cox and Riessen Victors In Pro Tennis at Newport
description: NEWPORT, R.I. (AP)Mark Cox of England and Marty Riessen of Evanston, III., scored victories in the opening of the oundrobin finals in the 510,000 Newport professional tennis tournament today.

title: Student Weds Elizabeth Dean
description: KENNETT SQUARE, Pa., Aug 29Miss Elizabeth Han nuzn Dean and Alain Raunay Singer Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Singer of Greenville, Del., were married here this afternoon in the Episcopal Church of the Advent by the Rev. Elbert K. St. Claire.

title: PRAGUE CRITICIZES EMIGRE CLERGYMEN
description: PRAGUE, Aug. 29 (Reuters) The Vatican's Velehrad Cen ter, an organization of exiled Czechoslovak Roman Catholic clergymen, was denounced here today as a center of espionage and slander whose recognition by Italian authorities would be considered a provocation.

title: Home Improvement
description: ELECTRIC systems to help protect against burglars and vandals are being installed in more and more homes as crime rates continue to soar in many communities. De signed so that they will sound an alarm if doors and win dows are opened while the system is turned on, many of these systems can also be wired to sound the alarm in case of abnormally high tem peratures (fire) or to warn of dangerously high smoke levels (statistics indicate that most fire fatalities oc cur at night when occupants are asleep and smoke over comes them before fire and heat does).

title: BOTH ARE 19 TO 1 AT ATLANTIC CITY
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 29 (AP)Audley Farm's Ziba Blue and M. J. Stavola's Apple Prin cess won the two divisions of today's Pageant Handicap at Atlantilc City.

title: Bridge
Lancers Win Soccer Title
description: ROCHESTER, Aug. 29 (UPI)  The Rochester Lancers de feated the Kansas City Spurs, 31, tonight to win the North ern Division championship of the North American Soccer League. Rochester takes on the Washington Darts, Southern Division champions, for the title.

title: Ford Building Still Drawing Visitors
description: The poisons of pollution are penetrating the Ford Foundation's indoor gardens but the greenery still looks verdant and inviting on a summer day.

title: The doctor had a strange little hobby
description: Published 101 years after Roget's death, this is the first biography of a man who, in the lexicon of his field, is a household word second only to Noah Webster_ A conspiracy of silence, writes D. L. Emblen, has robbed Roget of his rightful place in modern encyclopedias, literary histories and the like. Elsewhere, he remarks on the strange history of silence that has to this moment held Roget in almost complete anonym ity, except for his thesaurus. The Encyclopaedia Britannica scarcely mentions him, although, according to Mr. Emblen, some of Roget's articles, written 150 years ago, were still ap pearing in compressed, anonymous versions in the 1967 edition.

title: New Haven Soccer Team Cards Eight Home Games
description: New Haven College will play eight home soccer games in 1970, the school's 50th an niversary year.

title: Suits by Consumers Held Endangered
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29The Nixon Administration is taking an increasingly hard line against legislation that would open the Federal courts to a broad range of class action suits by consumers.

title: Troops in Ulster Termed Bar to Relief for Catholics
description: LONDON, Aug. 28  Two British social scientists who have interviewed political lead ers in Northern Ireland have concluded that the intervention of the British peacekeeping force there left the Roman Catholic minority isolated and put an end to all immediate hopes of reform.

title: Rockets By the Sea
description: SHORTLY after the new and full moon, six or seven times during the summer, the tides of the Atlantic beaches reach their highest. These are the spring tides, so named, not for the season of the year, but for the seem ing abruptness of their rise and fall. Sweeping the beaches, they sometimes leave the sands washed clean; sometimes they bring gifts from the sea. Their high est reach sets the limit to the seaward advance of land vegetation.

title: That white power killed him
description: Back in the 1950's, conspiracy theories of American politics seemed to be the exclusive property of the right. Many of us smiled with amused contempt at charges that Dwight D. Eisenhower was an agent of the Com munist conspiracy, that fluoridation of our water was a Red plot and that the N.A.A.C.P. was the means by which Communists would mongrelize and destroy America. In recent years, however, rightwing talk of sinister intrigues has taken a back seat to the left's growing belief in Establish ment conspiracies to kill off radicals or liberals who threaten the status quo, lock up dissenters in concentra tion camps and cancel the 1972 elec tions. Fueled by the assassinations of three charismatic liberal leaders in the 1960's, theories that the C.I.A., F.B.I., or rightwing vigilante groups, or perhaps all of them in concert, were behind the killings of the Ken nedys and of Martin Luther King have gained wide currency.

title: CARLSON'S CLASSIC I TAKES YACHT TROPHY
description: BELLPORT, L. I., Aug. 29The Growtage Trophy, a prize first placed in competition shortly after the turn of the century, was captured today by Roger Carlson in his EScow, Classic I, in the annual Queen of the Bay race.

title: 4 Riders Selected by A.H.S.A. For Junior Nations Cup Event
description: A strong team of four rid ers will leave for Toronto to morrow to defend the United States junior Nations Cup championship on Sept. 6.

title: APPEAL PLANNED ON PELTS RULING
description: The National Audubon So ciety plans to appeal a State Supreme Court ruling that per mits the processing and sale of skins of animals and reptiles facing extinction.

title: Observer: Let's Hear It for Hypocrisy
description: LONDON, Aug. 29  What the United States needs is a revival of hypocrisy. The con clusion is inescapable for any one from the new candid, tell itlikeitis America who has seen the monumental old hy pocrisy of London.

title: Train Engineers Who Block Roads In Hoboken May Be Facing Arrest
description: HOBOKEN, N. J., Aug. 29 (UPI)Trains that block roads in Hoboken will continue to get traffic tickets, according to Public Safety Director E. Nor man Wilson. But engineers may also face arrest.

title: Growing Universities Fight Cities for Room
description: BOSTON, Aug. 29  Urban universities, swollen by in creases in population and para phernalia, are finding them selves in deep conflict with their surrounding communities. In many cases, the communities have been successful in thwart ing the schools search for more space.

title: Emily Graham Lay Is Married To Paul Ignatius O'Connell
description: FALLS CHURCH, Va., Aug. 29Miss Emily Graham Lay, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Selden Lay Jr., was married in St. James Roman Catholic Church here this afternoon to Paul Ignatius O'Connell, son of Mrs. Val entine George O'Connell of Upper Montclair, N. J., and the late Mr. O'Connell. The Rev. Thomas McArdle per formed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass, assisted by the Rev. Maurice Carlton and the Rev. Albert Holtz.

title: Article 7  No Title
Four Players Tune Up for U.S. Open Tennis on Lexington Avenue
description: Four players who will com pete in the United States Open tennis championships, in a prelude to the start of the event Wednesday, staged an exhibition match before crowds of weekend shoppers on a barricaded street in midtown Manhattan yester day.

title: REQUIEM CLOSES MOZART FESTIVAL
description: The enlightened and enlight ening Requiem of Mozart, which for all its brooding and pathetic passages takes a humanistic attitude towards death, ended the final program in the Most ly Mozart Festival at Philhar monic Hall on Friday night. (It was repeated last night.) It was given an astonishingly mature reading by Michael Tilson Thomas, the gifted young as sociate conductor of the Boston Symphony.

title: Late Listings for Today's TV
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: First View of Bradshaw Worth A Thousand Words to the Giants
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 29Bob Lurtsema is a competent 250pound defensive lineman with the New York Giants. Like any lineman, he expects to have trouble with oppo nents who weigh the same as he does, but when he hits a quarterback, he would like to think the man would have the good form to fall down.

title: Business Index Rises in Week
description: The New York Times Weekly Index of Business Activity rose to 367.9 from 367.5 a week earlier. A year ago it was 362.1.

title: MISS PANDE WINS GRASS NET TITLE
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 29 Eliza Pande, a baseline play er with a telling looping back hand stroke down the line, won the United States women's amateur grass court tennis championship today by upset ting the topseeded Sharon Walsh, 36, 97, 62, in an all California final at the Wilming ton Country Club.

title: GEORGIA HOPEFULS TURN TO THE RIGHT
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 29Three of the four leading governorship candidates in the Georgia pri maries Sept. 9. all former mod erates in Southern terms, have shifted to the right.

title: Miners Fund Spent $28Million More Than It Took In
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29The $150milion United Mine work ers Welfare and Retirement Fund, the focus of much of the angry and disruptive contro versy swirling around the coal union, said in a financial state ment today that it had paid out $196.9million In the last year, $28milion more than it had taken in.

title: JAPANESE TO FIGHT U.S. CURB ON TV SETS
description: TOKYO, Aug. 29 (AP)  The Electronic Industries Associa tion of Japan said today that it would fight in court any deci sion by the United States Treas ury Department that might raise the price of Japanese made television sets in the United States.

title: New York
Offenbach Upsets Cologne
description: HANNOVER, West Germany, Aug. 29 (UPI)  Underdog Of fenbach withstood a late rush by F. C. Cologne today and went on to win the West Ger man Football Cup, 2L Offen bach, who only this season ad vanced to the West German First Division, jumped off to an early lead on a goal by Klaus Winkler.

title: DRIVE FOR BILLION PRESSED IN ISRAEL
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 29Plans for Israel's forthcoming appeal to the world's Jews for $1bil lion next year for non defense needs of the country were outlined this week at a meeting of the newly reorgan ized Jewish Agency.

title: Space Agency Aids Fisheries
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP)The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has agreed to make available a part of its Mississippi Test Facility at Bay St. Louis, Miss., to the Bureau of Commercial Fisheries for the Interior Department's marine resources assessment and harvesting program. The bureau asked that some of the land and buildings formerly used for rocket testing be made available for research on the use of remote sensing equip ment to monitor and develop fishery resources.

title: Yank Games This Week
description: Today  Minnesota, at Yankee Stadium, 2 P.M.

title: Vote on Herbicides
description: For Senators Gaylord Nelson, Wisconsin Democrat, and Charles Goodell, New York Republican, the issue was primarily a moral one the United States should stop using herbicides in Vietnam.They, introduced an amendment denying any further funds for the plantkilling program. In a little more than eight years, Mr. Nel son said in the Senate last week, the United States has sprayed more, than 100 million pounds of assorted herbicide chemicals [over Vietnam]... six pounds for every man,, woman and child in that country. If our role is to defend Viettiam, how can we risk de stroying the environment in which they must survive when we leave?

title: Giants Sink Pirates In 10 Innings, 109,
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 29Willie Mays Jim Ray Hart and Bobby Bonds slammed home runs as San Francisco wiped out a seven run deficit in the eighth inning and went on to beat the Pittsburgh Pirates to day in 10 innings, 109. Bonds twoout single in the 10th was the clincher.

title: In Search of a Broader ApproachThe New York Rotary Club
description: Anyone who has lived in a small town or even driven through one surely knows of Rotary, the granddaddy of all Service clubs.

title: letter from a friend
description: RIO de JANEIRO

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: POLICEMAN INJURED BY SHOTGUN BLAST
description: A Bronx patrolman wos shot and critically wounded early today as he approached two men standing on East Tremont Avenue between Belmont and Crotona Avenues in the East Tremont section of the Bronx.

title: RELIEVERS FAIL
THAI SAYS AGNEW VOWED TO FIGHT CRITICS OF U.S. AID
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 29Vice President Agnew has assured the leaders of Thailand that he will leave no stone unturned to make certain that implementation of the so called Nixon doctrine is not blocked by American critics, according to the Thai Foreign Minister, Thanat Khoman.

title: Stamps
description: RICHARD FAIRBANKS was the first post master in America and Winton M. Blount is the last of the more than 60 men who were also post masterson a higher level. As Postmasters General, they were given their posts by congressional action or by presidential appointment.However, the postal reform bill, which President Nixon signed on Aug. 12 and which will become fully effective a year from that date, re places what Americans have known as the Post Office De partment (created by the Second Continental Congress July 26, 1775) by a United States Postal Service, an in dependent corporation with in the executive branch of the government. The Post master General, who has been a member of presiden tial cabinets since March 9, 1829, will no longer be a member of that body of counsellors.

title: HECKL CAPTURES HIS FOURTH PRIZE
description: TURIN, Italy, Aug. 29 (AP)The United States continued to dominate the sixth World Uni versity games today winning six gold medals to increase its total to 19.

title: Spotlight:
description: For years, Wall Street brokers have been probing through corporate profitand loss statements and balance sheets in quest of informa tion that will give them a guide to which stocks to buy and which stocks to sell.

title: Husband and Wife Parting After Both Run for Mayor
description: TOMBSTONE, Ariz., Aug. 29 (UPI)  A husband and wife running for Mayor have an nounced a separation.

title: Madison, Wis., Is Tense After Blast
description: MADISON, Wis., Aug. 29Seventyone years ago, work men dismantled and removed an ornate wriughtiron fence that encircled the State Capitol in downtown Madison.

title: AllSports Betting Bill To Be Offered by Stein
description: Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein announced yesterday that he would introduce a bill to ex tend legalized offtrack betting in the city to all forms of sports as well as to numbers Gambling.

title: Friday Night Fights
description: OmahaArt Hernandez, Omaha, knocked out Duane Horseman, Chatfield, Minn., 3 rounds, middle weights.

title: Wide Repercussions Seen From Ecuador Bank Failure
description: GUAYAQUIL, EcuadorThe Government is planning to reopen the bankrupt Banco de Guayaquil, which closed its doors last June 30, leaving thousands of depositors and about 50 foreign banks hold ing worthless passbooks and commercial paper.

title: Marita Donnelly Wed to Navy Pilot
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 29Miss Marita Therese Donnelly and Ens. Dennis Jo seph Doody, U.S.N., were married here this morning in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Gerard F. Fagan, provost of Fordham University. Five other priests celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: Congo Terms Parrot Hazard
description: BRAZZAVILLE, Congo Re public, Aug. 29 (Agence France Presse)  The Government of this former French colony has classified a species of parrot, the Psittacus erithacus erist hacus, as a health hazard and has banned its sale or capture for three years. Health officials said the bird can transmit psit tacosis, a wasting disease which can prove fatal, to humans.

title: Grass Eater Pays $12.80 With Late Rush at Tropical
description: MIAMI, Aug. 29 (AP) The Elias Brothers Farms Grass Eater took command at the head of the stretch today to win the $5,000 added Singing Tower Stakes at Tropical Park. Feature Attraction was second, followed by War Lady.

title: U.S. Sailers Excel in Kel
description: KIEL, Germany, Aug. 29 (AP) John Dane of the United States placed first in the Soling Class race in today's opening round of the International Ger man sailing championships. David Curtis of the United States was second in the Soling race. Lowell North of the United States finished second in the Star Class race.

title: Manhasset Bay Race Week Results
description: ETCHELLS22 CLASS1, Randy Bartholomew; 2, Marvin Kapilow; 3, Bob Kirtland; 4, Howard McMichael; 5, Stanley Ogilvy; Bruce McKeige; 7, Karl Gleeson; 8, John Beeman; 9, Edward Greenberg; 10, Louis Piana; 11, Horace Hagedorn; 12, Dick Leather; 13, James Fulton.

title: Keystone Shortway Finished
description: CLEARFIELD, Pa., Aug. 29 (AP)The two final sections of the Keystone Shortway have been opened, completing the 313mile highway, which spans the west. Eventually the short way will become part of Inter state 80, linking New York with San Francisco. The entire roadway will be formally dedicated Sept. 17.

title: Field Of Travel
description: IF YOU have driven over the 50mile stretch of Interstate 4 between Orlando and Lake land in Florida in recent months you have been an ob server of  and perhaps a participant in  a new el ec tronic signaling system de signed to give aid to motorists with disabled vehicles. The system is called Flash, an acronym for Flash Lights and Send Help. This yearlong experiment, which will end in midNovember, is being conducted jointly by the United States Bureau of Pub lic Roads, the Florida Depart ment of Transportation, the Florida Highway Patrol and the contractor, a division of the CutlerHammer Company.

title: Thant Confers With Tito
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 29 (Reuters)  Secretary Gen eral Thant of the United Na tions discussed international problems for more than two hours with President Tito at the Yugoslav leader's residence on the island of Brioni today, the Yugoslav press agency, Tanyug, reported.

title: Tijerina Says He Is Tortured in Prison
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 29 Reies Lopez Tijerina, the MexicanAmerican leader, has charged that he has been tor tured, denied medical attention and kept in solitary confine ment in a Federal prison facil ity for seven months.

title: Race on ClosedCircuit TV
description: The race will be shown on closedcircuit television at Man hattan Center, 34th Street off Eighth Avenue, and the Island Garden Arena in West Hemp stead, L.I. Tickets are priced at $7.50 each and are available at all Ticketron outlets. Tickets by mail are obtainable from Meta vision, 277 Park Avenue, N.Y., 10017.

title: Penn State's Cub Eleven To Face West Va. and Pitt
description: Penn State's 1970 freshman football team will play two games  a home contest with West Virginia on Oct. 16 and a road game at Pitt on Nov. 7.

title: TEXAN CAPTURES VANDALIA HONORS
description: VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 29 (AP)  Larry Gravestock, a sportinggoods dealer in Wichita Falls, Tex., won the overall championship today at the 71st annual Grand American Trap shooting tournament. He shat tared 967 of the 1,000 targets thrown up for him during the competition.

title: Talk or TalkFight in Vietnam
description: The renewed prospect of secret talks for the first time in a year, now that North Vietnam has joined the United States in sending a highlevel negotiator back to Paris, is importantbut much more impor tant is whether either side has anything new to say. There is an opportunity for a new initiative that neither Washington nor Hanoi would be wise to ignore.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: By JOSEPH DURSO

title: MAX HENDLER
description: Max Hendler, a lawyer and the clerk of special term, Part V, of the State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, died yesterday in the Downstate Medical Center, Brooklyn. He was 60 years old and lived at 3060 Ocean Ave nue. Brooklyn.

title: Art
description: THE exaggerated esteem in which art ists are held today is indicated by a phrase that occurs in a publicity re lease from ACMthe Association for Computing Machinery, which is holding its 25th national conference Sept. 13 at the New York Hilton Hotel. Computers are creating art which is indistinguishable from the manmade product, the release states. That's a recommendation?

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: BOSTONConstruction will begin early next year on Bos ton's third highest building, even though there is no key tenant at the present time, it was announced last week.

title: Yonkers Drivers
KERRY'S TIME, $8.20, HAWTHORNE WINNER
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (AP)Kerry's Time, a recent upset winner of the A division of the Lindheimeer Handicap at Ar lington Park, scored a three quarterlength victory today in the $34,900 Chicago Handicap before 24,607 fans at Haw thorne.

title: Russia Launches Cosmos360
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 29 (AP)The Soviet Union launched Cosmos 360 today, the sixth this month in its unmanned Cosmos program. The satellite is orbiting the earth every 89.5 minutes at an angle of 65 de grees with a maximum dis tance of 198 miles and a mini mum distance of 130 miles from the earth.

title: JOLTS TO DOMINATE U.S. BOXING TEAM
description: The United States amateur boxing team that will face England Sept. 12 at the New Jersey State Fair in Trenton, it has been announced by Col. Donald F. Hull, executive di rector of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States.

title: At Beck: Acquisition Indigestion
description: A month ago, bustling, steelyeyed Charles F. Mc Devitt abruptly departed as president of troubled Beck Industries, Inc., after the re tailing conglomerate failed to attract enough buyers for a convertibledebenture issue and withdrew it.

title: INTREPID IS VICTOR 8TH THE IN ROW
description: NEWPORT, R.1., Aug. 29On the second leg of today's America's Cup trial, three small planes circled over the competing yachts.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: ExAddicts Gather Here for Natural High
description: Yogiraj Sri Swami Satchi dananda gently shot the cuffs of his saffroncolored robe and looked out over the sev eral thousand people, hip and straight, gathered on Hart Island in the Bronx for Phoe nix House's annual endof summer happening.

title: Man in Soviet Georgia Gets Death for Economic Crimes
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 30 (Reu thers)The former director of a mechanical repair shop has been sentenced to death in the Georgian Republic for accept ing bribes, theft of state prop erty and falsifying returns, ac cording to a local newspaper.

title: Jury Reports Split on McLucas, But Judge Orders It to Continue
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 30After five days of deliberation the Superior Court jury considering the fate of Lonnie McLucas, the first Black Panther to stand trial in connection with the Alex Rackley slaying, reported itself today to be in disagreement on a verdict.

title: Next: Temple and Delaware. Outlook At A Glance
description: PROSPECTSThe Crusaders lost a year of experience because of last season's outbreak of hepa titis, but the talent is there to develop a successful campaign.

title: TRANSFERS PLANNED BY SALVATION ARMY
description: The Salvation Army an nounced yesterday that Lieut. Commissioner J. Clyde Cox had been promoted to full commissioner and appointed commander of the organiza tion's 11state central territory, with headquarters in Chicago.

title: SMITH AND LUTZ CAPTURE DOUBLES
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 30.Think of all the classic mis matches  the second Louis Schmeling fight, RooseveltLan don, JohnsonGoldwater, Green BayKansas Citythen add the 1970 Davis Cup challenge round between the United States and West Germany.

title: DR. AGNES BYRNES, 90, OF HUNTER COLLEGE
description: Dr. Agnes M. Hadden Byrnes, emeritus professor of sociology at Hunter College, who founded and became first chairman of its sociology department in 1942, died yesterday in Wick ersham Hospital. She was 90 years old and lived in the San Carlos Hotel, 150 East 50th Street.

title: BUFFALO WILL BAR THE PANTHER PAPER
description: BUFFALO, Aug. 30The Po lice Department here said today that it would arrest all street venders of the Black Panther newspaper under a 1902 state criminal anarchy statute now under review by the United States Supreme Court.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To the Editor: I have been wading through news reports, editorials and television accounts about the current crisis in the Tombs and other city houses of detention in hopes of finding one refer ence to the deplorable bail sys tem in New York City. My search has been in vain; the money bail system remains as untouchable as motherhood.

title: GORDON SETTER BEST AT ROCKLAND SHOW
description: LADENTOWN, N. Y., Aug. 30 Mrs. Cheever Porter's Gordon setter, Ch. Legend of Gael C. D., was judged best at the 1,180 dog Rockland County Kennel Club show today.

title: Article 1  No Title
TRANSPORT STRIKE CRIPPLES LA PAZ
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 30A dispute between Bolivian bus, truck and taxi drivers and In dian farmers has left this capi tal virtually without transpor tation and cut off from the countryside.

title: Rural Bank's Closing Jars Community
description: FARMINGTON, Mo., Aug. 30 The First State Bank of Bonne Terre, closed since Aug. 24 be cause of alleged mismanage ment of about $1.5million in loans, is scheduled to open tomorrow under a new charter awarded to Commerce Banc shares, Inc.. of Kansas City.

title: EDITOR CONVICTED IN BLAST INQUIRY
description: ELKHORN, Wis., Aug. 30 (AP) An underground news paper editor was convicted of contempt today for refusing to testify before a grand jury in vestigating the bombing of University of Wisconsin build ing last Monday.

title: American Airlines Uses Mixed Media on Freight
description: American Airlines wants to sell more air freight and is turning to local media in four cities to do it. In the past, the big carrier has essentially used national media but it is now starting an experimental program us ing newspapers and, for the first time, radio spots.

title: Abuse Alleged in Use of Slum Dwellers to Harvest Jersey Crops
description: PHILADELPHIAAs 4 A. M. approaches, the black and Puerto Rican slums are silent, and hundreds of sleepyeyed men, women and children begin gathering to he taken from the worst parts of this city to what are regarded by many as the worst jobs in southern New Jersey.

title: Policeman Slain, 3 Shot, in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, Monday, Aug. 31Four Philadelphia po licemen were shot in a black neighborhood of West Philadel phia over the weekend, one fatally. The three wounded po licemen remained in serious condition early today.

title: WILLIAM O. WYCOFF
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 30  William Ozmun Wycoff, the first fulltime placement director at Williams College and a trustee of the college, died last night at the North Adams Hospital. He was 77 years old.

title: Gail Ann Lauter Is Married In Rye to Henry D. Podolsky
description: RYE, N. Y., Aug. 30Miss Gail Ann Lauter and Henry Dave Podolsky were married here this afternoon. Rabbi Morris Kertzer performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert I. Lauter.  The bride groom's parents are Mrs. Reuben Podolsky of Lynn, Mass., and the late Mr. Po dolsky.

title: TOKYO SAID TO PLAN PEACE MOVE IN HANOI
description: TOKYO, Aug. 30 (UPI) Kyodo News Agency said to day that Japan would seek to improve her relations with North Vietnam soon in an at tempt to bring peace to Indo china.

title: Steeles Gain Third Round In U.S. FatherSon Tennis
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30Chauncey Steele Jr. and 3d of Cambridge, Mass., advanced to the third round of the United States fatherson tennis doubles championship by defeating Ger ard and Jeff Podesta of Glen Ridge, N.J., 60, 62, today at the Germantown Cricket Club.

title: '65 LAW CHANGES ETHNIC PATTERNS OF IMMIGRATION
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30The pattern of immigration into the United States has been dras tically altered by legislation of the midnineteensixties.

title: Pupil Busing Is a Major Issue in Political Campaigns of Four Southern States
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 30The busing of pupils to achieve school desegregation has be come a major issue in four Southern states where impor tant statewide political cam paigns are being waged this summer.

title: Canada Maps Tax Relief For the Mining Industry
description: TORONTOIn its first sig nificant modification of last November's sweeping tax reform proposals, the Canadian Government has responded sympathetically to complaints from mining companies, an in dustry that accounts for a lot of jobs and export earnings.

title: Mary Jo Cook Is a L.I. Bride
description: FLORAL PARK, L. I., Aug. 30  The marriage of Miss Mary Jo Cook to Daniel Pat rick Santo Pietro, assistant director of Catholic Relief Services in Rio de Janeiro, took place in Our Lady of Victory Roman Catholic Church here today.

title: Patricia Kelly Triumphs In 34Mile Overnight Sail
description: BABYLON, L. I., Aug. 30Patricia Kelly of Bay Shore, L. I., in her Banshee captured the 34mile overnight Foulke Trophy race of the South Bay Cruising Club today. The sail was from this port to Bellport and return.

title: ISRAELI CABINET FAILS TO DECIDE POLICY ON TALKS
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 30The Israeli Cabinet failed to agree today on an opening negotiat ing position for the indirect peace talks with the Arab states, amid evidence of a grow ing split between Premier Golda Meir and Defense Min ister Moshe Dayan.

title: Mailer at Venice With Film Aiming To Be Memorable
description: VENICE, Italy, Aug. 30 (AP) Norman Mailer unveiled his film Maidstone at the Venice Film Festival today with the hope of wining major critical acclaim in a field of relatively unapplauded films.

title: SHIELDS CLASS SAIL TAKEN BY THERESA
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Aug. 30Patrick O'Neal sailed The resa to a second straight Shields Class victory today in the sea son's 31st Yacht Racing Asso ciation championship event, which also ended the Huguenot Yacht Club's 77th annual re gatta.

title: Prisoner's Wheelchair Helps Him to Escape
description: A wounded prisoner es caped from a fourthfloor room in St. Vincent's Hospital yesterday by turning his wheelchair into a weapon, the police said.

title: AMVETS Elect Illinoisan
description: Robert Showalter of Crete, Ill., yesterday was elected na tional commander of the 250,000 member American Veterans of World War II, Korea and Vietnam, the AMVETS. He was elected at the organization's 26th annual convention at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel.

title: Yanks Down Twins, 52, on First Grand Slam of White's Career in Fifth
description: The most notable thing that happened during Mickey Man tle's debut as a New York Yankee coach yesterday was the grandslam home run Roy White hit while Mantle was in the first base coach's box.

title: GOLDBERG VOWS AID FOR ADDICTS
description: Arthur J. Goldberg promised yesterday that within six months after he took office as Governor every heroin addict who wanted help would get it.

title: Food Stamp Plan Begins Here Today
description: A $30million monthly food stamp program begins in the city today, with two million publicassistance recipients and lowincome people eligible to participate.

title: The Air War in Asiaand Its Cover Up in Washington
description: WASHINGTON  It is not easy to hide a B52. Nor is it possible to concealas anyone who has flown over the jungles of Vietnam in a helicopter can plainly see the mooncraters caused by each plane's thirty ton bombload. Long after the war is a dying memory, these holes in the landscape of four countries in Southeast Asia will remain as reminders of. the American way of life and death.

title: McGrath Blames Our Times For Recent Riots at the Tombs
description: City Correction Commission er George F. McGrath said yes terday that rioting three weeks ago by prisoners at the Man hattan Men's House of Deten tion was not so much a protest against conditions there as a symptom of our times.

title: Bethpage Poloists Defeat Brookville in Overtime, 76
description: BETHPAGE, L. I., Aug. 30Fred Guest's third goal two minutes into a sudden death overtime gave the Bethpage polo team a 76 victory over Brookville today at Bethpage State Park.

title: ANGELS SET BACK INDIANS, 10 TO 9
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 30 (UPI) Alex Johnson drove in four runs with a homer and a single today to power the California Angels to a 109 victory over the Cleveland Indians. A total of nine homers were hit by the teams, two short of the major league record.

title: OPEN JUMPER TITLE IS TAKEN BY 18 KT.
description: BRENTWOOD, L. I., Aug. 30  Kathy Williams has ridden 18 Kt, in just three horse shows. In her first time she piloted the 7yearold brown gelding to a couple of ribbons. Last week 18 Kt. was reserve champion and today he cap tured the open jumper title at The Knoll Farm event here.

title: Tourist Influx Speeds Opening of New Moscow Hotel
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 30Rus sian hospitality, traditionally symbolized by bread and salt and often spiced with con fusion, surprised several hun dred foreign tourists last month when they found them selves standing In the glassy lobby of the Intourist, Mos cow's newest hotel.

title: PEPITONE'S HOMER LIFTS CUBS TO 2D
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 30 (AP)Joe Pepitone slammed a three run homer in the ninth inning today to break up a scoreless battle and give the surging Chi cago Cubs a 30 victory over the San Diego Padres.

title: STEPHEN VAN GLUCK
description: Stephen Van Gluck, program director of radio station WVNJ of Newark, died Friday of heart ailment in Mount Sinai Hospital. He lived at 5 Pearl Road, East Brunswick, N.J.

title: Eller Ends Holdout, Signs With Vikings
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 30 (AP)Carl Eller, an allpro defensive end, ended his twoweek holdout tonight when he agreed to a 1970 contract with the Minnesota Vikings. Terms of the con tract were not disclosed.

title: Bengals, Dolphins and Oilers Upset Their Prestigious Foes
description: Simply no matchthe Cin cinnati Bengals had best avoid the Cleveland Browns, the 1969 Century Division champion of the National Football League. That's what the football fans in Ohio were saying and think ing before Saturday night's preseason game that was billed as the Buckeye Battle.

title: GREEKS QUESTION 5 AS DRUG SMUGGLERS
description: CANDIA, Crete, Aug. 30 (Reuters)  Five Americans were questioned by the Greek police today after their arrest on drugsmuggling charges after a dramatic air chase across the Mediterranean

title: Sound Motive, Dubious Method
description: The Senate will vote tomorrow on the Hatfield McGovern amendment to set a timetable for ending the war in Vietnam, an objective devoutly wished by millions of Americans. The framers of the measure have labored responsibly and creatively to,extend the deadline for withdrawal of American forces and allow the President flexibility In applying that dead line.

title: BOND MOMENTUM EXPECTED TO GAIN
description: The rally in the credit mar kets gathered momentum last week, and it very likely will continue this week. Bond prices should continue to rise and in terest rates should keep work ing their way lower.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: GETHIN DECLARED VICTOR IN CANAM
description: ELKHART LAKE, Wis., Aug. 30  Peter Gethin of England, the newest member of the Mc Laren team, won the 200mile Road America CanAm race to day in circumstances so con troversial that his own team manager protested the result.

title: Votes of the Week In Congress
Search Begins for Doctors To Serve During Boycott
description: Officials at the Albert Ein stein College of Medicine began to search for obstetricians will ing to work temporarily at Lin coln Hospital yesteday, the sixth day of a boycott there by 27 physicians.

title: PITTSBURGH BOWS BY 73,21 SCORES
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 30 (AP)John Stephenson's sac rifice fly drove home Jim Hart with the winning run in the eighth inning as the San Fran cisco Giants beat the Pitts burgh Pirates, 21, and com pleted a sweep of today's dou bleheader.

title: Johnson of   F.C.C. Advocates Right of TV Reply to President
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 Nicholas Johnson, a member of the Federal Communications Commission, said today that every time the President spoke to the nation on television, the networks should give com parable treatment to opposite views

title: Judith E. Seidel, Editor, Is Bride Of L. I. Jacobson
description: Miss Judith Ellen Seidel, an editor with the Twenti eth Century Fund, was mar ried here yesterday to Leon Irwin Jacobson, a lawyer with Paul, Weiss, Goldberg, Rifkind, Wharton & Garri son. Rabbi Mark N. Gold man performed the ceremony at the Croydon Hotel.

title: 10 Pounds of Heroin Seized By Police in Bronx Raid
description: The police seized a suitcase containing 10 pounds of heroin valued at $500,000, and arrested a man and two women in sixthstory apartment at 581 Timpson Place in the South Bronx last night.

title: First Clean Cars Cross West Coast Finish Line
description: PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 30,A 1970 Plymouth sedan pow ered by liquefied propane gas was first across the finish line tonight in the transcontinental intercollegiate clean car race.

title: Italy to Orbit U.S. Satellites
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (Reuters)  Italy will launch three American scientific satel lites from its San Marco plat form off the east coast of Africathe first United States space probes sent aloft by an other country. The launchings, announced here today by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, will be carried out under a memorandum of understanding signed between the two countries last year.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: Nichols Wins Dow Jones Golf by a Shot on 69 for 276
description: CLIFTON, N. J., Aug. 30For a moment the ball hesi tated at the rim of the cup, then it fell in and Bobby Nich ols won the $60,000 first prize today in the $300,000 Dow Jones open golf tournment.

title: St. Patrick's Names Met Organist as Musical Director
description: A new musical era will be gin in St. Patrick's Cathedral next Sunday when John Fran cis, Grady, organist of the Metropolitan Opera, will also become organist and musical director at the cathedral.

title: Robbers Get Navy Weapons
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 30 (AP)  A small band of armed intruders held four sail ors at gunpoint in a Navy arsenal at Cecil Field today and escaped with hand guns, car bines and ammunition, the Fed eral Bureau of Investigation said.

title: RED SOX SUBDUE WHITE SOX TWICE
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 30 (AP) The Boston Red Sox slammed 22 hits in the first game today, and then cashed in on second game homers by Rico Petrocelli and Mike Andrews to sweep a doubleheader from the Chi cago White Sox 2111 and 41.

title: NIXON AIDES VOICE INTEGRATION HOPE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30On the eve of a historic wave of school desegregation in the South, the Nixon Administra tion was expressing confidence today that it would be carried out without any largescale re sistance or violence.

title: Page Captures Crown In Cotton Class Sailing
description: BAY SHORE, L. I., Aug. 30 Reginald Page of the Stam ford Yacht Club paced second in both races today to take the Cottontail Class national sailing championship. Page, in his Wab bitt, had a fourth and two firsts yesterday.

title: Miss Susan Etess Is Married To Barry Fallick at Grossinger
description: GROSSINGER, N. Y., Aug. 30Miss Susan Etess and Barry Fallick were married here this afternoon at Gros singer's, the resort hotel founded by the bride's grand parents, Mrs. Harry (Jennie) Grossinger and the late Mr. Grossinger.

title: Mortgage Lending And Savings Grow
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30Both savings flows and mort gagelending activity rose sharp ly in July at savings and loan associations, the Federal Home Loan Bank board reported to day.

title: J. W. Karaman, DivinityStudent, Weds Jane Foy
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Aug. 30 Miss Jane Wilson Foy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Wilson Foy, was mar ried here today to Joseph William Karaman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Bernard Karaman.

title: Allison Blues Band Reigns at Festival
description: UPPER SALFORD TOWN SHIP, Pa., Aug. 30Although no official proclamation was made, yesterday at the Phila delphia Folk Festival might have been declared Luther Allison Day.

title: INFLATION CHECK HELD INADEQUATE
description: The Federal Reserve System's present monetary policy will produce only limited relief from inflation, a new analysis showed yesterday.

title: GOODELL ASSAILS OTTINGER ON WAR
description: Senator Charles E. Goodell charged yesterday that his Democratic rival, Richard L. Ottinger, was a late opponent of the war in Vietnam, where as he said he had stood alone last fall in making the first attempt to legislate an end to the war.

title: AGNEW SEES GAIN IN CAMBODIA WAR
description: HONOLULU, Aug. 30Vice President Agnew, heading home today from a tour of five Asian nations, said that more than half the Communist combat forces in Cambodia have been elimina ted.

title: EAST LOS ANGELES CALM AFTER RIOT
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 30A force of 330 sheriff's deputies patrolled the East Los Angeles MexicanAmerican community today after an antiwar demon stration erupted into a riot yes terday. The riot caused one death, at least 53 injuries and extensive. property damage.

title: GIL HANOVER OUT OF HAMBLETONIAN
Bids Due Today on Building 144 New Haven Cars
description: The states of New York and Connecticut will open bids to lday for the contract to supply 144 new cars for the Penn Cen tral's New Haven commuter di vision. Optimism was expressed that the longplanned but often postponed bistate takeover of rail commuter service between New York City and New Haven would be consummated within a few weeks.

title: BREWERS TRIUMPH OVER ORIOLES, 52
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 30 (AP)Skip Lockwood of the Milwau kee Brewers beat the Baltimore Orioles, 52, today with relief help from Ken Sanders and ended his second fivegame los ing streak of the season.

title: Much Effort, Little Reform
description: The latest study by the Carnegie Commission on Higher Education says bluntly that the campus rebel lion has failed dismally in its most legitimate goals of bringing about educational reforms. The voluminous reports that followed the Berkeley uprising of 1964 have largely evaporated. Measured in faculty, admin istration and student committee manhours, the unrest on many campuses has given the appearance of high productivity; measured in meaningful educational change, it has too often been an exercise in futility.

title: South Vietnamese Vote As Reds Step Up Attacks
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 30Several,million South Vietnamese elected 30 Senators today in voting marked by ter rorist attacks in some areas and charges of fraud in others.

title: City Reported Facing a $4Million Cut in Poverty Aid
description: New York City is facing the threat of Federal cuts of more than $4million in its continuing antipoverty programs, David J. Billings 3d, chairman of the city's Council against Poverty, said yesterday.

title: MachineTool Orders Up a Bit in July
description: New orders for machine tools, a closely watched indi cator of future business activ ity, showed small gains in July for the second straight month, the National Machine Tool Builders Association reported yesterday.

title: FD Capital Fund Remains Clear of S.E.C. Charges
description: The FD Capital Fund has not been accused of any viola tions of the securities laws, a spokesman for the fund pointed out yesterday. A headline that appeared Saturday in The New York Times said incorrectly that the FD Capital Fund had been charged on such viola tions.

title: Immigration Shifts
Marylu Shore and John Simon, Students at Cornell, Are Wed
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Aug. 30Miss Marylu Shore and John Lewis Simon, graduate students at Cornell Univer sity, were married here this afternoon at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club by Rabbi Arthur Hertzberg.

title: Official Sees Business Slump But a Rapid Recovery in City
description: Ken Patton, the city's Eco nomic Development Adminis trator, said yesterday that he thought that New York City was heading into the slump that has already hit most of the nation, but that with basic business conditions here good he anticipated a quick recov ery.

title: GAY GHETTOS SEEN AS POLICE TARGETS
description: Representatives of homosex ual organzations charged yes terday that police harassment of homosexuals had been inten sified within the last three weeks in the gay ghettos of Manhattan.

title: Schoolman in the Middle
description: RICHMOND, Aug. 30Ten years ago, Lucien Doyle Adams, then an assistant superintendent of schools in the Richmond system, came home from services at the Episcopal Church and told his wife he was not feeling well.

title: HelpWanted Index in July At Lowest Level Since 65
description: Helpwanted advertising In July fell to the lowest level since October, 1965, according to the National Industrial Con ference Board.

title: Is It a Male or Female?; Danny La Rue Winning New Fans in London
description: LONDON  Female im personation is an old, if strange, theatrical tradition. It can be seen in the Jap anese Kabuki theater; at one time it was the common rule in Indian Kathakali dance, and in the Elizabethan thea ter all the girls were boys. Here no one not only com plained, but no one actually seemed to notice.

title: JOAN BAEZ SINGS FOR POLISH YOUTH
description: SOPOT, Poland, Aug. 30The voice of protestAmerican protestcame to Poland last Thursday night as Joan Baez galvanized an audience at the Sopot Folk Song Festival.

title: 3YEAR PACT ENDS 100DAY TV STRIKE
description: Metromedia, Inc., and a union representing television technicians announced last night that they had reached an agreement to end the 100day old strike against WNEWTV here and WTTG in Washing ton, D.C.

title: Hotel Says. Goldberg's Stall Owes $6,500 Rent
description: The Lancaster Hotel in Man hattan said yesterday that it had to turn the lights and air conditioning off in the guber natorial campaign headquarters of Arthur J. Goldberg several times during the last four and a half months in order to force the staff to pay at least token rent.

title: MRS. R. G. HUNTINGTON
description: MONTVALE, N.J., Aug. 30 (AP)  Mrs. Alice Booth Hunt ington of Montvale, who for 12 years served as director of New Jersey Girls State, held during the summer at Douglass Col lege, died yesterday in River Dale Hospital, Oradell. She was 72 years old and lived at 48 Huff Terrace. Mrs. Huntington, was the widow of R. Graham Huntington.

title: Poor in Chile Seize Land for Marxist Communities
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 26A sea of Chilean flags fluttered over tattered tents and card board shelters as some 1,200 indigent families founded a new Marxist community in a field here this week.

title: Farm Union Signs a Contract With Lettuce Grower on Coast
description: SALINAS, Calif., Aug. 30 (UPI)The United Farm Work. ers Organizing Committee an nounced tonight the signing of a contract with one of the larg est vegetable growers in the Salinas Valley, the first victory in the union's struggle to or ganize the salad bowl, which produces 70 per cent of the na tion's lettuce.

title: Bridge:
description: Tournament players using standard methods know how to bid a balanced hand with 21 highcard points: Open two notrump. The minority who stick with strong two bids and a 2224 point two notrump bid have to open one of a suit, a less satisfac tory action.

title: LINDBERGH STAND ASSAILED BY JEWS
description: Leaders of Jewish organiza tions yesterday assailed assert ions by Charles A. Lindbergh that the Roosevelt Administra tion, proBritish elements and American Jews had forced the United States into World War IIa War that he contended American had lost.

title: Forgotten Extras
description: The city has much to gain from its newly acquired popularity as a motion picture location. Most New Yorkers are undoubtedly willing to put Up with some of the minor inconveniences arising from a temporary rearrangement of the local landscape and the inevitable congestion of cameras and props.

title: ICKX WINS HONORS IN SALZBURG RACE
description: SALZBURG, Austria, Aug. 30 (AP)  Jackie Ickx, the ace Belgian driver, won today's twoheat Formula Two race on the Salzburg Ring, wheeling his BMW to victory ahead of Italy's Vittorio Brambilla.

title: Hendrick Captures Trenton 200 to Win Prize of $10,400
description: TRENTON, Aug. 30 (UPI)Ray Hendrick of Richmond drove his 1969 Camaro to a full lap victory today in the Tren ton 200mile race for modified stock cars and earned $10,400, the biggest auto racing payday of his career.

title: Commandos Report Attacks in Amman By Jordan's Army
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 30Spokesmen for the Arab com mando movement said tonight that the Jordanian Army had attacked commando installa tions in Amman for more than two hours tonight.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Intrepid Named Cup Defender
description: NEWPORT,. R.I., Aug 30Well done.

title: 20 Die in Argentine Crash
description: SALTA, Argentina, Aug. 30 (Reuters)A bus was hit by freight train at a crossing to night about 200 miles north east of here, and according to first police reports there were about 20 dead and 25 injured.

title: Meany Sees Democrats Losing Workers'
description: George Meany, president of the A.F.L.CI.O., says that the Democratic party has disinte grated and that trade union ists are no longer as attracted to it as they have been in the past.

title: Herman's Plans National Chain
description: Mostly, I like to work around the store like anyone else, in my shirt sleeves, said Herman of Herman's Sporting Goods, with a crink ly smile the other day.

title: Major League Baseball
description: American League

title: New Action in Cambodia
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Aug. 30Communist forces captured the district town of Srang early this morning, according to sol diers and refugees from the battle area 25 miles south of Pnompenh.

title: Use Buddy System For Night Patrols, Policemen Ordered
description: Only hours after a patrolman in the Bronx was wounded in an apparently unprovoked shot gun assault by two youths, the Police Department issued an order at 3 A.M. yesterday re quiring each patrolman walking a beat in the evening and night hours to work in close prox imity to another policeman.

title: Steel Mills Now Getting Slightly Larger Orders From Auto Makers
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 30Au tomobile companies are begin ning to place orders for steel to be delivered in October.

title: 30 Tenants Protest Plan To Raze 19th St. Buildings
description: About 30 residents of two East 19th Street apartment buildings picketed Columbus Hospital yeterday to protest the hospital's plan to tear down their homes and replace them with a garage.

title: LUCIEN LANGLOIS
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 30 (Cana dian Press)Lucien Langlois, editor in chief of the Montreal Matin, North America's largest. circulation Frenchlanguage morning newspaper died yes terday at the age of 54.

title: MARY CLARE
description: LONDON, Aug. 30 (AP)Mary Clare, the stage and screen actress, who had ap peared in more than 400 pro ductions, died yesterday in clinic here. She was 78 years old.

title: TIGER RALLY IN 8TH SUBDUES A'S, 65
description: DETROIT, Aug. 30 (AP)Bill Freehan, playing his last game before undergoing a back operation, singled to touch off a tworun Detroit rally in the eighth inning today as the Tigers rallied to beat the Oak land Athletics, 65.

title: For the Inventive Child, A Varying Toy
description: Activity toys have as many uses as an inventive child's mind can devise, which is usually more than the adult mind can conceive. The most recent addition is called PlayAll, three inter locking plastic pieces in orange, green and blue that form a 32inch wheel, a 75 inch snake, or used separately, a footboard, a rocker, or... Made by HiHo Products, it weighs 18 pounds and can be used indoors or out. It is $24, at F. A. O. Schwarz.

title: Jane Heffer Is Married to Teacher
description: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 30Miss Jane L. Heffer, daugh ter of Mrs. Jacob M. Seiler of New York and Mamaro neck, was married today to Agostino T. Galluzzo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Antonio Gal luzzo of Springfield, Mass. The ceremony, at the White Plains Hotel, was performed by the Rev. Robert Young, chaplain of the Dana Hall School in Wellesley, Mass.

title: Oz and Kelpie Gain Title In Greenwich Cove Sailing
Riverside Park Is as Diverse as the People Who Use It
description: Every Sunday for the last two months, a woman editor has pedaled her bicycle be tween her midtown office and her home in upper Man hattan, traversing the entire length of Riverside Park.

title: Campaign Researchers
description: It could be that the most important political figures in New York during the last cou ple of months have been Tanya Melich, Paul Schoss berg Daniel Oliver, Alton G. Marshall, Peter Edelman and James D. Griffin.

title: Mayor Urges Pollution Ban On Vehicles Be Expedited
description: Mayor Lindsay has urged Senate committee to resist in tensive industry pressure, by accelerating a ban on sales of polluting motor vehicles to 1975, moving the measure up five years from 1980.

title: Chess:
description: In capturing first place in the recent Buenos Aires in ternational tournament, Bob by Fischer scored 15 points of a possible 17 during the 18man roundrobin.

title: Transfer of 5,000 Iraqi Troops From Syria to Jordan Reported
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 29Highly placed Jordanian in formants said today that 5,000 Iraqi troops have been moved from Syria to Jordan in recent days.

title: RAHMAN TO RETIRE IN KUALA LUMPUR
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Aug. 30 (AP)Prince Abdul Rahman, the founder and lead er of this country since 1957 announced today that he would retire as Prime Minister on Sent. 21.

title: Service Academies Alumni Form Antiwar Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UPI)A newly organized group of antiwar graduates of the nation's armedservice aca demies has opened a drive to convince Americans that the only honorable peace now is to admit our mistake and get out of Vietnam.

title: PROSPECT
description: That long, young burden of back,

title: Vice President Lets His Sideburns Grow
description: AGANA, Guam, Aug. 31 (UPI)Vice President Agnew is letting his sideburns grow longer.

title: McLain, in Anger at Campbell, Is Asking Tigers to Trade Him
description: DETROIT, Aug. 30 (UPI)Denny McLain has reacted to his second suspension of the season by asking to be traded and blaming the Detroit Tigers general managera longtime supporter of McLainfor the team's collapse.

title: U.S. to Study Race Issues Among Troops in Europe
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30President Nixon, concerned with rising racial tension among American servicemen stationed in Europe, plans to send a team of investigators to, look into the problems at European military installations.

title: Ong's RearEngine Car Wins Fuel Dragster Title
description: CENTER MORICHES, L. I., Aug. 30Dwayne Ong of De troit drove his rearengine Pawnbroker to the A.A.fuel dragster championship today at the American Hot Rod As sociation nationals before 18, 212 at the National Speedway. It was the first national title for a rearengine fuel dragster.

title: Football in South: A Happy Link to a Feared Future
description: POPLARVILLE, Miss.One day last week, as the high school football team was practicing behind the gym nasium, a group of the town's businessmen gathered to watch.

title: Training Plane Grounded
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Aug. 30 (AP)The Air Force has tem porarily grounded all T38 jet planes at 11 training bases pending inspection for a defec tive part, officials said today, The T38 is used in advanced fighter pilot training.

title: Books of The Times
description: Suggestion for the Labor Day weekend. If. you've had enough of parties and sand and mountains, of people and dogs and demonstrations and doubleheaders... if you'd like to forget about traffic and packing and the end of summer, find your self a hammock or an armchair and read God Is an Englishman, the fifth and newest of R. F.

title: O.A.U. COUNCIL ACTS ON ARMS RESOLUTION
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 30 (Agence FrancePresse)The Council of Ministers of the Or ganization of African Unity ap proved a resolution today that would condemn France, Britain and West Germany for selling or planning to sell arms to South Africa.

title: Policemen as Targets
description: A sharp rise in the number of unprovoked attacks on policemen and police installations has provoked mount ing national concern. Only this weekend such incidents In this city and in Philadelphia resulted in the death of one officer and the wounding of two others. A few days earlier a survey by this newspaper found that so far this year fifteen policemen had been murdered unprovoked attacks, mainly by bombers and snipers. In all 1969 only seven men in blue died under similar circumstances.

title: JAVITS ASSAILS ADMINISTRATION
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits as sailed the Administration yes terday for not supporting his proposal to create an emer gency loan guarantee authority. He accused the White House staff of misleading President Nixon on the seriousness of the liquidity problem facing the nation's major corpora tions.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: AIDE'S PROMOTION CANCELED BY U. S.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30Complying with a personal re quest by Senator Barry Gold water, the State Department has canceled the appointment of Arthur J. Olsen, a Foreign Service officer, as the new di rector of the department's of fice of press relations.

title: Holy Cross Eleven Has Skill And Size but Lacks Experience
description: WORCESTER, Mass., Aug. 30 It will be a victory for us just to step on the field. That not entirely facetious remark came from Bill Whitton, the head football coach at Holy Cross College.

title: Oldak Chosen Top Helmsman Of Manhasset Bay Race Week
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 30Lee Oldak, a youth from the neighboring Knicker bocker Yacht Club who sailed in the Blue Jay Class, was chosen as the winner tonight of the Black Jack Trophy as the leading helmsman of the Man hasset Bay Yacht Club's race week.

title: Six IND Riders Are Hurt In Sudden Brooklyn Stop
description: Six persons were slightly in jured last night when a 10car IND subway train bound for Far Rockaway, Queens, made an emergency stop about 20 feet out of the High Street station in Brooklyn.

title: Isle of Wight Festival Turns Slightly Discordant
description: ISLE OF WIGHT, England, Aug. 30Carrying rucksacks and bedrolls, thousands of young men and women en gulfed this normally sedate island of chalk cliffs and cricket fields this weekend for an outdoor pop festival that reached a peak today in a surge of dust, music and litter.

title: Parking Fine Collections. Rise Under New System
description: The tide of enforcement is beginning to turn against the parkingticket scofflaw since responsibility for these cases was shifted July 1 from the city's Criminal Courts to the new Parking Violations Bureau of the Department of Transpor tation.

title: London: New View of Brendan Behan
description: LONDON  Unick O'Con nor's controversial new biog raphy, Brendan Behan, up roots more than a few of the sturdy myths, long ago plant ed by Brendan himself, and ever since dutifully watered or rather, whiskyed  by his admirers. He was never quite the brawling, spouting, broth of a slum boy who joked and sang his way into literature and theater when every man's hand was against him. True, he was born in a tenement, but in one of the string of five owned by his grandmother, who allowed the family to live there rentfree.

title: Amex Is Initiating a Network For Speedy Communications
description: The American Stock Ex change is initiating an industry wide communications network that will replace costly systems operated independently by bro kers, Ralph S. Saul, president of the exchange, disclosed over the weekend.

title: Laver Overwhelms Carmichael, Miss Melville Victor in Finals
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 30Rod Laver and Kerry Mel ville made it a sweep for Aus tralia today with impressive victories in the finals of the $25,000 Marlboro open tennis championships at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

title: KENNETH E. BRIGHAM
description: NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Aug. 30  Kenneth E. Brigham of Hampton, director of public relations and advertising of the Newport News Shipbuilding and Drydock Company of this city, died today at his summer residence in Kitty Hawk, N.C. He was 49 years old.

title: Young Models Who Insist They Need Something Else to Do
description: In these days when professional models havereplated movie stars as pinup girls, you'd think they'd all be con tent to let their faces he their fortunes.

title: Advertising: Bullish Look at the Agencies
description: There hasn't been much in the way of brokerage house reports on advertising agen cies these days, so when one appears, that's news. The in vestment firm of Sassower, Jacobs & Schneider issued one recently with a generally bullish appraisal of the field.

title: Personal Finance
description: One of the great myths per petuated by the insurance in dustry is that if you cannot buy auto insurance in the normal market  because of your occupation, poor driving record or outright discrimina tionyou can always turn to the assignedrisk plan, where rates are generally much higher but where coverage is always available.
